abstract: Mr. JOSEPH JEFFERSON. This admirable artist leaves us to-day in the California steamer. We can ill afford to part with Mr. JEFFERSON. His style is so genial and ele- ...
lead_paragraph: Mr. JOSEPH JEFFERSON. -- This admirable artist leaves us to-day in the California steamer. He contemplates making a tour of the auriferous regions, and possibly of pushing across the Pacific to Australia, where actors are always in demand, and never fail to reap a rich harvest. We can ill afford to part with Mr. JEFFERSON. His style is so genial and elegant, so quiet and nervous, so excessively funny, yet free from exaggeration, that we can scarcely hope to find his equal until he returns to us -- comes back richer and riper with travel, and, as we trust, stronger in health. There are some low comedians who think that they never can be low enough -- who vulgarize the profession for the sake of raising a nasty laugh. Mr. JEFFERSON is not one of these. Good taste is never offended in his performances, but always satisfied. Our friends in California, have a rare treat in store.

abstract: This powerful light, now on trial at Old Point Comfort, is an improvement on the old Drummond light. It is produced by the combustion of pure lime--oxyde of calcium--in the flame of the oxy-hydrogen blow-pipe. When this combustion takes place in the
lead_paragraph: This powerful light, now on trial at Old Point Comfort, is an improvement on the old Drummond light. It is produced by the combustion of pure lime -- oxyde of calcium -- in the flame of the oxy-hydrogen blow-pipe. When this combustion takes place in the focus of a reflector of parabolic form, a cylinder of intensely illuminated rays is projected along the axis of the paraboloid. A cone of rays of any required degree of divergency, is produced at pleasure, by moving the flame in either direction along the axis.

abstract: At Washington applications for shipment of various articles, machinery, drugs, medicines, cigars, etc., are almost daily refused. The Secretary of the Treasury, in closing one of three letters of refusal, says: "I am deeply sensible, of the inconvenience and injury to which the insurrection in the Southern States exposes loyal citizens of the country, and desire to administer this Department so as to mitigate rather than increase them. Any suggestion to that that end will be received and respectfully considered, with a view to such modification of existing rules and regulations for the benefit of commerce as may not be inconsistent with the general security and the restoration of the supremacy of the law."

abstract: The batteries erected by the rebels at the mouth of Acquia Creek, the terminus of the Richmond, Fredericksburgh and Potomac Railroad, about fifty-five miles below Washington, on the Potomac, were yesterday attacked by the Thomas Freeborn and the Anacosta, but how the attack terminated is not yet known. The Keystone State passed ...
lead_paragraph: The batteries erected by the rebels at the mouth of Acquia Creek, the terminus of the Richmond, Fredericksburgh and Potomac Railroad, about fifty-five miles below Washington, on the Potomac, were yesterday attacked by the Thomas Freeborn and the Anacosta, but how the attack terminated is not yet known. The Keystone State passed them at noon, on her way to Washington, and reported that the steamers were engaging the batteries with success. Capt. DAHLGREN, the Commander at the Navy-yard, immediately telegraphed the fact to the War Department, and received instructions to send two additional war vessels to the scene of action at once. The Thomas Freeborn and the Anacosta were among the vessels spoken of in our dispatches yesterday morning as being fitted out at the Washington Navy-yard for secret service. The capture of the batteries at Acquia Creek, which has, no doubt, been accomplished, is a stroke of the utmost importance, as it gives the Government possession of the railroad to Richmond.

abstract: RAN AWAY TO BECOME VIVIANDIERES. -- A Mr. QUIRE, residing in Morgan-street, Jersey City, left yesterday, for Washington, to hunt up a young, truant daughter Catharine, who, it is said, ran away in company with a girl named REBECCA ELLESTEIN, residing in the same street, for the purpose of serving the soldiers as viviandieres in the war. It has been ascertained that these girls, who worked in New York, joined the Garibaldi Regiment, and accompanied them to Washington during the fore part of the week.

abstract: As an exposition of its life, the literature of the South is a study. For even in our Slave States the thoughts of scholarly men, who have the leisure and inclination for reflection, are, in due process of time, translated into the prose of every-day conduct. The vagaries of CALHOUN, and the Utopian speculations of De Bow's Review, are to-day crystalizing in the edicts of the Confederate Congress and the preclamations of JEFFERSON DAVIS.
lead_paragraph: As an exposition of its life, the literature of the South is a study. For even in our Slave States the thoughts of scholarly men, who have the leisure and inclination for reflection, are, in due process of time, translated into the prose of every-day conduct. The vagaries of CALHOUN, and the Utopian speculations of De Bow's Review, are to-day crystalizing in the edicts of the Confederate Congress and the preclamations of JEFFERSON DAVIS. We have watched with interest the progress Northward, to and through the Border States, of the Gulf-State political doctrines. Evidently the Border States have been a delicate subject with the Confederates. Virginia has been dealt with as a weakling who might be wholly alienated by the slightest whisper of the foreign Slave-trade, and she therefore required some skillful preparatory training to fit her for her new associates. If we may judge from recent indications, Louisiana and Virginia are upon this question now quite accordant, and the twin slave markets, Richmond and New-Orleans, are shaking hands over the settlement of the question of labor supply. JEFFERSON DAVIS' laudation of the Confederate States as "homogeneous," may be safely said to-day to include the Virginia Secessionists, and "Hail Homoginia" takes the place -- in secession circles, at least -- of "Hail Columbia," from Richmond to the mouth of the Mississippi.

abstract: The really embarrassing question growing out of the war, and which, in its novelty, and in the difficulties surrounding it, transcends all others, is just beginning to show itself. War, like every work of destruction, is a very simple matter. A fool or a madman can apply ...
lead_paragraph: The really embarrassing question growing out of the war, and which, in its novelty, and in the difficulties surrounding it, transcends all others, is just beginning to show itself. War, like every work of destruction, is a very simple matter. A fool or a madman can apply the torch to an edifice, which only one in a million can rear. It is easy to destroy life, while the most skillful are baffled in their efforts to preserve it, no matter how slight the apparent cause or distemper which threatens it. If we capture prisoners, the books are full of precedents for their disposition. But what shall we do with the slaves that may fall into our hands by the fortunes of the war, who to the South are chattels -- to the North human beings? Gen. BUTLER'S decision, approved by the Government, only serves to place them on our hands. We may find useful employment for ten or twenty thousand, but what shall we do with fifty or a hundred thousand? They must be presently fed and clothed, and though clearly contraband in reference to the rebels, we cannot treat them as other articles contraband of war, put them up at auction, and sell them to the highest bidder. In numerous instances it will be found that they can never be returned to Slavery. Their former masters may have abandoned them in their flight. When in arms against the United States, they can no more expect that their negroes, than horses, which may happen to fall into our hands, shall be returned to them. Whatever may be the final event, we may have a hundred thousand slaves on our hands before the questions raised are solved. Till they are, they must be treated as beings entitled to our sympathy, not as chattels, or property.

abstract: The Brooklyn Phalanx, the first and only volunteer regiment raised in this city, is now so nearly full, that the Union Defence Committee will take charge of it to-morrow, and review them on Fort Greene.
lead_paragraph: The Brooklyn Phalanx, the first and only volunteer regiment raised in this city, is now so nearly full, that the Union Defence Committee will take charge of it to-morrow, and review them on Fort Greene. Yesterday, about 600 men belonging to the regiment were inspected on Flatbush-avenue, and were sworn into the service. Three more full companies will join the regiment this morning. It will take the whole of another week at least to uniform and equip the command.

abstract: HORRIBLE TRAGEDY IN ILLINOIS. -- On Saturday night, May 18, just at the conclusion of a religious service in Wilmington Village, Ill., the people on the way home heard strange noises, as of women screaming, and on hastily repairing in the direction, reached the residence of WM. MACE, an Englishman, where one of the most stocking spectacles presented itself. By the light of the moon, as the neighbors entered the yard, they espied a dead body, and on going further found the bodies of Mr. MACE and his wife, both mangled and bloody to a terrible extent. A pale light was first discovered, which in a few moments revealed the fact that the house had been fired from the inside, and the flames shortly bursting out, the yard door was discovered stained with blood, and the bodies of the three murdered victims presented a revolting spectacle. The youngman was of the name of RICHARD MCAULEY, about 24 years of age. He was shot in different places, and his skull was cleft to pieces. The old gentleman had also been shot, and then beaten in a most horrible manner; while the old lady's hands, arms, shoulders, face and neck seemed chopped to pieces with an axe. On surveying the premises, a fragment of a gun, some pistol balls and a large club were discovered, that led to the suspicion of some young men in the neighborhood, by the name of JIM WILKINSON and JOHN ALLEN, and on pressuring these inquiries, young WILKINSON hastily fled. ALLEN and a younger brother were taken and confined. A preliminary examination resulted JOHN ALLEN being committed and WILLIAM acquitted.

abstract: Ex-Gov. STEWART has written a letter to the St. Joseph Journal, contradicting the statement that he was driven from St. Joseph by Secessionists, and intimates that such a thing could not be done in a community where his sentiments "are greatly in the ascendant." He denounces severely the action of the Legislature in robbing the School Fund, and passing other laws that, if persisted in, "will bring us into open and hopeless conflict with the General Government." He intimates that the people of Missouri will never submit to the hasty legislation of the extra session.
lead_paragraph: Ex-Gov. STEWART has written a letter to the St. Joseph Journal, contradicting the statement that he was driven from St. Joseph by Secessionists, and intimates that such a thing could not be done in a community where his sentiments "are greatly in the ascendant." He denounces severely the action of the Legislature in robbing the School Fund, and passing other laws that, if persisted in, "will bring us into open and hopeless conflict with the General Government." He intimates that the people of Missouri will never submit to the hasty legislation of the extra session.

abstract: It appears, says the Memphis Bulletin, that a contemplated plan of insurrection has been on foot in the counties of White and Prairie, Arkansas. The plot was discovered about two weeks ago, in which white men were concerned. They were to commence a regular wholesale system of murder, plunder and house burning, beginning their operations in the neighborhood of Hickory Plains, White County. Three negroes and one white man named THOMAS WILLIAMSON, were arrested and hung at Hickory Plains, and a white man, named NORMAN WEBB, was ordered to leave the State in ten days. Another white man, whose name we did not learn, and who was concerned in the plot, was arrested and hung at Searcy.

abstract: This Court will continue in session during the month of June, to afford opportunity, to counsel who are ready or who may be ready to be heard. The rule respecting time allowed counsel in argument will be strictly enforced. No cause will be reserved on the day calendar for any purpose whatever when it is reached. In case a good reason is shown for postponement, the case will go down the general calendar for the next term. Engagement of counsel elsewhere will be no excuse. No formal opinion will be written in the causes argued during the month, except where some new and important question is involved. Twenty-five cases will be put on the day calendar.

abstract: Edward Saporras vs. James W. Elwell. This was an action at common law, brought by the plaintiff to recover the proceeds of certain grain shipped on board the barque Harriet Francis, by the plaintiff. The vessel having set sail from this port with the grain on board, met with storms in consequence of which she put back to this port for repairs.
lead_paragraph: Edward Saporras vs. James W. Elwell. -- This was an action at common law, brought by the plaintiff to recover the proceeds of certain grain shipped on board the barque Harriet Francis, by the plaintiff. The vessel having set sail from this port with the grain on board, met with storms in consequence of which she put back to this port for repairs. The matter put her into the hands of the defendant, to do her business as a commission merchant; and part of the grain being found so injured that it could not be carried forward, it was sold at auction and the proceeds collected by the defendant. The amount of the proceeds was paid to the plaintiff, after the deducting the freight on that sold, and this amount deducted the plaintiff now claimed to recover. The defendant claimed that the cargo was bound to pay the freight, and moreover that he was only the agent of the owners of the ship, and had paid these proceeds over to them before he received notice from the plaintiff not to do so. It appeared, however, that part of this payment had been made by transferring portions of the amount, on defendant's books, to other accounts on which the owner of the barque was owing him.

abstract: Gen. SCOTT is not prone to precipitate great battles. He is a commander of excessive caution, avoiding general engagements to the utmost extent of his power, and seeking by slow and sure approaches to so emmesh his enemy in gradually contracting web as to leave no loophole of escape but quick retreat; when, being master of the situation, he is able, in a few brilliant moves, to force inevitable check.

abstract: The Brooklyn Phalanx, the first and only volunteer regiment raised in this city, is now so nearly full, that the Union Defence Committee will take charge of it to-morrow, and review them on Fort Greene. Yesterday, about 600 men belonging to the regiment ...
lead_paragraph: The Brooklyn Phalanx, the first and only volunteer regiment raised in this city, is now so nearly full, that the Union Defence Committee will take charge of it to-morrow, and review them on Fort Greene. Yesterday, about 600 men belonging to the regiment were inspected on Flatbush-avenue, and were sworn into the service. Three more full companies will join the regiment this morning. It will take the whole of another week at least to uniform and equip the command.

abstract: The prostration of business at Portsmouth and Norfolk is most thorough and complete. The Navy-yard, the truck trade, and naval stores, on which the business and almost existence of the two cities is based, have ceased, and were it not for the abundance of vegetables and fish, there would be much suffering among the poor. The truck gardeners are giving away their peas and strawberries to any one who will take the trouble of gathering them. A great many of the immense pea-fields have been plowed in for the purpose of planting corn. The crop of garden truck and strawberries shipped to Baltimore, New-York and Philadelphia last year, during May and June, yielded $400,000, and the yield this year was confidently expected to amount to not less than $600,000.

abstract: The Delaware Gazette says: "The Ninth Pennsylvania Regiment of soldiers, commanded by Col. H.C. LONGNECKER, encamped in the woods of Mr. MCCRONE, at Hare's Coiner, on Sunday morning. They are from Camp Wayne, Chester County, Pa. That encampment, it is said, is about to be abandoned. All the furniture cars that could be hired in this city were engaged on Sunday morning, and proceeded to New Castle for the purpose of conveying the camp equipage from that point to Hare's Corner, while the soldiers proceeded by railroad, passing through Wilmington about eleven o'clock. It is said another regiment, on Tuesday, will take a position at or near Smyrna, and still another at Dover. Another report is that the regiment now at Hare's Corner will be divided, and parts of it stationed there, and other places along the Delaware Railroad. We bespeak for the men a kind reception by our people. We do not think there is any necessity for guarding the road; but the authorities may be better informed, and if they hold the opinion that the necessity exists, it is their duty to send the forces. Notwithstanding these reports, we believe the soldiers were sent to New-Castle in order that they may be near some point convenient for embarkation by water, and where they could be properly drilled."
lead_paragraph: The Delaware Gazette says: "The Ninth Pennsylvania Regiment of soldiers, commanded by Col. H.C. LONGNECKER, encamped in the woods of Mr. MCCRONE, at Hare's Coiner, on Sunday morning. Another report is that the regiment now at Hare's Corner will be divided, and parts of it stationed there, and other places along the Delaware Railroad. We bespeak for the men a kind reception by our people. Notwithstanding these reports, we believe the soldiers were sent to New-Castle in order that they may be near some point convenient for embarkation by water, and where they could be properly drilled."

abstract: The inaction of Great Britain in relation to the production of cotton by free labor in various tropical regions, has been not only absurd, but almost criminal. While her Abolition Presses and orators have denounced, in the bitterest terms, the slaveowners of the South, and have even sent agents over to stir up the minds of our people, or have supported "British Mission" Churches as citadels from ...
lead_paragraph: The inaction of Great Britain in relation to the production of cotton by free labor in various tropical regions, has been not only absurd, but almost criminal. While her Abolition Presses and orators have denounced, in the bitterest terms, the slaveowners of the South, and have even sent agents over to stir up the minds of our people, or have supported "British Mission" Churches as citadels from whence to discharge red-hot shot at their antagonists, the nation at large has been steadily increasing its pecuniary support of Slavery, by doubling its consumption of Southern cotton every ten years. England now must suffer, and it should suffer without petulant querulousness, the consequences of its own folly and want of foresight. Two years ago an American went to England to alarm the cotton manufacturers, and induce them to aid in the work of emancipation by increasing their supplies from other quarters, but they continued apathetic even to his warnings of a crisis, then impending. "The demand will create the supply," was their answer to most of the earnest appeals made to their consciences as to the guilt of their complicity with slaveholders. A number of their philanthropists, wiser than the commercial men, did, however, perceive the importance of the subject, and formed an Association to provide against the time of need. The nature of the peri's threatening "England may be seen by examining a few of the statistics relative to the cotton-trade and manufactures.

abstract: "The report which reached here yesterday that the Kentucky State troops had left Paducah to join Col. CHETMAN'S command, near the Tennessee line, has been confirmed. Over three hundred men left that ...
lead_paragraph: "The report which reached here yesterday that the Kentucky State troops had left Paducah to join Col. CHETMAN'S command, near the Tennessee line, has been confirmed. Over three hundred men left that city Tuesday evening, taking with them 1,300 stand of muskets, six pieces of artillery, with all munitions of war in the city. This action was precipitated by the belief that three thousand men were to be detailed from Cairo to secure these arms, and take possesion of the town. The citizens there are said to be in the constant expectation of the arrival of Northern forces, and many of them are preparing to leave, so confined are they that this expectation will speedily be realized.

abstract: One of the regiments that has suffered on account of the hitch between the Governor, the Military Board and the Union Defence Committee, is the Brooklyn Phalanx, Col. ADAMS. Three times has it been ready to go; three times have circumstances ...
lead_paragraph: One of the regiments that has suffered on account of the hitch between the Governor, the Military Board and the Union Defence Committee, is the Brooklyn Phalanx, Col. ADAMS. Three times has it been ready to go; three times have circumstances been adverse; three times, owing to the unparalleled exertions of the Colonel and his Staff, aided and abetted by Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER, has it been revived. Yesterday 500 men, in good trim, were reviewed by the Committee, and after the review three additional companies, of 100 men each, applied for acceptance, making in all 800 men.

abstract: Money is among the absolute necessities for sustaining a war, and money in the South, is becoming a scarce article. As gold disappeared, the banks suspended payment, and their suspension was legalized by the Legislatures of the several States. For a while their bills circulated at no very material discount. But a currency based upon moonshine, came to be appreciated, and they fell to a low figure in the public estimation. They went down from ten to twenty-five per cent. discount, and have at last failed to produce gold even at that. Skinplasters issued by City and Town Corporations, for a while supplied the place of irredeemable bank paper and the smaller denominations of coin; but even these are fast falling into disrepute. A dime is now, in most of the Southern States, worth from twenty to thirty-five cents in these paper pellets, and dimes are hard to be come at. As the currency of the South runs down in value, the prices of all the various articles of food and clothing run up, and the growing scarcity of these absolute necessaries is constantly augmenting their cost.
lead_paragraph: Money is among the absolute necessities for sustaining a war, and money in the South, is becoming a scarce article. Skinplasters issued by City and Town Corporations, for a while supplied the place of irredeemable bank paper and the smaller denominations of coin; but even these are fast falling into disrepute. The Board then adjourned till 5 o'clock Monday evening.

lead_paragraph: It Will be remembered by our readers that BROWN'S superb Painting called the "City and Bay of New-York," was purchased by several citizens of this City and Brooklyn, and sent as a present to His Royal Highness the Prince of Wales. abstract: "Recent information from Pensacola forces the sad conviction on our minds that the hour is not distant when the impetuosity of our army in Florida
lead_paragraph: "Recent information from Pensacola forces the sad conviction on our minds that the hour is not distant when the impetuosity of our army in Florida will be gratified amid the roar of battle and the wild carnage of war. It is now stated here, and by reliable persons, that Gen. BRAGG will in a few days make an effort to sink the dry-dock in a channel running between Port Pickens and Fort McRea. This attempt will be made for the purpose of causing the guns of the latter to operate successfully on any vessel that may attempt to force an entrance into the Bay of Pensacola.

abstract: We are informed upon apparently credible authority, that the Hudson Rides and National Guard, two Companies of Hoboken, left on the 30th, at 11 A.M., joining two more companies -- one in Jersey City and one in Nowark -- and thence all four companies join their regiment in Trenton. Before their departure from Hoboken they were presented with a banner, which cost. $300, by the ladies of Hoboken, and some ladies sang the Star Spangled Banner for them before they marched. All left in excellent spirits, and many of them left homes, families and business without compulsion, well aware of the task they are about to undertake; many of them have seen service before. They left heartily, cheering and being cheered at knowing that their families will not suffer for want in their absence. A Committee for relief has formed itself, and Mr. SMAGNY, we understand, has already a subscription for $800 per month. On arriving at Trenton at 3 P.M., they were marched up to the City Hall, there left standing until 8 P.M., and last night we received the following dispatch, which speaks for itself: TRESTON, May 31, 1861.

abstract: One of the most interesting features of the late session of the Montgomery Congress has been the frequent presentation of "claims," on subjects too numerous to mention, all of...
lead_paragraph: One of the most interesting features of the late session of the Montgomery Congress has been the frequent presentation of "claims," on subjects too numerous to mention, all of which were duly referred to the Committee on Claims. The member selected for the service of presentation seems to have been very generally Mr. CHARLES M. CONRAD, the Secretary of War of the United States during Mr. FILLMORE's Administration, and at that time one of the most determined of Union men. After losing his Secretaryship, he continued to haunt Washington during the sessions, and figured somewhat, we believe, in behalf of the retired and disturbed officers of the navy, but he found no Federal employment at the hands of his old constituents, and became politically seedy and unhappy. He was hovering about for the terms of Mr. PIERCE and Mr. BUCHANAN, though he never settled anywhere long enough to be counted until he turned up as a member of the Montgomery Congress.

abstract: "The revolution, I assert, which now disgraces the country, is the most unnatural and damning that ever sullted the pages of history.
lead_paragraph: "The revolution, I assert, which now disgraces the country, is the most unnatural and damning that ever sullted the pages of history. Heretofore, the young men and the old men, proud of a common country and a common heritage, have worked together for its prosperity and its glory. To-day, throwing away the ballot box for the bullet, they, seem plunging into the gulf of irretrievable ruin, and throwing away the rights gained by the Barons for the people, from Prince John at Runnymede. And why is this? There is not a single law upon the statute-book upon the subject of Slavery, nor has there over been for thirty years, that was not placed there by these same Disunionists. They cannot complain of them. Yet the hope, the happiness, the prosperity of thirty millions of people are now destroyed by them. Their commerce, trade and everything belonging to a great country, are sacrificed by them. The gulf between the rich man in hell, Lazarus, is not greater then that between these men and those who aim to preserve the Union and our prosperity. "This Union is not dissolved, nor will it be dissolved in the life-time of the youngest child now living."

abstract: In this Court on Saturday, before Judge ALLEN, the trial or John Jackson for murder, commenced on the previous day, was continued. Several witnesses,who were in the bar-room at the time of the fray, gave a different account of the occurrence from that given by the first two witnesses, Jones and Donovan, who were flatly contradicted in all the essential facts of the case. Several witnesses also testified to the prisoner's good character. The prisoner's counsel then proposed to put in evidence the testimony of Jones and Donovan before the Coroner's Jury, when the District-Attorney objected, saying that the authoriticity of the copy offered had not been sufficiently proved.

abstract: The safety and honor of this country, till the present war closes, will lie in the hands of its armies. That these armies shall be thoroughly efficient is demanded of every one concerned in their organization; and the claim is...
lead_paragraph: The safety and honor of this country, till the present war closes, will lie in the hands of its armies. That these armies shall be thoroughly efficient is demanded of every one concerned in their organization; and the claim is paramount to those of favoritism, prejudice and nepotism. As to the privates of the sixty thousand volunteers and regulars called for by the President, let the programme be rigidly carried out, which gives them one-half of all the promotions after being mustered into service -- the good effect will be incalculable.

abstract: The Seventh Regiment, Col. MARSHALL LEPTERTS, returned to their quarter last evening about 6 1/3 o'clock, having left Washington at 6 o'clock on the
lead_paragraph: The Seventh Regiment, Col. MARSHALL LEPTERTS, returned to their quarter last evening about 6 1/2 o'clock, having left Washington at 6 o'clock on the night previous. Two or three hundred people, principally ladies, were waiting to receive them on the Jersey side, and when the train arrived at 4 1/2 o'clock, there was a flutter of affectionate pocket-handkerchiefs, and a masculine string of "Hi! Hi! hi's!" It was in New-York, however, that our Seventh boys received their heartiest welcome. The streets were lined with people, and every window that could command Broadway was resplendent with fashion and beauty. When the regiment left for Washington, on the 19th of April last, the political and military situations were different to what they are now. The first was in danger; the second had no existence, except as we recognized it in these our sons going forth to do battle in our behalf. Hence there was a glad overflow of generous enthusiasm, a depth of emotion at their departure, which will probably never be experienced again. Now, when things are different, our people turn out in thousands to welcome them back, and to show that they have not forgotten an act of patriotic promptness. The pageant was a grand to the eye even if the music of swelling voices was not so great. All that delirious rapture of thankfulness which could only find utterance in wild shouts when the regiment went on their way South, would, of course, have been inappropriate on the occasion of their return, and those who listened for it, did so in vain. But the reception accorded to the fine fellows was sufficiently hearty. People were evidently glad to see them, and clapped their hands, shouted and waved their handkerchiefs with real delight.

abstract: The United StateS Grand Jury in Philadelphia expected to be able to make their final presentment on Monday, but were prevented by some informality in the paper.
lead_paragraph: The United StateS Grand Jury in Philadelphia expected to be able to make their final presentment on Monday, but were prevented by some informality in the paper. In consequence of the request of the jurors to be enlightened as to their power in the matter of investigating the alleged frauds committed by contractors for supplying the army with clothing, &c., Judge CADWALLADER gave them the following instructions: An act of Congress makes it criminal for any person having the charge or custody of arms, ordnance, muntiions, shot, powder or nabiliments of war belonging to the United States, or of any provisions for the victualing of any soldiers, gunners, marines and pioneers, to embezzle, purloin or convey away any of the same for lucre or gain, or for the purpose of hindering or impeding the service of the United States, or, knowing of, and being privy to, such offence, to counsel, aid or abet it. Another act of Congress makes it criminal to falsely make, alter, forge or counterfeit, or cause or procure to be falsely made, altered, forged our counterfeited, or willingly aid or assist in falsely making, altering, forging or counterfeiting any writing for the purpose of obtaining or receiving, or enabling any other person or persons, either directly or indirectly, to obtain or receive from the United States, or any of their officers or agents, any sum or sums of money, or to alter or publish as true, or cause to be altered or published as true, any such false, forged, altered or counterfeited writing with intent to defraud the United States, knowing the same to be false, altered, forged or counterfeited, or to transmit to, or present at, or cause or procure to be transmitted to or presented at any office, or officer, of the Government of the United States, any writing in support of, or in relation to, any account or claim, knowing the same to be false, altered, forged or counterfeited. As this enactment has been judicially interpreted, a criminal offence is committed under it by a person who, knowing a genuine writing to contain a false statement, uses it for any such fraudulent purpose. The same act makes it criminal to be knowingly in possession of any false, altered, forged or counterfeited writing for the purpose of enabling any person or persons, either directly or indirectly, to obtain or receive any money from the United States or their officers or agents, knowing the writing to be so false, altered, forged or counterfeited, with intent to defraud the United States. The act contains a provision which would have been implied, if it had not been expressed, that nothing therein contained should be construed to deprive the courts of the several States of jurisdiction under their laws over such offences. Another act of Congress makes any officer of the United States who is guilty of extortion under or by color of his office punishable criminally.

abstract: Mr. BRIGHT, on the 17th, presented, in the House of Commons, a petition from the manufacturers, clerks and laborers in the employ of Messrs. PLATT, machine makers of Oldham, signed by 2,300 persons, stating that they viewed with alarm the serious diminution which would probably take place in the supply of cotton, in consequence of the war between the Northern and Southern States of America, and praying the House to adopt such measures as would contribute to the development of the agricultural and commercial resources of India, so as to enable that country to compete on fair terms with America. The petitioners recommended the improvement of the tenure by which land is held; the establishment of efficient Courts of law for the better protection of the ryots, and the construction of all necessary public works, including railroads, canals, water-ways, works of irrigation, and particularly the opening of the navigation of the River Godavary.
lead_paragraph: Mr. BRIGHT, on the 17th, presented, in the House of Commons, a petition from the manufacturers, clerks and laborers in the employ of Messrs. The petitioners recommended the improvement of the tenure by which land is held; the establishment of efficient Courts of law for the better protection of the ryots, and the construction of all necessary public works, including railroads, canals, water-ways, works of irrigation, and particularly the opening of the navigation of the River Godavary.

abstract: There is a vast deal of patriotic indignation, among the Southern sympathizers just now, over what they are pleased to term the unconstitutional suspension of the habeas corpus by
lead_paragraph: There is a vast deal of patriotic indignation, among the Southern sympathizers just now, over what they are pleased to term the unconstitutional suspension of the habeas corpus by Gen. CADWALLADER. They affect to see infinite danger to constitutional freedom in his refusal to surrender a military prisoner in his custody, and in the further refusal to give up his command, and yield himself a prisoner upon the attachment issued for his arrest. If these cavilers would take time to consider the nature and office of the writ of habeas corpus, and the facts of the case which they criticise so severely, we think that, unless their sympathies are permitted to control their deliberate judgment, their convictions on this subject would be changed.

abstract: "Gen. JOHNSTON assumed command yesterday, and immediately set to work reconnoitering the surrounding country. Attached to his staff is Hon. HENRY
lead_paragraph: "Gen. JOHNSTON assumed command yesterday, and immediately set to work reconnoitering the surrounding country. Attached to his staff is Hon. HENRY A. EDMUNDSON, formerly a prominent member of Congress from this State. That Gen. JOHNSTON intends to hold this place may be inferred from the fact that he has brought his family with him. His accomplished wife is the daughter of the late Hon. LOUIS MCLANE, and a sister of Hon. ROBERT M. MCLANE, of Baltimore, recently Minister to Mexico.

abstract: The Montgomery despot and his fellowusurper, TOOMBS, not satisfied with defying the Federal power and the moral instincts of...
lead_paragraph: The Montgomery despot and his fellowusurper, TOOMBS, not satisfied with defying the Federal power and the moral instincts of mankind, now insult Heaven by issuing a proclamation claiming that their success thus far is due to Divine aid, and invoking a continuance of that aid in behalf of their accursed conspiracy and war. Who the Deity may be whom these men suppose to be capable of winking at their crimes and forwarding their schemes it is impossible to conjecture. Certainly neither the Bible, the Koran, the Vedas, nor the Book of the Dead, neither the populous Pantheon of ancient Rome, nor the traditions of any tribe above the level of the cannibal, contain any hint of the existence of any god or demigod who could lend his aid or shed his favors upon a usurpation confessedly based on the triple iniquities of Slavery, anarchy and piracy. Perhaps, however, Pontiff DAVIS and Vice-Pontiff TOOMBS, having spurned and trampled upon justice, freedom, honor, fraternity, and all the attributes that appertain to the Universal Father, and having (as Vice-President STEPHENS avers) established a Government and society upon a new and heretofore unheard-of foundation, have farther imagined that, in order to be consistent and logical, it was wise also to improvise a new faith and a new divinity, with new attributes and a new code for the government of the usurpation and the universe.

abstract: Col. MORRIS. U.S.A., says the Memphis Bulletin, who was recently captured by Col. VAN DORN, near Galveston, Texas, and was released on his pay...
lead_paragraph: Col. MORRIS. U.S.A., says the Memphis Bulletin, who was recently captured by Col. VAN DORN, near Galveston, Texas, and was released on his payrole of honor, was arrested again In Atlanta (Ga.) on May 24. He claimed to be released from the obligations of his parole, and at liberty to take up arms again. He is a very old man; says his proclivities are with the South, and that he owns two negroes now in St. Louis. When asked why he did not resign like Gen. TWIGGS and others, he said he was old and infirm, and could be of but little use to anybody, and did not like to give up his salary without he was sure the new government would provide for him. He said LINCOLN was wrong -- his policy suicidal; and that he had broken up the united Stales Army -- ruined the officers in properly, character and everything else. He said he "sought no advantages like HARNEY and ANDERSON, d -- m 'em!" -- all he wanted was to go and report to his Government. He was detained by Gov. BROWN, subject to the order of the War Department.

abstract: A gentleman just arrived in Chicago from Knoxvilla, Tenn., brings intelligence of affairs in that city. He informs the Journal that 2,500 secession troops are
lead_paragraph: A gentleman just arrived in Chicago from Knoxvilla, Tenn., brings intelligence of affairs in that city. He informs the Journal that 2,500 secession troops are stationed there, for the express purpose of overawing the Union men. It is a part of their business to engage in quarrels in saloons, and in street fights, with all who are not friendly to secession. Two men were shot last week for no other offence than speaking words of loyalty to the Federal Government.

abstract: Under this head there is so very little to chronicle, that we seat ourself in the accustomed chair more from the force of habit than from any
lead_paragraph: Under this head there is so very little to chronicle, that we seat ourself in the accustomed chair more from the force of habit than from any actual necessity which exists for - making mention" of books. Several new military publications have been sent in, but some foraging party of Zouaves or an advanced guard of cadets must have captured them, for it is certain they are gone before either titles or authors' names were registered. May they benefit the hands into which they have fallen; if their lines have fallen, among the lines of "raw recruits," may they speedily perfect them in drill; if they are in civilians pockets, may the abstractors become good soldiers in the same degree that they have proven themselves bad citizens.

abstract: The Grand Jury came in on Saturday with a number of indictments, and were discharged by the Court, with thanks for the industry they had evinced in the discharge of their onerous and long continued duties. The Court then adjourned sine die. Judge MCCUNN is now at liberty to take command of his regiment, which will be mustered into the service of the United States on Wednesday. Recorder HOFFMAN will open the June term of the Court this morning at ten o'clock.

abstract: Dr. S.G. HOWE, who was appointed by Gov. ANDREW to examine into the sanitary condition of the Massachusetts troops, reports that their wants are abundantly provided for, and that their health is good. He makes a number of valuable suggestions -- among them that the nurses employed for the troops should be men, not women, for the former in an emergency can fight. He gives the following illustration of the Puritan spirit which still lives among the troops. One of the companies complained to the Captain that the West-Point Cadet who drilled them was a most profane swearer. "I'll stop that to-morrow," says he. The next day's drill begins, and the Cadet begins to swear at the soldiers. "Please not swear at my men, Sir," says the Captain. "What do you know about the drill," says the Cadet, "and what can you do about my swearing?" "Sir," says the Captain, sternly, "I know this, and you ought to know it -- swearing is forbidden by the army regulation, and if you continue to break the rule, I'll order my men to march off the ground, and they'll obey me, and leave you to swear alone." The Cadet took the rebuke, and swore no more at that company.

abstract: Col. LABATUT, a highly respectable and wealthy citizen of New-Orleans, has organized a regiment of quadroons, which numbers 1,200 rank and file. Its members possess, in the aggregate, $21,000,000 of property, including a large number of slaves. The field officers are the only members of the regiment of pure Caucasian blood, the company officers being quadroons. This corps is destined only for the purposes of a home guard. A merchant of New-Orleans states that it is admirably instructed, and that Col. LABATUT expresses entire confidence in the gallantry and fidelity of his men.

abstract: A melancholy and fatal accident occurred in the vicinity of Lochaber, on Tuesday, the 7th inst., by which two sisters -- CATHARINE and ALEXINA MCDONALD -- were hurried into eternity. On the morning of the day mentioned the two young women, aged respectively 16 and 18 years, accompanied their mother to witness the devastation made in the vicinity of their dwelling by a recent land-slide. While being thus engaged, one of the girls, noticing a considerable crack in the portion of earth on which they were standing, suggested the propriety of retiring from such a locality. Mrs. MCDONALD at once proceeded to leave the spot, but on turning around to see if her daughters were following, she was horror struck at seeing them disappear beneath a mass of earth which had given way. Her immediate impulse was to rush to their rescue, but a man who witnessed the calamity caught her suddenly and saved her from sharing in the lamentable fate of her daughters. In half an hour after the accident the bodies were recovered, but of course life was extinct. This sad event has spread a marked gloom over the whole neighborhood, and must be most distressing to the relatives of the deceased. -- London (C.W.) Free Press.

abstract: The business of puni ishing the rebels has been much retarded by the difficulty of catching them.
lead_paragraph: The business of punishing the rebels has been much retarded by the difficulty of catching them. All who are of any importance or prominence have studiously kept out of the-way. BEAUREGARD vanished immediately after the last shot had been fired into burning Sumter; DAVIS, it is inferred from the attachment of his signature to various proclamations and published acts, has remained snugly housed at Montgomery, quite beyond the reach of attack or capture. Not MORPHY himself could prosecute a successful campaign on the chessboard, if the adversaries, King and Queen, were missing; and just so in this more serious game of life and death which the Government and the insurgents are playing, we shall be more or less in the fog until we see the exact square filled by our antagonists' principal piece. The difficulty is at last removed, by the presence of Pseudo-President DAVIS at Richmond; and of BEAUREGARD at Memphis. The whole case is before us. We shall have forthwith a comparison of the military skill which the veteran SCOTT and the unpracticed. DAVIS bring to the field; with a result all themore conclusive, because the best military leader of the South is at the head of the insurgents, and if he be beaten, we have overcome the best material they can throw into the conflict. We may now confidently look for a determination of the question, whether the Southern Congress shall meet at Richmond, or the National Congress at Washington, next month. It is very sure both meetings will not be held.

abstract: HOLMES HOLE, May 31 -- The schooner E.M. (By letter to Elwood Walker, Esq., Sec'y Board Underwriters.)

abstract: The circumstances connected with the murder of John M. SWAIN, a baker, residing at No. 199 Princestreet, who was shot dead on Friday evening at a...
lead_paragraph: The circumstances connected with the murder of John M. SWAIN, a baker, residing at No. 199 Princestreet, who was shot dead on Friday evening at a lager-beer saloon in the basement of the same building, by one of his neighbors, named SAMUEL MERRITT, were yesterday made the subject of inquiry by Coroner SCHIRMER. The testimony of the persons who witnessed the occurrence fully corroborated the report published in yesterday's TIMES. Both men had permitted themselves to become excited while discussing the troubles of the country, and deceased earnestly proclaimed himself a sympathizer with the rebels. MERRITT, the prisoner, insisted that his opponent should repeat after him the words "United States or nothing," and shot him for refusing. The inquest was held at the Eighth Precinct Station-house, which was filled with friends of the deceased and the prisoner, to whom the proceedings seemed deeply interesting. MERRITT fled after he had done the mischief, but in the course of a couple of hours surrendered himself to the police, asserting his innocence of having fired the fatal shot. This assertion he has since persisted in making; but the testimony left the jury no cause for doubting his guilt, and a verdict was rendered against him. He was committed to the Tombs, pending action by the Grand Jury. Following is the substance of the testimony:

abstract: Col. SCHUTTNEE'S regiment arrived this afternoon from St. Louis, and proceeded at once to Bird's Point, which they will permanently hold. They num-...
lead_paragraph: Col. SCHUTTNEE's regiment arrived this afternoon from St. Louis, and proceeded at once to Bird's Point, which they will permanently hold. They number over one thousand men, and are supplied with Minie rifles, camp equipage, and provisions, &c. for thirty days. To-morrow two batteries will be furnished them from here. All, came on the steamer Louisiana, which steamed around Battery Point, amid great enthusiasm on ship and shore. Gen PRENTISS and Staff escorted them to their new location, where their camp lines were defined by Col. WEBSTER, but owing to the storm, they remain on the boat to-night.

abstract: There is no civilizer like war, because nothing so thoroughly tries the strength and exposes the weakness of a people. The consciousness of the latter is always the first step to reform.
lead_paragraph: There is no civilizer like war, because nothing so thoroughly tries the strength and exposes the weakness of a people. The consciousness of the latter is always the first step to reform. The tendency of a nation, like that of an individual, is to indulge its predominant trait or characteristics till these become a monstrous deformity or vice, overshadowing every generous and noble quality, and proving fatal in the end unless corrected by an outward pressure, or emergency, sufficient to change the whole current of a nation's habits and ideas. Such an emergency may, and often does, involve the destruction of a whole generation. But its loss is amply compensated in the advantage of those that follow. Had the Emperor NICHOLAS lived a thousand years, he could never have been diverted from the grand purpose of his life, the possession of Constantinople, and the realization of the traditions of his ancestors. The Crimean war, the first of these traditions, dispelled for a time the dream of territorial aggrandisement, disclosed the weak spot in the Empire, exhausted its means, and turned the attention of the new Emperor to the subject of internal reform, instead of foreign conquest. The enfranchisement of the serfs was the result. In its results, the advantage of the war to Russia was incalculable, and compensated fifty times for the losses and sacrifices she sustained in her great defeat. It was the beneficent event in her history. Defeat was the only instructor that could reach her rugged nature, and turn it to deeds of humanity, to the development of her real strength.

abstract: We have late advices from Omaha, N.T., to the effect that the Sioux Indians had recently become enraged at the Pawnees, and were determined to exterminate them. They were able to muster about 3,000 braves, and were quite too much for the Pawnees, who are not so numerous nor so warlike. In view of this, the white traders living among the Pawnees agreed to help them. On the Sioux bearing of this, they threatened vengeance on all the while settlers of the Territory. The whites became alarmed, and in two weeks enlisted a thousand volunteers. These, added to the forces of the Pawnees, were too powerful for the Sioux, so that they deemed it inexpedient to proceed against their enemies. Thus the matter stands for the present.

abstract: The events of the last forty eight hours at the seat of war have been of the most stirring character, although they are to be considered as simply...
lead_paragraph: The events of the last forty eight hours at the seat of war have been of the most stirring character, although they are to be considered as simply the forerunners of movements of still greater magnitude. The war for the Union is now fairly inaugurated, and every day will be likely to bring us reports of startling moment. The affair with the rebel batteries at Aquia Creek, reported yestesday as in progress, appears to have been quite a brisk one. Beside the Freeborn and the Anacosta, the Resolute and a schooner tender named the Taylor were engaged. Three batteries were opposed to them, throwing very heavy metal, and yet, strange as it may appear, no one on board the vessels was killed, and but one wounded. The loss of the rebels is not known with certainty, though it is thought that it must have been considerable, as one account states that men were seen carrying dead and wounded to places of safety. The Pawnee finally went to the assistance of the vessels engaged, and two of the batteries were effectually silenced -- the third being so far away as to render necessary a landing force. It was reported that the New-York Seventy-first would be detailed for that service, in which case they will go down the river to-day.

abstract: The Eclectic for June is before the public with its accustomed promptitude. In making up the present number the careful Mr. BIDWELL
lead_paragraph: The Eclectic for June is before the public with its accustomed promptitude. In making up the present number the careful Mr. BIDWELL seems to have gone his usual round among foreign periodicals -- choosing the choicest of the exotics and transplanting them within the pale of his own green garden with quite as much nonchalance as though he bought and paid for them. This much, however, must be allowed in Mr. BIDWELL's favor -- if he perils his soul in these periodical prowlings, he does it for the benefit of the public.

abstract: The every  day literature of a people is said to be an index to its civilization. "Show me the leading newspapers of a nation," said DANIEL WEBSTEK, "and I Will tell you its status, without
lead_paragraph: The everyday literature of a people is said to be an index to its civilization. "Show me the leading newspapers of a nation," said DANIEL WEBSTEK, "and I Will tell you its status, without referring to its history." Judged by this standard, the civilization of some of the Southern States is certainly peculiar; a strange mixture of grossness and self-sufficiency -- vituperative and egotistical to a ridiculous excess. Take the Memphis Avalanche as an example. The Avalanche, a leading paper of Tennessee, thus discourses of the Government at Washington.

abstract: The comedy which General DON PEDRO DE SANTANA has just played for the benefit of Spain, is over. The Republic of San-Domingo is no more.
lead_paragraph: The comedy which General DON PEDRO DE SANTANA has just played for the benefit of Spain, is over. The Republic of San-Domingo is no more. The palaces and public monuments over which, not long since, waved the flag of independence and the emblems of freedom, have been stripped of their patriotic insignia, and replaced by the Spanish flag. The hall of the representatives of the people, in which the voice of no foreigner had been heard for over thirty years, now sounds under the measured steps of the Spanish sentinel, and its echoes repeat the clattering of his armor. To complete this work of debasement, SANTANA has declared, in an address to the people, that ties of consanguinity on one hand, the peace and prosperity of the Republic on the other, had compelled the majority to give up the constitution of the country, and to surrender to the Spanish Queen. But the hypocrisy of such a language has deceived no one. At the very moment the address of SANTANA was published, JOSE-MARIA CABRAL, the Commander of the Dominican army, the General who defeated SOULOUQUE in 1855, was issuing an appeal to the nation, in which he said: SANTANA has sold the Republic -- to-morrow we we shall be slaves, -- let us rise to the voice of freedom, etc. * * * Unfortunately his voice was stifled in the outcry of the Spanish troops, and by the shouts of the Spanish emigrants, brought from the island of Cuba and Porto Rico, by the care of SANTANA, who has been rewarded with the great cross of ISABELLA, for his services in this affair.
headline: {'main': 'Will Spain be able to retain Dominica?', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Will Spain be able to retain Dominica?', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Our foreign advices leave no room to question the discontent with which the commercial Powers regard the blockade of the Southern ports, and the reluctance with which they submit to the requirements of international law in that particular. They propose to be to the last degree exacting and punctilious in regard to it. The blockade must be perfect, not merely formal. It must be impossible for a vessel to enter; and to ascertain whether or not it is so, we shall pretty certainly be subjected to a series of test experiments, which will demand all the vigilance of our cruisers to defeat. Foreign ships will unquestionably attempt to break through our lines, and if they succeed, neither England nor France will continue to recognize a leaguer which they have thus ascertained to be incomplete. It so happens, however, that we are not restricted to a mode of closing the Southern ports, which any foreign Government may retain the option of pronouncing legal. It is in the power of Congress so to shut them up, that the mere attempt to enter a Southern harbor, even if no cruiser be present, will incur forfeiture, and create a ground of war against the Government whose flag the offending vessel may bear. An act declaring by name every port between Norfolk and the Rio Grande no longer a port of entry, and annexing the entire Southern Confederacy to the jurisdiction of the New-York Custom-house, would render it quite immaterial whether our cruisers were numerically strong enough to exclude European ships, and would relieve us from the necessity of demonstrating the blockade to have an effective existence. Such legislation should be among the earliest acts of Congress.
lead_paragraph: Our foreign advices leave no room to question the discontent with which the commercial Powers regard the blockade of the Southern ports, and the reluctance with which they submit to the requirements of international law in that particular. They propose to be to the last degree exacting and punctilious in regard to it. The blockade must be perfect, not merely formal. It must be impossible for a vessel to enter; and to ascertain whether or not it is so, we shall pretty certainly be subjected to a series of test experiments, which will demand all the vigilance of our cruisers to defeat. Foreign ships will unquestionably attempt to break through our lines, and if they succeed, neither England nor France will continue to recognize a leaguer which they have thus ascertained to be incomplete. It so happens, however, that we are not restricted to a mode of closing the Southern ports, which any foreign Government may retain the option of pronouncing legal. It is in the power of Congress so to shut them up, that the mere attempt to enter a Southern harbor, even if no cruiser be present, will incur forfeiture, and create a ground of war against the Government whose flag the offending vessel may bear. An act declaring by name every port between Norfolk and the Rio Grande no longer a port of entry, and annexing the entire Southern Confederacy to the jurisdiction of the New-York Custom-house, would render it quite immaterial whether our cruisers were numerically strong enough to exclude European ships, and would relieve us from the necessity of demonstrating the blockade to have an effective existence. Such legislation should be among the earliest acts of Congress.

abstract: The  absence of machinery for converting their rags into paper is causing our New-Orleass cotemporaries some trouble. They have resorted to sheets of half the ordinary size, and the...
lead_paragraph: -- The absence of machinery for converting their rags into paper is causing our New-Orleass cotemporaries some trouble. They have resorted to sheets of half the ordinary size, and the necessity of condensing into a narrow space the volume of news which the rapid movement of events furnishes daily leads to some provoking and embarrassing consequences. In the Delta, for instance, there is an account of two severe engagements between the National and the Rebel forces, of which, as we have no intelligence here, we can only await with impatience the details which their poverty of space at present withholds. Supply a sensation-head of large proportions to the following, dated at Nashville, May 27, and the reader will have a glimpse of reverses which our armies have sustained, but which the Administration, acting perhaps upon Palmetto precedents, has carefully suppressed:

abstract: A Royal proclamation published on Tuesday last defines with some care the official attitude of Great Britain in the American crisis. The Government is strictly neutral in the contest, and British subjects are ordered to be strictly neutral too.
lead_paragraph: A Royal proclamation published on Tuesday last defines with some care the official attitude of Great Britain in the American crisis. The Government is strictly neutral in the contest, and British subjects are ordered to be strictly neutral too. They are forbidden to enlist for land or sea service on either side, to supply munitions of war, to equip vessels for privateering purposes, to engage in any transport service, or do any other act calculated to afford direct assistance to either of the great parties to the struggle. British subjects infringing any of these rules will be liable to penalties for a misdemeanor, not a very formidable threat when the composition of British juries is considered, and to any punishment a successful enemy may deem it politic to inflict.

Events here had attained a consistency which had chrystalized opinions there; and in sitting down to the solution of this important problem we do so without the vexatious consciousness of the absence of any essential elements. The case is fully before us. We have only to pass upon it.

abstract: The ingenuity of the rebels is taxed to find a crime that has the race of novelty. No sort of offence which the barrister would describe as "within the pleas of the crown," have they failed to commit so frequently that the iteration must have palled the immoral sense. They have just found another, and the only exception, perhaps, to the previous universality of their accomplishments, in the robbery of the mails. The pestilent mob of vagabonds at Harper's Ferry have stopped the mail trains on the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, and detaining the mail-car, at their leisure have cut up the bags and rifled the contents. The amount of booty they have in this way secured will soon be known; but it is probably considerable, and may prove of some service in repairing their commissariat, and meeting, to some extent, the arrears of the payroll. In the meantime, having, as a vindictive measure, discontinued the mails in the rebel States, is it not time to abstain from trusting our own mails to lines of transportation which not only run through those States, but actually through the enemy's encampments? The Postmaster-General should give instant attention to this inconsistency.

abstract: The First Regiment of Maine Volunteers, which, it will be remembered, was detained at home owing to the breaking out of disease among the troops, arrived in this City yesterday, on route for the seat of war.
lead_paragraph: The First Regiment of Maine Volunteers, which, it will be remembered, was detained at home owing to the breaking out of disease among the troops, arrived in this City yesterday, on route for the seat of war. They left Boston at 8 o'clock, and Fall River at 12 o'clock on Saturday evening, and, though expected at 9 A.M., did not reach here until about 12 M. They are a stalwart and sturdy class of men, and look as if they could stand some of the rough usage which many of our volunteers have been obliged to undergo. There are four companies from Portland, and the balance are from Lewiston, Auburn and Norway, and that region of the State. The following are the principal officers:

abstract: A gentleman who is acquainted with all the circumstances attending the departure of the Naval Brigade of Col. BARTLETT, states that the Colonel received the order of the President to report his command to Gen. BUTLER, off Fort Monroe, on the 28th of May, and, meantime, to obtain whatever he might require for the equipment of his brigade from the Quartermaster's or Naval Department. Upon applying here, there was nothing to be obtained which they wanted, both these Departments being behind in the orders for clothing and other necessary articles. Determined, however, to obey the orders from head quarters, "without putting the Government to any further trouble," the Colonel decided to depart with his command, and accordingly took some five hundred Sharp's rifles which had been hurriedly completed for them at Hartford, the James larger fled cannon, and a large quantity of ammunition and rations, relying upon Gen. BUTLER to make all right, by giving the necessary requisition for the payment after he should arrive at Monroe. The delay in obtaining the proper requisition from the commander at Fort Monroe probably accounts for the report that they had been landed without arms. It is believed here that the brigade has been in no danger from this circumstance, and that the whole matter has been properly arranged before this.

abstract: The Southern Press isrejoicing over what it regards as the superior gentility of its soldiers, when compared with the Northern troops. A Richmond paper says "We have one company of Virginians, representing three or four millions of dollars. The captain is proprietor of an estate valued at $1,500,000; and the poorest man in the company is worth his $10,000 at least. What a contrast is this to the unwashed lumbermen of Maine, the bumpkins of Vermont, the thieving firemen of New-York, and the cobblers and greasy operatives of Massachusetts, who compose the mercenary hordes of the North." Flattering to Virginian pride, doubtless; but just wait till the "unwashed lumbermen of Maine," the "bumpkins of Vermont," the "thieving firemen of New-York," or the "cobblers and greasy operatives ofMassachusetts" get sight of this company of Virginia millionaires, and we shall see. We do not desire that such a thing should occur for our special gratification; but if it is fated to happen, we should like wonderfully to be a spectator. The locomotive powers of these F.F.'s would pretty surely be put to a crucial test.

abstract: Elizabeth Thompson, a colored woman, was arrested yesterday, charged with stealing three trunks containing a large quantity of wearing apparel, jewelry, &c., the property of a young woman named Ellen Livingston. The accused, it appears, was employed to attend Miss Livingston during a late illness, and embraced the opportunity to rob her of her trunks, which she caused to be conveyed from a room in Houston-street, near Broadway, where Miss Livingston resided, to one in Thompson-street, near Spring. Soon after the theft was committed, Miss Livingston died, and the fact of the robbery coming to the knowledge of the police, they arrested the woman Thompson and recovered the trunks and most of their contents. The prisoner was taken before Justice QUACKENBUSH, and committed for trial.

abstract: Custom hath not staled the infinite variety of the departures of the Highland Guard, for yesterday, when they bade farewell to our City, they were greeted with an ovation, such as has seldom been witnessed, even in these stirring times.
lead_paragraph: Custom hath not staled the infinite variety of the departures of the Highland Guard, for yesterday, when they bade farewell to our City, they were greeted with an ovation, such as has seldom been witnessed, even in these stirring times. From an early hour in the afternoon, the approaches to Palace Garden were crowded with eager expectants, who looked and longed for the plaid with unmurmuring persistency. According to the order issued by Brigadier Gen. SCOTT, the regiment was to have taken its departure at 2 o'clock, but it was soon known that the hour had been changed to four. By this time the streets were literally packed with a surging mass of humanity. Up Fourteenth-street and down Broadway there was not a window unoccupied; but the fair watchers lingered many an hour ere the braves came along. About 6 1/2 o'clock the sound of the pibroch was heard, and soon after the kilted pipers were seen treading their way through the multitude, preceded by an admirably-drilled squad of our Metropolitan Police. Then came the officers, variously clad in the tartans of their clans; then the Commanding Officer, Lieut.-Col. ELLIOTT, and various other military dignitaries; then the men, dressed in dark jackets tipped with red, and plaid pantaloons; and then the overwhelming applause of gratified thousands. The regiment numbers about 880 men, the majority of whom are extremely imposing in appearance. Scotias' fame in war, in arts, and in letters, is worldwide. Looking on these, her sons, as they went forth pesterday, it was not difficult to believe that her fame in the first of these "fine arts" will be maintained and renewed on American soil. If an occasion should arise for the display of valor; for the exercise of tough endurance, or the exhibition of content amid scenes of hardship and trial, we may rest assured that the Highland Guard will improve it and give an example to others. The men of whom it is composed are among the thriftiest and most industrious of our community. There is scarcely one who has not sacrificed a certainty of existence to go with this regiment and place his life at the disposal of the Government. It was the pibroch of the MCGREGOR's that saved the heroic defenders of Lucknow, and we may depend on it that in the moment of danger, the pipes of the Seventy-ninth will bring comfort to many a beleagured spirit. The men are remarkably athletic; many of them have seen service in the Crimean and Indian wars, and all of them are of that tough texture which prevails in North Britain, and seems to be best calculated to resist exposure and privation. The regiment was announced to leage for Washington on almost every day of the past week. It has been impossible to procure a decent bowl of Scotch broth since Monday last, so great has been the extremity of all the lassies. Deficiencies in the equipments have led to the delay. It was determined, and wisely, that the regiment should not leave until it had obtained all the arms and equipments that it required. Hence, while the men were ready to move at a moment's notice, and the officers were burning with impatience, the hour of departure had to be postponed from day to day. These little disappointments were all forgotten yesterday, and the Seventy-ninth marched through a gathering scarcely inferior to that which assembled to bid farewell to the Seventh, on the 19th of April last. In the matter of enthusiasm there was no difference at all. The streets were crowded, and every one cheered. No occasion can produce a more genial and kindly result.

abstract: The reconnoisance of Company B, Second Cavalry, on Saturday morning last, which extended into the town of Fairfax Court house, was, as we surmised, preliminary to the permanent occupation of that place.
lead_paragraph: The reconnoisance of Company B, Second Cavalry, on Saturday morning last, which extended into the town of Fairfax Court house, was, as we surmised, preliminary to the permanent occupation of that place. Three regiments of Federal troops proceeded there yesterday, and took quiet possession -- the fifteen hundred rebel troops reported as being stationed there having taken position in some other and more safe quarter. These three regiments are to be immediately followed by others -- enough, of course, to insure the permanent occupation of the place, which is of considerable strategic importance. The occupation of this town by our troops was preceded by another brilliant episode of the war, which probably had something to do with the precipitancy with which the rebel troops had left, and in which Company B, of the Second Cavalry, were again the principal actors. It will be recollected that on the occasion of their first dash into the town, on Saturday morning, they lost two of their men, who were taken prisoners by the rebels. It being understood that the rebels had threatened to hang these men yesterday morning, their comrades determined to attempt their rescue, and accordingly the company again proceeded to the town, and ascertaining by some means where the men were confined, they charged through the streets, rescued them, and brought them back to camp in triumph.

abstract: Recruiting for the past week was tolerably brisk, both at the army and navy offices. Thirty-two men were sent over to the island from Cedar, Chatham and Hudson streets.
lead_paragraph: Recruiting for the past week was tolerably brisk, both at the army and navy offices. Thirty-two men were sent over to the island from Cedar, Chatham and Hudson streets. The number of persons accepted at the Cherry-street naval rendezvous is steadily increasing. Over 290 men were put on board the North Carolina since Monday, which averages nearly 30 recruits per day. At Boston recruiting is dull. The officers of the Portland-street rendezvous say that the mania for volunteering in the militia regiments has materially lessened the regulars. Philadelphia sent to this City two detachments during the week, which have been added to the force at the station. The Baltimore establishment is still doing a better business than any of its competitors, notwithstanding the secessionism of that city.

abstract: The cotton manufacturers of England seem to be sorely puzzled in regard to American affairs, and the prospect of securing food for their spindles from this country.
lead_paragraph: The cotton manufacturers of England seem to be sorely puzzled in regard to American affairs, and the prospect of securing food for their spindles from this country. They have not fully convinced themselves that the seceding States are sincere in their rebellion, or that the loyal States are in earnest in suppressing it by physical force. They have not yet learned that negotiation is at an end, the day of compromises past. They have not realized the fact that our complications have at last narrowed down to the stern and hard arbitrament of the sword. The London News says:

abstract: We regret that the subjoined sketch of a discourse delivered by Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER last night should be all that the crowded condition of our columns will permit us to publish.
lead_paragraph: We regret that the subjoined sketch of a discourse delivered by Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER last night should be all that the crowded condition of our columns will permit us to publish. It will be remembere that day before yesterday three companies of Massachusetts State Militia were received here as component parts of what is known as the "Brooklyn Phalanx," or popularly speaking, "Beecher's Regiment." These companies having gone into the guardianship of the clergyman aforementioned, he deemed it proper to deliver to them and their brethren of the Empire State, together with a large number of laymen and ladies, words of advice, of monition, and of warning.

abstract: A series DISCOVERY OF EXTENSIVE FORGERIES. A series of bold and extensive forgeries have just been brought to light in Washington, Penn. The operator was
lead_paragraph: -- A series of bold and extensive forgeries have just been brought to light in Washington, Penn. The operator was a man named J.W. SMITH, a resident of Cross Creek township, and widely known in the neighborhood. It appears that for the last few years he has been operating in the live stock and produce business, and in that capacity has sought and obtained frequent accommodations for considerable sums of money, several of his immediate neighbors becoming indorsers. In this way things have been going on for some time past, the artful operator all the while managing, by the prompt payment of some of his notes and the renewal of others, to keep up his credit and secure the entire confidence of those with whom he was dealing. Failing to meet a note which matured in one of the Wheeling banks last week, however, notice of protest was sent to the persons whose names appeared as indorsers, when it was found for the first time that their names had been forged to the paper! This of course led other parties who held his notes to make inquiry, and soon brought to light the astounding fact that all the indorsements upon which he had drawn funds were daring forgeries. It turns out that his indebtedness upon this sort of fraudulent paper to different parties about town amounts to about $24,000, made up thus: Notes disposed of to Dr. F.J. LEMOYNE, of Washington, $14,000; to WM. SMITH & SON, $3,000; to Franklin Bank of Washington, $1,000; to Wheeling Banks, $5,000; to Wellsburgh Bank, $2,000. Besides the foregoing, all of which are forgeries, SMITH leaves other liabilities behind him amounting to some $8,000 or $10,000. The scoundrel has, unfortunately for justice, made his escape to parts unknown, and there seems now but little probability that his capture will soon be effected. He has not been engaged in business for some time, and it is surprised that he took the greater part of his ill-gotten gain with him in his flight. -- Pittsburgh Chron., June 1.

abstract: The old arsonal, situated on Central Park, was a scene of great excitement yesterday. Positive marching orders having been received, the Regiment formed into line about 12 o'clock, and was presented with the National colors. At about 1 o'clock, the whole body
lead_paragraph: The old arsonal, situated on Central Park, was a scene of great excitement yesterday. Positive marching orders having been received, the Regiment formed into line about 12 o'clock, and was presented with the National colors. At about 1 1/2 o'clock, the whole body was in motion; the line of march was down Fifth-avenue to Fourteenth street, thence to Broadway down, to the City Hall, where they placed in charge of the Corporation of of New-York city, the banner that was presented to the old members of the Scott Life Guard, shortly after their return from Mexico. After the subjugation of the rebels, and on the return of the regiment to this City, the Corporation will deliver into their hands again the old standard. At the conclusion of the above ceremony, the regiment marched to the foot of North Moore-street, where it embarked on the steamship Alabama. There are eight hundred and fifteen men in this regiment, including officers. Annexed is a list of the officers:

lead_paragraph: We publish to-day the opinion of Judge TANEY in the Merryman case, thus giving him the benefit of a judicial answer to our strictures upon his course in relation to that matter.
