abstract: The telegraph brings us the sad news that STEPHEN A. DOUGLAS is no more. He died at his residence in Chicago yesterday morning. Connected as he has been with events which for the
lead_paragraph: The telegraph brings us the sad news that STEPHEN A. DOUGLAS is no more. He died at his residence in Chicago yesterday morning. Connected as he has been with events which for the last few years have been and still are shaping the destinies of this country, his name will have a prominent place in history. The measures which he in the main originated, and to which his earnest advocacy and support were given, may be regarded as lying at the foundation of our present complications, and it is greatly to be regretted that he could not have been spared to take part in the struggle in the origin of which he was so prominent an actor, and to the successful issue of which his energy and conceded ability might have contributed so much.

abstract: The United States vs. One Package marked B, F., containing diamonds. -- This was an action brought to forfeit the goods for an alleged fraudulent undervaluation with intent to evade the payment of duties. The Government gave evidence showing that the package of diamonds was not made up in the ordinary way, but was made up of four different kinds and colors of diamonds, rendering it difficult to appraise them, but that on separating them the appraiser had raised their value some fourteen per cent. above the invoice price, and they claimed that this undervaluation was fraudulent. The claimant proved that the variation was not much more than was usual in estimating diamonds and gave evidence tending to show that the appraisal was too high, and the jury found a verdict for the claimant, releasing the goods. For the Government, Mr. Smith and Mr. Craig. For claimant, Mr. Joachimsen.
lead_paragraph: The United States vs. One Package marked B, F., containing diamonds. -- This was an action brought to forfeit the goods for an alleged fraudulent undervaluation with intent to evade the payment of duties. abstract: The favorable light in which the French Government looks at the policy adopted by the North, in the suppression of the Southern rebellion, and the offers made by M. THOUVENEL,
lead_paragraph: The favorable light in which the French Government looks at the policy adopted by the North, in the suppression of the Southern rebellion, and the offers made by M. THOUVENEL, the Minister of Foreign Affairs, to aid us in putting it down, must in great part, at least, be attributed to the efforts of the French Press and of French writers. Since the election of Mr. LINCOLN, the Parisian journals, served by intelligent correspondents at New-York, have taken a lively interest in our affairs, an interest which the existence of a French Republican Club in this City has contributed to increase. Though engrossed by the great question of the temporality of the Pope, and by the important privileges granted by the Emperor to the legislative body in November last, they have, from time to time, published articles on American questions as remarkable for the correctness of their statements as for the elevation of their sentiments and their abhorrence of Slavery. Many of them, and most particularly the Journal des Debats, hailed the election of Mr. LINCOLN as a return to the pure and noble policy of WASHINGTON, and as an era of regeneration for the United States. Prepared as public opinion was beforehand, it is no wonder that the news of the Southern rebellion has found the French Government ill-disposed towards the disturbers of our public peace and prosperity.

abstract: Englishmen are puzzled beyond measure at the anomaly which the United States present, of a country, convulsed by civil war, yet drawing, by virtue of its commercial strength, gold from all nations with which it deals.
lead_paragraph: Englishmen are puzzled beyond measure at the anomaly which the United States present, of a country, convulsed by civil war, yet drawing, by virtue of its commercial strength, gold from all nations with which it deals. With one-half of our ports closed, we are still the creditor-nation of the world. Such is our intrinsic strength, that we shall suffer really less from the war than Great Britain, which bears only a commercial relation to it. Food constitutes a very large item of our exports, and this is consumed to the same extent in war as in peace; especially such as we export -- flour, corn and provisions. All these are necessaries, not luxuries.

abstract: THE ROMAN CATHOLIC PROVINCIAL COUNCIL The triennial Ecclesiastical Convention of the Bishops induced within the Provincial Council of New York began its services, Archbishop HUGHES presiding, at the Cathedral in Mott-street, yesterday morning.
lead_paragraph: THE ROMAN CATHOLIC PROVINCIAL COUNCIL -- The triennial Ecclesiastical Convention of the Bishops induced within the Provincial Council of New York began its services, Archbishop HUGHES presiding, at the Cathedral in Mott-street, yesterday morning. The members of the Convention are the Bishops, McCloskey, of Albany; Timon of Buffalo; Bailey, of Newburgh; Loughlin, of Brooklyn; Bacon, of New-Hampshire; Fitzpatrick, of Boston; and McFarland, of Hartford. There were also present Bishops Barrajas, of San Luis Potosi; Espinosa, of Guadalajara, and two expelled prelates from Mexico. The prelates marched from the house of the Archbishop in full canonica's, escorted by the members of the Society of Saint Vincent de Paul. After high mass had been performed, the Council went into secret conclave, and will sit till Wednesday.

abstract: A series of bold and extensive forgeries have just been brought to light in Washington. Penn. The operator was a man named J. W. SMITH, a resident of Cross
lead_paragraph: A series of bold and extensive forgeries have just been brought to light in Washington. Penn. The operator was a man named J. W. SMITH, a resident of Cross Creek township, and widely known in the neighborhood. It appears that for the last few years he has been operating in the live stock and produce business, and in that capacity has sought and obtained frequent accommodations for considerable sums of money, several of his immediate neighbors becoming indorsers. In this way things have been going on for some time past, the artful operator all the while managing, by the prompt payment of some of his notes and the renewal of others, to keep up his credit and secure the entire confidence of those with whom he was dealing. Failing to meet a note which matured in one of the Wheeling banks last week, however, notice of protest was sent to the persons whose names appeared as indorsers, when it was found for the first time that their names had been forged to the paper! This of course led other parties who held his notes to make inquiry, and soon brought to light the astounding fact that all the indorsements upon which he had drawn funds were daring forgeries. It turns out that his indebtedness upon this sort of fraudulent paper to different parties about town amounts to about $24,000, made up thus: Notes disposed of to Dr. F.J. LEMOYNE, of Washington, $14,000; to WM. SMITH & SON, $3,000; to Franklin Bank of Washington, $1,000; to Wheeling Banks, $5,000; to Wellsburgh Bank, $2,000. Besides the foregoing, all of which are forgeries, SMITH leaves other liabilities behind him amounting to some $8,000 or $10,000. The scoundrel has, unfortunately for justice, made his escape to parts unknown, and there seems now but little probability that his capture will soon be effected. He has not been engaged in business for some time, and it is surmised that he took the greater part of his ill-gotten gain with him in his flight. -- Pittsburgh Chron., June 1.

abstract: Had we the power to choose when men should die, we might uncharitably hurry a host to their fate, while others we should earnestly grasp and retain. The present is not the time for the nation to lose Mr. DOUGLAS, At a moment
lead_paragraph: Had we the power to choose when men should die, we might uncharitably hurry a host to their fate, while others we should earnestly grasp and retain. The present is not the time for the nation to lose Mr. DOUGLAS, At a moment when the entire fabric of our institutions is shaken to its base, and men of character, energy and executive ability, and possessed of the popular confidence, are demanded to lead the great movement for the redemption of our national unity, Mr. DOUGLAS was not to be spared; and our private reasons for lamenting the death of the individual are aggravated immeasurably by the untimely death of an invaluable popular leader. It was just at the moment that the politician was lost in the patriot, and it had become possible for the errors of a political career to be nobly atoned, that the opportunity was torn away.

abstract: The States composing the C.S.A. are poor and already burthened with debts beyond their ability to pay. The Treasury of the Confederacy is empty. The plunder of mints and
lead_paragraph: The States composing the C.S.A. are poor and already burthened with debts beyond their ability to pay. The Treasury of the Confederacy is empty. The plunder of mints and sub-treasuries is quite exhausted. Forced loans, irredeemable bank issues, and equally irredeemable shinplasters, have given out. Utterly without the present means of raising the necessary millions to sustain rebellion, despairing of its credit abroad, and knowing that the people have neither the ability nor the will to bear increased taxation, the "Southern Confederacy" has hit upon a notable plan to replenish its exhausted finances and furnish itself with the sinews of war. The plan was concocted in secret session, and is being carefully promulgated through popular speeches and the Press. These, however, do not broach the subject boldly, but feel their way cautiously, noting with anxiety the effect upon the popular sense. In this, as in all other emergencies in the South, the everlasting cotton-plant is the El Dorado, the California mines, the Alladin's lamp, the philosopher's stone, that is to bring to the Confederate Treasury untold millions of solid gold. Six weeks ago a duty on exports of cotton was to supply every want, but the presence of American cruisers along the Southern coasts prevented exportation, and the slate and pencil demonstration vanished into air.

abstract: The mil THE WAR AND THE INSTITUTION.--The mil tary ardor of the Southern people in defence of what, by a singular perversion of language, they are pleased to call their "liberty," has formed the theme of unnumbered panegyrics which have very nearly exhausted the rhetoric of Southern writers.
lead_paragraph: -- The military ardor of the Southern people in defence of what, by a singular perversion of language, they are pleased to call their "liberty," has formed the theme of unnumbered panegyrics which have very nearly exhausted the rhetoric of Southern writers. They have not limited the war spirit to the whites, but, in view of the suggestion that there was danger of slave insurrections, they have endowed their chattels with enough of the attributes of men to make them share in the general enthusiasm, and to take up arms to maintain the integrity of Southern institutions.

abstract: Should the rebels longer defy the visible power of this Government, and insist on calling down a blow from the strong arm that loss when Sumter fell, some four months, at least, must elapse before the war can be carried rapidly and irresistibly "into Africa."
lead_paragraph: Should the rebels longer defy the visible power of this Government, and insist on calling down a blow from the strong arm that loss when Sumter fell, some four months, at least, must elapse before the war can be carried rapidly and irresistibly "into Africa." This interval, in a country so full as are the Northern States of mechanical facilities -- of materials, foundries, tools, skillful operatives, and ingenious and daring engineers, is quite time enough to prepare for a short and decisive campaign, especially since the events of the last two months have called universal attention to the specific wants of a great modern army.

abstract: FALSE FRIENDS--AN UNFORTUNATE COUNTRYMAN.--On Thursday night last, Mr. PETER ODELL, of Westchester County, chanced to enter a billiardsaloon in Second-avenue, where he played and drank a while with two youths named JOHN MONROE and CHARLES W. BANCROFT, both of whom were strangers to him, At 2 o'clock A.M. he departed for his lodg
lead_paragraph: FALSE FRIENDS -- AN UNFORTUNATE COUNTRYMAN. -- On Thursday night last, Mr. PETER ODELL, of Westchester County, chanced to enter a billiardsaloon in Second-avenue, where he played and drank a while with two youths named JOHN MONROE and CHARLES W. BANCROFT, both of whom were strangers to him, At 2 o'clock A.M. he departed for his lodgings, accompanied by the young men, who volunteered their escort, although ODELL had seen enough to induce a desire to rid himself of them. At the corner of the avenue and Thirty-fourth-street, they turned upon the countryman, beat him, wrenched away his watch, took his money and fled. As soon as possible, ODELL made his way to the Police station and gave a description of the robbers, who were arrested on Monday night. Having been fully identified by the complainant Justice CONNOLLY held them for trial.

abstract: A special dispatch from Wheeling, published in Thursday's Pittsburgh Chronicle, announced the capture at Sistersville, Va., of two rifled cannon, the property of the rebels. It appears that information of the presence of cannon there was conveyed to Maj. OAKS by a Mr. BAGGS, and the former chartered the Eunice, and, with about fifty armed men aboard, started down the river. They reached Sistersville about 2 o'clock, landed a short distance above the town and established a guard. Mr. BAGGS indicated the place where the cannon were to be found, and some eight or ten men were sent up, while the others were placed in a position to protect them. The cannon were concealed in an old barn, and covered with rakes, plows and straw. The barn was broken open, the guns disinterred, and in less than fifteen minutes they were aboard the boat, together with a valuable lot of ammunition. The men, after getting under way again, fired a volley or two to let the Secessionists know they were about, and got back to Wheeling at 10 o'clock on Thursday morning.
lead_paragraph: A special dispatch from Wheeling, published in Thursday's Pittsburgh Chronicle, announced the capture at Sistersville, Va., of two rifled cannon, the property of the rebels. It appears that information of the presence of cannon there was conveyed to Maj. OAKS by a Mr. BAGGS, and the former chartered the Eunice, and, with about fifty armed men aboard, started down the river. They reached Sistersville about 2 o'clock, landed a short distance above the town and established a guard. Mr. BAGGS indicated the place where the cannon were to be found, and some eight or ten men were sent up, while the others were placed in a position to protect them. The cannon were concealed in an old barn, and covered with rakes, plows and straw. The barn was broken open, the guns disinterred, and in less than fifteen minutes they were aboard the boat, together with a valuable lot of ammunition. The men, after getting under way again, fired a volley or two to let the Secessionists know they were about, and got back to Wheeling at 10 o'clock on Thursday morning.

abstract: In token of respect to the memory of Senator DOUGLAS, the Boards of Trade and Courts adjourned at an early hour. All the flags in city were at half-mast, and prominent buildings were draped in mourning. The remains of the illustrious Senator will lay in state at Bryan Hall from to-morrow noon until Wednesday evening, when, if the present arrangements are carried out, they will be taken to Washington for interment.

abstract: Among the falsehoods industriously circulated by the rebel leaders and the rebel Press, to delude and stimulate their followers, is what they are pleased to term the "hatred of the South" on the part of the people of the loyal States, as if the war was being prose
lead_paragraph: Among the falsehoods industriously circulated by the rebel leaders and the rebel Press, to delude and stimulate their followers, is what they are pleased to term the "hatred of the South" on the part of the people of the loyal States, as if the war was being prosecuted to satisfy popular malignity against brethren of the same nationality and kindred of the same race. There never was a greater fallacy, a more wicked perversion, than this. That the people of the Northern States hate the treason of the South, and would not hesitate to punish the unprincipled leaders who have fomented it into rebellion, is entirely true. This is inevitable, growing out of, and is the converse of their love for the Union against which that treason is in revolt; but there is not, and never has been, in the Northern minds, any such passion as hatred to the South. The history of the past proves this, and the instincts of every true heart attests it. The North has always been in the majority, and yet the honors and emoluments of official place have been enjoyed by the South to an extent greatly beyond their numerical proportion. From the Executive chair down to the lowest place in the Federal Government, the offices have, in a large majority, been held by Southern men. In the Army, the Navy, the Judiciary, the Secretaryships, the Foreign Missions, the Consulates, the clerkships in the Departments, the South has always had a majority. The course of the Government, the policy of the country, have been shaped to meet the pleasure and promote the interests of the South. The North has sometimes protested against this favoritism; but the South has been importunate, and the North has yielded. If there was "hatred to the South" in the Northern heart, would this have been so?
headline: {'main': 'Hatred to the South.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Hatred to the South.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Louisville Journal of May 13th says: "We don't know where Mr. ETHERIDGE is at this time; but, wherever he may be, we would warn him of the danger of his returning to Tennessee. We could give him facts which would convince him that he can return turn only at the imminent risk of his life. Instructions have certainly been given by Gen. PILLOW that he shall be hung, or shot, or otherwise killed at the first opportunity. He has been keenly watched for in all directions. Men were hunting for him last night in the cars at or near the Tennessee line.

abstract: They had a great gathering the other day at Nashvilie. The occasion was the presenta tion of a flag to a company of rangers, and "the confirmation of the nomination of Gen. WASHINGTON BARROWS for Senator from Davidson, and Col. IRA P. JONES for Representative."
lead_paragraph: They had a great gathering the other day at Nashvilie. The occasion was the presenta tion of a flag to a company of rangers, and "the confirmation of the nomination of Gen. WASHINGTON BARROWS for Senator from Davidson, and Col. IRA P. JONES for Representative." Patriotism and politics having combined, it was their own fault, of course, if they failed to have a good time generally. Among the orators who "thrilled the people with their eloquence " was one "A.L. DEMOSS, Esquire." We have not the slightest idea who A.L. DEMOSS, Esq., is. Perhaps not to know him "argues ourselves unknown." Still it is our misfortune to be wholly ignorant of his origin, his dwelling-place, and his history. But for all that, A.L. DEMOSS, Esquire, is immense in oratory, magnificent in tropes and figures; wonderful in grandeur of conception, daring in imagery. Here is one of the diamonds with which among a thousand others his speech, as reported in the Nashville Union, was gemmed:

abstract: We have no important movements to report as having occurred across the Potomac within the last twenty-four hours. To-day, however, an ad vance will be made by a portion of our forces, some four miles further into Virginia.
lead_paragraph: We have no important movements to report as having occurred across the Potomac within the last twenty-four hours. To-day, however, an ad vance will be made by a portion of our forces, some four miles further into Virginia. The Federal troops were yesterday engaged in perfecting their entrenchments, and worked with a will, notwithstanding the heat of the weather. The number of the rebel troops in and around Fairfax, and between that point and Manassas Gap, is now set down at not exceeding forty-six hundred in all, but it is of course impossible to ascertain the number with positive certainty. Their strength and disposition to resist the advance of the Federal troops will probably soon be tested. From the nature of our advices from Fortress Monroe, also, there can hardly be a doubt that an important movement will soon be made there. The number of our troops now there approaches ten thousand, and transports are daily arriving with accessions.

abstract: In following the English journals in their treatment of the American Question, the double duty is imposed on the reader of noting at once the change in its opinions and in its sentiments--the state both of the head and of the heart.
lead_paragraph: In following the English journals in their treatment of the American Question, the double duty is imposed on the reader of noting at once the change in its opinions and in its sentiments -- the state both of the head and of the heart. There is no evidence, from the latest advices, which we give elsewhere, that they have been touched with any effectual saving grace; their spirit is just as contemptible, their morality just as low as ever, but their insight improves; and as there are now many influences conspiring to clarify their vision -- a conspicuous instance of which is the letter which Mr. CLAY, our new Minister to Russia, addresses to the London Times -- we shall be prepared to see the lending journal and its followers visited with a successive series of revelations, which to a mind not blinded with prejudice, are no revelations at all, but very obvious facts.

abstract: FIRE IN A HOOP-SKIRT MANUFACTORY. -- Shortly before 7 o'clock, last evening, a fire originated from some unknown cause in the hoop-skirt manufactory of Mr. M. PLATH, on the fourth floor of building No. 80 Cliff-street. By extraordinary and well directed efforts the firemen succeeded in confining the flames to the premises where they broke out. The loss of Mr. PLATH is estimated at $2,000; insured for $4 000 in various City Companier. Messrs. BUMBACHER & DEPEW, occupants of the adjoining building, No. 78, suffered a loss by water upon machinery of about $200 -- insured. No. 80 was owned by Mr. COOLIDGE. It was damaged to the extent of $500.

abstract: We call attention to the letter of Mr. CLAY, Minister from the United States to St. Petersburg. This lively letter-writer proposes six questions, -- three relating to his own country, three relating to England. The first question he is more successful in asking than answering, -- "What are we fighting for!" "We are fighting," says Mr. CLAY, "for nationality and liberty." We can understand a fight for nationality between different races, but a fight for nationality between men of the same nationality is to us, we candidly confess it, an inexplicable enigma; nor can we better understand how a people, fighting to put down rebellion, to force their fellow-citizens to remain in a Confederacy which they detest, and to submit to institutions which they repudiate, can be called the champions of liberty. If the South seriously threatened to conquer the North, to put down trial by jury, freedom of the press, and representative government, the contest might be for liberty; but, as this is not so, the introduction of such topics is mere rhetorical amplification, "Can you subdue the revolted States?" "Of course we can," says Mr. CLAY. So on that point there is no more to be said. "Can you reconstruct the Union when one-half of it has conquered the other?" "Nothing easier," says Mr. CLAY. The victim of to-day will become the confederate of to-morrow: the traitors will be cast out, and the Union firmer than ever -- witness the happy results of the conquest of Ireland by England, repeated over and over again, and always repeated in vain.
lead_paragraph: We call attention to the letter of Mr. CLAY, Minister from the United States to St. Petersburg. If the South seriously threatened to conquer the North, to put down trial by jury, freedom of the press, and representative government, the contest might be for liberty; but, as this is not so, the introduction of such topics is mere rhetorical amplification, "Can you subdue the revolted States?" "Of course we can," says Mr. CLAY. So on that point there is no more to be said. "Can you reconstruct the Union when one-half of it has conquered the other?" "Nothing easier," says Mr. CLAY. abstract: The Boston Journal, of June 3, says: "WILLIAM G. BUTTERFIELD, of Stoneham, a private in Company L of the Sixth Massachusetts Regiment, which was commanded by Capt. DYKE, arrived in the city this morning. Mr. BUTTERFIELD was wounded by a ball through the leg in the memorable passage through Baltimore. He managed, with the aid of his comrades, to go with his company to Washington, and is now able to walk about, though the wound has not healed. He was ordered home by the Surgeon of the regiment.

abstract: ERS -- ISAAC A. CAGWIN, of Verona, Onieda County, N.Y. a few days since came to this City for business purposes, and was enticed by a "decoy" into an alleged gambling house at No. 537 Broadway, kept by a man named HENRY JUDD, where he lost $575 at the game of faro. In the hope of retrieving his fortune he again called at the same house on Saturday evening last and participated in other games of chance, nothing with the loss of an additional $700. This lost ill luck threw him into a fit of virtuous indignation, and determining that the public good required the extermination of the gamblers, he went before Justice CONNOLLY and made an affidavit of the facts. A warrant was issued and placed in the hands of Sergeants WILSON and WADE, of the Eighth Precinct Police, who executed it late on Monday night. They surprised the happy "sports," and captured eight who were engaged in their exciting pursuit, and seized as well an extensive assortment of expensive paraphernalia, in bulk about a cart-load The prisoner were taken before Justice CONNOLLY, who detained them for examination. They gave fictitious names but the "dealer," "decay" and two or three others of the party, have been identified by CAGWIN as among the number who participated in the amusement of "plucking" him.

abstract: The great want of the Government now is rifled cannon. For the want of this efficient weapon the vessels that attacked the batteries at Aquia Creek were twice repulsed, and finally forced virtually to give up the capture of the position. In this respect the rebels have us at an advantage, and until the Government remedies this defect it cannot cope even handed with the rebel batteries.

abstract: "The United States have accepted this civil war as an inevitable necessity." Such is the declaration of Mr. SEWARD in his dispatch to the American Minister at Paris. The Secretary of the United States Government must have pondered well those words before he consigned them in a document to be laid before the first Power of Continental Europe. But they express a fact, one which has not received sufficient attention in England. It is often lightly asked here why the two sections of the American Union cannot separate, and live peaceably side by side. Those who thus speak have bestowed but a slight and superficial attention upon the nature of the causes of disagreement. The question may be met by another -- if nothing hinders them living peaceably side by side, why should they separate and sacrifice the Union, which is their common strength and glory? The statesmen of the North know full well that, however quietly they might acquiesce in the separation of the South, there could be no peace between Governments founded on principles so radically antagonistic as those embodied in the respective Constitutions of the Confederacy and of the United States. The promise, if seriously given would not and could not be kept. We have heard a good deal of the Monroe doctrine, and the determination of the citizens of the United States never to allow any European Government to transfer its institutions to a fresh portion of the American Continent; but the United States Government might with much less danger to its tranquillity allow this than permit the formation of a great Slave Power stretching from the Ohio to the Gulf. There is nothing in the forms of European Governments more inimical to the peace and freedom of the non-slaveholding States than the political doctrines openly proclaimed by the secession leaders. If the Confederacy could establish itself it would manifest itself to the world on the very morrow as a propagandist, aggressive, freebooting State, perpetually menacing its neighbors and embroiling them in hostilities. Its large idle population of poor and turbulent whites form the appropriate material of fillibustering forces, and would be ever annexing somebody. The extension of the area of Slavery, it should be remembered, was the very question on which the present rupture has taken place. Severed from the Union, the South would send out its bands in all directions, and carry Slavery far and wide. The acquisition of Mexico is one of the commonest promises made to their adherents by the Secession leaders. Is the [???] the American [???] Certainly it could not; it is therefore better to meet the mischief in its early stage. The only object the South have in separating is that Slavery hitherto limited by counteracting principles, may henceforth become sovereign, expanding itself, and pervading and moulding every institution of Government. And experience proves that the growth of negro slavery is the measure of the decrease of the white man's freedom. Where the black man is held in bondage the white man is deprived of the commonest liberties, and most neither speak his mind nor exercise his injury.

abstract: The treason of LETCHER and of the Commissioners who made the disgraceful surrender of Virginia to JEFFERSON DAVIS, has reduced the Old Dominion to a condition utterly contemptible. It was bad enough to have Gov.
lead_paragraph: The treason of LETCHER and of the Commissioners who made the disgraceful surrender of Virginia to JEFFERSON DAVIS, has reduced the Old Dominion to a condition utterly contemptible. It was bad enough to have Gov. PICKENS announcing in his bombastic proclamation that a regiment from South Carolina was on the march to protect the tomb of Washington from the Northern Goths and Vandals, after South Carolina had commenced active hostilities for the very purpose of dragging Virginia into a movement which it was well known a large majority of her citizens condemned. But a lower deep was to be reached, when President COBB, of the Montgomery Congress, proclaimed to the citizens of Atlanta that, as Virginia had "at last shaken off the bonds of Lincoln," her soil was to be made the battle-ground; and added, as if apprehensive that the laggard sons of the Old Dominion would not come up to the mark, that Georgia, "solitary and alone, if need be, would fight until she sees the last foul invader in his grave." Still more pitiable was the exhibition at Richmond on the occasion of JEFFERSON DAVIS' triumphant entry. When on his visit to the new Fair Grounds, he was greeted on leaving his saddle by an "enraptured" crowd of "soldiers and civilians" whom we are told by the enthusiastic Enquirer this august magistrate "indulged to a hand-shaking performance!" It is hardly conceivable that the natives of the same soil which produced WASHINGTON and PATRICK HENRY should have so degenerated as to brag of the "indulgence" of shaking hands with a man whose name is a byword for dishonesty in two hemispheres. He is not at all proud, say the Virginia gentlemen; he "indulged" us by condescending to shake hands, notwithstanding he is our military dictator. What are the Virginia chivalry coming to when they stoop to being patronized by PICKENS, COBB, and JEFFERSON DAVIS!

abstract: The attention of general officers of the army belonging to the staff and regiments, has been called to the order of the War Department, permitting them to appear on horseback during service in the field, comparisoned as their comrades of the regular mounted troops.
lead_paragraph: The attention of general officers of the army belonging to the staff and regiments, has been called to the order of the War Department, permitting them to appear on horseback during service in the field, comparisoned as their comrades of the regular mounted troops. They may wear over the saddle, housing of dark blue cloth, with the usual adornments of goldlace, a blue web surcingle, black leather bridle, yellow collar, black leather holsters, with gilt mounting, yellow metal or gilt stirrups. Officers of the Corps of Engineers and Topographical Engineers, have the same privilege.

abstract: Every one will look with some interest at the Message of the President of the Confederate States. The political documents which come to us from the other side of the Atlantic are often prolix and dull, dwelling on endless details, and troubling themselves without many things which in other countries are left [???] important channels of communication; but an apology for secession will command the attention of all who are watching the conflict in America with tear, or sympathy, or courtesy. It need hardly be said that Mr. DAVIS gives an historical retrospect of the reactions between the States which formed the late Union, and endeavors to prove from it that the Southerners, in seceding, have only availed themselves of a right which was inherent in their respective States, and was by no means annulled by the Federal compact Foreigners have always been struck by the legal tone which pervades the discussions of American states-men. While the Judges of the new Republic are founder of researching to first principles than their brethren in the old country, the politicians, on the other have, discuss questions of public policy in the spark of lawyers interpreting the act of Parliament. The two tendencies doubtless arise from the nature or a Confederation which, while it brings into the closest private relations men living under different and conflicting laws, yet unless their public interests only through the medium of a formal document called a Constitution. This Constitution, every sentence of which bristles with the decisions of Federal Judges and State Judges during 70 years, has now received another and most important gloss from the pen of Mr. JEFFERSON DAVIS, the Preston and in every way the master spirit of the new Confederation.

It need hardly be said that Mr. DAVIS gives an historical retrospect of the reactions between the States which formed the late Union, and endeavors to prove from it that the Southerners, in seceding, have only availed themselves of a right which was inherent in their respective States, and was by no means annulled by the Federal compact Foreigners have always been struck by the legal tone which pervades the discussions of American states-men. While the Judges of the new Republic are founder of researching to first principles than their brethren in the old country, the politicians, on the other have, discuss questions of public policy in the spark of lawyers interpreting the act of Parliament. The two tendencies doubtless arise from the nature or a Confederation which, while it brings into the closest private relations men living under different and conflicting laws, yet unless their public interests only through the medium of a formal document called a Constitution. This Constitution, every sentence of which bristles with the decisions of Federal Judges and State Judges during 70 years, has now received another and most important gloss from the pen of Mr. JEFFERSON DAVIS, the Preston and in every way the master spirit of the new Confederation.

abstract: In token of respect to the memory of Senator DOUGLAS, the Boards of Trade and Courts adjourned at an early hour. All the flags in the city were at half-mast, and prominent buildings were draped in mourning. The remains of the illustrious Senator will lay in state at Bryan Hall from to-morrow noon until. Wednesday evening, When, if the present arrangements are caried out, they will be taken to Washington for interment.

abstract: The New-Orleans Delta, of May 29, says: "The United States steamer Brooklyn, Capt. POORE, having notified the authorities at the Balize that a strict blockade of the mouth of the river had been ordered, and that he was on hand to render the blockade effective, was boarded yesterday, under a flag of truce, by the Captains of several British and French vessels now on the bar, and Capt. POORE was asked if he intended to prevent the departure of the vessels then on the bar belonging to English and French owners, and loaded with freights to foreign ports. POORE declared that he should certainly prevent their departure, or seize them if they attempted to run the blockaded. As their ships are all heavily loaded with valuable cargoes, including two thousand hogsheads of tobacco shipped by the French Consul on account of the French Government, and several hundred on account of Rothschilds and other foreign houses, such a decision naturally produced considerable excitement in this City. The British and French Consuls took the matter in hand, and by telegraph caused Capt. POORE to understand that they would not permit such nonsense and that the British and French squadrons would be here in a few days to protect the interests of their Governments. The last news from the Balize was that POORE had backed down, and the ships are all going out. The British and French merchants in this city, who are largely engaged in our trade, will demand the protection of their Governments, and it is hoped by both them and our own citizens, as all the trade we have or intend to have is with their ports, that their fleets will speedily appear in the Gulf.

abstract: Among the brilliant new reputations of our times is that acquired by Dr. LIGHTHILL, who has added to the distinction our City has enjoyed in other departments of medical practice, an unrivaled reputation of the treatment of disorders and affections of the eye and ear. abstract: A Zouave, according to WORCESTER, is a creature who wears an Arab dress, and, like an English play, is taken from the French; according to a more recent authority, he is a "red devil". Neither of these definitions convey a correct idea of Col. HAWKINS men.
lead_paragraph: A Zouave, according to WORCESTER, is a creature who wears an Arab dress, and, like an English play, is taken from the French; according to a more recent authority, he is a "red devil". Neither of these definitions convey a correct idea of Col. HAWKINS men. They are not clad in light and airy costume, like the children of the desert, although they can "fold their tents" and "as silently pass away;" nor are they red. They stand in a firm texture of Northern manufacture, and are blue to the sight of man. Hence, it may be expected that after a while we shall hear the querulous voice of the Southern Press objecting that we have now given them the blue devils -- as well as the red. A man is awful according to his might in mind or muscle. Judged by this standard, the Hawkins' Zouaves will speedily become a terror to evil-doers. A body more imposing in all the great requisites of warfare has seldom been seen in this City. The men are of the requisite size to combine strength with activity, and the already so far proficient in their drill as to command the attention of military men. Their progress down Broadway, yesterday, must have been as pleasing to themselves as to the public. It was a sight which, whilst it gladdened the eyes of the Colonel, gave confidence to the best hopes of the populace.

abstract: At noon to-day the Pawnee and Thomas Freeborn stood in towards the steamboat landing at Aquia Creek. When about two miles off, a battery opened upon the Pawnee with two rifled caution and a heavy gun, suppose to be a 68 pounder. The twosteamers stood as near as the sheal water would permit and opened upon the battery. The Pawnee with her Dahlgren guns, and the Freeborn with two heavy 32 pounders.
lead_paragraph: UNITED STATES STEAMER PAWNEE, Saturday, June 1, 1861.

abstract: The war into which we are now entering makes general notions on military matters a want which our people of citizen-soldiers cannot fail to appreciate.
lead_paragraph: The war into which we are now entering makes general notions on military matters a want which our people of citizen-soldiers cannot fail to appreciate. The readiness with which they have adapted themselves to the present emergency, the intelligence they have displayed in the husbanding of our hitherto unknown military resources, the order they have preserved in the confusion of the hour, the ardor and enthusiasm manifested in every quarter, are significant symptoms of our qualities as a military people. All that remains for us to do is to add to our native genius that which knowledge alone can give. The art of war, which ancient and modern military nations always strove to make popular among the masses, in interesting the country in the operations of the army, and in availing themselves of the general informations resulting from such a system has, in the present circumstances, become as necessary to us as it was to them. Not that we deem necessary for our people to possess the science of a FREDERICK or a of NAPOLEON, but because had not this science been popular among the Prussians and the French at that time, neither FREDERICK nor NAPOLEON would have appeared. It is the military spirit of the people which makes great generals, and not great generals who make military nations. To create such spirit must then be the duty of those into whose hands the direction of public opinion has been intrusted. Enough has been done of late to show that a nation truly great cannot rest on justice, unless justice, like its Roman emblem, rests on a sword. Let us, then, arm public opinion with the offensive and defensive weapons with which the art of war has supplied us; that is to say, let us have summary and popular review of the manner in which armies are formed, organized and set in motion. In that way, everybody will be able to acquire some slight notions on military topics, and our taste gradually increasing with our knowledge, we will finally be as great in the art of war as we are in the art of peace.

abstract: The war must end in an accommodation of some sort, however severe the struggle, however decisive the issue. The South may be thoroughly defeated, but cannot be destroyed. Surviving the conflict, she will be in a position to negotiate with her victors. The more she is humiliated, the mere she will be embittered. On the other side there will be exhaustion, or at least weariness. The conquerors will be divided, and the vanquished will find advocates for clemency among the claimants to the spoil. Either secession must be permitted, or terms of reconciliation adjusted. Even the victorious Republican North -- the Free-Soilers and Abolitionists -- may be glad at such a stage to accept the mediation we now urge them to invite. They can have no nearer kinsmen, no truer friends than the Liberals of the mother country. In the name of those men -- in the name, at any rate, of Liberal principles, and of the Liberal cause throughout the world -- we beseech the New-England communities, so nobly forward in the strife, to pause ere they irrevocably commit themselves to the chances of battle; and to trust the interests of liberty rather to the arbitration of its friends in Europe than of the blind and senseless sword.

abstract: Experience has shown that Enfiled rifles and long range cannon do not prevent the shock of contending armies in close conflict. Even siege operations, on a large scale and of prolonged duration, are varied by sorties in force from the garrison, precipitatin regular engagements where hand-to-hand fighting is the order of the day.
lead_paragraph: Experience has shown that Enfiled rifles and long range cannon do not prevent the shock of contending armies in close conflict. Even siege operations, on a large scale and of prolonged duration, are varied by sorties in force from the garrison, precipitatin regular engagements where hand-to-hand fighting is the order of the day. Incidents of the Crimean War are striking illustrations of the fact. The investment of that remarkable fortress was constantly varied by important skirmishes, in which, thousands of men on either side crossed bayonets; and there were two really great battles -- those of Inkermann and Balaklava -- fought, some time after the beleaguered Russians were supposed to be shut safely up behind their earthworks.

abstract: The Governments of France and Great Britain are scarcely likely to differ on the policy to be adopted in the present crisis, and it is not improbable that this question has already been discussed by the two Cabinets. The Emperor NAPOLEON resided for some time in the United States, and is fully competent to judge of the relative strength of the relative strength of the rival sections; and when M. Thouvenet declared that the maintenance of the Union is necessary for the interest of France he doubtless spoke the sentiments of his master. The Emperor NAPOLEON is opposed to a disruption of the Union, and it is rumored that he has even gone so far as to offer aid to President LINCOLN against the seceders. We have no means of ascertaining what are the intentions of our own Government or the individual opinious of any statesman in the Cabinet; but we do not believe it will conduce to the welfare of Great Britain for the two Powers to be at issue on this American question.

abstract: We believe that Canada, equally with England, will stand neutral in the quarrel, and that the provinces of British America will be enabled to maintain their own without fear of aggression on the part of any assailant. But to be forearmed is true and sound policy.
lead_paragraph: We believe that Canada, equally with England, will stand neutral in the quarrel, and that the provinces of British America will be enabled to maintain their own without fear of aggression on the part of any assailant. But to be forearmed is true and sound policy. The battle field may extend from Washington to the south and west; but though Canada, from the loyalty of its people and its geographical position, may be exempted from all part in the contest, the policy which dictates military preparation, can neither be gainsaid nor controverted. We believe that, as a consequence of the Merrill Tariff, the stream of commerce and of emigration will be diverted from the United States to Canada. We have no apprehension that war's alarms will resound in the provinces. We find that whilst separation is an accomplished fact in the United States, British North America is clamorous for Federal Union. When we remember that Canada, Nova Scotia, and New-Brunswick possess a population equal to that of the thirteen colonies which eighty years ago revolted from this country, we cannot believe that they have no weight and authority in the future destinies of the American continent. Owing to the folly, the turbulence, and the violence of the South, the balance of power has been virtually transferred from republican America to monarchical Canada. At the request of Sir FENWICK WILLIAMS, the regular troops in the province are about to be augmented; but the true solution of the question of self-defence depends upon the volunteers, whom the home Government, with a view to the inquiries of the Military Colonial Expenditure Committee, now sitting, wish to patronize and extend. It is fortunate that the founder of the movement is Sir ALAN M'NAB, a gallant and honest soldier, who has equally, proved his loyalty to his mother country and his devotion to the best interests of North America. But it is the duty of Canada, on public and commercial grounds, to be prepared. It is stated that thousands of British subjects are flocking, with their goods and money, into Canada, being desirous of escaping from the horrors and calamities of civil war. The course of trace will be diverted from the belligerent Powers to the only State which by its in and waters can communicate directly with the North and the West. If the balance of power should fall to the lot of British North America, Canada, by her energy, activity and preparedness, is wiSely showing her appreciation both of her duties and rights at a great and important crisis, which a year ago no man living could have foreseen.

abstract: Slowly, yet with energy, the Government is winding its tolls around the traitors of treason ridden Virginia.
lead_paragraph: Slowly, yet with energy, the Government is winding its tolls around the traitors of treason ridden Virginia. Every day sees the army, with its face set Southward, growing stronger, pushing forward here or there -- from Grafton and the Ohio River in the Northwest, from Fortress Monroe and the Chesapeake in the Southeast, and from Alexandria and other strategic points on the Potomac -- uniting always in its advance both caution and courage, and proclaiming as it goes friendship, freedom and the perpetual unity of the Republic. Eastern Virginia is, in a military point of view, already almost entirely surrounded by the Federal forces; and as JOHNSTON must soon evacuate Harper's Ferry, if he has not by this time been driven away, and Manassas Junction be speedily taken possession of by our troops, the revolting section will be practically cut off from the West, and hemmed in between river, mountain and sea; while it may be assaulted simultaneously and with overwhelming force by columns advancing from three of the cardinal points of the compass. The Eastern coast-line of the State, its boys and its rivers, are commanded by Federal man-of-war and their aids; Union troops hover along the whole Southern line of the Potomac, from the Shenandoah to Hampton Roads, daily moving their pickets southward; Richmond, which is both the military and political centre of Eastern Virginia, is immediately menaced; Gen. MCCLELLAN marches swiftly from the West, scattering the traitors as he goes, and will doubtless soon effect a junction with PATTERSON and the Pennsylvania troops -- if, indeed, that is the programme, -- while the forces at Alexandria, at Monroe, at and near Washington, and the immense reserves at Columbus, Chambersburgh, New-York, and at other points in the East and West, (an army greater than the whole white population of Eastern Virginia and all the Southern mercenaries now on her soil,) but await the signal from the great commander to precipitate themselves with resistless fury upon whatever opposes their southward march. Whatever may be Gen. SCOTT's plan of the Virginia campaign, the country is assured that, with the resources at his command, there will be no backward step from its soil until the local and Confederate usurpers are driven beyond its borders.

abstract: In this Court, yesterday, on motion of the District Attorney, all the indictments at present untried, (except that of Hackley, the disposition of which pends the decision of the Court of Appeals,) were removed to the General Sessions, where they will be tried. There will, therefore, be no more trials in the present term of the Oyer and Terminer, which has not, however, finally adjourned, but will sit at intervals, until the decision of the Hackley case.

abstract: We do net think Mr. CASSIUS M. CLAY has made a happy presentation of himself to the British public. He failed entirely to appreciate the traits of the people he assumed to address and instruct.
lead_paragraph: We do net think Mr. CASSIUS M. CLAY has made a happy presentation of himself to the British public. He failed entirely to appreciate the traits of the people he assumed to address and instruct. His letter in the London Times is of a piece with those characteristics for which Mr. Bull feels unmitigated disgust. If he hates anything it is an enthusiastic admirer of institutions not his own, especially when the contrast is unfavorable to his national vanity. Mr. CLAY expatiates prodigally upon those of the United States. He eagerly rushed into the venerable presence, and, with palpitating heart and flushed cheek, delivered, in no very mincing manner, a piece of his mind. He argued pretty strongly and conclusively, and entreated England to extend her sympathy to those who, on this side of the water, are seeking to save from overthrow whatever is best in her institutions and ideas. All this, under other circumstances, might have been very well, but in London it was very ill. It proves that Mr. CLAY has seen very little of the world. John Bull does not want a lecture from Brother Jonathan. Nothing could be more badly timed, and nothing so well fitted to provoke hostility where the object was to secure friendly cooperation. John Bull has a very weak side, but Mr. CLAY failed entirely to hit it. He vaunted the very institutions for which the former feels a thorough disgust. Mr. CLAY glorified America. Mr. Bull tells us that everything is going wrong in America. What we feel most proud of is to him an offence. He knows we shall never get on till we mend our ways and copy after him. Mr. CLAY is like most Americans who, on their first visit to London, expect to find eager listeners to their glowing accounts of our own vast country, its resources, our progress in subduing and peopling it, and the excellence of institutions that can produce such results. Their hearts are running over with the subject, but their ardor is soon chilled when it comes in contact with English indifference and conceit. The last quality is the great foible of that nation. What to others would be a deformity, is to an Englishman an ornament. It is so English, is something to be proud of. Nothing that other people have done is worth study or thought.

abstract: One hundred and eighty of the men constituting a portion of Lieut. BARTLETT's Brigade, returned from Fortress Monroe yesterday by the steamer, Coutza coalcos. lead_paragraph: One hundred and eighty of the men constituting a portion of Lieut. BARTLETT's Brigade, returned from Fortress Monroe yesterday by the steamer, Coutza coalcos. On which they embarked from States Island about ten days ago. After landing, the men formed and visited several of the newspaper establishments to announce their arrival. Their appearance was calculated to excite commiseration. Misunderstanding, mismanagement and misfortune seem to have marked the brief career of this regiment. The failure of Lieut. BARTLETT to make good his promises of arms, uniforms pay, &c., caused disaffection among officers and men. The contractors who furnished the Sharp's rifles and uniforms, went to Portress Monroe with their goods, but very properly refused to deliver them without a legal requisition from the proper authority, on which they could draw their pay. Upon their arrival, Gen. BUTLER, out of a kind regard for the health and comfort of the men, ordered them landed, and temporary provision was made for them until he could hear from Washington, and a messenger was dispatched for the purpose, Mr. [???] ordered the whole force back to New-York. On promulgating the order, Gen. BUTLER kindly provided each man who chose to go back with the means of returning, and offered those who preferred to remain pay and rations to work upon the intrenchments. Those who returned were very destitute, and complain loudly of having been deceived. Some of them also roll of hard times which they endured while at the fort, on account of short allowance, and being exposed to the enemy without arms or shelter. There is, however, evident exaggeration in some of these statements. They presented the following statement of their grievances to the Union Defence Committee: To the Union Defence Committee:

abstract: EVERY MOTHER should be prepared to act in the capacity of both nurse and physician to her children; she can, if she will, discharge these duties much better than any one she can employ. abstract: The Ladies' Patriotic Association of Trinity Parish, in this City, makes the following report of the result of its labors in behalf of our volunteers. The Secretary, Mrs. A.T. CLAYTON, states that since the organization of the Association, on the 26th of April last, $1,779 have been received from subscriptions, and from Trinity Church, $1,000. The Association has expended in the purchase of articles and materials and in payment for work done by the needy, $1,471.50. These have been made or purchased 5,299 garments, of which 1,906 have been distributed through the Medical Association Depot at [???] Institute, the remainder in contributions to the Seventy-first Regiment N.Y.S.M., to Miss DIX for hospital use, to Col. LANSING's Westchester Chasseurs, to the Garibaldi of Guard and to volunteers in the New-York Hospital, with 943 havelock caps to N.Y.S.M. Regiments.
lead_paragraph: The Ladies' Patriotic Association of Trinity Parish, in this City, makes the following report of the result of its labors in behalf of our volunteers. The Secretary, Mrs. A.T. abstract: A HEARTLESS PERFORMANCE. -- Quite an excitement was caused in Chicago, on Friday evening, by the fact becoming known that a tailor, named EDWARD ELY, had unbecomingly invaded the chamber where Senator DOUGLAS lay dying, and presented and pressed the payment of a bill of $9 50. J.S. NEW-HOUSE, Esq, paid the bill, but a mob collected and threatened to break into Mr. ELY's store and take him out by violence. The Police had to interfere before the matter was quieted.
lead_paragraph: A HEARTLESS PERFORMANCE. -- Quite an excitement was caused in Chicago, on Friday evening, by the fact becoming known that a tailor, named EDWARD ELY, had unbecomingly invaded the chamber where Senator DOUGLAS lay dying, and presented and pressed the payment of a bill of $9 50. abstract: The engagement at Philippi took place at 5 o'clock on Monday morning. The plan was well laid for the surprise, but the impetuosity of a few troops gave the rebels evening. They fled in haste, leaving their baggage, forty horses, four wagons loaded with provisions, and five hundred maskets.
lead_paragraph: CINCINNATI, Wednesday, June 5.

abstract: The meat markets have all been fully supplied with live animals during the past week. abstract: Mrs. WINSLOW, an old and experienced nurse, has devoted herself for more than thirty years exclusively to the care of children. She has a SOOTHING SYRUP for children teething, which we believe a most invaluable preparation, not only for children teething, but in all cases of Dysentery or Diarrhoea. We speak of what we know, when we say this SOOTHING SYRUP acts like a perfect charm in the above cases. We have witnessed the most satisfactory and pleasing results from the use of it, upon suffering infants and children, in a great variety of cases. It gives universal satisfaction, is perfectly safe for the feeblest infant, and pleasant to the taste. We sincerely believe the mother who has a child suffering from any of the above complaints, and neglects to provide this medicine for its relief and care, is depriving the little sufferer of the remedy of all the world best calculated to give it rest, and restore it to health.

abstract: Cotton has cursed the civilized world with the two really meanest, but apparenly most terrible, incubi that ever crushed sense and feeling out of the human mind.
lead_paragraph: Cotton has cursed the civilized world with the two really meanest, but apparenly most terrible, incubi that ever crushed sense and feeling out of the human mind. To its development of the slave-owning and spinning-jenny despotisms of the United States and England to the prodigious point of power they have within the last few years asserted over the destinies of both countries, Cotton has achieved the most infernal grandeur of imperious sway that ever held the race in fear and vassalage. Until its bloated influence collapses, we must not be surprised at any course of conduct it may force its seris to follow. The first gun from Sumter woke us from the horrid dream in which it had been strangling out our life; but it still site grinning on the big, broad chest of Mr. Bull, and holds him nerveless in its clutch. We must appreciate this fact, to comprehend the tone of leading British newspapers, and the position held by leading British statesmen on the great American question of the day.
headline: {'main': 'England and the Cotton Despotism.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'England and the Cotton Despotism.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Dr. WM. J. WALKER, of Boston, who is one of the most opulent surgeons in the country, has given property estimated to be worth $90,000, to establish Professorships of Mathematics in three of the colleges of Massachusetts. These institutions are Williams, Amherst and Tuffs Colleges, each of which will receive $30,000 for the purpose above named. Dr. WALKER is a graduate of Harvard College, and a Unitarian.

abstract: It will be seen from our dispatches that a movement of the Federal troops was made yesterday in the direction of Manassas Gap. The exact nature of this movemnet, however, does not appear, though there is no doubt, now that the Government has concluded to strikes a blow, that it will be an irresistible one.
lead_paragraph: It will be seen from our dispatches that a movement of the Federal troops was made yesterday in the direction of Manassas Gap. The exact nature of this movemnet, however, does not appear, though there is no doubt, now that the Government has concluded to strikes a blow, that it will be an irresistible one. The intrenchments thrown up by our troops are now nearly perfected, and make the safety of the Capital sure beyond question. Reports relative to the movements of the rebel forces are somewhat conflicting. Yesterday, it was understood that, in the vicinity of Manassas Gap, they numbered not above 5,000, and now we have a report that there is an aggregate of 20,000 at Manassas Junction, Centreville. Fairfax Station and Fairfax Court-house. It is stated, also, on good show of authority, that the ubiquitous BEAUREGARD is positively at Manassas Gap Junction, having arrived there on Monday last. This, in the face of the equally positive statement that he, last week, arrived at Memphis to take command of the rebel forces on the Mississippi.

abstract: A HEARTLESS PERFORMANCE. -- Quite an excitement was caused in Chicago, on Friday evening, by the fact becoming known that a tailor, named EDWARD ELY, had unbecomingly invaded the chamber, where Senator DOUGLAS lay dying, and presented and pressed the payment of a bill of $9 50. J.S. NEW-HOUSE, Esq., paid the bill, but a mob collected and threatened to break into Mr. ELY's store and take him out by violence. The Police had to interfere before the matter was quieted.

abstract: "President" DAVIS' first levee at Richmond was given on Thursday. The Examiner says: "The citizens of Richmond, of all classes, congregated to the number of several thousands, to pay their respects to the President, and to have the pleasure of shaking hands with him. There was no formal introduction or courtly display.
lead_paragraph: "President" DAVIS' first levee at Richmond was given on Thursday. The Examiner says: "The citizens of Richmond, of all classes, congregated to the number of several thousands, to pay their respects to the President, and to have the pleasure of shaking hands with him. There was no formal introduction or courtly display. Many of the citizens were acquainted with the distinguished man at the head of the Government and they introduced those who were not acquainted with him. The bearing of the President, and manner of reception, were dignified and simple, so that the humblest, as well as the highest, felt at ease. There was, evidently, a heartfelt respect for President DAVIS, and a sense of gratification on witnessing this, the first public ceremony indicating Richmond as the seat of Government. It was interesting to see such a large assemblage of all classes, the rich, beautiful, and fashionable mingling with those in the humblest walks of life, and was illustrative of our institutions. Mrs. GEORGE WYTHE MUNFORD, in the absence of Mrs. LETCHER, stood by the side of the President, to introduce ladies."

abstract: This Regiment, composed of the stalwart sons of Maine, and commanded by Col. O.O. HOWARD, reached this City, yesterday, via Fall River, en route for Washington, whither they have been ordered by the War Department.
lead_paragraph: This Regiment, composed of the stalwart sons of Maine, and commanded by Col. O.O. HOWARD, reached this City, yesterday, via Fall River, en route for Washington, whither they have been ordered by the War Department. The rain came down in torrents at the time of their landing, and continued throughout the march up Broadway. They marched to the old Arsenal, on the corner of White and Elm streets, which had been tendered by Gen. ARTHUR for their accommodation. A bountiful dinner was provided for the men at the Park barracks, while the officers enjoyed the hospitality of the Astor-house. The Regiment is officered as follows:

abstract: GENTLEMANLY BURGLARS IN MISFORTUNE PROMPT ARRESTS. Yesterday morning Mr. B.F. HARDY, dry goods dealer, at No. 332 Bowery, discovered that his store had been broken into on Wednesday night and robbed of $2,000 worth of silks and laces.
lead_paragraph: GENTLEMANLY BURGLARS IN MISFORTUNE -- PROMPT ARRESTS. -- Yesterday morning Mr. B.F. HARDY, dry goods dealer, at No. 332 Bowery, discovered that his store had been broken into on Wednesday night and robbed of $2,000 worth of silks and laces. The Detective Police were notified, and officers FARLEY and EUSTACE examined the premises, finding that the side window and front door had been forced. From the manner in which the burglary had been effected, the Detectives felt confident that the delinquents were DAVID BARTLETT and JOHN WATSON, both noted rogues, and having visited the boarding house, No. 222 Thompson-street, where the burglars had been living since last December, the officers were fortunate enough to find them. At the time the Detectives entered the room, BARTLETT, WATSON, and a man named JOHN WILLIAMS, were engaged in overhauling, assorting and preparing for sale to a receiver of stolen goods the entire proceeds of the burglary, and the two were taken into custody, after a futile attempt on their part to escope by leaping from the window. The officers also found in the apartment a number of skeleton keys and other implements of rogue-craft, which doubtless had been used in the burglary. The prisoners were taken before Justice CONNOLLY, who committed them for examination. Their arrest was a source of intense surprise to the lady with whom they had been boarding, as their appearance and behavior during the few months they had lived with her was very gentlemanly. The officers deserve much commendation for the arrest of these rogues and the recovery of the property, all of which was effected within a few hours after they had been advised of the matter.

abstract: This Regiment, composed of the stalwart sons of Maine, and commanded by Col. O.O. HOWARD, reached this City, yesterday, via Fall River, en route for Washington, whither they have been ordered by the War Department.
lead_paragraph: This Regiment, composed of the stalwart sons of Maine, and commanded by Col. O.O. HOWARD, reached this City, yesterday, via Fall River, en route for Washington, whither they have been ordered by the War Department. The rain came down in torrents at the time of their landing, and continued throughout the march up Broadway. They marched to the old Arsenal, on the corner of White and Elm streets, which had been tendered by Gen. ARTHUR for their accommodation. A bountiful dinner was provided for the men at the Park barracks, while the officers enjoyed the hospitality of the Astor-house. The Regiment is officered as follows:

abstract: In consequence of the heavy Northeast storm which prevailed yesterday, no further demonstrations in the direction of the Manasses Gap Junction were made by the Federal troops. They were held in readiness, however, to move at a moment's warning, or to repel an attack had one been attempted. The rebels still threaten to move on Alexandria, but they probably have as much as they can attend to in other directions.

abstract: The ladies at White Plains, Westchester County, have formed a Society for the purpose of manufacturing clothing for our soldiers. At a meeting on Monday last, pursuant to a notice given at the churches in the village, a large number of ladies were present full of enthusiasm and determination to do all they can to help our soldiers and contribute to their comfort. At this meeting, large contributions were received from different parties, of material to be manufactured into clothing and Havelocks, all of which was distributed among the members at once. This organization is only one of many that are now in full operation in the county, where the ladies are not to be excelled in patriotism or liberality.

abstract: The regular semi-monthly meeting of the Board of Charities and Correction was held yesterday afternoon. The report of the Committee of the Whole states that the number of persons transferred from the City Prison to the Workhouse as vagrants, was 510; of whom 320 were females. The resignations of A. RIVESH as House Surgeon, First Medical Division Bellevou Hospital, and J.H. BAXTER, House Physician, Island Hospital, were accepted. The resignation of THOMAS J. GUFFEN. Engineer at Island Hospital, was also accepted, he having received an appointment as Assistant Engineer in the United States Navy. Dr. BAXTER has been appointed Assistant-Surgeon the Twelfth Regiment of Massachusetts, Col. FLETCHER WEBSTER. At the various institutions the surplus labor continues to be employed in making clothing for volunteers to the United State Army.

abstract: Individual business capacity, energy and enterprise are as much a source of National wealth, as are rich agricultural districts, vast cotton fields, mines of the grosser metals, mountains of coal, gold placers or waterfalls, those natural motors for propelling machinery.
lead_paragraph: Individual business capacity, energy and enterprise are as much a source of National wealth, as are rich agricultural districts, vast cotton fields, mines of the grosser metals, mountains of coal, gold placers or waterfalls, those natural motors for propelling machinery. The nation that is possessed of these, will flourish, while the people who lack them will run to decay, whatever the natural resources of their country may be. But business capacity, individual energy and enterprise may be overborne by those sudden changes and mutations to which the commercial world has always been more or less subject. These mutations are often such as no forecast can anticipate, and against, which human prudence cannot guard. They make their advent without one note of warning, scattering the wisest calculations of business men, like a whirlwind. Fortunes, apparently the most stable, are hurled down, and plans that promise the most certain success, turn out to be the instrumentalities of ruin the most hopeless. We need not go beyond the history of the last five years, to illustrate our position. In 1857, at a time of the greatest apparent prosperity, when our storehouses were full, when there was abundant demand for our staples all over the world, when our factories and forges were in full career, and all the branches of industry flourished, a sudden storm arose -- a commercial and financial tempest swept in mad fury from the Atlantic to the Pacific, bearing down everything that was not founded on granite and iron-bound, in the resistless rush. Banks suspended; thousands of houses of established credit and reputed wealth were swept away, and bankruptcy overwhelmed hundreds of thousands who had entered upon a career that held out promise of success. City and country suffered alike. Inland trade; and ocean commerce, the manufacturing the mining, the mechanical and agricultural interests, were all involved in the common calamity. That storm passed away; but the ruin it had wrought was seen and felt all over the Republic. Men of the highest business qualifications, by tens of thousands, were overwhelmed in hopeless bankruptcy, crushed beneath mountains of debt that [???] all their energies and [???] them out from every field of enterprise. We do not speak now of mere adventurers, speculators in fortune, who stake everything upon a single cast, but of men earnestly engaged in legitimate pursuits, whose capital was invested in the practical business of the country, and whose labors aided in the forward movement of the world. Capitalists whose fortunes were invested in solid securities, who hazarded nothing in the ventures of commerce or upon the exigencies of trade, and who were disconnected with the productive interests of the country, weathered the storm. It was the active, energetic, practical business men of the country was were shipwrecked and who are still drifting among the breakers, or fast on the shoals of bankruptcy.

abstract: GENTLEMANLY BURGLARS IN MISFORTUNE? PROMPT ARRESTS.?Yesterday morning Mr. B.F. HARDY, dry goods dealer, at No. 332 Bowery, discovered that his store had been broken into on Wednesday night and robbed of $2,000 worth of silks and laces.
lead_paragraph: GENTLEMANLY BURGLARS IN MISFORTUNE -- PROMPT ARRESTS. -- Yesterday morning Mr. B.F. HARDY, dry goods dealer, at No. 332 Bowery, discovered that his store had been broken into on Wednesday night and robbed of $2,000 worth of silks and laces. The Detective Police were notified, and officers FARLEY and EUSTACE examined the premises, finding that the side window and front door had been forced. From the manner in which the burglary had been effected, the Detectives felt confident that the delinquents were DAVID BARTLETT and JOHN WATSON, both noted rogues, and having visited the boarding house, No. 222 Thompson-street, where the burglars had been living since last December, the officers were fortunate enough to find them. At the time the Detectives entered the room, BARTLETT, WATSON, and a man named JOHN WILLIAMS, were engaged in overhauling, assorting and preparing for sale to a receiver of stolen goods the entire proceeds of the burglary, and the two were taken in to custody, after a futile attempt on their part to escape by leaping from the window. The officers also found in the apartment a number of skeleton keys and other implements of rogue-craft, which doubtless had been used in the burglary. The prisoners were taken before Justice CONNOLLY, who committed them for examination. Their arrest was a source of intense surprise to the lady with whom they had been boarding, as their appearance and behavior during the few months they had lived with her was very gentlemanly. The officers deserve much commendation for the arrest of these rogues and the recovery of the property, all of which was effected within a few hours after they had been advised of the matter.

abstract: The Sickles Brigade encampment is located at Staten Island, about 15 minutes' ride from the lower or Vanderbilt's landing. It may be reached by the Staten Island boats is the landing, and thence by stage or railroad or private conveyance in either case a delightful ride.
lead_paragraph: The Sickles Brigade encampment is located at Staten Island, about 15 minutes' ride from the lower or Vanderbilt's landing. It may be reached by the Staten Island boats is the landing, and thence by stage or railroad or private conveyance -- in either case a delightful ride. "Camp Scott," as the encampment is named, is situated on a nearly level plateau in full view of the ocean, from which a delicious and bracing breeze constantly furnishes food for healthy lungs. The grounds occupy a space of 850 acres, calculated to accommodate the Brigade of 5,000 men when the men are forthcoming. Already there are nearly 300 tents erected, and a further supply was received yesterday. There will be in all 800 tents, arranged in five regimental groups. The Headquarters and Hospital are at present located in a convenient farm-house adjacent, to which wooden temporary buildings are erected for the Quartermaster's and Commissary's departments, cooking, &c. A huge cooking-range, said to be capacious enough for cooking for 4,000 men, will, it is said, soon be erected. There are also erected a number of wooden shanties for various purposes, beside a huge tent, which at present serves to shelter several hundred of the troops. The following are the

abstract: -If any proof were needed of the heavy discount in "Southern patriotism and valor," it is afforded in the significant fact that the Confederate Government is offering for each recruit a premium of two dollars. The most favorable estimate which the rebels can present of their enrolled forces will not make their number over 100,000 men, and of these not more than 50,000 are now in the State of Virginia. Of this number 15,000 are necessarily separated from the main bodies of the forces, and of the 35,000 remaining at the important positions now held by the rebels, it may be safely estimated that at least 10,000 are poorly armed and equipped, or would gladly embrace the opportunity to desert or be taken prisoner either from a dislike of the service, or a feeling of loyalty to our Government.

abstract: In this Court yesterday, before Recorder HOFFMAN, Joseph Gleason, a boy seventeen years of age, was tried for robbery of a German by the name of Buck, who was sure that somebody knocked him down and took his money; but he was not so clear as to the identification of the prisoner. For the defence, an alibi was attempted to be proved. The jury took the case, and rendered as verdict of assault and battery, recommending the prisoner to mercy. The prisoner was reminded for sentence.

abstract: The loyalty of Western Virginia, properly seconded by the Administration at Washington, affords the surest means of rescuing that ancient and respected State from the ruthless hands of the conspirators who have obtained a temporary control, and from the despotism which they have inaugurated there.
lead_paragraph: The loyalty of Western Virginia, properly seconded by the Administration at Washington, affords the surest means of rescuing that ancient and respected State from the ruthless hands of the conspirators who have obtained a temporary control, and from the despotism which they have inaugurated there. To this end a Convention has been called, to assemble at Wheeling early in the approaching week; and it is in the wish to further a prompt and energetic cooperation with that Convention by the Government and the Federal troops now in Virginia, upon a well-matured and consistent plan, that we venture to discuss that subject.
