abstract: A forward movement towards Harper's Ferry by the Pennsylvania troops was made from Chambersburgh yesterday, a strong ad vance having probably reached Hagerstown, six miles beyond the Maryland line, last night. lead_paragraph: -- The secession leaders have discovered another mine from which to replenish their Treasury with the necessary millions, and enable them to snap their fingers at the "Northern hordes." "One hundred thousand people," say they, "go North every Summer a pleasuring, who spend $500 each on an average. This will amount to $50,000,000, which, as own pleasure-seekers will remain at home, will be saved and made available for the public defence."

abstract: About 6 1/2 o'clock Wednesday afternoon, a collision occurred between a gravel train finishing up the read, and an extra freight train, some three miles from Hunter's Point. The gravel train had been waiting on a siding, the freight train being delayed; the gravel train went out on the track, pushing the cars ahead loaded with gravel, when the freight train was seen approaching. Before the trains could be entirely stopped, a collision occurred, three of the gravel cars being thrown from the track and considerably broken, by coming in contact with the engine of the freight train. There were about fifty men upon the gravel train, all of whom jumped from the train just before the collision. Nine or ten of them were more or less bruised, but no lives were lost or limbs broken.
lead_paragraph: About 6 1/2 o'clock Wednesday afternoon, a collision occurred between a gravel train finishing up the read, and an extra freight train, some three miles from Hunter's Point. abstract: The regular monthly meeting of the New-York Sanitary Association was held last evening at the Cooper Institute.
lead_paragraph: The regular monthly meeting of the New-York Sanitary Association was held last evening at the Cooper Institute. The ordinary business having been transacted, Dr. ELSIHA HARRIS, Chairman of the Committee which had visited the President of the United States and the Heads of Departments, on the subject military hygiene, made a verbal report as to what had been accomplished. He stated that himself and co-adjutors had been kindly received by the President and members of the Cabinet, as well as by Gen. SCOTT. Every facility was afforded the Committee for prosecuting inquiries, and they were assured that every practicable suggestion which they offered would be considered by the proper authorities. Their recommendations, especially with regard to the regimental cuisine, received particular attention, and impressed Gen. SCOTT and Brigadler-Gen. MANSFIELD so deeply, that the committee were informed that immediate steps should be taken with a view of attaching a competent professional cook to each company, who should be placed on the footing of a non-combattant.

abstract: The policy of the Confederate Government, as announced by Mr. COBB in his recent speech, is unique, if regarded in a purely commercial and financial point of view; but it would seem, after all, to be in accordance with the eternal fitness of things for a Government which has been founded with reference to a particular class interest, to look to that interest for the means of subsistence. The rebellion has been gotten up by cotton planters, and it is but proper that cotton should pay the cost of the war which has resulted from it.

abstract: The requisition for 18,000 men for the Navy is being promptly met, the facilities for obtaining men being much greater now than heretofore, on account of the suspension of Southern trade, which has employed, on an average, from seven to eight thousand seamen. On account of the large numbers offering, the Government will be able to select a superior class, which will give great efficiency to our future Navy.

abstract: Each arrival from Europe indicates more unmistakably the indifference with which England views the more aspects of the American struggle; and its imperfect appreciation of the material considerations which should attach it to one party, in preference to another.
lead_paragraph: Each arrival from Europe indicates more unmistakably the indifference with which England views the more aspects of the American struggle; and its imperfect appreciation of the material considerations which should attach it to one party, in preference to another. In addressing ourselves to foreign Governments, we have ceased to found our appeals upon anything higher than self-interest. We only desire a just measurement of the advantage to be secured in conciliating the American people by abstinence from openly avowed partiality for the South; and this secured, we care not how perfect may be the actuality of the friendly Powers. But we must insist on this self-interest being enlightened. We have a right to demand an acknowledgment that justice and expediency both sustain this Government in its defensive efforts; and it must always be impossible to restore amicable feelings towards any European Power, which persistently disputes the righteousness and wisdom of our cause.

abstract: Wednesday, under the auspices of the Fashion Course Pleasure Ground Association, there was a trotting match between three year olds for a purse and stake of $700, mile heats, best three in five, in harness. H. WOODRUFF named a, S. Shepard Nap. S. MeLOUGHLIN named s, in Jessie.
lead_paragraph: Wednesday, under the auspices of the Fashion Course Pleasure Ground Association, there was a trotting match between three year olds for a purse and stake of $700, mile heats, best three in five, in harness. H. WOODRUFF named a, S. Shepard Nap. S. MeLOUGHLIN named s, in Jessie. The grey gelding by owner, b.r.b. Kibby by H. JONES, and b. Kibby by H. WOLLEY, Jessie won the first race, and Shepard Nag the last three; the others paid forfeit. The time made was 2:46, 2:40, 2:41, 2:47 and 2:43 1/2. The race was the most exciting one of the season, and the betting was very heavy. The mare was the favorite; one hundred dollars to thirty previous to starting, and after having won the first two heats, she was the favorite at one hundred to ten. On the third heat the horses both got away well together, the mare leading, but the stallion passed her on the back stretch and kept the lead to the stand, winning the heat easily. The backers of the stallion now became wild with excitement, and one hundred to ten was freely offered on him without takers. The stallion, in the opinion of many old turf men, bids fair to rank among the best trotters in the country. On the same day there was a trot over the same course for a purse of $250 the horses to trot nearest to three minutes, mile heats, between v.r.g. Tycoon: b.g. Horace; b.g. Conway, and s.m. Lady Greeley, with the following result:

abstract: Thomas Brien vs. Denis Snow. -- This action was brought to recover for alleged slanderous words spoken by the defendant of the plaintiff. The plaintiff alleges that on the 25th of September, 1860, the defendant, in the presence of quite a number of other persons, called him a damned thief, and that he, the defendant, could prove it. The plaintiff claims to have been much injured in his character by reason of there slanderous words spoken, and claims damages to the extent of $1,000. The defendant alleges that at the time the words were spoken the plaintiff and defendant were partners in business in this City, and that the plaintiff, before these words were spoken, appropriated a large amount of the proceeds of the partnership property, which he refused to account for, and the defendant, therefore, becoming somewhat irritated, made use of the language of which plaintiff complains. Verdict for plaintiff for $75.
lead_paragraph: Thomas Brien vs. Denis Snow. -- This action was brought to recover for alleged slanderous words spoken by the defendant of the plaintiff. abstract: Died at the New-York Hotel, on Wednesday evening, the 6th inst., after a protracted illness, Brevet Brig.-Gen. JOHN GARLAND, in the 89th year of his age. Few officers of the United States Army have seen as much service as Gen. GARLAND. Entering the army from Virginia in the War of 1812, he served on the Indian frontier, afterwards in Florida, and led his command, the Fourth Infantry, in every battle fought in Mexico, save that of Buena Vista. With how much of judgment and bravery this long service has been discharged, the recorded history of those wars and his rapid promotion bear ample testimony.
lead_paragraph: Died at the New-York Hotel, on Wednesday evening, the 6th inst., after a protracted illness, Brevet Brig.-Gen. JOHN GARLAND, in the 89th year of his age. With how much of judgment and bravery this long service has been discharged, the recorded history of those wars and his rapid promotion bear ample testimony.

abstract: The regular monthly meeting of the New-York Sanitary Association was held last evening at the Cooper Institute. The ordinary business having been transacted, Dr. ELSIHA HARRIS, Chairman of the Committee which had visited the President of the United States and the Heads of Departments, on the subject
lead_paragraph: The regular monthly meeting of the New-York Sanitary Association was held last evening at the Cooper Institute. The ordinary business having been transacted, Dr. ELSIHA HARRIS, Chairman of the Committee which had visited the President of the United States and the Heads of Departments, on the subject military hygiene, made a verbal report as to what had been accomplished. He stated that himself and co-adjutors had been kindly received by the President and members of the Cabinet, as well as by Gen. SCOTT. Every facility was afforded the Committee for prosecuting inquiries, and they were assured that every practicable suggestion which they offered would be considered by the proper authorities. Their recommendations, especially with regard to the regimental cuisine, received particular attention, and impressed Gen. SCOTT and Brigadier-Gen. MANSFIELD so deeply, that the committee were informed that immediate steps should be taken with a view of attaching a competent professional cook to each company, who should be placed on the footing of a non-combattant.

abstract: The Adjutant-General of the United States Army has approved of a new stirrup, invented and patented in England, France and America, byt Capt. EAGLE, United States Army, now of the Hudson street rendezvous, in this City.
lead_paragraph: The Adjutant-General of the United States Army has approved of a new stirrup, invented and patented in England, France and America, byt Capt. EAGLE, United States Army, now of the Hudson street rendezvous, in this City. It is made of iron, covered with leather, weighs two pounds, eight ounces, and will probably supersede every stirrup now in use, both in the service and out of it. Among other peculiarities, it effectually prevents accidental spurring of the horse, by always keeping the feet parallel to the horses' sides, or rather, causing such constraint as to render this position more convenient to the rider than any other; in short, making the proper position of the foot the pleasantest. Volunteer Captains can probably learn more of it by seeing Capt. EAGLE.

abstract: Col. LANSING'S Regiment still remains at the Park Barracks, and yesterday received a large portion of their uniforms. The remainder will probably be supplied to-day.
lead_paragraph: Col. LANSING's Regiment still remains at the Park Barracks, and yesterday received a large portion of their uniforms. The remainder will probably be supplied to-day. The regiment will go into quarters at Staten Island, as soon as Col. WILSON's Regiment, whose place they intend to occupy, shall leave -- probably on Monday or Tuesday next. A malicious and characteristic libel was issued from the Daily News office yesterday, respecting the Park Barracks, to the effect that the small-pox had broken out there, and that the barracks were a pest-house and a nuisance, which should be avoided by our citizens. To show how little confidence is placed in the statements emanating from that paper, an unusually large number of ladies visited the barracks yesterday, and requested as a particular favor, that Capt. GREENE would conduct them to the quarters where the small-pox was raging most fiercely. The Captain escorted them through the barracks, but was obliged to acknowledge his inability to gratify them with the sight of a small-pox patient. It is only necessary to state, which we do on the authority of Capt. GREENE, who has had immediate supervision of the Park Barracks, from the day they were built, that not a single case of small-pox, or any other disease, has occurred in the barracks since they were established.

abstract: AMERICAN BIBLE SOCIETY. The stated meeting of the managers was held at the Bible House, Astor place, on Thursday, the 6th inst, at 3 o'clock P.M., Hon. LUTHRE BRADISH in the chair.
lead_paragraph: AMERICAN BIBLE SOCIETY. -- The stated meeting of the managers was held at the Bible House, Astor place, on Thursday, the 6th inst, at 3 o'clock P.M., Hon. LUTHRE BRADISH in the chair. The committee appointed at a previous meeting of the Board reported resolutions expressive of the sentiments of the Managers on the character and services of the late Hon. JOHN M'LEAN, one of the oldest Vice-Presidents of this Society, which were adopted. Rev. PASTOR FISCHE, of Paris, was present, and addressed a few words to the Board in regard to the operations of the French and Foreign Bible Society, especially in the employment of Bible readers. Grants of books were made to the American and Foreign Christian Union; books in Spanish. German, and Italian, for distribution in Callao and Lima, and also books in Spanish for Panama; Bibles for Japan; and six volumes in raised letters for the Blind. Numerous grants were made for the supply of the army, including one thousand volumes for this purpose to the Washington City Bible Society. Several grants were made to poor Sunday schools.

abstract: From a proof-sheet of an estimate of the Agricultural products of Iowa, for the current Year, 1861, prepared by Mr. WM.D. WILSON, Secretary Agricultural College, Des Moines, we glean some interesting information.
lead_paragraph: From a proof-sheet of an estimate of the Agricultural products of Iowa, for the current Year, 1861, prepared by Mr. WM.D. WILSON, Secretary Agricultural College, Des Moines, we glean some interesting information. WILSON availed himself of the opportunity afforded by the presence at the Capital of Iowa of the members of the Legislature of that State, during the week preceding May 22, and succeeded in eliciting a number of important facts. He first presents a tabular statement of the average increase of the crops, this year, over 1860, the harvest prospects, and the proportion of last year's crops of Wheat and Corn remaining on hand, in each county of the State. abstract: The Franklin Tennessee Review contains an account of a meeting held there on May 25, in which ANDREW EWING, JOHN BELL and other former Union leaders of the state took part. EWING declared that "the old Union" was disabled forever, and urged the people to arm against the Administration. Mr. BELL's speech, the Review says, was "able, statesmanlike, and conclusive. He held up before the gaze of the people the glaring duplicity of the Lincoln Administration, and denounced, in unmeasured terms, the war policy of Mr. SEWARD. Mr. BELL took substantially the same ground with Mr. EWING, on the reconstruction question, and urged immediate and united armed resistance to the forces of the North that are being poured down upon us for our destruction and subjugation.

abstract: The advance of a detachment of the Western troops, into Kentucky, by order of Gen. PRENTISS, marks a new and highly important stage in the progress of the war.
lead_paragraph: The advance of a detachment of the Western troops, into Kentucky, by order of Gen. PRENTISS, marks a new and highly important stage in the progress of the war. Kentucky has chosen to occupy a position of neutrality in an issue which is to decide whether the supreme Government of the land is to perish at the hands of traitors in arms, or to be perpetuated indefinitely. It has discarded, as thoroughly as South Carolina, its obligations to Federal authority. It had no hesitation about nullifying the call of the President for troops to aid in repressing the rebellion, and no shame in leaving the task of restoring and vindicating the National Government to other States, while it assumed an attitude of practical hostility toward the loyal States.

abstract: Our correspondent at Paris furnishes, in his letter printed elsewhere, a gratifying report of the reception accorded by the Empe ror to Mr. DAYTON, our new Minister.
lead_paragraph: Our correspondent at Paris furnishes, in his letter printed elsewhere, a gratifying report of the reception accorded by the Empe ror to Mr. DAYTON, our new Minister. In a conversation which followed the customary formality of recognizing a new Envoy, the Emperor entered warmly into the discussion of American affairs, expressing his approval of the energetic course adopted by the Administration of Mr. LINCOLN, and his hope that it would be successful. Sensible -- no one more so -- that diplomatic phrases usually conceal the truth, the Emperor gave a practical proof of his sincerity by offering any aid the Government at Washington might suggest for the reduction of the rebels. The position of France thus well assured, guarantees that, of Spain. Through the rest of the Continent there has never been any sympathy with the rebels, or any desire but for the early triumph of the Unionists; so that, with the exception of England, mankind may be said to unite in acknowledging the justice and entire expediency of our action.

abstract: The people of Tennessee are to determine to-day whether they adhere to the Union, or plunge into rebellion. There is great difficulty in conjecturing the result. Since the Legislature, without authority, passed the ordinance, there have been several marked fluctuations of sentiment in the State; at one moment the balance inclining to the side of loyalty, and at the next descending to the verge of treason. The defection of JOHN BELL and ANDREW EWING did much to injure the Union cause; and but for the courageous and incessant labors of JOHNSON, ETHERIDGE, NELSON and BROWNLOW, the popular vote for secession would have been decisive. As it is, the daring and better concerted action of the Secessionists has had its influence in Eastern Tennessee, to an extent, we fear, discouraging a hope of a loyal success; for, with the west end of the State almost unanimous for withdrawal, and the middle pretty nearly balanced, the only question has been whether the East would he sufficiently near unanimity in the right to counterbalance the West. The doubts overhanging the question will not, in all probability, be solved for several days, if indeed we ever obtain a correct return of the polling.

abstract: The United States steam corvette Pensacola is progressing towards completion at the Washington Navy-yard. She is a new vessel, and has never been to sea. Before the insurrection of the South she was very fortunately removed from Pensacola to Norfolk, and subsequently from the latter place. Having
lead_paragraph: The United States steam corvette Pensacola is progressing towards completion at the Washington Navy-yard. She is a new vessel, and has never been to sea. Before the insurrection of the South she was very fortunately removed from Pensacola to Norfolk, and subsequently from the latter place. Having been for some months on the stocks, the Pensacola was launched at the Warrington Navy-yard on the 13th of August, 1858. She was designed by Mr. JOHN LINTHALL, to whom has been given the designing of the new craft just ordered. Her draught of water is 17 feet, when loaded; her tonnage, 2,158. She will carry 18 nine-inch broadside guns. The cut-water and quarter galleries of the vessel are admirable specimens of naval ornamental architecture; but her distinguishing peculiarity is her capstan, in which a part of the mahogany used by Gen. JACKSON during the defence of New-Orleans is conspicuously placed. This mahogany was part of an old frame or bed on which a Spanish mortar was mounted by "Old Hickory," in 1814, and which, after the declaration of peace, was brought to Pensacola, where it remained for years. The Pensacola cost $82,917 42, while the Richmond, built at Norfolk, and about the same size, cost $126,816 08. The machinery of the former is being constructed by Messrs. DICKERSON & SICKLES. "Naval presentiments" being generally verified, it is right to say that the Pensacola has been termed, in advance, "the worst steamer ever built in the navy." Professional men think she will be a great failure.

abstract: The relative position of the belligerent forces across the Potomac has not changed materially within the last twenty-four hours, though the impression prevails everywhere that a serious collision cannot much longer be delayed.
lead_paragraph: The relative position of the belligerent forces across the Potomac has not changed materially within the last twenty-four hours, though the impression prevails everywhere that a serious collision cannot much longer be delayed. The Federal intrenchments beyond Arlington House, opposite Georgetown, are being rapidly strengthened -- thirty-six cannon having already been mounted on the embankment. Our troops there look for an attack from the direction of Manasses Junction at any moment. The Federal and the Rebel pickets are also gradually approaching each other on the Fairfax road.

abstract: Col. LANSING'S Regiment still remains at the Park Barracks, and yesterday received a large portion of their uniforms. The remainder will probably be supplied to-day. The regiment will go into quarters at
lead_paragraph: Col. LANSING's Regiment still remains at the Park Barracks, and yesterday received a large portion of their uniforms. The remainder will probably be supplied to-day. The regiment will go into quarters at Staten Island, as soon as Col. WILSON's Regiment, whose place they intend to occupy, shall leave -- probably on Monday or Tuesday next. A malicious and characteristic libel was issued from the Daily News office yesterday, respecting the Park Barracks, to the effect that the small-pox had broken out there, and that the barracks were a pest-house and a nuisance, which should be avoided by our citizens. To show how little confidence is placed in the statements emanating from that paper, an unusually large number of ladles visited the barracks yesterday, and requested as a particular favor, that Capt. GREENE would conduct them to the quarters where the small-pox was raging most fiercely. The Captain escorted them through the barracks, but was obliged to acknowledge his inability to gratify them with the sight of a small-pox patient. It is only necessary to state, which we do on the authority of Capt. GREENE, who has had immediate supervision of the Park Barracks, from the day they were built, thatnot a single case of small-pox, or any other disease, has occurred in the barracks since they were established.

abstract: The present disastrous condition of affairs compels the Foreign Committee to make the following statement, and to ask for it the earnest and prayerful attention of the Church.
lead_paragraph: The present disastrous condition of affairs compels the Foreign Committee to make the following statement, and to ask for it the earnest and prayerful attention of the Church. They are filled with anxiety and apprehension by the fact that they are left almost entirely without means for their work; and are accordingly forced to the conclusion that, unless the Church should awake to a new sense of duty, its missionary operations must suffer the most serious embarrassment and disaster. It is the estimate of the Treasurer, (see statement below) that $25,000 will be needed before the first of October, in order that the Committee may end its financial year without debt. The Committee cannot but claim that their financial affairs have been conducted with forethought and discretion, and that they are in no way responsible for any embarrassment that may occur. Their operations are carried on at great distances, and cannot be adapted at once to diminished resources at dome. In anticipation, however, of our present difficulties, the Committee, some time since, directed all their operations to be reduced to the lowest possible scale, and everything at the stations is now placed upon the most economical footing. No further reduction can be made without sad injury to the work, and grievous sacrifice of advantages already gained. The Committee cannot believe they will be driven to this. They know that the amount necessary for their entire relief might be raised without the slightest inconvenience to any; and at this time, when we are called even to painful self denial and sacrifice, they cannot but trust that a work so full of love to man, and so dear to the heart of Christ, will be sustained. But it this is to be done, and our operations are to be continued, even on the present reduced scale, a prompt and effective effort is imperatively required. That this effort may, by God's blessing, be successful, the Committee would suggest:

MELVILLE, of Newport, loaded for Boston, that about the 10th of May Capt. MELVILLE, after having put in his boat a quantity of water and provisions, left the John Pearce in his boat alone, saying he was going to see his consignee about some retotake in his cargo, but instead steered out to see, and although afterward followed by the mate in another boat could not be found, and had not again been seen. The Captain left on the table, in the cabin of his vessel, a note which read as follows:

abstract: Messrs. MANSFIELD, of Rockland Female Institute, at Nyack, on the west side of the Hudson River, open their extensive establishment in Summer as a boarding-house, for which use it is admirably adapted. They have all the means and appliances for comfort and recreation. in doors and out, with neither musquitoes nor fever and ague. It communicates daily with the City by five steamboats, four trains on the Northern Railroad of New-Jersey, and all the regular trains of the Hudson River Railroad, having a steam ferry between Tarrytown and Nyack. -- Independent.

abstract: STATES. At Bow-street Office in London, on the 18th ult., an elderly man, of gentlemanly appearance and address, who stated that his name was OTTLEY, and that he was formerly an officer in the Royal Artillery applied to Mr. CORRIE for advice under the following.
lead_paragraph: STATES. -- At Bow-street Office in London, on the 18th ult., an elderly man, of gentlemanly appearance and address, who stated that his name was OTTLEY, and that he was formerly an officer in the Royal Artillery applied to Mr. CORRIE for advice under the following circumstances: Mr. OTTLEY stated that he got into the Royal Artillery School at Woolwich, by the influence of the late Duke of York, and, after passing the usual examinations, obtained his commission, and served as an officer of Artillery for twenty-one years. Government offered at that time, about twenty-years back, what was called a "boon" to officers who had served for a certain number of years. The so-called "boon" was the permission to sell their commissions and the grant of a piece of land in Canada. He accepted the offer, and when he went out to Canada he found that his property was fifteen miles from any human habitation; that the road to it lay for the greater part of the year under three or four feet of snow; and that the land itself was perfectly useless to him, being so covered with timber that it would require an enormous capital to clear it. The only benefit he ever got from it was, that he cut down a quantity of the timber, which he made into two rafts, floated them down the river and sold them. No doubt the property might have been made valuable if he had had capital to improve it. He then became manager and editor of the Ottawa Advertiser newspaper, after which he removed to Stratton Island, and became professor of mathematics and military tactics at Stratton Island College. Subsequently he edited the New-York Picayune for four years, and more recently he became editor of a newspaper in New-Orleans. But when the recent disturbances broke out he was required to take an oath of allegiance to the new Southern (Secession) Confederacy, and to abjure his own country. This he refused to do; but finding that several persons who had so refused had been hanged on suspicion of being Abolitionists, and that others were ignomoniously expelled, he was obliged to make his escape and return to England. After an absence of forty years from London, he could find none of his old friends, and could get no employment. Mr. CORRIE regretted that he could do no more than give him some temporary assistance from the poor-box, and hoped that he might get some employment shortly.

abstract: According to the verbal statement of Gen. SCOTT last week, there are now under arms and in the pay of the Government of the United States 220,000 men.
lead_paragraph: According to the verbal statement of Gen. SCOTT last week, there are now under arms and in the pay of the Government of the United States 220,000 men. To maintain this army, after its equipment, will require $1,000,000 annually to each regiment, or $220,000,000 a year. The Navy will require, in addition, at least half that sum, so that with the ordinary expenses of the Government, we may safely put down our national expenses at this time at the rate of $365,000,000 a year, or $1,000,000 a day.

abstract: The undersigned, on behalf of the New-York Medical Association for supplying liat, bandages, , to the Army, desire to acknowledge with gratitude the important aid received in their work from the different societies, churches, schools, and individuals in the City and vicinty.
lead_paragraph: The undersigned, on behalf of the New-York Medical Association for supplying liat, bandages, , to the Army, desire to acknowledge with gratitude the important aid received in their work from the different societies, churches, schools, and individuals in the City and vicinty. Without such aid it would have been impossible to have given their Association its proper efficiency. The extremely liberal manner in which its wants have been met has of itself precluded the possibility of acknowledging in detail the contribution it has received. To have done so would have involved an expense of at least $600 per month. for advertising -- an expense which the existing state of their finances would hardly have justified them in incurring. They trust that this will be received as a sufficient apology for an apparent neglect, and that the societies will continue their contributions as heretofore.

abstract: The Paris correspondent of the London Globe writes: "A specimen of overbearing intolerance has occurred here. On Saturday, the new Ambassador, accredited by President LINCOLN to Belgium, (Hon. Mr. SANDFORD,) passed through Paris, and the residents here, belonging to the Union, having assembled to welcome him, made speeches and subscribed liberally for the maintenance of the Star Spangled Benner, the money being intended to supply the upholders of Congress, at Washington with Whitworth guns. Galignani, of course, gave a short abstract of the proceedings, without a syllable of even constructive partiality for North or South. Some Southern slaveholders have chosen to take offence at any mention of such a meeting at all and had the presumption to insist on a scurrilous and libellous recrimination being inserted in that strictly neutral newspaper. The drift of this document was that Northerners might meet at Paris, being too craven to be on the field of danger, while no Southern gathering is held there, because the repealers are gone home, and are now at their post, that of honor."
lead_paragraph: The Paris correspondent of the London Globe writes: "A specimen of overbearing intolerance has occurred here. abstract: New-Orleans, as we learn from late New-Orleans papers, is a bankrupt city. At a meeting of the Board of Aldermen, on the 15th inst., the Chairman
lead_paragraph: New-Orleans, as we learn from late New-Orleans papers, is a bankrupt city. At a meeting of the Board of Aldermen, on the 15th inst., the Chairman of the Finance Committee stated to the Board that "the city was dead broke, and that he could not see financial daylight." Another Alderman, of large property, resigned his seat, and the Finance Committee reported in favor of suspending all new works, to relieve the finances of the city in that quarter. The Delta, commenting on the city's admitted bankruptcy, exposes another source of anxiety. A large number of tax-payers, it says, are at the present time "utterly destitute of the means necessary to pay taxes on their small property," and should the time for payment not be extended, many will be compelled "to allow their homesteads to pass under the hammer of the Sheriff."
headline: {'main': 'A BANKRUPT CITY.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A BANKRUPT CITY.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The engagements with the batteries at Aquia Creek, and the other recently at Pig Point, have had no other practical effect than disabling numbers of our sailors, and the injury to a greater or less extent, of two of our war steamers. The enemy still occupies both the positions apparently uninjured. It is said that the attack on the latter place was for the purpose of "feeling the position of the enemy." It was, to say the least of it, an expensive manipulation. "We cannot help believing that this unequal skirmishing neither adds to our prestige, nor pays in results the hazards encountered.

abstract: The position of our country is at this present moment the engrossing subject in all minds. Thousands of our countrymen are knit to the destinies of the South by the presence...
lead_paragraph: The position of our country is at this present moment the engrossing subject in all minds. Thousands of our countrymen are knit to the destinies of the South by the presence there of relatives and friends, and wait with trembling and fear the arrival of every mail and message; while hundreds of thousands who are free from such ties quiver with indignation and grief at the recollection of the barbarities committed by the traitorous scoundrels of the South -- who have revolted from our sway, and demand, as with one voice, the infliction of a punishment complete and terrible. Never was the heart of our united Republic more stirred than it is at this period of its existence, and woe to those in power who disregard its promptings. With these sad events it is not our province to deal; but, bearing upon them, we have advice and a warning to give, which, if attended to, will save life, lessen sorrow, strengthen our arms, and shorten, the struggle.

abstract: The Wheeling Intelligencer states that a formidable company of artillery embarked for Grafton on Monday. The corps had four brass 12-pounders, ninety-five men and fifty-five horses. They are an independent company, and were organized in Cincinnati about five years ago. They had been stationed at Marietta for the past six weeks, but owing to the damage done to the bridges on the Northwestern Virginia Railroad, they did not go up with the infantry, considering the route by Wheeling the quickest to Grafton. Quite a large number of persons collected about the depot, as the troops were landing. Their equipments were most complete. The horses were the observed of all observers, and afforded particular delight to all equine fanciers -- being sleek, active, large and strong. The men, before leaving, gave three cheers for the State of Ohio, three cheers for Benwood, three cheers for the Union men of Virginia, and three cheers for nearly everything else. The corps will be heard of hereafter.

abstract: The part taken bg the French Press in the formation of public opinion on the subject of our recent troubles, and the direction impressed, through its undisputable influence,...
lead_paragraph: The part taken bg the French Press in the formation of public opinion on the subject of our recent troubles, and the direction impressed, through its undisputable influence, upon the French Government, form an interesting chapter in the history of our country, which it would be unjust for us to overlook or forget. Whatever may be said of the education of the people, of their fitness for self-government, and of their action in shaping the course of events, it is nevertheless true that societies and nations are judged rather from the talent and principles of their leaders than from another standard. It is on that account that the French have exercised and still exercise on the Continent of Europe that influence which no other nation enjoys to the same degree, and it needs only a look at the copious manner in which the English Press, so jealous of English institutions and manners, records all that transpires in Paris, in science, politics and literature, to know that it is not overrated. French editors and writers are, taken as a whole, men of talent and principle, and though their journals are not so well informed in the news department and miscellaneous matters as the English, they generally exhibit a loftier tone, a higher morality, less passion, and a deeper insight of men and things. It is to such qualities and to the adoption of the French language by the educated classes of Europe, that they owe the large circulation they enjoy all over the continent.

abstract: An informal meeting of the Underwriters of this City was held early in the forenoon of yesterday. The remonstrances of a number of leading merchants, against the 5 cent. war premium on marine risks, were carefully considered.
lead_paragraph: An informal meeting of the Underwriters of this City was held early in the forenoon of yesterday. The remonstrances of a number of leading merchants, against the 5 cent. war premium on marine risks, were carefully considered. It was agreed to reduce the extra rate, temporarily, to 2 1/2 cent., and to submit the question for final settlement to a formal meeting of the Board, as early as practicable. Mr. RICHARD LATHERS, President of the Great Western Company, visited the Produce Exchange during business hours, for the purpose of making known what had been agreed upon. He communicated the information to some of his personal acquaintances and a number of the members of the Commercial Association, privately. It was suggested to him that the merchants at large would be pleased to hear directly of the action of the Underwriters, and that as they were then assembled on the floor of the Exchange, an excellent opportunity of publicly reporting the news was presented. Acting on this suggestion, Mr. LATHERS, without consulting any of the officers of the Association, took his stand on the President's desk, and proceeded to explain what the Underwriters had done, and why they did so. He announced the reduction of the war rate to 2 1/2 cent., which was received with cheers; but the expression of his opinion, as to what policy Great Britain was likely to adopt in reference to privateering, did not meet with much favor. Yet, Mr. LATHERS asserted it was the belief of the Underwriters that the English nation would discountenance the privateers of the C.S.A., at least as far as to exclude them, and their prizes, from all British ports. Although entertaining this opinion, the Underwriters deemed it sound policy to prepare for the worst; hence, the claim of a war rate.

abstract: A few days since, says the Pittsburgh Chronicle, we noticed the seizure at Memphis, of two boats, the Grampus and Mohawk, owned by Capt. CHESTER, of this city. Mr. C. has returned home, and gives the following account of the matter. He states that he left New-Orleans on the 20th ult., with his tow-boats, for the purpose of bringing them home. At Vicksburgh he was informed that he would have trouble in getting through the blockade at Memphis. Accordingly, to aid him in getting through, when he reached the place where the Kentucky, a Memphis boat, had exploded, he took her in tow, and towed her to Memphis, three hundred miles. He arrived at Memphis, on Saturday, May 25, and applied to Gen. PILLOW for a permit to pass the battery above, and at the same time informing him of the fact of his having towed up the Kentucky. The General was busy, and referred him to the blockade committee, to whom he stated his case. They told him he could not be permitted to pass. He then told them he had a tow at Kentucky City, which he wished to go up and bring down. He was told they had let one d -- d boat, the Bellwood, pass for a like purpose, but she had never returned. To this he replied that he had met the Bellwood below Memphis, going down with her tow. But the committee refused to let him pass with his boats, alleging that the Cairoites would seize and keep them, and they might as well have the boats as the Cairoites, On Monday, the 27th, he sent Capt. LME and Mr. VALENTINE, an attorney of Memphis, to the committee in his behalf, to obtain the release of his boats, if possible, and also of a barge of nut coal, left by him at Memphis, which had been seized before his arrival there. The result of their visit was announced in the following note:

abstract: The New Orleans Picayune of May 28th gives the following additional particulars of the capture of three Massachusetts whalers by the armed privateer Calhoun. The schooners John Adams and Mermaid, of Provincetown, and brig Panama, all whalers, captured by the privateer Calhoun, ninety miles from the Pass, as prizes, reached that city May 27. The crews of these vessels consisted of sixty-three men; and the oil on board, of two hundred and fifteen barrels of whale and sperm. On the day they arrived the United States brig-of-war Brooklyn was off Pass L'Outre. It ii supposed that bark Egypt, of Boston, from New-Orleans for Bordeaux, succeeded in getting to sea before the seizure of Northern vessels commenced.

abstract: A schooner, the name of which was not ascertained, was overhauled by boats from Fort McHenry, on Thursday, while passing down the river on its way to Virginia. A large quantity of powder, said to be thirty-five tons, was seized and removed to the Fort. United States Marshal BONIFANT had received information of the sailing of the vessel, with powder destined for Virginia, and chartered the tug Vigilant for the purpose of going in pursuit, but the officers of the Fort succeeded in overhauling the vessel before leaving the river.

lead_paragraph: The proponent, Edmon Blankman, Esq., by his counsel, further examined as witness to substantiate and prove the will in question, in addition to the numerous witnesses already produced and examined in his behalf, Jacob Fisher, a merchant in Park-row, who testified that he was well acquainted with Mr. Maillard, now deceased, and the attesting witness to Mrs. Blankman's will; that he had seen him write very often, and was well acquainted with his handwriting, and that the signature of Maillard, and the address following at the bottom of the will, is in the proper handwriting of Mr. Maillard; that a few days after the execution of Mrs. Blankman's will, Mr. Maillard had told the witness that he had witnessed Mrs. Blankman's will.

abstract: The events in North America produce, as might naturally be expected, a great sensation in Europe. They take by surprise the whole European public, who were 1st from expecting anything of the kind,...
lead_paragraph: The events in North America produce, as might naturally be expected, a great sensation in Europe. They take by surprise the whole European public, who were 1st from expecting anything of the kind, for public opinion in Europe had been accustomed to consider as imperishable the work of those illustrious legislators who, three-quarters of a century ago, traced the Federal Constitution, and therein displayed profound sagacity.

abstract: BURGLARIES. Between 12 and 1 o'clock on Friday night the clerk in HENRY STUKEE'S liquor store, No. 349 Spring-street, was awakened by a noise in the cellar, and, going down, found a man named...
lead_paragraph: BURGLARIES. -- Between 12 and 1 o'clock on Friday night the clerk in HENRY STUKEE'S liquor store, No. 349 Spring-street, was awakened by a noise in the cellar, and, going down, found a man named WILLIAM BURNSIDE, with a lighted candle, overhauling the stock with the idea of stealing some of it. Officer WATSON, of the Eighth Precinct, arrested the burglar, who had effected an entrance by forcing the cellar door. He was committed by Justice CONNOLLY for trial....Two young men, named THOMAS MCDONALD and JAMES O'BRIEN, were caught, early yesterday morning, in the provision store of E. DENINS, No. 178 Duane-street, the front door of which they had broken in. About $20, taken from the money drawer, was found in their possession. They were held for trial by Justice KELLY.

abstract: The aggregate receipts of Flour and Grain last week were ten per cent. larger than in the week previous, notwithstanding the unfavorable influences of depressed prices and scarcity of money for purchases.
lead_paragraph: The aggregate receipts of Flour and Grain last week were ten per cent. larger than in the week previous, notwithstanding the unfavorable influences of depressed prices and scarcity of money for purchases. With a better supplied and more settled money market, bringing as it will a recovery of prices, the weekly aggregate may soon be expected to run to larger figures than at any time last Fall, as the wheat surplus still in the country is by no means inconsiderable, and the corn crop can hardly be said to have commenced its movement.

abstract: As the time for the meeting of Congress in extraordinary session approaches, the expectation of the people, heretofore fixed upon the Executive, is transferred to the National Legislature.
lead_paragraph: As the time for the meeting of Congress in extraordinary session approaches, the expectation of the people, heretofore fixed upon the Executive, is transferred to the National Legislature. It is not to be denied, that much which sacrificing patriotism conceived itself authorized to demand of the Administration, has not been conceded; and indications, too numerous and too various in character to be mistaken, prove that the intense earnestness of purpose, and the fixed resolve of the masses, that the war should be at once fierce and rapid, are not shared by those whose business it is to execute the popular will. That an increased energy has been infused into more military movements, and that sound judgment has been displayed in the selection of a few military leaders, is not to be questioned. The scope and character of the campaign, as dictated by the comprehensive mind and thorough experience of Gen. SCOTT, also merit the perfect public confidence awarded them. But in all matters of detail, in the choice of incompetent civilians for positions of the largest importance; in providing for the shelter, the food and the comfort of troops; in the treatment of the enemy, and of traitors captured arms in hand; in its indecision in regard to the slaves of fugitive masters, as also with regard to the property of rebels generally, there is too much evidence that the Administration does not realize the strength of the impulse which has carried the North into the war, and is disposed to divest the struggle of those essential terrors, without which warfare, a barbarism at best, becomes a protracted and exhaustive enemy of order and civilization.

abstract: We find in the Auburn Advertiser the report of the Committee appointed at a meeting of citizens to proceed to Albany for the purpose of ascertaining the facts in regard to the uniforms furnished to the Cayuga Regiment, and the action which the Military Board proposed to take in view of it.
lead_paragraph: We find in the Auburn Advertiser the report of the Committee appointed at a meeting of citizens to proceed to Albany for the purpose of ascertaining the facts in regard to the uniforms furnished to the Cayuga Regiment, and the action which the Military Board proposed to take in view of it. They say that the Board individually and collectively appeared as surprised and mortified at the imposition which had been practiced upon themselves and through them upon the volunteers, as did the Auburn people. That the Board submitted to the Committee the contract under which the clothes had been furnished, with specimens of the several kinds of cloth attached, each of which appeared to be a proper and suitable material. That the further precaution had been taken of submitting the inspection of clothing to a committee of prominent citizens of New-York, consisting of GEO. OPDYKE, WILSON G. HUNT and JOHN A.C. GREY, in whom the Board had a right to rely, and who had consented to assume the trust of such inspection.

abstract: -- Virginia rushed into secession under the pretence that her fugitive slaves were not returned by the North. She has lost already by the war more slaves than escaped in any two years preceding it, with the prospect of a stampede of a large portion of the remainder. Contraband property having legs to run away with, and intelligence to guide its flight, will be very like to escape, especially when a hope of liberty stimulates its locomotion. A great fact in Natural History, the existence of which has been persistently denied by Southern ethnologists, is in course of demonstration -- to wit: that a negro loves freedom just as much as does a white man, and that whenever he has a chance he will run for it. By and by it may further appear that he will even fight for it. The war that is moving South may, in spite of every precaution, put ideas into the heads of the slave, and teach him a lesson that may trouble the repose of the masters, in spite of both North and South.
lead_paragraph: -- Virginia rushed into secession under the pretence that her fugitive slaves were not returned by the North. By and by it may further appear that he will even fight for it. abstract: Maps of the war multiply, and protraits and photographs of Generals and Colonels increase Mr. SCHAUS emulates Mr. RUMPF's "Bird's-eye view of the Seat of War," by a map to which we must accord the palm as yet.
lead_paragraph: -- Maps of the war multiply, and protraits and photographs of Generals and Colonels increase Mr. SCHAUS emulates Mr. RUMPF's "Bird's-eye view of the Seat of War," by a map to which we must accord the palm as yet. It contains all the points of interest South, at and near which our armies are now stationed, and to which they will soon be advancing. A scale of distances is appended, and the map to all appearence, is as complete and accurate as the most enthusiastic campaign tracer could desire. Mr. SCHAUS also publishes an admirable bird's-eye view of Fortress Monroe, Old Point Comfort, and the Hygeia Hotel, at that Point. A more cruel misnomer for a point destined to prove so excessively uncomfortable to the Virginians, and indeed to all "secessionists," could not well be devised. That Gen. BUTLER and his command, however, will make themselves comfortable there, we have not a doubt.

abstract: "The Ellicott's Mills train, due at 8 3/4 o'clock this morning, did not get in till after one, in consequence of being detained at the Relay by the train going west undergoing a very strict search. Several persons were arrested and held by the military, and we learn that a large number of trunks were taken from the train, and some $50,000 in gold and silver. It was not ascertained where the coin was destined. There was a good deal of excitement and much speculation indulged by the passengers.

abstract: Two negroes were hung in Memphis (Tenn.) on Friday, May 31. One, called ISAAC, had been sentenced for the murder of an overseer on his master's plantation two years ago, and the other, known as MOSES, had been convicted of killing an Italian organ grinder a few months ago. Before the drop fell, ISAAC addressed the multitude present in a speech which occupied an hour in its delivery.

abstract: The Washington Republican says: " The fact that the rifle-cannon shot from the batteries at Aquia Creek is of a different make from any used in our service has led to the inquiry where they were manufactured. Our reporter examined one, which was lodged on the steamer Freeborn in Saturday's fight. It is a shot three inches in diameter and nine inches long, conical, cylindrical, with an iron saucer at the powder end, by which the expansion to prevent wind-age is effectuated in part. The edge of the saucer is about an eighth of an inch thick, and reveals that the gun from which it was fired has three rifle grooves. From where the edge of the sancer ends, up to the point where the cone pointing the shot commences, the whole circumference of the shot is neatly turned or planed off to the depth of a sixteenth of an inch. Around the shot, probably, was a sabot ofcanvas, wood, iron, or lead, further to do away with windage. An examination of the rifled cannon ammunition in the ordnance works at the Navy-yard, discloses no similar specimen of shot, but one of the workmen there remembers that a party from Maryland applied, two or three years since, to have some shot of this description cast there for exhibition to, and the approval of, the Government. But though the shot were cast, it is not remembered that the invention was offered to the United States; but it was reported subsequently, that it was sold elsewhere for $12,000. Who paid the money? Floyd? the State of Virginia? and where were the shot cast, at Baltimore or Richmond? We wait for an answer, and should be glad to hear from WINANS or TREDEGAR, WISE or FLOYD, on the question."
lead_paragraph: The Washington Republican says: " The fact that the rifle-cannon shot from the batteries at Aquia Creek is of a different make from any used in our service has led to the inquiry where they were manufactured. From where the edge of the sancer ends, up to the point where the cone pointing the shot commences, the whole circumference of the shot is neatly turned or planed off to the depth of a sixteenth of an inch. Around the shot, probably, was a sabot ofcanvas, wood, iron, or lead, further to do away with windage. An examination of the rifled cannon ammunition in the ordnance works at the Navy-yard, discloses no similar specimen of shot, but one of the workmen there remembers that a party from Maryland applied, two or three years since, to have some shot of this description cast there for exhibition to, and the approval of, the Government. But though the shot were cast, it is not remembered that the invention was offered to the United States; but it was reported subsequently, that it was sold elsewhere for $12,000. Who paid the money? Floyd? the State of Virginia? and where were the shot cast, at Baltimore or Richmond? We wait for an answer, and should be glad to hear from WINANS or TREDEGAR, WISE or FLOYD, on the question."

abstract: When Gen. TWIGGS ordered the surrender of the forts and munitions of war under his command in the military department of Texas, every officer and every seldier of the Southern forces knew that he was a traitor, and that...
lead_paragraph: When Gen. TWIGGS ordered the surrender of the forts and munitions of war under his command in the military department of Texas, every officer and every seldier of the Southern forces knew that he was a traitor, and that they were absolved by his treason from their duty of obedience to his orders. They knew that they would have been justified in tearing from his shoulders the epaulettes he had dishonored, and sending him home a prisoner, even in irons. There were one hundred and twenty-one officers and over three thousand Federal troops in Texas at the time, who might have concentrated, offering an amount of resistance which no force that could have been mustered by that State could have overcome. There were plenty of arms, plenty of ammunition, plenty of equipments of every kind, as well for garrison duty as for long marches, plenty of supplies, plenty of money for their maintenance, and, above all, plenty of loyalty and courage on the part of the soldiery. They were, moreover, veteran troops, accustomed to long marches and the hardships and perils incident to the border service. Had they been drawn together, as they might easily have been, they could have marched to the coast, where they could have been met by transports to convey them North, or might have hewn their way through Western Arkansas to Kansas, and home in that direction. There was no lack of officers to command them. Col. WAITE, who succeeded TWIGGS, took command the very day after the treason of TWIGGS was promulgated, and before a gun had been given up or a fort surrendered. He was clothed with ample authority to concentrate all the forces in Texas, and use them as the interests or the honor of the country might require. Instead of this, they were permitted to remain in scattered detachments, and ordered, at last, to surrender in detail to the rebel troops as prisoners of war, to be released only on condition of taking an oath not to serve against the Confederacy during the war. With this surrender, passed into the hands of the traitors about thirty-five thousand stand of arms, near thirty pieces of mounted, and more than forty pieces of heavy artillery, with munitions of war, including cavalry horses, wagons, tents, mules, ammunition, and provisions, to the estimated value of near two millions, and between fifty and sixty thousand dollars in Federal gold, provided for the maintenance and pay of the troops. In addition to this, every fort, arsenal and military post in Texas, were handed over to embolden treason and strengthen the hands of rebellion; and the marvel of it all is, that this vast surrender was made without firing one gun or striking one blow, even on the defensive. How shall this be accounted for, consistently with the fidelity and bravery of the officers in command, after the villainy of TWIGGS became manifest? Their general officer was a traitor; but his treason was discovered, and his command superseded before an article had been actually surrendered, and no principle of official morality required loyal men to carry out his treasonable compacts. They were away from the central power of the Government; but they were a part of the Government, and a power within themselves sufficient to resist aggression and hew their way home. They were ignorant of the plans or designs of the Administration at Washington, and their means of communication were cut off -- still their own sense of duty, their instincts of right remained. They knew the fact that it was treason that demanded of them to lay down their arms, and, knowing this, a soldier's duty would teach them resistance, and a soldier's courage and patriotism would have made it successful.

abstract: At a meeting held in Mendota, Ill., June 1, J. H. HARRIS presiding, resolutions were adopted calling on Congress to pass a law providing that the President shall enter upon the discharge of the duties of his office immediately after election.
lead_paragraph: At a meeting held in Mendota, Ill., June 1, J. H. HARRIS presiding, resolutions were adopted calling on Congress to pass a law providing that the President shall enter upon the discharge of the duties of his office immediately after election. The meeting also resolved that the utterance of secession sentiments on the floor of Congress or elsewhere ought to be made sedition by law, and to attempt to effect secession in Congress or elsewhere ought to be made high treason; that any member of Congress guilty of such sedition or treason should be expelled from Congress and be forever ineligible to be again elected. That the President of the United States ought to arrest and bring to trial all persons accused of such sedition or treason, and every person convicted ought to be ineligible to Congress or to hold any commission or office under the United States. And that we ought to use the military and naval forces of the United States to suppress any attempt at secession, and on failure thereof be guilty of treason. The proceedings of the meeting are to be presented to the United States Senate be Judge TRUMBULL and to the House of Representatives by Hon. OWEN LOVEJOY.

abstract: Henry H. Morange vs Peter Morris. -- This action was brought to compel the specific performance of a contract for the sale of land. In September, 1857, the plaintiff entered into a contract with the defendant for the purchase of the front lots on Fifth-avenue, between Eighty-eighth and Eighty ninth streets, in this City, for the sum of $30,000, and as appears paid ten per cent. of the purchase money. It appears that the the defendant agreed that on the 21st of September, 1857, at a certain place at 12 M., he would deliver to the plaintiff a warranty deed with full covenants, and that the property should be free of all incumbrance. It appears, however, that the lots were heavily incumbered with various liens, upon which the plaintiff refused to take the deed. Justice ALLEN at Circuit, before whom this cause came on for trial, held that plaintiff was entitled to a verdict, on the ground of defendant's inability to give a title in accordance with the terms of his contract to convey. A verdict accordingly was entered for the plaintiff The defendant having appealed to the General Term, the judgment was affirmed with costs. H. Morange, in person, Wm. Fullerton for plaintiff; Thomas J. Glover for defendant.

abstract: A correspondent of the Buffalo Courier writes from Niagara Falls, under date of June 7: "The monotony of life at Niagara Falls was broken to-day by an episode. It was rumored that the little steamer Maid of the Mist was about to attempt an exploit.
lead_paragraph: A correspondent of the Buffalo Courier writes from Niagara Falls, under date of June 7: "The monotony of life at Niagara Falls was broken to-day by an episode. It was rumored that the little steamer Maid of the Mist was about to attempt an exploit. Report said that Mr. BUCHANAN had sold her to parties on Lake Ontario, to be delivered on that tranquil sheet of water, and that at least one individual in your city had a lien on her which would be seriously invalidated in case the Maid should succeed in finding anchorage at a British dock. It was said, moreover, that said individual was making quick time hitherward to prevent the absquatulation of his property.

abstract: Mr. WINFIELD SCOTT ANDERSON was arrested on Wednesday morning, at the Relay House, Md., by the officer of the guard at that point, who was directed to do so by Col. JONES, commanding the Massachusetts Regiment. He was removed from the car and conducted to the guard-house, where he now it. The facts in the case are said by his friends to be as follows: Having business to transact with the Bank of Winchester, Virginia, Mr. ANDERSON, who is the eldest son of Gen. JAMES ANDERSON, purchased at the Camden Station a ticket for Monocacy, and took a seat in the train. A person in the employ of the Government, who was at the depot when the train started, immediately communicated the fact to another official, when a dispatch was forwarded to the Relay to take Mr. A. in custody. He had in his possession a package of newly-engraved notes of the denomination of one dollar, for the Bank, which were engraved by the firm and not yet signed. They were five thousand in number. He had also in his possession a few private letters to parties in Harper's Ferry. A quantity of baggage was also taken from the same train, and come of it detained.

abstract: Mr. W. MCCLEERY, who was sent by the proprietors of the "Fort Pitt" Works in Pittsburgh, to Baltimore, to remove the spiks from the columbiads recently spiked by some secessionists there, has returned. He states that the files used in spiking the guns were of the rat tail kind, fastened at the point with a sort nail. Before Mr. MCCLEERY arrived, an effort was made, but without success, to remove them by blowing them out. The spikes were allowed to remain, and new vents were bored to the guns by Mr. MCCLEERY. The guns are now as good as even, and are at present at Fort McHenry. The great "Union" gun was at the depot in Baltimore on Monday, with a heavy guard over it. Hereafter guns will be shipped from Pittsburgh, vent down, which will preclude their being interfered with.

abstract: During the Presidential campaign of last Fall, were presented to the American people, as candidates for the two highest offices in their gift, the names of JOHN BELL, of Tennessee, and EDWARD EVERETT, of Massachusetts.
lead_paragraph: During the Presidential campaign of last Fall, were presented to the American people, as candidates for the two highest offices in their gift, the names of JOHN BELL, of Tennessee, and EDWARD EVERETT, of Massachusetts. These candidates, it was claimed, should be supported, irrespective of party organizations, as the peculiar friends and upholders of the Union as it is. Their banner was the Stars and Stripes simply, and around it were invited to rally all who loved their country, all who regarded this great Republic, reaching from ocean to ocean, and from the lakes to the gulf, as a solid indivisible whole, who were against the madness of Southern secession, and what they were pleased to term the sectionalism of the North; who were willing to cut loose from the corruptions of old politicalorganizations on the hunt for spoils, and of forming anew into one great political brotherhood, of which JOHN BELL was to be the head, and whose watchword was the Union, in its integrity, against all assailants from whatever quarter. Around this standard rallied thousands of conservative citizens, and hundreds of thousands of young and ardent men, whose hearts were imbued with patriotism, and who rejected the party drill and party machinery of the times, as standing in the way of the prosperity and endangering the peace of the Union. JOHN BELL was the peculiar champion and embodiment of the Union sentiment throughout the nation. He was to strike down secession at the South and abolition at the North. He was to grasp these disturbing elements in his fist and choke them into everlasting silence. He was to repair and solidify the foundations of the Union, so that neither earthquake nor tempest could shake them. With these high professions, and this lofty political creed, he entered upon the canvass. His followers struggled valiantly, proclaiming with an earnestness that evinced the sincerity of their faith, that the loyalty and patriotism of their chief was the only cure for the evils of the times, and his election the only sure guarantee of the salvation of the Republic. The American people decided against them, and JOHN BELL was defeated.
headline: {'main': 'Where is John Bell?', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Where is John Bell?', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Mr. H.C. STRUNK, formerly of Philadelphia, but for the last four or five years a resident at Millborough Springs, Bath County, Va., reached Philadelphia on June 5, having been forced to leave his home on the 23d of May, under threats of personal violence. Mr. STRUNK was the owner of a farm of 175 acres, which was tolerably well stocked. He had made no secret of his Union sentiments, and prior to the election of delegates to the State Convention, there was not any necessity for it, as was shown by the election of the Union candidate in Bath County by a large majority. On the 23d of May the secession ordinance was submitted to a vote of the people, and Mr. STRUNK, supposing that he would be permitted to vote as he pleased, when he gave his name at the election poll, and was asked how he intended to vote, replied for the Union. Squire MCCLUNG, who was one of the commissioners to receive the votes, remarked that it was the first Union vote polled that day. As he said this, WM. HOWARD, a violent Secessionist, seized Mr. STRUNK by the throat, dragged him some distance, to a bank six feet high, over which he was thrown. With the assistance of others, HOWARD then dragged him to a pond, into which they threw him. He crawled out, and was pushed back two or three times. HOWARD drew a pistol from his pocket, and would have shot Mr. STRUNK, but for the interference of a person in the crowd. It was finally proposed that he should have three hours to leave the place, and he did leave within the specified time, abandoning all his property but such small articles as he was able to sell to the neighbors, who sympathized with him. One of them loaned him money, to enable him to reach Washington, which he did by the way of the Manassas Gap and Fairfax Court-house.

abstract: Although troops are moved almost daily across the river from Washington into Virginia several camps having been changed to the other side yesterday it is believed that the probabilities of an engagement at Manassas Gap Junction are dimin-...
lead_paragraph: Although troops are moved almost daily across the river from Washington into Virginia -- several camps having been changed to the other side yesterday -- it is believed that the probabilities of an engagement at Manassas Gap Junction are diminishing although the rebel forces there evidently expect to be attacked by the Federal troops, and are continually strengthening their position. That they will attack our line of intrenchments is now regarded as extremely improbable, as they cannot hope to bring against it any force which would insure success. This line, therefore, is sufficient to hold them in check while Gen. PATTERSON's command from Chambersburgh and the column of troops from Ohio are driving the rebels from Harper's Ferry. Even should the latter retreat upon Manassas Junction, the combined forces of the rebels could hardly venture an attack upon our intrenchments, as they would in that event be threatened by the Pennsylvania and Ohio troops following in pursuit.

abstract: The Washington Republican says: "By a gentleman arriving from Galveston, Texas, we learn that a large number of captures have been made of American vessels, and the prizes taken into New-Orleans. He saw five ships taken up the Mississippi River in tow of the captors' armed tug-boats.
lead_paragraph: The Washington Republican says: "By a gentleman arriving from Galveston, Texas, we learn that a large number of captures have been made of American vessels, and the prizes taken into New-Orleans. He saw five ships taken up the Mississippi River in tow of the captors' armed tug-boats. From what he could learn, he judged that about twenty vessels in all, had been already captured. They are taken into some port or bayou on the Gulf, the cargo taken out of them and divided among the captors, and the vessel stripped. The master and crews of the vessels are either kept in prison, or sworn or bribed to secrecy, by being given a share in the spoils.

abstract: Several gentlemen of rhyming proclivities, have, on different occasions, attempted to say something about Niagara, but we are not aware that any one of them has ever succeeded in saying...
lead_paragraph: -- Several gentlemen of rhyming proclivities, have, on different occasions, attempted to say something about Niagara, but we are not aware that any one of them has ever succeeded in saying anything very striking, or particularly worthy of being remembered. It is obvious enough, that the man who attempts to span the tide with a sonnet, or send himself and the torrent down to posterity through the elongated pipe of an epic, has considerably more water on hand than he can well dispose of. In addition to this first and very obvious difficulty, there are a variety of minor obstacles to be overcome. It was never intended that Niagara should be played upon, as "a harp of a thousand strings" -- the name doesn't rhyme well. Two ingenious gentlemen, however, have overcome this latter difficulty. One, if remembrance serves us rightly, commences his address with: "O, Niaggerer, you're a staggerer;" the other, and more dulcet-voiced poet of the two, says:

abstract: Notwithstanding the general depression in business, and the popular but erroneous idea that no one wants amusement in these times, the theatres (there are but two or three open now, to be sure,) continue to be thronged, and this in spite of novalty-lacking bills.
lead_paragraph: Notwithstanding the general depression in business, and the popular but erroneous idea that no one wants amusement in these times, the theatres (there are but two or three open now, to be sure,) continue to be thronged, and this in spite of novalty-lacking bills. LAURA KEENE's, the "Seven Sisters" are "running" as vigorously as on the first night of their appearance. The piece bids fair to carry through the reason to September, when a substitute may be expected. At the Winter Garden, Mr. GAYLER's comic drama of "Our American Cousin at Home" seems to be in a fair way to enjoy a career of similar success. It has been materially curtailed, and is now an affair which may be enjoyed without stopping up too late o' nights. All the dialogue, which had no direct bearing on the action of the piece, has been excised, and the comic situations and scenes, in consequence, succeed each other with with great rapidity. Mr. BLAKE's part -- although still unworthy of his great talents as an actor -- has been curtailed and compressed into reasonable limits. His great reputation insures for the performance an amount of consideration which otherwise it might not command. Mr. SOTHERN is admirable as the two Dundrearys, and his changes are as remarkable for their rapidity as they are for their separate realizations of character. The other parts are rendered with great quickness, and this, with the admirable scenery, has won a pronounced success for the piece. We notice several improvements in progress at the Winter Garden, conducted especially for the comfort of its frequenters. A wide area is in course of construction around the parquette and upper circle, by which a system of free ventilation will be established superior to anything of the kind now known in a City theatre. Mr. JACKSON has acted discreetly in thus anticipating the main objection of Summer visitors to places of amusement, and obviating it.

abstract: Some centuries ago, when victories were won by the mere power of endurance and physical strength of combatants, when the batile-axe and the sword, wielded by stalwart arms, held the place of cannon...
lead_paragraph: Some centuries ago, when victories were won by the mere power of endurance and physical strength of combatants, when the batile-axe and the sword, wielded by stalwart arms, held the place of cannon and the rifle of the present times, the soldier was valued in proportion to his strength and his ability to deal or ward heavy blows in his encounters with the enemy. In those times, men of gigantic strength and inured to military service, called around them followers as strong and skilled in the use of arms as themselves, and offered their services to engage in the wars of whatever Prince chose to employ them. All they asked was a commission to save them from the penalties attached to mere robbery, taking their chances of pay out of the plunder they might be able to gather from the enemy against whom they stipulated to fight, looking to their commissions to secure to themselves the immunities of prisoners of war in case of their capture. These marauding bands sallied out against the enemy for their own personal emolument. They plundered cities and sacked towns, without reference to the sacredness of private property, and the robbery of peaceful citizens was regarded as a source of legitimate spoil. More adventurers, engaging in national strifes on private account, they had small regard for the amenities even of war. Humanity had no place in their creed. Whatever brought gain to their treasury was legitimate capture. Whoever could pay ransom was made prisoner, and if those who could not, were spared, it was through caprice rather than principle. The lust of gain stimulated their activity, while it obliterated all the softer qualities of their nature. Thus in the mediaeval wars of Europe, the belligerent nations swarmed with these land privateers, who had small regard for the rights of neutrals, and who did not always respect the rights even of those whose commission they held. Border towns suffered from their raids, and when plunder of the enemy failed them, they levied military contributions on their friends.

abstract: A plan was submitted to the Board of Underwriters, last week, for creating an effective Ocean Police, with a view to the repression of privateering.
lead_paragraph: -- A plan was submitted to the Board of Underwriters, last week, for creating an effective Ocean Police, with a view to the repression of privateering. Its author, M. D'EPINEUIL, formerly an officer in the French Navy, assumes that the Government has not at liberty the vessels necessary to maintain a thorough surveillance of the seas, and that it will gladly accept any patriotic aid which corporations, whose interest it is to render commerce as secure as possible, may think proper to lend. He suggests to the Board the propriety of at once fitting out a half-dozen fast-sailing steamers of small tonnage, well armed and manned, which shall be tendered to the Government as a volunteer naval force, equivalent in all respects to a volunteer land force, with especial reference to guarding the great trading thoroughfare between America and England. Lieut. D'EPINEUIL estimates that a half-million dollars will cover the expense of outfit, leaving to the Navy Department nothing beyond the cost of maintaining the squadron in service.

abstract: It is impossible to exclude considerations as to the ultimate adjustment of our national difficulties, from entering into public thought, and thus in some degree influencing public action.
lead_paragraph: It is impossible to exclude considerations as to the ultimate adjustment of our national difficulties, from entering into public thought, and thus in some degree influencing public action. Suppose the war over, and the stern logic of Force to have done its convincing work -- what then? Shall we not have the Union restored only in its outward semblance, without that spiritual union that can alone give it living cohesive power? Will the Government have achieved a moral as well as a material victory? There is, in fact, not only a physical, but a metaphysical problem presented for solution to the national mind.

abstract: A large first-class locomotive and six passenger cars passed down Howard-street, Baltimore, on Thursday, on their way to Washington, being intended, it is presumed, for the Orange and Alexandria Railroad. Trey belonged to the Pennsylvania Central Road, and were yesterday brought down from Harrisburgh. Two locomotives from Philadelphia, with a number of cars, also pasted to the same destination a few days since. A train of gondola cars, loaded with light Jersey wagons and ambulances for the wounded, left Locust Point the same day for Washington.
