abstract: -- We give place this morning to an abstract of a discussion of privateering in that important body, the French Academy of Moral and Political Sciences. The immediate interest of the topic, the weight attached to such names as those of MICHEL CHEVALLIER, the Baron DUPIN, WOLOWSKI, PELLAT, GIRAUD, and the other participants in the debate, and the amount of historical and statistical erudition it evoked, render the report highly instructive and authoritative. It will be seen that the balance of logical, moral and political considerations was adverse to the right; while the argument in its favor was that which has done veteran service -- that no other means is so available for equalizing the naval force of a third-rate Power, with that of a great maritime State. The sense of the Academy was evidently hostile to the system.

abstract: The French Academy of Moral and Political Sciences was recently the theatre of a great debate on the subject of Privateering.
lead_paragraph: The French Academy of Moral and Political Sciences was recently the theatre of a great debate on the subject of Privateering. It was discussed in all its relations -- historical, legal, economical and moral -- and the whole subject exhausted. Among those who took part in the discussion were Messieurs MICHEL CHEVALLIER, WOLOWSKI, GARNIER, PELLAT, and other distinguished publicists, economists, and jurists.

abstract: Sundry and divers telegraphic correspondents at Washington promulgated to the world, last week, that Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER was waited upon...
lead_paragraph: Sundry and divers telegraphic correspondents at Washington promulgated to the world, last week, that Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER was waited upon at the depot in that city, as he was about to return to New-York, and that then and there a "ring and bolt,"taken from the wrist of a suffering chattel, was presented to him. Not only did the telegraphers state that the presentation was made, but they, at a cost of 4 1/2 cents a word, sent on the speeches as delivered on the occasion, with the addendum that Mr. BEECHER would reply formally on Sunday morning, before his congregation at Plymouth Church. A cotemporary even went so far as to announce editorially, that Mr. BEECHER had determined to do so, and to give the text from which he was to speak.

abstract: While we certainly do not intend to underrate the value of military education, yet we by no means suppose that military talent or...
lead_paragraph: While we certainly do not intend to underrate the value of military education, yet we by no means suppose that military talent or genius for command are confined to the graduates of our military schools. Colleges and universities are great aids to the poet and the orator, but the learning of these institutions will not stand in the place of that inspiration which gives true poetry its charm or eloquence its power. All the schools and all the teachings in the world would not have made a BURNS of BUCHANAN, nor a PATRICK HENRY of JOHN TYLER. Education develops and strengthens genius, but it cannot create it. It will not make a good financier of a natural spendthrift, any more than it will give high and chivalrous courage to a born coward.

abstract: ROW IN A GROGGERY--TWO MEN STABBED.--On Saturday night about 12 o'clock, a quarrel and fight took place amongst a number of drunken men, in a groggery in Hester-street, near Centre-street, during which James Garvey, one of the number, drew a knife and stabbed Jeremiah Bush in the side and abdomen, inflicting dangerous injuries.
lead_paragraph: ROW IN A GROGGERY -- TWO MEN STABBED. -- On Saturday night about 12 o'clock, a quarrel and fight took place amongst a number of drunken men, in a groggery in Hester-street, near Centre-street, during which James Garvey, one of the number, drew a knife and stabbed Jeremiah Bush in the side and abdomen, inflicting dangerous injuries. GARVEY was, immediately after, arrested by Officer GARRISON, of the Fourteenth Ward, and while on the way to the Station was approached from behind by JOHN F. LUBY, another of the rowdies, who stabbed him in the back and then fled. An hour later, LUBY was arrested and locked up in a cell at the Station. BUSH was conveyed to the New-York Hospital, where his wounds were pronounced of a very serious. nature. GARVEY was attended by a physician at the Station-house, and is not very severely injured. On Sunday morning he and LUBY were brought before Justice STEERS, who commiited them for examination.

abstract: The Albany Evening Journal says: "We are glad to learn that the State is responding nobly to the proposition to organize a regiment to fill the place made vacant by the fall of ELLSWORTH. The Secretary is overwhelmed with applications, requests for information, &c. Meetings have been held at various places, and large subscriptions raised. In Laurens, Otsego County, fifty dollars have been subscribed, and ELISHA A. COOK, a gentleman six feet two inches in his stockings, chosen to represent that patriotic town. Geo. W. Fox has been selected for St. Johnsville."

abstract: With deep regret, we announce the death of Dr. MICHAEL EYRE FOYE, surgeon of the Thirty-eighth Regiment New-York volunteers, Col. WARD -- a loss not only to the service, but one which will be deeply felt by a large number of our citizens, to whom he has endeared himself not only by his skill as a professional man, but by his many social and genial qualities as an associate and friend. The deceased was a man of great experience, having practiced in all parts of the world, winning golden opinions of all with whom he came in contact. His loss will be deeply felt. His companions of the Crimean war, and his associates while in the English navy, will learn with deep sorrow that he has at last fallen before the stern destroyer. His funeral will take place at East New-York, on Tuesday, June 11, at 2 P.M. All professional gentlemen and friends of the regiment are invited to attend.

abstract: The body of ADAM HILL, a German tailor, fifty-four years of age, was found, yesterday, in the dock, foot of Stanton-street, East River, and Coroner JACKMAN held an inquest upon it. No testimony as to how the deceased got into the water could be obtained, and the jury rendered a verdict of "found drowned." An unknown woman, about thirty years of age, was found in the East River, near the foot of Jackson-street. She had dark brown hair, and wore a striped basque, striped shawl and frock. Corner JACKMAN held an inquest in the case, and a verdict of "death by drowning" was rendered.
lead_paragraph: The body of ADAM HILL, a German tailor, fifty-four years of age, was found, yesterday, in the dock, foot of Stanton-street, East River, and Coroner JACKMAN held an inquest upon it. abstract: From the unsettled condition of affairs in the Cotton States, and the fears in regard to the future cotton supply in England, it has been determined to open new sources, which...
lead_paragraph: From the unsettled condition of affairs in the Cotton States, and the fears in regard to the future cotton supply in England, it has been determined to open new sources, which shall relieve Manchester from the contingencies of a servile insurrection, and the dependence upon the Southern States for the principal staple of British manufactures. The discoveries of Dr. LIVINGSTONE in Southeastern Africa induced the British Government to furnish him with ample appliances to develop the resources of that region, with an eye to its capacities for cotton growing. In the course of twenty or thirty years, no doubt, considerable quantities of cotton will be exported thence; but, as it will take years to civilize that portion of Africa, no large amount can be depended upon from the neighborhood of the Zambezi. The researches of BURTON, SPEKE, PETHERICK, BARTH, DU CHAILLU, and others, have demonstrated that the whole of inter-tropical Africa is a cotton-producing region. It was, however, the fortune of our countryman, Mr. BOWEN, to describe to the American public the remarkable country of Yoruba, the field of his missionary labors. Though a portion of the country was traversed by MUNGO PARK, and noticed by the LANDERS, yet its true condition was imperfectly known until the publication of BOWEN's account of his labors and researches. These have supplied us with a definite idea of what the native Africans are doing on their own soil, and give a higher impression of native character than we have generally received. There is no doubt, in fact, that the Valley of the Niger is destined to play an important part in the great drama of the future.
headline: {'main': 'Cotton Culture in Africa.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Cotton Culture in Africa.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Virginia, of all the seceded States, is reaping the earliest harvest of secession. From the Blue Ridge to the Atlantic she is trampled over by armed men her homes disquieted,...
lead_paragraph: Virginia, of all the seceded States, is reaping the earliest harvest of secession. From the Blue Ridge to the Atlantic she is trampled over by armed men -- her homes disquieted, and terror gathered around their hearthstones -- her people driven from peaceful industry and stripped of their property by a reckless soldiery. The rude music of the fife and drum breaks the repose of the Sabbath, and the blasphemy of rough and profane men usurps the place of prayer. Her cities are camps, and her towns garrisons. Her commerce is annihilated, her trade destroyed, and her business reduced to the standard of daily interchanges of the simplest necessaries of life. Freedom of opinion, of speech, and action, are as thoroughly extinguished in Eastern Virginia as in the most despotic monarchy in the world. The supremacy of the law has given place to the reign of the demagogues, and a constitutional judiciary is superseded by the irresponsible tyranny of vigilance committees.

abstract: A meeting, prompted by benevolent citizens, was notified to be held last evening, at Irving Hall, for the purpose of making better provision for the support and education of soldiers' children.
lead_paragraph: A meeting, prompted by benevolent citizens, was notified to be held last evening, at Irving Hall, for the purpose of making better provision for the support and education of soldiers' children. Notwithstanding the brief notice given of the meeting, the Hall was nearly half filled at the hour mentioned. Dr. HORACE WEBSTER, President of the Free Academy, was elected to preside, and Rev. Mr. WARREN was chosen Secretary. The President briefly stated the objects of the meeting, but by some misunderstanding the speakers who had been engaged for the occasion were not present. Mr. CYRUS W. FIELD, in a few remarks upon the benevolent and patriotic objects contemplated, and the necessity of a fuller attendance, moved an adjournment, to enable the Committee to give more general notice, and secure speakers. The meeting was adjourned accordingly. Another meeting will be called at an early day, at which it is expected Rev. Mr. BEECHER, DR. CHAPIN and others will be present.

abstract: A MYSTERIOUS CASE. On Friday afternoon last a girl about 14 years of age was found under the railroad bridge on Claison-avenue. She had apparently been violently handled, and when discovered was unable to assist herself.
lead_paragraph: A MYSTERIOUS CASE. -- On Friday afternoon last a girl about 14 years of age was found under the railroad bridge on Claison-avenue. She had apparently been violently handled, and when discovered was unable to assist herself. She stated that her name was MARIA STEDMAN, and that she resided at Greenport; that a man and two boys had taken her from home, and after beating her, threw her into the place where found. She was taken to the Seventeenth Ward Station house, where she has remained insensible ever since, and her recovery is doubtful. Strict search has been made for the parents of this girl, but thus far without success.

abstract: All movements of the Federal troops still indicate that Harper's Ferry is to be the first scene of strife, provided the rebel forces see fit to retain their position there.
lead_paragraph: All movements of the Federal troops still indicate that Harper's Ferry is to be the first scene of strife, -- provided the rebel forces see fit to retain their position there. At midnight last night the Rhode Island Regiment, which, during the campaign thus far has been stationed at Washington, broke up their camp, and early this morning they started by rail in the direction of the Ferry, taking with them their splendid Marine battery. In anticipation of movements from Washington and the Relay House, however, we learn that the Rebels on Saturday night destroyed the bridges at Point of Rocks and at Berlin, so as to render necessary some engineering operations on the part of our forces. Gen. PATTERSON's advance from Chambersburgh had not, at last accounts, reached Hagerstown, though it is probable that point has been attained before this time. The rebels on that side of the Shenandoah, in order to impede the crossing of the Potomac, have seized every boat and skiff they could find on the river; but as the river is easily forded at various points by infantry and cavalry, they will not prove much of an impediment. Beside, it is probable that Gen. PATTERSON is fully prepared with all appliances to make the crossing perfectly easy.

abstract: The Boston Common Council have voted to dispense with the usual 4th of July dinner this year, and to devote the sum which it would cost to the relief of the destitute families of the volunteers. But the Board of Aldermen have declined to unite in the patriotic movement, and referred the subject to the Committee on the Fourth of July, which is equivalent to instructing them to go ahead and provide the dinner as usual. There was some sharp sparring among the Aldermen in debating this question, in which intimations were thrown out that, bills for suppers at four or five dollars a plate had been contracted by members of the City Government.
lead_paragraph: The Boston Common Council have voted to dispense with the usual 4th of July dinner this year, and to devote the sum which it would cost to the relief of the destitute families of the volunteers. But the Board of Aldermen have declined to unite in the patriotic movement, and referred the subject to the Committee on the Fourth of July, which is equivalent to instructing them to go ahead and provide the dinner as usual. There was some sharp sparring among the Aldermen in debating this question, in which intimations were thrown out that, bills for suppers at four or five dollars a plate had been contracted by members of the City Government.

abstract: A gentleman, resident of Trenton, has recently returned from spending the Winter at Savannah and Augusta, Georgia.
lead_paragraph: A gentleman, resident of Trenton, has recently returned from spending the Winter at Savannah and Augusta, Georgia. We called upon him yesterday to learn just what the feeling was there with regard to the present difficulties between the North and the South -- knowing as we did, that his associations and means of acquiring knowledge had been such as to entitle his statements to great weight.

abstract: We solemnly believe that the American Republic has had, and still has, the most subtle, strong, tranquil, virtuous, active and happy government that the world has ever known; and that...
lead_paragraph: We solemnly believe that the American Republic has had, and still has, the most subtle, strong, tranquil, virtuous, active and happy government that the world has ever known; and that it possesses greater power of indefinite expansion and of permanency, and affords greater security for the liberty, peace, prosperity and happiness of the people who live under it, and for those: who are to live under it in future ages, than can be realized from any form of government now existing on earth, or than ever has invented since the world began.

abstract: Two regiments of regular cavalry have been ordered from the Department of the West to the seat of war in Virginia. We could scarcely have looked for so speedy a corroboration...
lead_paragraph: Two regiments of regular cavalry have been ordered from the Department of the West to the seat of war in Virginia. We could scarcely have looked for so speedy a corroboration of our argument that this arm of the service would have to be reinforced, before the active movements of the mounted scouts, attached in such numbers to the rebel force, could be reciprocated and neutralized. Unfortunately the war establishment of the country has been kept up on so strict a peace footing as to leave very few of Uncle Sam's bold, accomplished dragoons at liberty to respond to the call of the Commander-in-Chief. The entire cavalry arm of the regular service is not more than sufficient to support a body of twenty-five thousand infantry through a single campaign. Of what there are, more than one-half must be retained upon the frontier, to keep the Indians in check; for the red man laughs at any but a mounted foe; consequently, not more than two thousand five hundred horsemen can be gathered for immediate duty where Gen. SCOTT most wants them. Measures must be taken at once to remedy this serious deficiency.

abstract: On Wednesday, ten 8-inch columbiads, (64 pounders,) two 8-inch and two 10-inch mortars manufactured at the Fort Pitt Foundry in Pittsburg were tested at the proving ground, near Tarentum. Esperiments were made with iron plates, to test the effect of common balls upon them the result of which was, that the heaviest iron casings were deemed insufficient to resist the shot of columbiads, unless the force of the ball had been considerably spent. For instance, a 12-pound shot, at the distance of 300 yards, was fired at an iron target, made of six plates, three-quarters of an inch in thickness and strongly bolted together, making a mass nearly five inches thick. The ball penetrated three of the six plates, and depressed the whole mass several inches. The ball was crushed to fragments, and the hemisphere coming tocontact with the metal, appeared to have been partly fused. Other experiments were tried, with about the same result.

abstract: The Address of the Convention of Union men of the Border States, is not a paper to which in ordinary circumstances Messrs.
lead_paragraph: The Address of the Convention of Union men of the Border States, is not a paper to which in ordinary circumstances Messrs. CRITTENDEN, GUTHRIE, DIXON, and WICKLIFFE, would have willingly lent their names. Drawn with noteworthy skill, and mustering such arguments as offer the best apology for the position they have determined to hold, the address is nevertheless full of inexcusable perversions and omissions of fact, and instances of the flimsiest reasoning. Of perversions of fact, the ascription of our great nation's conflict to the labors of the Abolitionist, is the most unjustifiable, because it gives a false character to the position of the Government, and shields from appropriate reprobation the men who are wholly responsible for the evils which have come upon the country. Much of the error obscuring the English view of our controversy arises from this deliberate substitution of innocent for the guilty parties; and while we may pardon much to the incurable ignorance of the Briton, we find it difficult to be equally clement to those of our own political leaders, who willfully commit the same injustice.

abstract: To say that books are neglected, in the face of the present national crisis, is merely to repeat a truism applicable to all kinds of merchandise, except to those more immediately connected with war and its attributes.
lead_paragraph: -- To say that books are neglected, in the face of the present national crisis, is merely to repeat a truism applicable to all kinds of merchandise, except to those more immediately connected with war and its attributes. One class of books only -- that on military subjects -- is the exception, and the demand for these far outruns the supply, although the best text books are all of home production, and the United States has been fertile in creditable productions of this nature, while the English Press (until the late volunteer excitement) could scarcely show a single work beyond the mere technical rules and regulations of the service. Gen. SCOTT's Infantry Tactics, Major GILHAM's Manual of Instructions for Volunteers and Militia, Col. HARDEE's Tactics, Capt. VIELE's Hand-Book for Active Service, GIBBON's Artillerist's Manual, BENTON on Ordnance and Gunnery, and many others that might be named, form the only stock now in demand at the book-stores, and they are works which, in their practical application to the purposes intended, do honor to the service that produces them. It is worthy of remark that one of the most useful little manuals of the kind, The Volunteer's Hand-Book, is prepared by JAMES K. LEE, of the First Regiment of Virginia Volunteers, and is published at Richmond, Va.

abstract: Great Britain will never recognize the Southern Confederacy so long as the Army of the Union advances into the territory of the States that have fallen into the toils of JEFF. DAVIS and his fellow-conspirators.
lead_paragraph: Great Britain will never recognize the Southern Confederacy so long as the Army of the Union advances into the territory of the States that have fallen into the toils of JEFF. DAVIS and his fellow-conspirators. We do not predicate this assertion on any special announcement made to Mr. SEWARD by Lord LYONS, nor on exclusive information conveyed by Lord PALMERSTON to us in advance of official dispatches to the State Department; but we make the declaration advisedly, and venture to base its claims for prophetic reliability on precedents which the British Government itself has given us to go by.

abstract: The regiment of lumbermen now in camp at Harrisburgh must be "some persimmons," if one half what is reported of them be true. Their skill with the rifle is a touch above extra.
lead_paragraph: The regiment of lumbermen now in camp at Harrisburgh must be "some persimmons," if one half what is reported of them be true. Their skill with the rifle is a touch above extra. The entire lives of the men are spent in the pineries of Potter and Elk Counties, except when they are engaged in rafting, and their only pastime is with the rifle, which brings the smallest as well as the largest game to their feet. The use of small shot they consider unworthy the skill of the hunter. They bring down a squirrel from the top of a pine so lofty that the game, is scarcely visible to ordinary eye-sight. The men, in their daily work of cutting timber, receive more or less ax-wounds, and for this reason several of them were rejected on inspection. They grumbled immensely at their rejection, and are determined to fight, and for this purpose are seeking admission to other regiments. One man who was rejected lost his temper, and offered to bet the inspector that he would walk fifty miles without complaining of weariness, and not eat or drink anything until the work was accomplished. More than this, he offered to double the first wager that he could pierce the eyes of JEFF. DAVIS, or any other traitor, with his rifle, at a distance of two hundred and fifty yards. The inspecting officer was so impressed by the man's remonstrance against rejection, that he declined the bet and ordered him to fall back into the ranks. Five of the rejected men exhibited their skill with the rifle at Philadelphia, by knocking a five cent piece from a split stick at the distance of one hundred and fifty yards. The "Wild Cat" Regiment, if composed of such fellows, is evidently a "big thing."

abstract: The plan of the campaign which is to extinguish the rebellion is wisely kept by the Government from common knowledge. We can only calculate the events that are to follow from those before us.
lead_paragraph: The plan of the campaign which is to extinguish the rebellion is wisely kept by the Government from common knowledge. We can only calculate the events that are to follow from those before us. There is reason to believe that Virginia is to be at once purged of the insurgent army, and that in due time Tennessee will be occupied and New-Orleans eventually captured. From such general indications we may infer details. It is clearly not the policy and not the purpose to leave any considerable body of the rebels in the rear of our army. Wherever they are posted they must be dislodged, before the line of operations is carried further southward. For this reason, and not because the post of Harper's Ferry is of strategic importance, it has been thought indispensable to beat the rebels from that position, and to make secure the western communications along the valley of the Potomac. It has also doubtless occurred to our military authorities that the safety of Washington depends very largely upon the strength of our force along the line of that river. Of the real force at the service of the insurgent leaders, it is probable that the Government knows as little as the public. In the moderated language of their later manifestos, they apparently abandon the thought of seizing the Federal Capital; but this language may have been dictated by the policy of slackening the haste with which the defences of Washington are strengthened; and of diverting attention from the real point of attack. Let us bear in mind that all our knowledge of the numbers and plans of the rebels are obtained from those unreliable and contradictory witnesses, "gentlemen just from the seat of war," who pour their reports into the ear of confiding correspondents. Practically we know nothing of their programme; and we shall have made inadequate preparation to encounter it, if precaution against all possible variations are neglected. The breadth of the Potomac, the possession of the bridges by an imposing national force, and the impossibility of effecting a passage against opposition so formidable, must prevent a direct assault; but the feasibility of turning the flank of the Washington army by crossing at a higher point with a powerful body of troops, cutting off direct communication with the North, and surrounding the Capital by a rapid coup de main, has no doubt been entertained at Richmond, and we do not know that it has been relinquished. Doubts upon this subject have most probably suggested the movement of troops now in course of execution towards Leesburgh, Point of Recks, Harper's Ferry and Williamsport, with a view to guarding against a surprise of this damaging character.

abstract: It would seem scarcely possible that in this age and country, and especially under institutions guaranteeing the largest liberty to the citizens, that a system of oppression and wrong, such as now prevails in the Southern States, could exist.
lead_paragraph: It would seem scarcely possible that in this age and country, and especially under institutions guaranteeing the largest liberty to the citizens, that a system of oppression and wrong, such as now prevails in the Southern States, could exist. If there were no constitutional restraints, no laws limiting the exercise of power, humanity itself would almost anywhere else on the face of the earth be a sufficient guarantee against the atrocities which have come to be the everyday occurrences of Southern life. There are now in the Free States hundreds of families and thousands of individuals driven out of the Slave States, banished from their homes without even the remotest forms of a trial, their property destroyed and themselves impoverished by the terrorism not only winked at, but sustained and applauded by the public authorities. We are informed that there are now in Washington and the neighborhood of that city, hundreds of persons who have been forced to flee from their homes, on account of some real or fancied opinions entertained by them in favor of the Union. Some of these are women, whose property has been plundered, leaving them penniless, whose sons have been seized and imprisoned, or forced to join the rebel army, to save their own lives. Some are wives, whose husbands have been suspected of opposition to the treason of secession, and been arrested, and themselves, with their children, compelled to escape for safety from the State. Some are daughters, banished, hunted out of the "Old Dominion," on account of the real or imaginary attachment of their fathers to the flag of their country, and some are sisters, whose brothers have offended against the majesty of secession. All these have been driven into banishment and destitution by the mob-spirit, guided, set on, and sustained by heartless demagogues in official place.

abstract: THE LONG ISLAND RAILROAD -- ANOTHER SUMMER TRAIN TO GREENPORT -- The President of the Long Island Railroad Company, for the purpose of giving increased facilities to the many who seek the shores of Long Island during the Summer and Fall, for health and recreation, has decided to run the train which leaves James-slip at 3:30 P.M., through to Greenport on Saturdays, during the present month. After the 1st of July the same train will be run through to Greenport every day. This arrangementwill prove of great convenience to those doing business in the City, who have their families residing on the Island. To those doing business in New-York, the change of the terminus of the road, from South Brooklyn to Hunter's Point, is of great advantage in point of time. Travelers from the lower and central part of the City, who go by James-slip Ferry, gain half an hour; and those in the upper part, who go by the Thirty-fourth street Ferry, gain an hour.
lead_paragraph: THE LONG ISLAND RAILROAD -- ANOTHER SUMMER TRAIN TO GREENPORT -- The President of the Long Island Railroad Company, for the purpose of giving increased facilities to the many who seek the shores of Long Island during the Summer and Fall, for health and recreation, has decided to run the train which leaves James-slip at 3:30 P.M., through to Greenport on Saturdays, during the present month. After the 1st of July the same train will be run through to Greenport every day. This arrangementwill prove of great convenience to those doing business in the City, who have their families residing on the Island. To those doing business in New-York, the change of the terminus of the road, from South Brooklyn to Hunter's Point, is of great advantage in point of time. Travelers from the lower and central part of the City, who go by James-slip Ferry, gain half an hour; and those in the upper part, who go by the Thirty-fourth street Ferry, gain an hour.

abstract: The most extraordinary item of intelligence which reaches us by the last mail, is the announcement that the Federal Government has notified to foreign Powers, that it will cease to hold intercourse with any foreign Power which recognizes any Commissioners from the rebel States.
lead_paragraph: The most extraordinary item of intelligence which reaches us by the last mail, is the announcement that the Federal Government has notified to foreign Powers, that it will cease to hold intercourse with any foreign Power which recognizes any Commissioners from the rebel States. If the Federal Government has adopted this course, it has acted most unwisely. The question of recognition of a State enjoying de facto independence rests upon considerations which are too well understood and appreciated to be affected by any threat of this description. England, at least, will not be deterred from acting with justice either to North or South when the subject of recognition has to be decided. It is the duty of the two belligerents to diminish as far as possible the pressure of war upon neutral commerce. We do not believe that this object can be gained by having recourse to the barbarous practice of privateering. The Americans, according to their theory, are perfectly justified in employing privateers; but when these vessels are required to enforce the highest bellligerent rights -- those of blockade and search -- the contending parties may eventually find to their cost that they have acted not only in a manner unnecessarily injurious and oppressive to neutral commerce, but one calculated to alienate the sympathies of the people of Europe. At present it seems that the invaluable commerce of this country is to be placed at the absolute mercy of either belligerent. We trust and hope that England may be kept out of the quarrel, but to accomplish this object the British Government must take and maintain a firm and resolute attitude, and adequately protect British commerce from that system of rapiue which, since the determination of the Congress, is in reality only piracy under another same. The Federal Government bas, at the present time, too much upon its hands to indulge in vain and idle threats. Let it by its power reduce the rebellious States to obedience, before it attempts to dictate a course of policy to foreign Powers -- those Powers who hitherto have honestly and studiously abstained from intervening in the contest.

abstract: A horrible tragedy, resulting in the death of an old man named JOHN STEVENSON, at the hands of his son JOSEPH took place, on Sunday night, at No. 30 Newark-street, Hoboken. The affair, as related by the family, is as follows: They allege, that on Sunday evening Mr. STEVENSON came home, very much under the influence of liquor, and commenced beating his wife in most brutal and cruel manner.
lead_paragraph: A horrible tragedy, resulting in the death of an old man named JOHN STEVENSON, at the hands of his son JOSEPH took place, on Sunday night, at No. 30 Newark-street, Hoboken. The affair, as related by the family, is as follows: They allege, that on Sunday evening Mr. STEVENSON came home, very much under the influence of liquor, and commenced beating his wife in most brutal and cruel manner. The youngest son, JOSEPH, about twenty-four years of age, interfered to protect his mother, when the old man turned upon and made a savage attack upon him. JOSEPH alleges that he then drew a revolver and pointed it at his father with a view of frightening him, and that while it was to pointed, the piece was accidentally discharged. The ball entered the left breast some two or three inches below the heart, and passing upward, came out on the right side. The old man immediately fell to the floor, when a physician was summoned, but the wound was fatal, and death ensued a few hours afterwards.

abstract: Whatever the laws ef nations, which had their origin in the barbarity of medieval Europe, may have established on the subject, the fact is palpable that privateering is but another name for piracy.
lead_paragraph: Whatever the laws ef nations, which had their origin in the barbarity of medieval Europe, may have established on the subject, the fact is palpable that privateering is but another name for piracy. If the privilege of preying upon the commerce of the enemy were confined to the citizens or subjects of the belligerents, there would be a semblance of reason and justice in the practice of granting letters-of-marque and reprisal. But the indiscriminate distribution of these letters to the lawless and reckless rovers of the sea, without regard to nationality, and to professional pirates, strips the practice of all claim to toleration, and fully authorizes any nation, Christian or heathen, in the forum of conscience, to treat it as piracy, and to hang those who engage in it without the ceremony of a civil trial.

abstract: "A banner with a strange device" was seen boating in our harbor yesterday. Some thought it was a revival of the Lone Star of Texas; others, that with its beautiful combination of red, white and blue secession had attempted to do away with the "bars." But the flag we refer to is by far the prettiest belonging to South America.
lead_paragraph: "A banner with a strange device" was seen boating in our harbor yesterday. Some thought it was a revival of the Lone Star of Texas; others, that -- with its beautiful combination of red, white and blue -- secession had attempted to do away with the "bars." But the flag we refer to is by far the prettiest belonging to South America. It waved above the steamer El Paquete Maule, which was built for a Chilian Company, by GEORGE K. STEVENSON, Esq., who came from Valparaiso for the purpose of superintending the construction. We say "a Mississippi steamboat," and so the Chilians say El Paquete Maule, or the steamer which is to run up to Constitucion, on the river Maule, south of Vatparaiso.

abstract: The steamer Georgia arrived yesterday from Fortress Monroe, having on board ninety more of BARTLETT'S Naval Brigade, four of whom visited the TIMES Office last evening. They presented a pitiable spectacle, and reminded one, by their appearance, more of the returned fillibusters who, some years since, marched in their rags to the City Hall.
lead_paragraph: The steamer Georgia arrived yesterday from Fortress Monroe, having on board ninety more of BARTLETT'S Naval Brigade, four of whom visited the TIMES Office last evening. They presented a pitiable spectacle, and reminded one, by their appearance, more of the returned fillibusters who, some years since, marched in their rags to the City Hall. Two of the number were lads, who had enlisted as drummers, and neither had any covering for their bodies but a pair of pants, shoes and undershirt, over which one carried a woolen blanket. When they left Fortress Monroe, two hundred more would have come on the steamer, had they been permitted. Only four hundred and fifty are now remaining there. They deny that they have been organized as a coast guard, or that the men are willing to accept such a position in the service, as it implied only employment as common laborers. They had enlisted as a Naval Brigade, under pay of $20 per month; and were informed by Col. BARTLETT that arms and clothing were already provided for them.

abstract: The superiority of breach-loading cannon is practically acknowledged by the numerous and costly efforts made to produce them. The Armstrong gun, with all those breech-loading.
lead_paragraph: The superiority of breach-loading cannon is practically acknowledged by the numerous and costly efforts made to produce them. The Armstrong gun, with all those breech-loading imperfections that require as many machinists as artillerists to serve it, is adhered to as the gun of England; and WHITWORTH, CLAY, and men of that stamp, representing not only the highest mechanical experience and facilities, but unlimited means for experiment, are straining every resource to produce practicable breech-loaders. The obvious features of this system are, the protection of breech-loading gunners within shot-proof batteries on gun-boats, etc., and the greater simplicity and cheapness of the projectile, which is compressed rather than expanded into the grooves by the explosion; in addition to which we may safely grant that high military and engineering authorities would not thus persistently adhere to it if its advantages were not manifold and decided. Yet, however excellent the principle may be of putting the charge in at the breech of a gun, there have been serious practical objections, wholly of a mechanical character, the formidable cause of them all being the expansion of the metal by the heat of repeated explosions. To load at the breech, a hole of some sort, large enough to take in the charge, must be opened from without to the bore or chamber, and closed again before firing, by some arrangement tight and strong enough to resist the whole force of the explosion, and yet moveable with such facility that it can be instantly opened by hand, to put in the succeeding charge. This stopper, whether it be a wedge, a plug, or a cap, must have a perfect joint with the barrel of the gun, for the gas formed by the explosion will leak, or rather blow, with great velocity out of an aperture immeasurably small, not only wasting so much of its mechanical effect, but gradually cutting away the metal itself, and enlarging its vent in geometrical ratio. Any leakage soon destroys the apparatus. The stopper must, therefore, not only fit, surface to surface, but it must be held in contact with a resistance sufficient to hold an expansive power of 5,000 feet per second, and then it must be easily detachable, or the arm will still be useless. It would appear to be difficult enough to produce such an apparatus out of materials which, when once formed, would retain their shape and size. But when we consider that all metals expand differently in degree by heat, and that the same part may expand more and differently in one place than in another, it is evident that a loose joint may soon become immovable, or a very tight joint hopelessly loose and leaky, depending on which part of the apparatus is most exposed to heat. Even railway bars laid end to end and touching continuously, expand so much as to throw themselves from the sleepers, by the heat of the sun, while the temperature of the gases resulting from the ignition of gunpowder, is some 4,300°. It is therefore impracticable to place a revolving or movable chamber, or any stopper of large dimensions, and subject to this heat, within or between any solid parts not so exposed; and yet, whatever does stop the hole where the charge was put in, must be as strongly and rigidly connected to the barrel, as the molecules of the barrel are connected by cohesion, in order to resist the explosion and prevent leakage. To this end, the plan generally adopted, is to fasten the stopper by a screw of sufficient strength and dimensions, by which the expansion of the parts may be adjusted. In the Armstrong gun, the bore extends entirely through the breech. Into this bore, from the top, outside, a mortice is made to receive a wedge which is inserted behind the charge after the latter is put in. The wedge, thus resists, or rather, transfers to the rear of the breech, the force of the explosion; and to keep it tightly against the chamber in which the explosion occurs, it is forced up from the rear by a screw passing into the bore in the breech, and is thus always held in contact, whatever may be the expansion of the parts by heat. To put in a new charge the screw is withdrawn so much that the wedge can be lifted out. In practice, however, the wedge cannot be kept tightly enough in place to prevent the leakage of gas, without it is jammed into such close contact that it cannot be unscrewed again with the necessary facility. Again, the expansion of metals by heat may be irregular; one part of the stopper may be tight while the rest is not in contact. For instance, CLAY's gun has a large excentric, hollow breech, into which an immense plug is screwed from the rear. In this screw-plug is a continuation of the bore of the gun, through which the charge is put into the chamber from the rear. The plug is then screwed in a half turn further, so that the hole in it, through which the charge was put in, is moved away from the bore of the gun, and the solid flat end of the plug jammed tightly over the end of the bore. This goes very smoothly for a time; but since the parts of the plug and of the breech where the explosion occurs, get quite hot, while the rest is cool, only the top section of the chamber is covered by the plug, and the screw works hard after firing a few rounds. The same thing would occur with a Colt's revolver of cannon dimensions, as any one may imagine. It is evident that no mechanical adjustment can remedy the grand defect. Some new principle must be struck out.

abstract: Among the few pleasant things which the hour presents for our contemplation, is the perfect confidence which pervades the popular mind in the ability of the Government to vindicate its authority and perpetuate itself.
lead_paragraph: Among the few pleasant things which the hour presents for our contemplation, is the perfect confidence which pervades the popular mind in the ability of the Government to vindicate its authority and perpetuate itself. That confidence is not confined to any particular Department, nor any particular individual connected with the affairs of the State. When the note of war was sounded, all parties sprang to arms. Democrats, Republicans and "Union men" found themselves standing side by side, with their faces towards the enemy, without pausing to inquire how they became thus suddenly united, or what had become of their past political enmities. They stood together not only as against the common foe, but in support of an Administration constitutionally elected, and that was exerting its energies to maintain the integrity of the Union. They did not look over the record to see who voted for, or who against it. All they demanded to know was that it was exerting itself earnestly to meet, as it should be met, the impending crisis; and being satisfied of this, they sustained it in the generous spirit which true patriotism inspires. There are, of course, a few political organs, with whom the supremacy of party is of higher consideration than the preservation of the Constitution, who are delving among the embers of party prejudices, and endeavoring to fan them into life, but their voice is disregarded and their course rebuked by the contempt into which they have fallen.

abstract: In the House of Lords on the 29th, ult., Lord BROUGHAM, seeing the Colonial Minister in his place, said he wished to call his attention to a matter which, in his opinion, was at the present moment one of the greatest possible importance; he referred to the growth of cotton in our various colonial possessions.
lead_paragraph: In the House of Lords on the 29th, ult., Lord BROUGHAM, seeing the Colonial Minister in his place, said he wished to call his attention to a matter which, in his opinion, was at the present moment one of the greatest possible importance; he referred to the growth of cotton in our various colonial possessions. He would abstain from referring to one part of the subject, cause it would lead him, however unwilling, to make some observations on that very painful state, of things existing in the United States of America. He considered that it had become absolutely essential, independently of those events in America, that Her Majesty's Government should promote, by every means in their power, the growth of this great staple, and he would fain urge upon his noble friend to lose no time in recommending the different colonial Governments to encourage, by all means in their power, the growth of this article. He had received from Jamaica samplescotton, and they had been submitted to persons of known skill in this country, who pronounced them to be the finest sorts they had seen, and they had fixed the price so high as to show that the cultivation of cotton would most clearly be remunerative after paying all the expenses. It was said that this cotton would in the market be worth ls. per pound; but even if it should not be worth more than 6d. per pound, yet as they could upon one acre of land in Jamaica grow 600 pounds in weight, that would realise L15. He was assured that the planters might grow 600 pounds an acre easily, and he had been furnished with all the items relating both to the cultivation of cotton and to the expenses attending it, and he found that all the expenses would not exceed L8 an acre. There could be no doubt whatever that with due encouragement cotton might be grown to an unlimited extent in our colonial possessions, not only in Africa but in the East Indies, and he looked forward with confidence to the time when those countries would be capable of furnishing the supply necessary to this country.

abstract: A horrible tragedy, resulting in the death of an old man named JOHN STEVENSON, at the hands of his son JOSEPH, took place, on Sunday night, at No. 30 Newark-street, Hoboken. The affair, as related by the family, is as follows: They allege, that on Sunday evening Mr. STEVENSON came home, very much under the influence of liquor, and commenced beating his wife in a most brutal and cruel manner. The youngest son, JOSEPH, about twenty-four years of age, interfered to protect his mother, when the old man turned upon and made a savage attack upon him. JOSEPH alleges that he then drew a revolver and pointed it at his father with a view of frightening him, and that while it was so pointed, the piece was accidentally discharged. The ball entered the left breast some two or three inches below the heart, and passing upward, came out on the right side. The old man immediately fell to the floor, when a physician was summoned, but the wound was fatal, and death ensued a few hours afterwards.

abstract: The Confederate mail service is not performed to the satisfaction of the Vicksburg Whig. Confederate nature being as unregenerate as human nature in general, the Editor growls. "The mails between Vicksburg and Shreveport (he says) are badly managed;" and he asks: "Is there any reason why the mail to Monroe, with a daily train of passengers, should not be carried daily?" Certainly not, unless it may he a trifling difficulty of a lack of funds to pay for the service. And then there is a great deal of botheration owing to the stage leaving Monroe immediately after the arrival, of the cars, by which the people, beyond that important geographical centre are kept without intellectual provender, except that which is twenty-four hours past maturity. Postmaster-General REAGAN will have to give his attention to this matter.

abstract: An important movement of troops took place yesterday, from Washington, in the direction of Harper's Ferry, though that is not supposed to be their ultimate destination.
lead_paragraph: An important movement of troops took place yesterday, from Washington, in the direction of Harper's Ferry, though that is not supposed to be their ultimate destination. From the most reliable indications at hand, it is probable they were ordered to proceed to Edwards' Ferry, on the Potomac, about thirty miles from Washington, and equidistant between that point and Harper's Ferry, where they will cross over into Virginia, and establish another line of formidable intrenchments similar to those already erected opposite Georgetown, and outside of Alexandria. This is rendered the more probable from the fact that a company of sappers and miners, with a large quantity of intrenching tools, accompanies the command. Simultaneous with this movement up the Maryland bank of the Potomac, it is believed that a portion of the troops now in Virginia will also move up on the Virginia bank, as a large train of baggage wagons yesterday crossed over from Washington. The troops which are known to have moved are from battalions of District of Columbia Volunteers, two Connecticut regiments, the First, New-Hampshire, and the Ninth, New-York.

abstract: STUYVESANT INSTITUTE. -- Mr. GEORGE CHRISTY commenced a Summer season of entertainments at this cosy little hall last evening, and succeeded in attracting an excellent audience, both in point of numbers and quality. The company includes some of the best knows names in the world of Ethiopian Minstrelsy, and is sufficient, in the fullest sense of the word, for the interpretation of the various departments of Mrs. CHRISTY's admirable performance. Those who would be touched with a simple melody, or moved to mirth by an exuberance of fun, should patronize Mr. CHRISTY.

abstract: "A banner with a strange device" was seen boating in our harbor yesterday. Some thought it was a revival of the Lone Star of Texas; others, that -- with its beautiful combination of red, white and blue -- secession had attempted to do away with the "bars." But the flag we refer to is by far the prettiest belonging to South America. It waved above the steamer El Paquete Maule, which was built for a Chilian Company, by GEORGE K. STEVENSON, Esq., who came from Valparaiso for the purpose of superintending the construction. We say "a Mississippi steamboat," and so the Chilians say El Paquete Maule, or the steamer which is to run up to Constitution, on the river Maule, south of Valparaiso.

abstract: W. Labach et al. vs. The Goodhue Fire Insurance Company. The plaintiff's bring this action to recover a loss under a policy of insurance issued by the defendants to C.A. Steg Co., for $2,500, on a frame dwelling-house, detached from other buildings, on James River, in Henrico County, Va.
lead_paragraph: W. Labach et al. vs. The Goodhue Fire Insurance Company. -- The plaintiff's bring this action to recover a loss under a policy of insurance issued by the defendants to C.A. Steg Co., for $2,500, on a frame dwelling-house, detached from other buildings, on James River, in Henrico County, Va. The house, as appears, was at the time occupied by mill workmen. The policy was issued in August, 1858, and the building was destroyed by fire in December, 1858.

abstract: The rebels crossed at Mercerville, on Saturday night, and attempted to seize canal boats and 800 bbls. Flour, but failed in consequence of the Shrpsburgh Home Guards being stationed there. The Guards, under Captains LITTER and HEWITT, drove them back to Mercerville, above Sheppardstown. The Virginians burnt three canal boats and destroyed two locks between the Point of Rocks and Harper's Ferry.

abstract: BOARD OF ALDERMEN AND COUNCILMEN THE MODE OF PUBLISHING ITS PROCEEDINGS TO BE INVESTIGATED. At a meeting of the Board, last evening, a resolution to appoint a special Committee of Three, who should be empowered to send for persons and papers, for the purpose of investigating the present mode of publishing the proceedings of the Board, was adopted over the Mayor's veto.
lead_paragraph: BOARD OF ALDERMEN AND COUNCILMEN -- THE MODE OF PUBLISHING ITS PROCEEDINGS TO BE INVESTIGATED. -- At a meeting of the Board, last evening, a resolution to appoint a special Committee of Three, who should be empowered to send for persons and papers, for the purpose of investigating the present mode of publishing the proceedings of the Board, was adopted over the Mayor's veto. The special order, relating to the majority and minority reports on the communication of the Comptroller, on the subject of making additional appropriations for the present year, was taken up and discussed at some length. The minority report was defeated, and the report of the majority laid over. The Board then adjourned till Thursday evening.

abstract: ARREST OF BURGLARS -- Yesterday morning between 4 and 5 o'clock, Officer KILGAULEY, of Jersey City, while on his beat in Prospect-street, met two suspicious men, and their, answers to his questions being unsatisfactory, he seized one of the men when the other ran away. An alarm rap , was given when Officers JORDAN, Snow and NUGENT gave chase for several blocks, when one of the officers coming in close proximity, the fugitive faced about and drawing a large carving-knife, threatened the life of any one that should molest him. Three or four pistol shots, rather too close to be pleasant, made the fellow succumb, and the prisoners were taken to the lock-up. During the forenoon, Mr. R.C. BURBANK, of No. 16 Seavien-place, Hoboken, appeared before Recorder MORTONDALE, and identified the property, consisting of knives, a silver cake basket, clothing, &c. The prisoners, who gave their names as CHARLES MACK and ANDREW SMITH, were committed for trial.

abstract: In the House of Lords on the 27th ult., on the order of the day for going into committee on the Offences in Territories near Sierra Leone Prevention Bill, Lord BROUHAM said he highly approved this bill. He thought it absolutely essential that extension should be given to the jurisdiction of Sierra Leone.
lead_paragraph: In the House of Lords on the 27th ult., on the order of the day for going into committee on the Offences in Territories near Sierra Leone Prevention Bill, Lord BROUHAM said he highly approved this bill. He thought it absolutely essential that extension should be given to the jurisdiction of Sierra Leone. He considered that this bill improved the constitution of that colony, and tended to increase the benefits which we had given by it to the unhappy people of Africa, being, as Mr. PITT once observed, a very small compensation for all the evils which he had been a party to inflicting upon them. Those evils had been continued to the greatest extent, and in a far greater degree than any act of ours, by the extension of that jurisdiction, how beneficial soever, could tend to remedy -- he alluded to the atrocious conduct of Spain in that increase of the African slave trade, which, notwithstanding the treaties entered into and the turns of money actually paid as compensation, had increased from 12,000 slaves imported in 1857 to 16,000 in 1858, and to no less than 30,000 in the year 1859. Now we found that Spain was increasing her dominions in the West Indies; and he was by no means satisfied with the assurance given him, when he last brought this matter before the House, that there was no intention of extending slavery, and thereby also, as a consequence, the slave trade, to that territory. Having had access to the decree of annexation by the Spanish Government since he last addressed their lordships, he found it stated that "it was impossible to reject the prayers of a whole nation imploring readmission into the bosom of the mother country. So said the Spanish Government. What said the Governor of Hayti, Gen. GEFEBARD? He distinctly called that statement an absolute falsehood. He denied that there was any imploring of the people there to be admitted into the bosom of the mother country, and added that in their circumstances it was utterly impossible that the free will of the people could be known; for Gen SANTANA had established the reign of terror so entirely over them that "they," to use Gen. GEFFARD's owe expression, "trembling under it, could manifest no free will." The decree stated that the annexation of San Domingo had taken place, and the same decree went on to say, -- "Already the Spanish flag is flying under that sky where the immortal COLUMBUS had borne it, with the Gospel in his hand, to plant that civilization the most glorious of all then known." Royal memories were proverbially short; else, had the Spanish Government recollected their treatment of COLUMBUS, they would have been ashamed to name that man whose immortal services they had required by sending him home in chains, which were struck off, no doubt, in compliance with the popular indignation, but which he required to be buried with him when, a few years afterwards, he died in absolute want. It was also a sample of their short memory that they referred to "the Gospel which he carried in his hand," and which the Spanish Government desecrated by a series of constant ruthless persecutions. And as to the civilization which they bragged of having, given to the New World, it was testified by their exterminating the natives by packs of bloodhounds. He observed that the decree said, "Slavery, the inevitable evil of the other colonies, is altogether unnecessary for the cultivation of that fertile territory." Was San Domingo more fertile than Cuba? Nothing of the kind. And it went on to add that "there is no intention of reestablishing Slavery there." He did not know what the intention might be. Perhaps there was no intention of establishing the Slave-trade when the Spanish Government bargained for a sum of money for putting it down instead of extending it, and yet they had extended it. The means they took to carry on the Government of their new acquisition were not such as gave him any great confidence in their want of intention to establish Slavery there. For to whom did they intrust the execution of this decree? The execution of the decree of annexution was intrusted to the Captain-General of Cuba, who was to take the necessary means of carrying it into execution. Now, it there was a Captain General in all the world whom he should trust less than another for not planting Slavery again in San Domingo, it would be the Captain General of Cuba. He should have absolute confidence in him for extending the establishment of Slavery in that part of the Spanish dominions. He regarded with the utmost possible surprise this conduct of the Spanish Government, and, recollecting their conduct on the Slave trade in the island of Cuba, he was not in the least degree moved by the disavowal of their intention to introduce Slavery into San Domingo, being perfectly convinced that they would reestablish it there if they had any occasion or temptation to do so Cuba had now been for years and years a refuge for all the distressed nobles of the highest rank at the Court of Madrid when sunk in poverty by their own extravagance and loaded with debt, who returned in a year or two afterwards full of plunder, which plunder consisted of the fees paid to them for the evasion of the abolition law, and the introduction of slaves.

abstract: Mr. ARCHER GURNEY, an amiable Englishman, with the characteristic national ignorance of our affairs, sends from Paris an appeal to the people of the North. In another column we transmit it to its address.
lead_paragraph: Mr. ARCHER GURNEY, an amiable Englishman, with the characteristic national ignorance of our affairs, sends from Paris an appeal to the people of the North. In another column we transmit it to its address. The writer has no doubt of his thorough mastery of the situation in all its bearings. He regards the South as a "free people," who desire to exercise the right of self-government; a right which the North exerts its undeniable superiority of strength to withhold." In doggedly insisting upon this position, we are displaying a Pharamic obstinacy, which must visit upon us plagues, following in the train of civil war, worse than those poured upon the Egyptians. To show that we do not misapprehend Mr. GURNEY, it is sufficient to say that he holds the Union between the Northern and Southern States to be equivalent to that between England and Ireland, only that Ireland is satisfied with her English relations, and is not likely to secede.

abstract: In the House of Commons, on the 28th ult., Lord J. RUSSELL brought up copies of a correspondence with the Government of the United States of America.
lead_paragraph: In the House of Commons, on the 28th ult., Lord J. RUSSELL brought up copies of a correspondence with the Government of the United States of America. The noble lord said: In moving that this correspondence should lie upon the table, it may be convenient to the House, and especially so to the commercial interests in this country, that I should state the substance of the correspondence which has lately taken place with the Government of the United States of America, with regard to the blockade. On the 19th of April, the President of the United States issued a notification that it was intended to institute a blockade of the ports of the seven States which had seceded; and on the 27th of April another notification was issued, announcing that it was intended to blockade the ports of North Carolina and Virginia. When Lord LYONS applied for an official notification of the establishment and commencement of the blockade, he was told by the Secretary of State that it was not usual to make such a notification, but that it would be made by the different naval commanders, at the several ports, when the blockade was instituted. It results from the correspondence, that the blockade is to be notified in that manner, and that one blockade has already been so notified, viz.: that of the ports of Virginia and North Carolina, by flag officer PRENDERGAST, who has declared that he is in a situation to make an efficient blockade of those ports. There has been no notification of a similar kind with regard to the ports of the other States which it was declared were also to be blockaded, The rules, so far as Lord LYONS has been able to ascertain them, and of which he has given an account to Admiral MILNE, commanding the squadron in those waters, are, first, that the notification is in each place to be made by the naval officer commanding the squadron or the ships which institute the blockade; and, in the next place, that fifteen days are to be allowed, after the establishment of the blockade, for vessels to come out of the ports. It appears that whether they were loaded or not at the time the blockade was established, provided they come out within fifteen days, their passage is to be allowed. On the other hand it is not permitted by the United States' Government that vessels should be sent to ports which are blockaded for the purpose of bringing away the property of British subjects, or the vessels or property of other nations. An application for such permission was made, to which the Secretary of State replied that if such a facility were granted it would be used by American citizens wishing to bring away property. Lord Lyons ends his communication to Admiral Milne very properly. He says that if the blockade is carried into effect according to the rules established by the law of nations we must of course conform to it; and that we can only see that the blockade is sufficient and regular. [Hear, hear.]

lead_paragraph: -- A traditional individual is said to have tried the experiment of feeding his horse on shavings, he deceiving the animal by means of a pair of green spectacles over the equine eyes as to the quality of the food. But, as the animal expired at the moment when he had become accustomed to the diet, the experiment was not regarded as a success.

abstract: -- It is always with a feeling of satisfaction the American reader sits down to a report of a debate in the British House of Commons on American affairs, the certainty of his learning several things of which he has been previously uninformed is so absolute. A happier illustration could not be had than that furnished in another column. Mr. DUNCOMBE informs the House, with much warmth, that English subjects have been grossly misused at the South; tarred, feathered, plundered, impressed, and otherwise tortured; and that so treated, hundreds and thousands are actually "in the hands of the savages." Mr. BERNAL OSBORNE, the farceur of the House, and clearly sympathetic with our rebels, throws doubt on the statement of the honorable gentleman who preceded him, but while indisposed to believe in Southern excesses, he has a story to tell of the North, far more revolting. It is of "outrages committed by the militia of New-York, in one of the Southern States occupied by them, where the commanding general, on the pretext that one of his men had been poisoned by strychnine, issued an order of the day, threatening to put a slave in every man's house, to incite the slaves to murder their masters. Such was the general order issued by Gen. BULTEN." This is really too bad of Mr. OSBORNE, the facts are so widely different from his representation of them. It was Gen. BUTLER, not BULTEN; the troops were from Massachusetts, not from New-York; the general order referred to was not founded upon the poisoning of one man, but of a score of men; and the penalty threatened was a prohibition of future purchases of the various delicacies which unknown hawkers were vending through the camp. Only this and nothing more. It is sufficient to recall the resolute determination of Gen. BUTLER to repress, at all hazards, every attempt at a negro insurrection, to realize on what a narrow base of fact this parliamentary romancer founded his tale. What are we to expect from English justice, when we get so little of English truth?

abstract: The decision of the British and French Governments, announced by the Adriatic, not to open their ports to Southern privateers, will be hailed with pleasure by the American peopie, as an evidence
lead_paragraph: The decision of the British and French Governments, announced by the Adriatic, not to open their ports to Southern privateers, will be hailed with pleasure by the American peopie, as an evidence that England begins to see the folly of allowing her friendly relations with this country to be disturbed. It will have a very important bearing, too, upon the results of the conflict in which we are engaged. Following it, we think a like decision on the part of Spain, Denmark and the Dutch Government may be safely counted upon, together with that of the friendly Governments of Mexico and Central and South America. This will close all the harbors of the West India Islands, and those of the continent, as well as the European ports, to which the privateers of the rebel States could hope to have access with their prizes. It will do vastly more than this, for it will prevent them from fitting out their piratical crafts. While their own ports are sealed by a blockade, through which it will be next to impossible for them to reach the ocean, they will find no friendly harbor in which to arm and prepare for sea their buccaneering expeditions.

abstract: The first essays at war of a people addicted to peace end, uniformly, in defeat. Our army has had its first reverse. Ordered to make a night advance upon the enemy's lines to the Westward of Fortress Monroe, some
lead_paragraph: The first essays at war of a people addicted to peace end, uniformly, in defeat. Our army has had its first reverse. Ordered to make a night advance upon the enemy's lines to the Westward of Fortress Monroe, some three thousand of the national troops marched courageously upon the errand; and confiding in the presumed knowledge of their officers -- accomplished military skill was not expected -- marched into the very jaws of death. Their misadventures were not due to any heedlessness on their part, or to any deficiency in the qualities which make good soldiers. They fought both friends and foes with equal resolution; and only retired, when the exhaustion of ammunition in the presence of a powerful enemy, strongly intrenched, and with every advantage of position, rendered a further contest impossible. The fact that they retreated without panic or disorder, carrying their wounded and their guns with them, is the best proof of the calm courage and self-control which governed their movement. The loss of life, and the number injured, presents a painful catalogue; but it is a record of soldierly heroism, which must forever set at rest all doubt as to the fitness of our people for the most hazardous exposure of the battle-field, and for the encounter of danger in its most startling forms. Let us do homage to the discipline and fortitude of our brave fellows, who, defenceless for two hours under the enemy's fire, only retreated when their incompetent commander gave the tardy word. Whatever of triumph the affair may afford the enemy, we are taught the gratifying lesson that we have the best possible fighting material to defend the country.

abstract: A gentleman of high literary ability, well-known by his contributions to literature, as well as by his efforts in other departments, and who has been honorably connected with the public service, has been reduced, through a protracted, and, it is feared, a permanent blindness, to a condition of extreme pecuniary embarrassment. The Editor of THE TIMES knows the circumstances of the case, and makes this appeal to those who may be disposed to aid the gentleman referred to and his suffering family. Any moneys that may be sent to this office for their relief, will be gratefully acknowledged and properly applied.

abstract: The Fourth Connecticut Regiment, which left Hartford on Monday afternoon in the steamers City of Hartford and Granite State, arrived at Jersey City yesterday morning, and left at 10 o'clock for the seat of war, via Philadelphia, after taking a hearty breakfast and being cordially welcomed by hosts of friends. The outfit of the regiment was complete,
lead_paragraph: The Fourth Connecticut Regiment, which left Hartford on Monday afternoon in the steamers City of Hartford and Granite State, arrived at Jersey City yesterday morning, and left at 10 1/2 o'clock for the seat of war, via Philadelphia, after taking a hearty breakfast and being cordially welcomed by hosts of friends. The outfit of the regiment was complete, and highly creditable to Yankee forethought. The uniform is fatigue gray, and each man has, in addition, a blouse and a light felt hat. The two flank companies are armed with Sharpe's rifles, and the rest with the regulation musket, which will probably be exchanged for Enfield rifles. Like the other three regiments from the State, the Fourth is provided with twenty-four baggage-wagons and ambulances, besides horses for most of the Line Officers. The Regiment has been encamped at Hartford three weeks, and is mustered into the United States service for three years. Their motto is the Hartford City motto, "Post nubila Phoebus." They carry 60,000 ball cartridges, of which 10,000 are for Sharpe's rifles. Col. WOODHOUSE, who commands the regiment, held a Lieutenant's commission in the New-England Ninth Regiment, during the Mexican War, and was at the storming of Chapultepec. He has been several years Quartermaster-General of Connecticut, and resigned the office of City Clerk of Hartford to take this command. The following is a complete list of the Commissioned Officers:

abstract: -- The vexed question of the Quartermaster Generalship has at last been solved. The position has been offered to Capt. MEIGS, whose services upon the Washington Aqueduct, in the completion of the defences at Key West, and in the reinforcement of Fort Pickens, are the best evidence of extraordinary executive talent. If Capt. MEIGS has thus far furnished no reason to expect a very rigid economy in the conduct of his bureau, his honesty is a warrant that peculation will cease to be tolerated there; and on the whole the country will profit largely by the change. Too much importance cannot be attached to this branch of the service. It was the masterly ability of Quartermaster-General JESUP that contributed as much as anything else to our successes in Mexico; it was the incapacity of the same Department in England that caused all the disasters of the war in the Crimea. Recent mismanagement in this particular has already done much to dishearten our volunteers, and to discourage the enlistment of men. We have no doubt Capt. MEIGS will at once rectify matters.
lead_paragraph: -- The vexed question of the Quartermaster Generalship has at last been solved. The position has been offered to Capt. If Capt. MEIGS has thus far furnished no reason to expect a very rigid economy in the conduct of his bureau, his honesty is a warrant that peculation will cease to be tolerated there; and on the whole the country will profit largely by the change. Too much importance cannot be attached to this branch of the service. It was the masterly ability of Quartermaster-General JESUP that contributed as much as anything else to our successes in Mexico; it was the incapacity of the same Department in England that caused all the disasters of the war in the Crimea. Recent mismanagement in this particular has already done much to dishearten our volunteers, and to discourage the enlistment of men. We have no doubt Capt. MEIGS will at once rectify matters.

abstract: --The election for members of the present Congress takes place in Maryland to-morrow. The canvass has been a very active one, though, owing to the presence of the National troops, order has been perfectly preserved, even in Baltimore, where the secession tendency is most violent. There is no doubt, indeed, that the display of so strong a force on the loyal side has had its effect in preventing the institution of that reign of terror, without which the elections in the seceding States could not have obtained their appearance of unanimity. As to the result of the election there is no reason for apprehension. The unconditional Union men have nominated their best representatives, such as Mr. HENRY WINTER DAVIS, Ex.-Gov. THOMAS, and Mr. CHARLES B. CALVERT, gentlemen of great personal popularity and influence. The Secessionists have named candidates in every district, the only one deserving especial note being Mr. ROBERT MCLANE, late Minister to Mexico, who is opposed to Mr. DAVIS. In this, the Fourth District, there is unfortunately a third candidate, running in the Union interest; but it is not thought that he will cripple the strength of Mr. DAVIS sufficiently to elect MCLANE.

abstract: Orders were received at the head-quarters of the army in this City yesterday, directing the acting Commandant of the post to prepare and equip for the road at once a force of 310 men. In compliance with these instructions 60 were sent off in a few moments, and 250 subsequently. The utmost celerity was used in getting them ready, which was done without the slightest confusion.

abstract: During the recent stay of the Seventh Regiment in Washington, Gen. SCOTT, in reply to the request of Col. LEFFERTS to keep the regiment in active service, said: "Why Colonel, yon do not want your regiment here you have a regiment of officers."
lead_paragraph: During the recent stay of the Seventh Regiment in Washington, Gen. SCOTT, in reply to the request of Col. LEFFERTS to keep the regiment in active service, said: "Why Colonel, yon do not want your regiment here -- you have a regiment of officers." In this remark, Gen. SCOTT recognized the most effective service the Seventh Regiment has rendered the country in the officering of various regiments that have volunteered for the war from this and other States. It has furnished four Colonels and an Acting-Brigadier-General, (Col. DURYEE,) besides any quantity of Captains, Lieutenants, and non-commissioned officers. The following list is by no means complete, but will give some idea of the wide field over which the discipline of the Seventh is to be extended through the acknowledged skill of its officers. No doubt every member of the regiment could add to the list names within his own circle of acquaintances. We should be glad to have them forwarded to us, together with corrections of any errors that may have crept into this. The Seventh Regiment New-York State Militia, (National Guard,) has supplied the following officers to other regiments:

abstract: A PRIZE FIGHT INTERFERED WITH BY THE POLICE. -- The pugilists, WOOD and KING, whose names are familiar in connection with the Willett's Point affair a year since, made arrangements for a prize fight to take place near East New-York, yesterday morning. Capt. MULLEN, of the Sixth Precinct, received information of the affair at 2 o'clock, and, with a force of twenty men, started for the scene. He found the preparations for the fight had been made in a meadow, near the hotel of JOHN J. SNEDIKER. The alarm being given, however, the parties and their friends fled, and no arrests were made. After ineffectual pursuit, the police returned to the city.
