abstract: An armed fleet of any kind being better than no fleet at all, in this emergency, we had hoped that the hasty preparation of the plans for our new gun-boats would have afforded some excuse for their defects; but we are
lead_paragraph: An armed fleet of any kind being better than no fleet at all, in this emergency, we had hoped that the hasty preparation of the plans for our new gun-boats would have afforded some excuse for their defects; but we are doomed to hopeless disappointment, for "A Government Engineer" has laid open, in another column, the ultimate knowledge and policy of the Department, by indorsing these plans per se. We would do ourselves the justice to hope, at the start, that we may be enabled to discuss this subject with becoming humility, when a Government officer, so extraordinarily capable that he can "perceive" the percentage of speed gained over the English boats by looking at the specifications that lie before him, waives the unapproachable dignity of his position to address us.

abstract: THE SHOOTING AFFAIRS IN HOBOKEN. -- It is stated, that after Mr. JOHN STEVENSON, of Hoboken, was shot by his son, an ante-mortem examination was held, at which Drs. JULIEN, CHAUBERT and members of the family were present. That the deceased did not blame his son, and regretted the difficulty which led to it. It is said that there is no ground to sustain a charge of willful murder. The facts in the case will be developed at the inquest as soon as Mrs. STEVENSON recovers sufficiently to give her evidence.

abstract: The rebels crossed at Mercerville, on Saturday night, and attempted to seize canal boats and 800 bbls. Flour, but failed in consequence of the Shrpsburgh Home Guards being stationed there. abstract: The Fourth Connecticut Regiment, which left Hartford on Monday afternoon in the steamers City of Hartford and Granite State, arrived at Jersey City yesterday morning, and left at 10 o'clock for the seat of war, via Philadelphia, after taking a hearty breakfast and being cordially welcomed by hosts of friends.
lead_paragraph: The Fourth Connecticut Regiment, which left Hartford on Monday afternoon in the steamers City of Hartford and Granite State, arrived at Jersey City yesterday morning, and left at 10 o'clock for the seat of war, via Philadelphia, after taking a hearty breakfast and being cordially welcomed by hosts of friends. The outfit of the regiment was complete, and highly creditable to Yankee forethought. The uniform is fatigue gray, and each man has, in addition, a blouse and a light felt hat. The two flank companies are armed with Sharpe's rifles, and the rest with the regulation musket, which will probably be exchanged for Enfield rifles. Like the other three regiments from the State, the Fourth is provided with twenty-four baggage-wagons and ambulances, besides horses for most of the Line Officers. The Regiment has been encamped at Hartford three weeks, and is mustered into the United States service for three years. Their motto is the Hartford City motto, "Post nubila Phoebus." They carry 60,000 ball cartridges, of which 10,000 are for Sharpe's rifles. Col. WOODHOUSE, who commands the regiment, held a Lieutenant's commission in the New-England Ninth Regiment, during the Mexican War, and was at the storming of Chapultepec. He has been several years Quartermaster-General of Connecticut, and resigned the office of City Clerk of Hartford to take this command. The following is a complete list of the Commissioned Officers:

abstract: AARON ACKERMAN, of Allendale, Bergen County, a few days ago plowed up a dozen pewter plates, two large turkey dishes, alio of pewter. All were in a good state of preservation. They were packed one within the other, so that they were only corroded around the edges. They had undoubtedly been buried during the time of the Revolution -- Patterson Guardian, June 6.

abstract: -- The non-intercourse policy has compelled the Southern journals to fall back upon native talent to display the insignia of rebellion in their columns. Southern designers and engravers are relieved from Northern competition. Cuts symbolical of all manner of martial and patriotic topics are printed in the Southern papers, fully equalling the early attempts of ALBERT DURER, who engraved on wood over 300 years ago. Southern art and Southern civilization, we must reflect, are in their infancy. Both belong to other ages.

abstract: During the recent stay of the Seventh Regiment in Washington, Gen. SCOTT, in reply to the request of Col. LEFFERTS to keep the regiment in active service, said: "Why Colonel, you do not want your regiment here--you have a regiment of officers."
lead_paragraph: During the recent stay of the Seventh Regiment in Washington, Gen. SCOTT, in reply to the request of Col. LEFFERTS to keep the regiment in active service, said: "Why Colonel, you do not want your regiment here -- you have a regiment of officers." In this remark,Gen. SCOTT recognized the most effective service the Seventh Regiment has rendered the country in the officering of various regiments that have volunteered for the war from this and other States. It has furnished four Colonels and an Acting-Brigadier-General, (Col. DURYEE,) besides any quantity of Captains, Lieutenants, and non-commissioned officer. The following list is by no meant complete, but will give some idea of the wide field over which the discipline of the Seventh is to be extended through the acknowledged skill of its officers. No doubt every member of the regiment could add to the list names within his own circle of acquaintances. We should be glad to have them for warded to us, together with corrections of any errors that may have crept into this. The Seventh Regiment New-York State Militia, (National Guard,) has supplied the following officers to other regiments:

abstract: We place but little faith in the telegraphic rumors which reach us almost daily to the effect that the renowned trench-digger and braggart, PILLOW the "Major-General commanding the Army of Tennesse," as he styles
lead_paragraph: We place but little faith in the telegraphic rumors which reach us almost daily to the effect that the renowned trench-digger and braggart, PILLOW -- the "Major-General commanding the Army of Tennesse," as he styles himself -- is about to make an immediate attack upon Cairo. Undoubtedly it is the point which, next to the political capital of the Union, is most ardently coveted by the leaders of the revolt. Its importance, in a military aspect, can hardly be overrated. Not only does it command the Upper Mississippi, and its great tributaries, the Missouri and the Ohio, but also the chief internal river courses of Kentucky and Tennessee; while it also directly threatens, by land and river, Memphis and all the cities and States bordering on the Lower Mississippi.

abstract: The most serious collision which has thus far taken place between the Federal forces and those of the rebels and, as it proved, the most unfortunate for us occurred on Monday morning at a place known as Great Bethel, about twelve miles from Fortress Monroe, and near the road conducting to Yorktown. Gen. BUTLER, having heard
lead_paragraph: The most serious collision which has thus far taken place between the Federal forces and those of the rebels -- and, as it proved, the most unfortunate for us -- occurred on Monday morning at a place known as Great Bethel, about twelve miles from Fortress Monroe, and near the road conducting to Yorktown. Gen. BUTLER, having heard that the rebels were engaged there in throwing up intrenchments, determined to dislodge them, and for this purpose detailed the Albany Regiment, commanded by Col. TOWNSEND, DURYEE's Zouaves, and the Seventh Regiment, (German,) commanded by Col. BENDIX, together with a detachment of United States Artillery, commanded by Lieut. GREBBLE, with four 12-pound howitzers, the whole numbering some three thousand, under command of Brig.-Gen. PIERCE. The troops moved on the expedition about midnight on Sunday night, those from Hampton crossing Hampton Creek on batteaux manned by members of the Naval Brigade. Owing to an unfortunate mistake relative to signals, two of the regiments came in collision in the darkness while on the way, and fired into each other, under the mutual supposition that they were enemies. The casualties from this event, however, were not considerable. After the mistake was rectified, the entire force moved on Great Bethel, where the enemy was encountered in much larger force than was anticipated, strongly intrenched, and having heavy ordnance, several pieces of which were rifled cannon. Several attempts tempts were made to carry the position, in which our troops behaved in the most gallant manner, but for lack of a sufficiency of artillery and ammunition, this enterprise had finally to be abandoned, with a loss of about 30 killed and 100 wounded. The withdrawal of our troops was executed in good order, and the enemy appears to have had no disposition to pursue them. A list of the killed and wounded, so far as they are all present known, is given elsewhere. The losses on the part of the rebels, if any, are unknown. A rumor reaches us from Washington that Gen. BUTLER on Monday night made another attack on the rebel batteries, and carried them. The rumor is quite likely to be true.

abstract: A CHANCE TO BE IMPROVED. -- In the course of next week, we shall probably witness the arrival here of the French squadron sent out to reinforce the West India fleet. Admiral RAYNAUD, the commander, comes with instructions to examine all the principal navy-yards and harbors of the coast, from Portland southward. No better opportunity could be afforded, of testifying the national appreciation of the conduct of the French Government, in renewing its declarations of warm friendship, at this critical era of our fate; and we trust the authorities of this City, and of the other places which the Admiral designs to visit, will be prepared to receive him with marked demonstrations of courtesy and respect. Something more than policy exacts such manifestations.
lead_paragraph: A CHANCE TO BE IMPROVED. -- In the course of next week, we shall probably witness the arrival here of the French squadron sent out to reinforce the West India fleet. abstract: The Marshal (Texas) Republican says that the Guards and Texas Hunters, who left that place for the Northern frontier, have returned. They report that Col. EMORY, in command of the U.S. forces, had left Forts Washita and Arbuckle, and was rapidly making his way to Kansas. He sent word to Gen.
lead_paragraph: The Marshal (Texas) Republican says that the Guards and Texas Hunters, who left that place for the Northern frontier, have returned. They report that Col. EMORY, in command of the U.S. forces, had left Forts Washita and Arbuckle, and was rapidly making his way to Kansas. He sent word to Gen. YOUNG, that as soon as he had honorably discharged his forces in Kansas, he intends resigning and joining the Southern army. Gen. YOUNG captured several wagons, with munitions of war, provisions, and two cannon. Hon. B.H. EPPERSON, who was among the volunteers under Col. YOUNG, writes that a gentlemanwho spent a night with the U.S. troops, not far from Fort Arbuckle, says that he conversed with Capt. CRITTENDEN, a son of Hon. JOHN J. CRITTENDEN, (doubtless Major GEORGE CRITTENDEN, once a resident of Galveston) who said that one-third of the men and officers were Southern men, and resolved not to fight -- that they were getting out of the way -- that he and others were determined to resign as soon possible. He, however, stated that the commanding officer, EMORY, would order them to fight if they were assailed, and they would be obliged to do so -- they were making forced marches and were throwing everything away that was heavy; they had about one hundred wagons and three companies of infantry. The United States troops are making for Leavenworth, which is about 600 miles through the Indian territory. Col. YOUNG has abandoned the pursuit; but at the last accounts it was still kept up by some companies from Arkansas and the Indian nation.

abstract: The Albany Atlas and Argus is one of the few Northern journals which from force of habit cannot elevate itself above partisan association. Its issue of yesterday contains a characteristic attack upon Gov. BANKS, based upon the oft-refuted falsehood, that he on one occasion declared his willingness to "let the Union slide." While Gov. BANKS has always been a steadfast friend of the Union, as a civilian and a statesman, and while he will be as a General in the field, the Atlas and Argus must not forget that itself was an influential ally of the Southern conspirators, and only disowned their service when the masses of the Democratic Party compelled it, most reluctantly, to wheel into the patriot ranks

abstract: Katharine Thompson vs. James Laing This action, which was tried before Mr. Justice Moncrief and a jury on the 27th of March, 1861, and on the plaintiff's case the complaint was dismissed.
lead_paragraph: Katharine Thompson vs. James Laing -- This action, which was tried before Mr. Justice Moncrief and a jury on the 27th of March, 1861, and on the plaintiff's case the complaint was dismissed. The action was brought to recover damages for the non-performance of a contract for the stone-work upon four houses on Thirtieth-street in this City. The answer alleges that the contract was obtained through fraudulent representations; and that owing to other contractors for the same work being in possession of the building, under plaintiff's authority. defendant was prevented from the performance of his contract. On the trial of this cause the husband of the plaintiff was offered as a witness in her behalf and was rejected, on the ground, that he not being a party to the suit his evidence did not come within the purview of the act of 1860. To this the plaintiff excepted, and on this appeal is made the principal question in the case. It is contended by the appellant that it was clearly the intent of tae legislature, in the act of 1860 to allow husband and wife to be witnesses on behalf of each other. That the Legislature, by its acts giving to a married woman the right to bring an action in her own name, with respect to her separate property, without joining her husband in the action, clearly intended, by the Act of 1860. that it was her right to have the same facilities for obtaining testimony as any other suitor in a Court of justice. That so for as husband and wife are excluded from testifying to such facts as may disclose any communication between them, with reference to the subject matter of the action, it is right and proper; but their testimony in other respects should be admitted as competent. There are, as yet, no authorities bearing directly upon the point in this State; but in England; under the State of 27th Victoria, one law is very similar to the one this state, and there appear to be decisions bearing more directly upon the subject, which have been quoted in support of this portion. Decision reserved

abstract: The Cincinnati papers announce that an effort is being made, by merchants of that city, who have been largely engaged in shipping provisions to the South, to induce the Government to permit the trade to be reopened. They argue that by it only the surplus provisions of the Northwest will be disposed of, in return for which the North will receive large amounts of Southern specie, thus helping to deprive our enemies of the "sinews of war." By the same system of argument we might benefit the North by selling the rebels, for cash, any "surplus" muskets, artillery, powder and ball; though we are unable to perceive what advantage an army with money, but without provisions and arms, would have over an enemy well provisioned and armed, but without money. We presume that, so far from the effort succeeding, the embargo will be made more perfect.

abstract: Before recording anything more than an interlocutory judgment upon the disaster near Yorktown, justice requires us to await the official dispatches of Gen. BUTLER.
lead_paragraph: Before recording anything more than an interlocutory judgment upon the disaster near Yorktown, justice requires us to await the official dispatches of Gen. BUTLER. That these had not reached Washington as promptly as the detailed accounts of newspaper correspondents is the occasion of surprise. The probability is, however, that Gen. BUTLER was indisposed to let his report of the mishap go forward without the palinode of a subsequent success; and that when he shall be heard from, he will have a tale of vindicated honor to tell. While, therefore, we retain the impression conveyed by the first rumor of the business -- an impression extremely unfavorable to the military skill and good judgment of those who ordered and conducted the unfortunate expedition, it is only reasonable to suspend a final opinion until the officers have made their defence.

abstract: A correspondence with the United States Government upon the subject of blockade has been laid before Parliament.
lead_paragraph: A correspondence with the United States Government upon the subject of blockade has been laid before Parliament. The first communication from Lord LYONS to Lord JOHN RUSSELL transmits a copy of a note from the Secretary of State of the United States, communicating copies of the President's Proclamation declaring a blockade of the ports of States of South Carolina, Georgia, Alabama, Florida, Louisiana, Mississippi and Texas. This Proclamation declares the letters-of-marque and authorization of the seceded States to be insufficient to protect anybody acting under them from the penalties of the laws for the prevention of piracy.

abstract: The meeting of the Convention, now in session at Wheeling, is an event of historical importance to the State of Virginia. It promises to provide a temporary Government for
lead_paragraph: The meeting of the Convention, now in session at Wheeling, is an event of historical importance to the State of Virginia. It promises to provide a temporary Government for the State, to perform those functions, so far as may be, which its Executive treasonably abandoned by practically giving all authority into the hands of the leaders of the Southern rebellion, who have established a military despotism over the Commonwealth. Probably not more than a fourth of the counties are represented; but this paucity of representation is due alone to the military rule which has prevented the loyal citizens of other sections of the State from uniting and selecting delegates.

abstract: There was one circumstance in the startling tidings, communicated the other day from Washington, that Mr. BURLINGAME was rejected as our representative to the Austrian
lead_paragraph: There was one circumstance in the startling tidings, communicated the other day from Washington, that Mr. BURLINGAME was rejected as our representative to the Austrian Court which caused the announcement to wear a wholly incomprehensible air. Mr. Burlingame had not then reached Vienna! This was calculated to suggest that there must be a false bottom to this diplomatic drawer; and a telegram from our Washington correspondent this morning puts us in possession of several facts which furnish the elements of a hypothesis that will account for this nice bit of diplomacy by motives much nearer home than those assigned as prompting that pretended act.

abstract: The course of Gov. JACKSON'S ture love does not run smooth. Missouri is likely, in spite of all his ardor and industry, to remain snugly wedged in that angle of the Union of which Iowa and Illinois are the sides.
lead_paragraph: -- The course of Gov. JACKSON's true love does not run smooth. Missouri is likely, in spite of all his ardor and industry, to remain snugly wedged in that angle of the Union of which Iowa and Illinois are the sides. His financial expedients have failed him; arms are not to be had without money; soldiers cannot be had without arms; and in all his paths he meets the inevitable LYON. Having exhausted intrigue at Jefferson City, he has resorted to negotiation at St. Louis. His negotiations have had the same fate as his intrigues. Gen. LYON will concede nothing that can promote the plans of the Governor. The utmost he will do to gratify the disappointed officer is to guarantee him for a fortnight against arrest as a traitor.

abstract: Intelligent Union men here assign two reasons for the non-advance of Gen. PATTERSON'S division. First, that the Legislature is in session at Frederick, and that a column from Washington must come by that route. They hope that the Legislature will adjourn this week, and the Government desires to keep the troops out of Maryland until after the Congressional election to-morrow.

abstract: THE NEW-JERSEY REGIMENTS. The three NewJersey regiments now encamped at Trenton have received orders from the General Government to prepare themselves with all diligence for active duty.
lead_paragraph: THE NEW-JERSEY REGIMENTS. -- The three NewJersey regiments now encamped at Trenton have received orders from the General Government to prepare themselves with all diligence for active duty. The uniforms, which are being made at Newark, will be completed next week. The equipments of these regiments, it is said, will be as complete as that of any regiment that has yet gone to the seat of war. Some of the companies have not yet their complement of men, as all who were enlisted did not pass inspection, and a few refused to take the oath for three years. In addition to the regular United States pay, the State pays $6 per month to married men, and $4 per month to single men. Lieut. EVANS, of Co. J, is now receiving recruits at his office in Hoboken. The citizens of Hoboken have raised a monthly subscription, to be paid in weekly installments, to the families of needy soldiers, who have enlisted in the service of the United States from that city, whether in New-Jersey or other regiments.

abstract: THE NEW-JERSEY REGIMENTS The three NewJersey regiments now encamped at Trenton have recevied orders from the General Government to prepare themselves with all diligences for active duty.
lead_paragraph: THE NEW-JERSEY REGIMENTS. -- The three NewJersey regiments now encamped at Trenton have recevied orders from the General Government to prepare themselves with all diligences for active duty. The uniforms, which are being made at Newark, will be completed next week. The equipments of these regiments, it is said, will be as complete as that of any regiment that has yet gone to the seat of war. Some of the companies have not yet their complement of men, as all who were enlisted did not pass inspection, and a few refused to take the oath for three years. In addition to the regular United States pay, the State pays $6 per month to married men, and $4 per month to single men. Lieut. EVANS, of Co. J. is now receiving recruits at his office in Hoboken. The citizens of Hoboken have raised a monthly subscription, to be paid in weekly installments, to the families of needy soldiers, who have enlisted in the service of the United States from that city, whether in New-Jersey or other regiments.

abstract: Paymaster-Col. VAN BUREN paid off, on behalf of the State of New-York, the Sixth Regiment Volunteers, Col. WILLIAM WILSON, yesterday. The amount was $9,330,144. In order to facilitate the departure of the regiment, Col. VAN BUREN gave the Paymaster of WILSON's Zouaves a letter to the Broadway, Park.
lead_paragraph: Paymaster-Col. VAN BUREN paid off, on behalf of the State of New-York, the Sixth Regiment Volunteers, Col. WILLIAM WILSON, yesterday. The amount was $9,330,144. In order to facilitate the departure of the regiment, Col. VAN BUREN gave the Paymaster of WILSON's Zouaves a letter to the Broadway, Park, and Manhattan Banks, and to the Union Defence Committee, asking them to cash the order on the Comptroller of the State, so as to save the Paymaster a journey to Albany. Neither of the banks, nor the Union Defence Committee, had patriotism enough to do so, though it would only have been loaning the money for eighteen, or twenty-four hours at the furthest; consequently, the poor men have to leave this City without a cent of money in their pockets.

abstract: The telegraphic operator stationed at Martinsburgh, and a brakeman on the Baltimore and Ohio day. The latter says the furtherest bridge burnt was over the North Branch, 5 miles east of Cumberland;
lead_paragraph: The telegraphic operator stationed at Martinsburgh, and a brakeman on the Baltimore and Ohio day. The latter says the furtherest bridge burnt was over the North Branch, 5 miles east of Cumberland; the next over Patterson's Creek; the next at Sleepy Creek, 17 miles west of Martinsburgh, and the next over the Obequeon, two miles east of Martinsburgh There will be no trouble in building the first, but some with the last, which is 100 feet wide, with no arch, and 90 feet above the water. Gen. JOHNSTON ordered the Obequeon bridge to be rebuilt, but it was not accomplished.

abstract: The letter of Ex-Secretary HOLT, which is given in another column, is that expression of genuine Kentucky loyalty for which, until this moment, we have waited hopelessly. It is an echo of that ardent patriotic feeling which it was feared had expired with HENRY CLAY. A large number of the people of that State have undoubtedly yielded to the superficial but subtle logic of secession, and only desire an opportunity to make their secret treason overt. The so called Union men, with violent demonstrations of affection for the Union, the Constitution and the laws, have declared their intention to leave the work of vindicating and restoring them to other hands, with the threat of active hostility to the Government if it attempt to march to the holy war across the soil of Kentucky. From, such protestations of dangerous allegiance and menacing fealty we may turn with satisfaction faction to the full-hearted and courageous declarations of Mr. HOLT; and we trust that, when they have reached the masses of the Kentucky population, they will rekindle a patriotic triotic sentiment, nearly extinguished by the treason of the seditious, and the cowardice of the pretended friends of the Union.

abstract: Sylvester Brush vs. Hezekiah Kohn The plaintiff in this action is the owner of the premises No. 68 Broadway, in this City the defendant his lessee.
lead_paragraph: Sylvester Brush vs. Hezekiah Kohn -- The plaintiff in this action is the owner of the premises No. 68 Broadway, in this City -- the defendant his lessee. On the 1st of May, 1859, the plaintiff let and hired to the defendant, for the period of one year, the premises in question, for a sum certain, which, it is alleged, defendant has failed to meet, the amount alleged to be due being $600. The defendant scouts the idea of being indebted to the plaintiff in any such amount, and alleges a tender of the amount he thought due the plaintiff. One of the principal defences, however, in this case, is the allegation of eviction. It seems that there is a water-closet upon the premises, from which defendant alleges he was evicted, being prevented from the full use, occupation, and enjoyment thereef. All this resulted in much annoyance and inconvenience to him. He therefore thinks it but just and proper that, in consideration of his sufferings and the damage he has sustained, he should not be called upon for the whole amount due on his rent. The case is still on.

abstract: The correspondent of the London Times, in the South, presents, in his betters, some phases of Southern opinion which are not familiar to the people of the North, nor do we believe that they have any substancial existence in fact.
lead_paragraph: The correspondent of the London Times, in the South, presents, in his betters, some phases of Southern opinion which are not familiar to the people of the North, nor do we believe that they have any substancial existence in fact. How far he may have been deceived by his surface intercourse with the "gentlemen planters" of the seceded States, or how far their "elegant hospitality" may have influenced his calmer judgment, we have no means of knowing; but this much we think we may safely assert, that whatever the views or sentiments of the aristocratic few in some of these States may be, the idea of a "Constitutional monarchy" has no place in the thoughts of the people. Faith in republican institutions, in the democratic principle, is as much a fixed and permanent fact in the minds of the Southern masses, as in any other portion of the Union. However the fallacy of a primary allegiance to their States may have overcome their loyalty to the Republic, yet the theory of their revolt is based in no respect upon a present or remote return to monarchical rule. That idea, outside of South Carolina at all events, is entirely obsolete in the American mind. The Union may, at some remote period, but not now, be shattered into petty States; but when that time comes, and this great Republic shall be severed, each fragment, as it falls, will be a Republic -- weak and feeble it may be, but still a Republic. Chaos and confusion may prevail, and the reign of demagogues be substituted in the place of legitimate authority, but whatever of gangrene and rottenness there may be in the substance, the form will still be republican. They may be cursed as a large portion of the South is to-day, with a terrorism, under a vitiated popular sentiment mightier than constitutions, more powerful than legislative enactments; a despotism that crushes freedom of speech, of opinion and action; but the pretence of its usurpations will be the maintenance of democratic liberty, the defence of republican institutions.

abstract: We publish in another column the more important of the communications referred to by the Foreign Minister on Tuesday night as having been received from Lord LYONS and the Federal Government.
lead_paragraph: We publish in another column the more important of the communications referred to by the Foreign Minister on Tuesday night as having been received from Lord LYONS and the Federal Government. From this correspondence it is abundantly clear that Mr. LINCOLN and his colleagues, in issuing the notifications of blockade of the 19th and 27th of April, and in furnishing instructions to the commanders of the blockading squadron, are under the impression that they have done all that is required by the law of nations, and that all violators of the blockade after this warning, must take the consequence of their own acts. The resources of the Federal Government would seem to be sufficient to institute an efficient blockade of most of the Southern ports, and we shall probably soon hear that the blockade is complete. By the last advices, we learn that, on the 14th of the present month, gunboats were stationed off the months of the James, Elizabeth, and York Rivers; off Fort Monroe; and at the opening of Chesapeake Bay; while it is stated that the ports of Florida have been under blockade since the 6th inst. The cruisers of the Federal Government have been at active as need be. Several seizures have been already made and reported. On the 14th, the Argo was captured in Chesapeake Bay, coming from Richmond with a cargo of tobacco, valued at $150,000. This prize fell to the lot of the gunboat Quaker City. The Crusader has seized the Wanderer off Key West, and the United States ship Yankee is reported as having been off Cape Hetlopen with no less than three steamers in charge. These prizes are all, it is believed, American vessels, and we do not find that there is any disposition to molest the neutral flag anywhere, or on any pretence. It is to be observed, moreover, that all the seizures so far have been made by the cruisers of the Federal Government. The authority conveyed in President DAVIS' proclamation, and confirmed by the Southern Congress to it out vessels under letters-of-marque and reprisal, does not seem, so far, at least, to have enabled those who have obtained such letters to protect the shipping of the South, much less to encounter anywhere the blockading squadron. This is the more strange, seeing that applications are said to have been made for letters-of-marque from the shipowners of New-England, the whalers of New-Bedford, and elsewhere in the Northern State -- persons, we should say, who would be able to fit out a most effective and formidable fleet of privateers.

abstract: The United States vs. The Bark Sarah, c. This is a libel of condemnation, field against the bark Sarah, under the acts of 1794 and 1818, for fitting up for the Slave-trade. The versel was seized in this port under suspicious circumstances, and the District
lead_paragraph: The United States vs. The Bark Sarah, &c. -- This is a libel of condemnation, field against the bark Sarah, under the acts of 1794 and 1818, for fitting up for the Slave-trade. The versel was seized in this port under suspicious circumstances, and the District Attorney brought this suit to forfeit her to the Government. Joshua Cullard, the claimant, alleges that the vessel was going on a legitimate voyage, and that she had no lumber on board, or anything else, to show that she was destined for the illegal traffic. The case is still on.

abstract: John M. Cebellos vs. Augustus Schell This was an action to recover back constructive storage, amounting to $350, paid on a shipment of goods. It appears that where a party has entered goods to go into the Bonded Warehouse, and desires to withdraw
lead_paragraph: John M. Cebellos vs. Augustus Schell. -- This was an action to recover back constructive storage, amounting to $350, paid on a shipment of goods. It appears that where a party has entered goods to go into the Bonded Warehouse, and desires to withdraw them for consumption or exportation before actually having gone into the Bonded Warehouse, the privilege has been granted upon the payment of half a month's storage. Since 1854 the United States have had no bonded warehouses, and have had no interest in the storage, but the exaction of this half a month's storage has been continued, and the money paid into the United States Treasury. This was the pioneer case of several brought to recover bank storage, paid under similar circumstances, and the total amount involved is very large. The Judge ordered a verdict in favor of the plaintiff, subject to the opinion of the Court. The argument will be heard on Thursday.

abstract: There are in this City and its vicinity probably ten thousand men enlisted and organized into fragments
lead_paragraph: -- There are in this City and its vicinity probably ten thousand men enlisted and organized into fragments of regiments, who might fee mustered, at once into active service, and forwarded to Washington. The men are willing to go. They are ready and anxious to take part in the stirring events which seem so near at band. The Government wants them, is ready to receive and place them on active duty. The difficulty appears to be with the commanders of these organizations, who are unwilling to forego the prospects of service when their commands shall, as they hope perhaps they soon will be, full. We do not intend to be understood as censuring them in the slightest degree. We appreciate their honorable ambition, but we suggest whether, in the present crisis, patriotism and the public good do not require that some of them shall stand aside, and permit these imperfect regiments to be consolidated. The companies formed under different field-officers might be brought together, making as many regiments as the enlistments already made would fill, and could thus be enabled to go forward to take part in the battles which in all probability are soon to be fought. These ten thousand men would be a valuable reinforcement to Government forces now in the field, but in their present condition are entirely useless, and likely to remain so for weeks to come.

lead_paragraph: "On yesterday morning some 600 soldiers most of them Louisianians, lately from Pensacola, arrived at our depot. Quite a number of them came into town, and seeing Gov. FOOTE concluded, a large body of citizens, in addition to the soldiers, had joined the assemblage.

abstract: The people of Louisiana are particularly enraged about the blockade. That "LINCOLN, SEWARD Co.'s pigmy squardron" should flout the Star-spangled Banner right
lead_paragraph: The people of Louisiana are particularly enraged about the blockade. That "LINCOLN, SEWARD & CO.'s pigmy squardron" should flout the Star-spangled Banner right at the Balize, and almost within sight of the Crescent City, is most intolerable, and not to be endured -- if, indeed, they could only help it. The New-Orleans Crescent of the 5th inst. gives vent to its feelings. It is wroth because the "Commander of the Brooklyn has been graciously pleased to allow" but very limited water privilege to the buccaneers of the Gulf; and is grievously mortified at the thought that "one solitary steamer can dictate terms to the Southern Confederacy; but finally consoles its readers with the cheerful thought that "there ought to have been a sufficient force within the Military Department of Louisiana to have blown this Brooklyn out of the water on her first appearance."

abstract: A REJECTED VOLUNTEER HANDS HIMSELF Yesterday morning a man presented himself at a Recruiting-office in Tammany Hall and wanted to enroll his name as a volunteer.
lead_paragraph: A REJECTED VOLUNTEER HANDS HIMSELF -- Yesterday morning a man presented himself at a Recruiting-office in Tammany Hall and wanted to enroll his name as a volunteer. As his height was only five feet four inches, which is below the standard, he could not be taken. He went away, remarking that he must do something for a living, and soon afterwards he was found hanging by the neck, in a corner of the yard, to a nail in the wall. He was not dead when taken down, but he survived only a few minutes. Deceased is supposed to have recently come from Philadelphia. He was about 25 years of age, bad dark hair, and wore a dark woolen jacket, blue overall, and black pants. A wallet containing same small change was found upon him, and a business card with the name and address -- "THOMAS RIEDY, horse shoe nail shop, rear of No. 120 Spruce-street, Philadelphia." Colonel JACKMAN held an inquest.

abstract: J. Blankman, deceased. After the proponents had closed their evidence, the contestants, before resting their case, called Thomas C. Fields, late Public Administrator, who testified that in the early part of June, 1860, Mrs. Blankman called upon him for the purpose of getting his advice as to whether she had...
lead_paragraph: J. Blankman, deceased. -- After the proponents had closed their evidence, the contestants, before resting their case, called Thomas C. Fields, late Public Administrator, who testified that in the early part of June, 1860, Mrs. Blankman called upon him for the purpose of getting his advice as to whether she had a good title to the house in Thirty-fourth-street, occupied by her, and also for the purpose of getting him to draw her will. He asked her if she had ever made a will, in reply to which she stated that she had some years before; that in that will she left her property to her family, and that she did not wish to make any material change in her will. She appointed a day for bringing down that will for Mr. Field to examine before drawing another for her. She did not come again at the appointed time, and that he never saw her afterwards.

abstract: The marine guards for two men or war arived in this City on Wednesday evening remained over night at the Brooklyn Barracks, and yet next day for Portsmouth, N.H.
lead_paragraph: The marine guards for two men or war arived in this City on Wednesday evening remained over night at the Brooklyn Barracks, and yet next day for Portsmouth, N.H. They were sent from the National Capital to go on board the sailing corvettes Dale and Marion, which were preparing for sea at Kittery. These vessels were both last attached to the African Squadron. The Dale sunk, at her wharf some time since, but has been raised and caulked.

abstract: The Twentieth Regiment of New-York Volunteers, known as the United Turner Rifles, Col. MAX WAGER commanding, took its departure yesterday for the [???] of war. Major-Gen. BUTLER is to have the benefit of this fire body of men. Their destination is Fortress Monroe, where they will join many hundreds of their country men who are fighting bravely beneath the flag of the Union. The Regiment, we regret to state has been treated parsimoniously both by the State authorities and the Union Defence Committee. From the former they received common muskets instead of rifles -- the Germans pet speciality; from the latter, $5 000. Had it not been for the patriotic contributions of German citizens, the Regiment would still be languishing in the City.

abstract: One nation often serves as a mirror which reflects to another dispositions which, from prudential motives have long been suppressed or concealed.
lead_paragraph: One nation often serves as a mirror which reflects to another dispositions which, from prudential motives have long been suppressed or concealed. It is not pleasant to tell Mr. So-and-so, to his face, our opinion of him, especially so long as he is our equal in position and power. But when we believe him to have fallen, we are outspoken in proportion to our supposed immunity. In this way, the crisis in America has unmasked England as nothing else could. Her ruling classes believed that the final dissolution of the great Republic was accomplished. The eagerness with which this was proclaimed showed the wish to be father to the belief. Our institutions were denounced -- "the best of them," says the London Times, "having gone all wrong for a long time past:" the character of our people was caricatured and vilified; and the contest in which we are engaged stigmatized as an unprincipled struggle for territorial aggrandizement. Not the slightest sympathy was expressed for us in our great strait, when it seemed for a moment that we might go down; nor for the cause for which we were fighting -- the rights of humanity and a Constitutional Government. England stood by, not an indifferent spectator, but eager to witness a final dissolution that would rid her of a hated commercial rival, and stamp as utterly impracticable those institutions which for a long time have threatened to subvert her own. Thank Heaven, our Government is not dead, or dissolved. What was to have been the fatal blow has only given to it new life and power. What was valuable in its institutions is to exert a tenfold greater influence than ever. A giant stands for the fallen victim, confronting his libeler face to face. Whatever may be the result, the entente cordiale is completely severed, not to be restored, till a new sentiment and a new Government in England shall supplant the old. The lowest of all qualities has that country displayed -- jealousy of a child, whom she would crush rather than suffer to exist as a rival. Henceforth the two countries will stand as antagonists in ideas and in aims. The peace between them will be that of an armed neutrality. Her historical relation toward us has been that of an arrogant superior. We have long tried to outgrow the sense of the insults and injuries we have received, and had hoped we had succeeded, but the last is the unkindest cut of all. It dispels our illusions of the possibility of a hearty friendship with her, and shows that we must look elsewhere for friends in fighting the battle of humanity.
headline: {'main': 'English Misrepresentations of America.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'English Misrepresentations of America.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: It is said that earnest and serious souls among Americans have felt, these latter years, when abroad, as though they were without a country. That feeling of orphanage, thank Heaven, is now forever ended; and there is a profound and almost pathetic fervor in the voice of the heart which has come over the sea from the sons of America now sojourning in Paris.
lead_paragraph: It is said that earnest and serious souls among Americans have felt, these latter years, when abroad, as though they were without a country. That feeling of orphanage, thank Heaven, is now forever ended; and there is a profound and almost pathetic fervor in the voice of the heart which has come over the sea from the sons of America now sojourning in Paris. Placed at a distance -- and distance has that same insulating quality possessed by Time -- the issue rises before them with true historical clearness as "a wanton outbreak, aiming at the destruction of a Government that has accomplished so much for humanity;" and Col. FREMONT -- in a speech through which one sees glowing a deep central flame of feeling, though a flame tempered and restrained, as it were -- uttered the sentiment of the whole assemblage when he said: "We shall not permit them to dishonor our flag and desecrate our sacred graves. They cannot be permitted to dismember our country and destroy our nationality. We shall maintain these in their fullest integrity, and in the face of every evil and at every hazard. Above every consideration is our country -- as we have learned to love it -- one and indivisible, now and forever -- and so we will maintain it; we will do our duty loyally, and we will make no compromise with treason, and no surrender to rebellion."
headline: {'main': 'The Americans in Paris.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Americans in Paris.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: No fresh movement of troops has yet taken place at Washington. The President yesterday went over the Potomac and reviewed several of the regiments now intrenched in Virginia. A rumor prevailed in the afternoon that Gen. BEAUREGARD, at the head of the rebels, was about to make a demonstration from Manassas Gap Junction, but this, like all recent reports relative to BEAREGARD, had no foundation in fact.

abstract: Marshall P. Wilder et al. vs. Wm. G. Lane et al. -- This action was brought to recover for goods sold and delivered by Parker, Wilder & Co., a Boston firm, to Lane, Boyce & Co., a New York firm, in July and August, 1860. The plaintiffs claim a special contract in each sale, by which the defendants were to give their notes at eight months for the goods purchased, at the end of each month when the purchase was made. The defendants deny any special contract as to the time of giving the notes. Two receipts were produced to show that the usual course of business between them and the plaintiffs was to give their notes, on demand of the plaintiffs, at the expiration of the business season, for goods purchased during the season. The plaintiffs, in reply, produce a receipt for a note given Sept. 24, 1858, for goods bought Aug. 28 preceding, and allege no such usage between them.
lead_paragraph: Marshall P. Wilder et al. vs. Wm. G. Lane et al. -- This action was brought to recover for goods sold and delivered by Parker, Wilder & Co., a Boston firm, to Lane, Boyce & Co., a New York firm, in July and August, 1860. The defendants deny any special contract as to the time of giving the notes. Two receipts were produced to show that the usual course of business between them and the plaintiffs was to give their notes, on demand of the plaintiffs, at the expiration of the business season, for goods purchased during the season. The plaintiffs, in reply, produce a receipt for a note given Sept. 24, 1858, for goods bought Aug. 28 preceding, and allege no such usage between them.

abstract: In my last letter I gave an account of such matters as passed under my notice on my way to this city, which I reached, as you are aware, on the night of Saturday, May 4.
lead_paragraph: In my last letter I gave an account of such matters as passed under my notice on my way to this city, which I reached, as you are aware, on the night of Saturday, May 4. I am on difficult ground, the land is on fire, the earth is shaking with the tramp of armed men, and the very air is hot with passion. Mty communications are cut off, or are at best accidental, and in order to reopen them I must get further away from them, paradoxical as the statement may appear to be. It is impossible to know what is going on at the North, and almost the same to learn what is doing in the South out of eyeshot; it is useless to inquire what news is sent to you to England. The telegraphic communications are now broken, so are all the mall routes. Newspapers and letters now and then reach well-known people here from New-York in six or seven days. Events hurry on with tremendous rapidity, and even the lightning lags behind them. The people of the South at last are aware that the "Yankees" are preparing to support the Government of the United States, and that the secession can only be maintained by victory in the field. There has been a change in their war policy. They now aver that 'they only want to be left alone,' and they declare they do not intend to take Washington, and that it was merely as a feint they spoke about it. The fact is, there are even in the compact and United South men of moderate and men of extreme views, and the general tone of the whole is regulated by the preponderance of the one or the other at the moment. I have no doubt on my mind that the Government here intended to attack and occupy Washington -- not the least that they had it much at heart to reduce Fort Pickets as soon as possible. Now some of their fritnos say that it will be a mere matter of convenience whether they attack Washington or not, and that as for Fort Pickens, they will certainly let it alone, at all events, for the present, inasmuch as the menacing attitude of Gen. BRAGG obliges the enemy to keep a squadron of their best ships there, and to retain a force of regulars they can ill spare in a position, where they must to in lose enormously from diseases incidental to the climate. They have discovered, too, that the position is of little value so long as the United States hold Tortugas and Key West. Out the Conferences are preparing for the conflict, and when they have organized their forces, they will make, I am satisfied, a very resolute advance all along the line. They are, at present, strong enough, they suppose, in their domestic resources, and in the difficulties presented to the advance of a hostile force by the nature of the country, to bill defiance to invasion, or, at all events, to inflict a very severe chastisement on the invaders, and their excited manner of speech so acts upon their minds that they begin to think that they can defy, not merely the United States, but the world. Thus it is that they declare they never can be conquered, that they will die to a man, woman and chilo first; and that if fifty thousand, or any number of thousands, of Black Republicans get one hundred miles into Virginia, not one of them shall ever get out alive. Behind all this talk, however, there is immense energy, great resolution, and fixed principles of action. Their strategy consists in keeping quiet till they have their troops well in hand, in such numbers and discipline as shall give them fair grounds for expecting success in any campaign with the United States troops. They are preparing with vigor to render the descent of the Mississippi imposible, by erecting batteries on the commanding levees or embankments which hem in its waters for upwards of eight hundred miles of bank, and they are occupying, as far as they can, all the strategical points of attack, or defence within their borders. When everything is ready, it is not improbable that Mr. JEFFERSON DAVIS will take the command of the army, for he is reported to have a high ambition to acquire reputation as a General, and in virtue of his office he is Generalissimo of the armies of the Confederate States. It will be remarked that this plan tress upon the assumption that the United States cannot or will not wage an offensive war, or obtain any success in their attempts to recover the forts and other property of the Federal Government. They firmly believe the war will not last a year, and that 1862 will behold a victorious, compact slaveholding confederate Power of fifteen States, under a strong Government, prepared to hold its own against the world, or that portion of it which may attack it. I now but repeat the sentiments and expectations of those around me. They believe in the irresistible power of cotton in the natural alliance between manufacturing England and France and the cotton producing Slave States, in the force of their simple tariff, and in the interests which arise out of a system of free trade, which, however, by a rigorous legislation they will interdict to their neighbors in the Free States, and only open for the benefit of their foreign customers. Commercially, and politically, and militarily, they have made up their minds, and never was there such confidence exhibited by any people in the future as they have, or pretend to have, in their destiny. Listen to their programme.

abstract: It is a great satisfaction to find that Gov. JACKSON, of Missouri, is, after all, a friend of the Union and the Constitution. To set doubt at Test, he has issued a proclamation which clearly defines the opinions of himself and his immediate environment upon this point. The Union is to be preserved -- the Constitution is to be obeyed -- the laws of the United States are to be respected. Thus much is net gain, and we may be thankful for it.

abstract: The fact that Kentucky has so long remained in the Union, despite the bad examples of Virginia and Tennessee, and despite the industrious machinations of Gov. MAGOFFIN and Vice-President BRECKINRIDGE to involve her people in the treasonable Confederation of JEFF. DAVIS, is prima facie evidence of a remarkable soundness of political sentiment.
lead_paragraph: The fact that Kentucky has so long remained in the Union, despite the bad examples of Virginia and Tennessee, and despite the industrious machinations of Gov. MAGOFFIN and Vice-President BRECKINRIDGE to involve her people in the treasonable Confederation of JEFF. DAVIS, is prima facie evidence of a remarkable soundness of political sentiment. Every State that has "seceded" has yielded to less than a tithe of the temptation that Kentucky has successfully withstood. And it is because of these well-known facts to her credit that we have been disposed to consider with the greatest leniency the position taken by the land of HENRY CLAY, in the present emergency of the Union.

abstract: In the Matter of the Application of Sylvester Murray. -- Sylvester Murray, an interesting looking infact, with a countenance indicative of meekness and long-suffering, having aspired beyond his years to perform service for his Uncle Samuel, as a high private in the regular army was rescued by his mother on a writ of habeas corpus from the performance of any such rash design. His Honor thinking that his infancy afforded a sufficient plea for his liberation from any further duty, restored him to his mother's arms, and they twain departed in peace.
lead_paragraph: In the Matter of the Application of Sylvester Murray. -- Sylvester Murray, an interesting looking infact, with a countenance indicative of meekness and long-suffering, having aspired beyond his years to perform service for his Uncle Samuel, as a high private in the regular army was rescued by his mother on a writ of habeas corpus from the performance of any such rash design. abstract: IRVING HALL. -- Mrs. PAGE, a lady well known to the world of art and literature, although a comparative stranger to the public, gave an agreeable entertainment at this establishment last evening, reading with Mr. J.B. BROWN, a number of well-known pieces. Elocution is a thing so little studied in the present day, that we welcome with more than ordinary warmth, any aspirant to public fame who seems to regard it conscientiously as an essential part of an artistic education. Mrs. PAGE is gifted with a pleasing voice, which is yet imperfectly weeded of certain sharpnesses, but seems susceptible of a wide range of melodious inflection. She reads with intelligence, and in her action is unrestrained and graceful. The stage is evidently her proper sphere, as indeed it is her only one. We are persuaded that with proper discipline and industry, Mrs. PAGE would speedily become a leading attraction to a Metropolitan manager. As it is, she starts well, and has certainly made a good impression.

abstract: It will be recollected that the Legislature of this State ad pled a resolution recommending a Convention of the Bankers of the Concederate State.
lead_paragraph: It will be recollected that the Legislature of this State ad pled a resolution recommending a Convention of the Bankers of the Concederate State. The recommendation was accepted to some extent, and delegates assembled at Atlanta, Ga., on June 2, from two of the Tennessee Banks; nine of the Georgia Banks; one of the Alabama Banks; one of the Florida Banks, and eight of the South Carolina Banks.

abstract: Wynter S. Bond vs. James C. Willett.--This action was brought against the defendant as Sheriff c., of the City and Country of New-York. The plaintiff seeks to recover the possession or valve of a quantity of silks alleged to have been taken by the Sheriff, but which were imperfectly levied upon.
lead_paragraph: Wynter S. Bond vs. James C. Willett. -- This action was brought against the defendant as Sheriff c., of the City and Country of New-York. The plaintiff seeks to recover the possession or valve of a quantity of silks alleged to have been taken by the Sheriff, but which were imperfectly levied upon. The defendant denies the plaintiff's title, and claims that the silks are legally in his possession, by virtue of a levy thereon, made on the 27th of August, 1856, under an execution issued out of this Court in favor of Frederick A. Conkling and others, against Remsen & Dingee, merchants in this City, having their store at Nos. 204 and 206 Sixth-avenue. Mr. Bensel, the Deputy-Sheriff, who made the levy, testified that the proceeded to the band made the levy notwithstanding Mr. Dingee's objections, he wishing to see his lawyer. Deputy Bensel told Dingee to seen his lawyer to the Sheriff's office, and proceeded to make the levy, making a memorandum of the inventory, which was read in evidence. This memorandum, or inventory, the Deputy put inside of the execution; an indorsement was also made on the execution.

abstract: Now that we Americans have given vent to our national indignation and disgust at the time-serving utterances of certain English
lead_paragraph: Now that we Americans have given vent to our national indignation and disgust at the time-serving utterances of certain English statesmen and English Presses, in behalf of the Cotton State rebellion, we can afford to let the matter drop. We may depend on it that the self-interest, as well as the moral convictions, of all the enlightened nations of the earth, will prevent them from ultimately taking any active part with the Pro-Slavery conspiracy that now threatens to destroy our Union. That England should have seized the passing opportunity to make herself disagreeable to a people with whom she has twice been in conflict, without either honor or profit, might have been expected. But that her rulers are ready to hazard a war with the United States Government, when the result will be merely to show a sympathy with human Slavery, should never have been anticipated. It is simply absurd, and will not happen. We may go on with our blockade and with our fighting, without fear of England's intervention against us.
headline: {'main': 'English Intervention Impossible.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'English Intervention Impossible.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The news of the evacuation of Harper's Ferry by the rebels was received at the War Department to-day about 12 o'clock. They went away with baggage down the road to Winchester, destroying all they could not carry, and, like a steam-plow, taking up the railroad track and burning the bridges as they run.

abstract: -- The Southern Confederacy says, that "on no ground, as yet has the foul invader dared to venture where their enraged and burning soldiery can meet him in fair and open fight." The experiences at Grafton, Phillippa, Romney and Harper's Ferry demonstrate that their "enraged and burning soldiery" are so much better at retreating than the Federal troops are at marching, as not to afford an opportunity for a "fair field and open fight."
lead_paragraph: -- The Southern Confederacy says, that "on no ground, as yet has the foul invader dared to venture where their enraged and burning soldiery can meet him in fair and open fight." The experiences at Grafton, Phillippa, Romney and Harper's Ferry demonstrate that their "enraged and burning soldiery" are so much better at retreating than the Federal troops are at marching, as not to afford an opportunity for a "fair field and open fight."

abstract: The approaching session of Congress should be as brief as possible, and to that end the business to be submitted for its consideration should be digested and condensed in advance.
lead_paragraph: The approaching session of Congress should be as brief as possible, and to that end the business to be submitted for its consideration should be digested and condensed in advance. The events which have called them together are so recent and familiar, that the members can scarcely fail to comprehend at once the most important duties to be required of them, and will so be prepared for their prompt discharge. The times demand vigorous action, looking to immediate results, and not to speculation or experiment. Money in large amounts must be provided. The Navy must be increased, the Army enlarged. These are primary necessities which everybody understands, and about which no lengthened discussion will be necessary. They should be first in order, and the enactments called for in regard to them should be promptly made. After these will come a general bankruptcy law, the passage of which is suggested in many quarters as among the imperative duties of the session. A modification of the revenue laws will probably be asked for, and will have to be considered.

abstract: Walter S. Bond vs. Jas. C. Wallett, Sheriff, &c. -- This case, which was reported in THE TIMES of yesterday, was decided as follows: "The levy made by the Sheriff on the goods in the store was sufficient in the first instance to entitle him to hold the property against third persons. The stay of proceedings granted on the day after the levy, and which continued in force until the goods were replevied by the plaintiff in the action, prevented the Sheriff from taking any further steps to enforce such levy, and prevents any conclusion of abandonment of the levy by the Sheriff. The judgment must be affirmed, with costs."

abstract: A correspondent informs us that during a sums of money that the National Government dare not hang a traitor.
lead_paragraph: A correspondent informs us that during recent visit to Washington, he was present at a party of gentlemen who offered to bet heavy sums of money that the National Government dare not hang a traitor. He declares, further, on information derived during the same visit, that shipments of arms, provisions, &c., for the South, are constantly taking place in Northern ports, and especially in New-York, mainly, by way of Baltimore, Cincinnati and St. Louis. And he expresses the opinion, moreover, that the Government is not even yet fairly awake to the fact that it is engaged in a life-and-death struggle, and that the only way to crush treason is by hanging the traitors.

abstract: We ventured, in our edition of the 4th inst., to suggest to Gen. BUTLER the certainty that he would find, along the old road leading from
lead_paragraph: We ventured, in our edition of the 4th inst., to suggest to Gen. BUTLER the certainty that he would find, along the old road leading from Hampton, through Yorktown and Williamsburgh, to Richmond, a well-planned and well-garrisoned redoubt, or some other earth-work, with a strong profile, at every available point on his march. We ventured further to intimate that there were more roads than one by which his division could operate upon the Capital of Virginia, and to allude to the cost, in men and time, necessary to attack and take those positions as too great to justify the expenditure.

abstract: THE SUSPICIOUS DEATH IN OLIVER-STREET. Coroner SCHIRMER help an inquest, yesterday, at No. 43 Oliver-street, upon the body of CATHARINE CRAWFORD, an Irishwoman, 25 years of age, who died on
lead_paragraph: THE SUSPICIOUS DEATH IN OLIVER-STREET. -- Coroner SCHIRMER help an inquest, yesterday, at No. 43 Oliver-street, upon the body of CATHARINE CRAWFORD, an Irishwoman, 25 years of age, who died on Thursday forenoon under circumstances leading to a belief that she had been violently treated by JOHN CRAWPORD. her husband. Several witnesses testified, but neither was able to swea that deceased had been thrown down stairs, although such was the general impression. The jury declared that she came to her death from injuries received by filling down a flight of stairs, at the house No. 43 Oliver street, June 12, 1861. From the testimony the jury is unable to say how or in what manner the fall was occasioned.

lead_paragraph: The telegraph has announced the appointment by Gov. YATES, OF Illinois, O.H. BROWNING, Esq., to fill the vacancy in the United States Senate, caused by the death of Senator DOUGLAS. Mr. BEOWNING has been for many years a resident of the City of Quincy. He is by profession a counselor at law, and he occupies a place in the front rank of the practioners of Illinois. His name was recently brought prominently before the country by his able defence of Mrs. BURCH, in the trial of that well-known divorce suit, he being the senior counsel of the defendant.

abstract: Rumor for once has been right. The varions indications which have pointed to a speedy evacu ation of Harper's Ferry by the rebels have proved
lead_paragraph: Rumor for once has been right. The varions indications which have pointed to a speedy evacu ation of Harper's Ferry by the rebels have proved reliable, and that place is now ready for the occupation of Gen. PATTERSON's troops. On Thursday evening all the outlying pickets of the rebels were called in by Gen. JOHNSON, the men were recalled from the Maryland side, and preparations were made for a speedy retirement. Between 4 and 5 o'clock yesterday morning -- trains having for some time been laid for that purpose -- the bridge across the Potomac leading to Harper's Ferry Village was blown up and entirely, destroyed, and the retreat commenced in the direction of Winchester, and was conducted with the greatest haste. Eight car loads of provisions, it is stated, were destroyed, to prevent their falling into the hands of the Federal troops -- there being no facilities for getting them away. Notwithstanding the preparations which have been made for this movement of the rebels, it is evident that it was made in hurry and confusion -- caused, probably, by reports that the Federal troops were rapidly approaching from Greencastle and Cumberland. If it is true, as reported, that the retreat of the rebels is in the direction of Winchester, the ultimate destination is, no doubt, Manassas Junction, by way of Strasburg and Front Royal, taking care to destroy the bridges over the Shenandoah at the latter point. Whether their progress to the Junction will be interfered with by the Federal column supposed to be operating in the vicinity of Leesbugh, remains to be seen.

abstract: Last April a commission was issued to Hon. CARL SCUURZ, authorizing him to raise a Regiment of Cavalry, and a furlough of three months given him for
lead_paragraph: Last April a commission was issued to Hon. CARL SCUURZ, authorizing him to raise a Regiment of Cavalry, and a furlough of three months given him for that purpose. But our relations with Spain demanding his presence at his post at Madrid, he tendered the command of the regiment to Maj. A.E. MCREYNOLDS of Michigan, who served with distinction, in the Mexican war. We learn that the transfer has been ratified by the Secretary of War, and that the regiment will be accepted under his command. The regiment is to be composed of twelve companies -- seven from New-York, three from Philadelphia, and two from Ohio. The men already enlisted are in a forward state of drill, and expect to go into camp next week. The Government only proposes to furnish the arms, leaving the horses and equipments to be furnished by the State and by private efforts. A number of gentlemen in New-York, have expressed themselves willing to furnish the horses, taking as payment the Governmental allowance of fifty cents a day for their use. The head-quarters of the Regiment are at the Palace Gardens, and recruiting offices have been opened at No. 648 Broadway, and No. 43 Cortlandt-street. Those who wish to join the only Volunteer Cavalry Regiment vet ordered and accepted by the Government, had better come forward early and enroll their names.

abstract: Notwithstanding the mistakes of fact and opinion which marked some of the earlier letters of the special correspondent of the London Times, we are indebted to him for very
lead_paragraph: Notwithstanding the mistakes of fact and opinion which marked some of the earlier letters of the special correspondent of the London Times, we are indebted to him for very interesting and important revelations of Southern sentiment, The eagerness of the rebels for the countenance and aid of England compels them to receive Mr. RUSSELL with a degree of courtesy which is by no means characteristic of their intercourse with "outside barbarians;" -- and it is but simple justice to a man placed in a position of no slight embarrassment, to say that he has, so far as we can judge, performed the delicate and difficult task intrusted to him with frank and fearless fidelity. He reports what he hears and sees in the Southern States, -- what the leaders of the rebellion say, what they think, what they propose to do, and what they expect to do it with. All this is what we very much need to know, and, under the circumstances, it is precisely what we could not ascertain except through some such channel of contraband information as the special correspondence of the Times has opened for us.

abstract: The reply of JEFF, DAVIS to the Maryland Commissioners, who lately went "a journeying" to Montgomery, bears little evidence of
lead_paragraph: The reply of JEFF, DAVIS to the Maryland Commissioners, who lately went "a journeying" to Montgomery, bears little evidence of that confidence which characterized the earlier productions of the traitor President. Its softened tone and insinuating blarney in relation to Maryland spmpathy with secession, and the earnestness with which it is reciprocated, are but introductory to the great fact which looks anxiously out from the body of that document, to with a desire for a cessation of hostilities until Congress shall meet in July. Heretofore his language has been, no negotiation, no compromise, no return to the Union, no recognition of the Constitution, but onward, right onward to Washington, there to dictate the terms of peace from the parlors of the White House, or the rotunda of the Capitol. His great idea of the age, the grand reconstruction of society, the new civilization based upon human Slavery, was to be initiated at the point of the bayonet, and was to culminate, not in the independence and advancing glories of the South alone, but by the subjugation of all the States; was to spread from ocean to ocean, and from the lakes to the Gulf. Successful, beyond all precedent, in the stealing of forts and arsenals, sub-treasuries and mints, he embraced the faith that Southern arms were to be as invincible in propagandism, as Southern thieving had been triumphant in its villainy.

abstract: The latest news received by the Haytian papers up to the 25th of May, are not calculated to increase our confidenes in the power of Spain to retain undisturbed her recent acquisition the Republic of
lead_paragraph: The latest news received by the Haytian papers up to the 25th of May, are not calculated to increase our confidenes in the power of Spain to retain undisturbed her recent acquisition -- the Republic of Dominica. Though MARSHALL O'DONNELL, has, in the Madrid Gazette, decreed that the territory constituting the Dominican Republic was, on the 19th of May, incorporated to the Spanish Monarchy, and intrusted the execution of that decree to the Governor of Cuba, it is visible that the possession of this Territory will be an inexhaustible source of troubles and annoyances for the Spanish Cabinet. The haughty arrogance of the Spanish officers and their overbearing manners, have indisposed the officers of the Dominican Army, and it is said SANTANA himself is but an instrument into the hands of the Spanish Lieutenants, before whom he trembles and humiliates himself. Meanwhile, a great fermentation prevails in several districts of the Island. Outbreaks have been heard of in many cities. At Moca an insurrection burst out among the soldiers and was suppressed, but with great difficulty. The Spanish Governor has established an inquisitorial tribunal, to exercise a strict watch upon the enlightened and wealthy citizens, and all suspected persons are arrested and put in jail. BENJAMIN ROJAS, Vice-President of the Republic of Cibao, SEBASTIAN VALVERDE, brother of Ex-President VALVERDE, one Senator and one General are among the prisoners. Seven persons accused of participating in an insurrection movement at Azua have been shot.

abstract: John Shephard vs. Calvin F. Rosenbergh. This is one of those peculiarly disagreeable cases to report, growing, as it does, out of family troubles. It appears that the plaintiff is a member of the Norfolk-street Methodist Church, and that his wife is the sister of the defendant, who is a physician. Plaintiff alleges that he was assaulted by the defendant, and should be entitled to recover therefor. The defendant answers by denying plaintiff's allegations, averring that he was the party assaulted. Defendant further alleges that the plaintiff was in the habit of beating his wife, who called in the defendant, her brother, to consult with her, in reference thereto; that upon entering the house, the plaintiff seized him, tore his clothes, and attempted to strike him with a cane. Such are the allegations cross and counter allegations of the parties to the action.

abstract: This State, says the Albany Evening Journal of June 7, has now twenty-eight regiments in the service of the General Government, which have been ordered to Washington and Fortress Monroe, besides one regiment which leaves the State to-day, a second to-morrow, and a third on Monday next. By the middle of the next week, therefore, there will be thirty-one regiments from New-York in the field, fully armed and equipped, ready for action.

abstract: The Richmond Whig says, during the month of May, nearly 500,000 ins. of Virginia bacon were brought to this city, by canal and railroads, against 22,041 lbs. for the corresponding month of last year. This enormous increase ought to counterbalance the deficiency of Western bacon, which has, heretofore, been chiefly sold in this market. The receipts of flour in May, were only 4,992 barrels, against 8,000 barrels same time last year; but still prices declined. The receipts of butter were 27,707 lbs., against 7,623 lbs. same time last year, or nearly fourfold, and the consequence is, that prices are reasonable -- the wholesale price of the most choice lots being 25c. lb., while very good is selling at 20c. The receipts of country lard in May, were 53,591 lbs.; same time last year 7,643 lbs. The receipts of corn, 20,070 bushels; same time last year 8,225 bushels. This is exclusive of large receipts by Richmond and York River Railroad, which are not embraced, as we have no record of the general receipts by that route of May last year, by which to compare.

abstract: It will be seen by reference to a brief summary of news from Central America, which will be found elsewhere, that the certainly of not being hereafter bullied and invaded by the Southern fillibusters, has given so much encouragement to the authorities of Central America that a new life has been imparted to all public services as a consequence of that feeling. The imposing demonstration of the North, and the confidence in the integrity and honesty of Mr. LINCOLN's Administration, has evidently contributed to spread among the population of Central America a feeling of security, the effect of which is to be seen in the efforts made by natives and foreigners in improving the soil and in working out the immense wealth it contains. According to the latest news, routes are to be opened, companies organized, immigration is to be encouraged, and the cultivation of cotton developed by means of privileges equivalent to a premium. These facts ought to be a source of gratification and praise. We must not forget that if we are bound as a civilized nation to countenance the arts of peace among others, the situation in which we are placed in consequence of our struggle with the rebels, and the events which can result from our conflict with them, have rendered the good dispositions of the Republics of Central America of consequence to us. Hence the necessity of cultivating these dispositions, by the assurance that every effort on their part to strengthen themselves will be received by the Northern States with the greatest satisfaction.

abstract: The papers published in Nicaragua give a long and brilliant account of the journey of President RIVAS through the Department of Conchales, which he had just visited.
lead_paragraph: The papers published in Nicaragua give a long and brilliant account of the journey of President RIVAS through the Department of Conchales, which he had just visited. The population of the various cities of that Department received him with music and banners, torch-light processions and dinners, and his tour was all along the occasion of patriotic effusions. At Libertac, a city inhabited by miners, the French residents organized in his honor a banquet, in which toasts were drunk to the alliance of France and the Central American Republics. The President availed himself of these opportunities to speak of the fertility and wealth of the soil upon which they were living, and urged the people to do all in their power to increase and develop the benefits Nature has bestowed upon them.

abstract: The Frankfort Commonwealth says: "The aggregate vote for delegates to the Border State Convention, is 107,334. There are no returns from the counties of Ballard, Hickman, Marshall, Simpson and Woodford. The total vote of Kentucky, at the last Presidential election, was 146,216. Notwithstanding no Union votes are counted from five counties, and that many precincts were not opened, the Union majority is 69,452 is safe to-say that this State is for Union by 80,000 majority. That will do.
