abstract: Orders have been received from the Government that the twelve regiments now organized in this State, shall, on the 18th, rendezvous as follows: At Quincy, Cols. Smith's, Palmer's, Goode's, Scott's; at Alton, Cols. Ross', Turner's, Marsh's, Hecker's; at Casseyville, Colonels Wyman's, Dougherty's, Mulligan's. The Commissioners for the purchase the State arms and equipments, who have been in session during the week at Springfield, have adjourned until Wednesday next. They will then make awards.

abstract: The New-Haven Journal says that Major WINTHROP, who was killed at the battle of Great Bethel, was a native of New-Haven, a son of the late FRANCIS B. WINTHROP, a nephew of President WOOLSEY, of Yale College, and a descendant of the Winthrops who were Governors of the Colonies of Connecticut and Massachusetts in their infancy. He graduated at Yale College in 1848.

abstract: Tennessee, says the Louisville Journal, of the 3d, is now upon a war footing. Unquestionably, she menaces the Union men of Kentucky. In pursuance of an understanding with the Kentucky Secessionists, she stands ready to aid them at any moment in carrying the secession cause in this State by fire and steel. She has called out 65,000 men, and she has 34,000 on drill every day. These 34,000 men are armed with Maynard rifles, Minie rifles and Sharp's rifles -- the Minie ball being used for all of them. A considerable number of the arms were furnished from Montgomery, and 12,000 sabres are from Georgia. Cannon are cast as rapidly as possible, at two establishments in Nashville and at one in Memphis. Five millions of dollars wore appropriated by the Legislature for the arming of the State, and all the county Courts are exercising the authority given them by the Legislature, to levy whatever tax they please upon their respective counties for the support of the families of the volunteers. Twelve or fifteen thousand troops are encamped at Union City, on the immediate border of Kentucky, and seven thousand on the Nashville Railroad, almost on the Kentucky line, ready to be precipitated upon Louisville at any time, at the shortest notice.

abstract: Col. BAKER's command numbers about 950 men, all of whom, with the exception of two companies, are uniformed with the State regulation of grey, which is at once neat and very serviceable. Five hundred old muskets are now in use for drilling, but the new rifled muskets, or Enfield rifles, will be given them.
lead_paragraph: Col. BAKER's command numbers about 950 men, all of whom, with the exception of two companies, are uniformed with the State regulation of grey, which is at once neat and very serviceable. Five hundred old muskets are now in use for drilling, but the new rifled muskets, or Enfield rifles, will be given them. The regiment has acquired a good degree of perfection in drill. The health of the command is good, but there are a few persons on the sick list, whose proper care require the appointments of a hospital establishment, which they are yet without. This department should secure early attention, by those who have the care of the sanitary regulation at the camp. Col. BAKER, who has been absent in Washington for several days, has not yet returned, and in consequence the grand parade and reception, announced for to-day, is postponed until Sunday next.

abstract: The Memphis Appeal, of June 2, has this paragraph: "The Falls City brought from Baton Rouge, yesterday, 240 cases, containing 4,800 muskets. Fifteen hundred of them are consigned to this place, and the remainder go on to Mount Vernon Arsenal, Alabama. On Thursday, the Charleston Railroad brought in fourteen 32 and sixty 4-pound Dahlgren guns, and the next day eight more."

abstract: We shall soon be in receipt of most stirring news from Missouri. Gov. JACKSON, of that State, has, at length, committed an overt act of treason against the United States.
lead_paragraph: We shall soon be in receipt of most stirring news from Missouri. Gov. JACKSON, of that State, has, at length, committed an overt act of treason against the United States. He has issued a proclamation, calling for fifty thousand troops, to expel the Federal forces from that State. His rallying cry is, "Rise, then, and drive out ignominiously the invaders who have dared to desecrate the soil which your labors have made fruitful, and which is consecrated by your homes." Simultaneously with the issue of this rebellious proclamation, Gov. JACKSON caused certain bridges on the Pacific Railroad to be burned, and he and his coadjutors in the State Government, all traitors alike, fled from Jefferson City, and have sought an asylum in some of the stronger Pro-Slavery counties further up the Missouri River.

abstract: Col. THOMAS C. HINDMAN, late Member of Congress from Arkansas, has reached Memphis with a regiment of 800 Arkansas troops, on the way to Richmond. He acknowledges, in the Memphis Avalanche of June 10, the present of a Confederate silk flag from Mrs. JEFFERSON DAVIS, sent from New-Orleans.
lead_paragraph: Col. THOMAS C. HINDMAN, late Member of Congress from Arkansas, has reached Memphis with a regiment of 800 Arkansas troops, on the way to Richmond. He acknowledges, in the Memphis Avalanche of June 10, the present of a Confederate silk flag from Mrs. JEFFERSON DAVIS, sent from New-Orleans. He also complains bitterly of the State of Arkansas for not furnishing his regiment shoes and blankets. In the course of his dispatch the following nice little confession comes out:

abstract: JOSEPH W. TUCKER, editor of the State Journal, was arrested by the United States Marshal to-day, charged with treason, and taken before the United States Commissioner. He was afterward brought before Judge TREAT, under a writ of habeas corpus, and admitted to bail in $10,000 bonds to appear for examination Monday next. EDWARD BLANNBRHASSET also entered bonds to the amount of $10,000, to appear before the United States Circuit Court, July 8.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS, Friday, June 14 -- Midnight.

abstract: A real, but not very formidable specimen of a privateer, sailing under the pirate flag of the Southern Confederacy, with a letter-of-marque duly signed by JEFF. DAVIS, arrived at this port, yesterday, in charge of Midshipman McCook, and a prize crew from the United States steam frigate Minnesota.
lead_paragraph: A real, but not very formidable specimen of a privateer, sailing under the pirate flag of the Southern Confederacy, with a letter-of-marque duly signed by JEFF. DAVIS, arrived at this port, yesterday, in charge of Midshipman McCook, and a prize crew from the United States steam frigate Minnesota. She is a "low black" schooner, but not "long," being only some fifty tons measurement, with raking masts like a pilot-boat, and, for an old-fashioned vessel, is quite sharp, and is said to be a first-rate sailer. She had no name on the stern, but the word Savannah, in raised letters, on the front part of her trunk cabin, is no doubt the name of the vessel. She has been a Charleston pilot-boat, and for two years past was laid up in that port, condemned.

abstract: Our point then is, that our people should soon begin to think of something else besides war. Not that they should or could lose interest in it -- but they should not confine their attention to it. There is something else besides war in the American horizon. Much of it, indeed, is as clear as ever. The storm has visited us, but is now passing away. The country is selling much and buying little. Gold is daily arriving at the sea-board for eventual circulation, by meats of the Government, among the people, and for a larger than usual basis for future credit. All who can make or do anything for war are profitably employed, and those who produce for foreign consumption are rapidly increasing their means, whether for the payment of old debts or new purchases. Food is consumed, clothes wear out; and with the agricultural population selling to a good market, at home and abroad, people must soon begin to buy. The recent failures have been few and comparatively light, and the crops all over the North present a very favorable appearance. -- Boston Commercial Bulletin, June 15.

abstract: Federal, State and City Governments are spending millions of money for war purposes. Extraordinary sources of revenue are earnestly discussed, and must soon be resorted to, if public credit is to be maintained. It seems to be agreed upon on every side that the prime necessaries of life, like tea, coffee, sugar, etc., must be subjected to a heavy tariff, while direct taxes, more onerous than were ever borne by this country, will supplement the heaviest indirect taxation that trade will tolerate. All this, and more, the people will endure willingly, if our righteous war can be prosecuted with requisite vigor and success, and the gigantic rebellion can be crushed out.

abstract: Such was the rather startling and disturbing announcement made to us by telegraph yesterday. But yet it is no more true now than it has been at any time since the abandonment and burning of Gosport Navy-yard. At that time the Federal Government withdrew all its forces in Eastern Virginia into Fortress Monroe, and, as the fort was surrounded by hostile territory, the sole communication of the Government with the post has since been by sea. If a detachment had been started by land from Fortress Monroe two months ago, it would very soon have met Confederate enemies blocking the way, and the place would have been found "invested."
lead_paragraph: Such was the rather startling and disturbing announcement made to us by telegraph yesterday. But yet it is no more true now than it has been at any time since the abandonment and burning of Gosport Navy-yard. abstract: ACCIDENT AT THE UNION RACE COURSE. About 4 o'clock, yesterday afternoon, a man named THOMAS CARNEY, was killed on the Long Island Railroad, at the Union Course.
lead_paragraph: ACCIDENT AT THE UNION RACE COURSE. -- About 4 o'clock, yesterday afternoon, a man named THOMAS CARNEY, was killed on the Long Island Railroad, at the Union Course. He had been attending a trotting match there, and was standing by his horse, near the railroad track, when the animal took fright from the noise made by an approaching car, and ran off. The deceased attempted to catch his horse and fell upon the track, when the train passed over his body. He resided in Plymouth-street, Brooklyn, and leaves a wife and family.

abstract: The story of the "Seven Sisters" continues to interest the patrons of Miss LAURA KEENE'S Theatre; and the still tougher one of "Our American Cousin at Home" does not flag at the Winter Garden. Nothing remains to be said of either of these productions.
lead_paragraph: The story of the "Seven Sisters" continues to interest the patrons of Miss LAURA KEENE's Theatre; and the still tougher one of "Our American Cousin at Home" does not flag at the Winter Garden. Nothing remains to be said of either of these productions. They have passed successfully the fiery ordeal of criticism, and seem to rest prosperously on their merits. So far as we can ascertain, both pieces are likely to be played for many weeks to come.

abstract: "The fact that three Provincetown whaleman were captured at sea by the Southern privateer Calhoun, and taken to New Orleans, has been briefly stated in the papers. We learn from one of the captured officers a few additional particulars.
lead_paragraph: "The fact that three Provincetown whaleman were captured at sea by the Southern privateer Calhoun, and taken to New Orleans, has been briefly stated in the papers. We learn from one of the captured officers a few additional particulars. The vessels seized were the brig Panama, Capt. POW, and the schooners Mermaid, Capt. SOPER, and the John Adams. Capt. CATON, all of Provincetown. The three Captains named, together with Mr. CATON, first mate, Mr. FRANK JOSEPHS, second mate, and FRANK ROGERS, steward of the Mermaid, reached this city on Saturday evening, they having all left New-Orleans in company on the 3d inst.

abstract: The Danbury (Conn) Times states that two of the prominent citizens of that place recently paid a visit to Ex-President MARTIN VAN BUREN. The conversation naturally turned in the direction of the present unsettled state of the country. Mr. VAN BUREN remarked that he had recently an interview with Ex President PIERCE, and that neither could see anything hopeful or indicating a prospect of an immediate settlement of our national difficulties. "As for myself," said he, "I do not expect to live to see it; but our Government must be sustained at whatever cost." Mr. VAN BUREN is now 79 years of age. It is twenty-four years since he assumed the duties of President of the United States.
lead_paragraph: The Danbury (Conn) Times states that two of the prominent citizens of that place recently paid a visit to Ex-President MARTIN VAN BUREN. The conversation naturally turned in the direction of the present unsettled state of the country. Mr. VAN BUREN remarked that he had recently an interview with Ex President PIERCE, and that neither could see anything hopeful or indicating a prospect of an immediate settlement of our national difficulties. "As for myself," said he, "I do not expect to live to see it; but our Government must be sustained at whatever cost." Mr. VAN BUREN is now 79 years of age. It is twenty-four years since he assumed the duties of President of the United States.

abstract: "A dispatch from Cairo, published here on Friday morning, stated that Gen. PRENTISS, in command at Cairo, had sent troops across the Ohio into Kentucky, to break up a camp of Secessionists.
lead_paragraph: "A dispatch from Cairo, published here on Friday morning, stated that Gen. PRENTISS, in command at Cairo, had sent troops across the Ohio into Kentucky, to break up a camp of Secessionists. We didn't believe the statement, nor do we believe it now, for we know it to be inconsistent with the orders under which Gen. PRENTISS is acting. The following, which we have just received from Frankfort, will put an end to all anxiety, if any is felt, upon the subject. Although emissaries of the Southern Confederacy are raising troops in various parts of our State for hostilities against the United States, no United States troops will be sent to set foot upon our soil:

abstract: "Within the past few days there have been some transfers of bank and other stock owned by Northern parties to residents here, not in the way of actual sales, but as a cover to property which is considered jeopardized by the hostile relations existing between this Confederacy and the Abolition Government at Washington.
lead_paragraph: "Within the past few days there have been some transfers of bank and other stock owned by Northern parties to residents here, not in the way of actual sales, but as a cover to property which is considered jeopardized by the hostile relations existing between this Confederacy and the Abolition Government at Washington. A case in point occurred yesterday, where a party applied to the Mechanics' and Traders' Bank to transfer certain shares of stock to himself under a power of attorney transmitted from New-York. The President of the Bank entertaining serious doubts as to the propriety and legality of such a transfer, addressed a communication to the Attorney-General of the State, soliciting his opinion in the premises. The answer of this officer is conclusive as to the illegality of the proceeding. He pronounces every negotiation, agreement or contract between a person domicilated within the Confederate States and an alien enemy, such as those must be deemed who are domiciled in the United States, to be absolutely null and void. No intercourse, other than a hostile one, can be tolerated between the people of the two sections. The remittance of money for any purpose is unlawful and forbidden. So far as the latter point is concerned, Congress has provided by special enactment that all payments to the enemy are prohibited."

abstract: One of the most surprising things to Northern men, in the contest now being waged in this country, is the remarkable State feeling of the Southern communities. We can easily see how State-rights might be used as a pretence for covering the aggressions of Slavery.
lead_paragraph: One of the most surprising things to Northern men, in the contest now being waged in this country, is the remarkable State feeling of the Southern communities. We can easily see how State-rights might be used as a pretence for covering the aggressions of Slavery. But that petty Southern provinces should really feel -- as we must allow that they do -- that they are historical and independent Sovereignties, that their soil is "sacred," even from the touch of the National Government, that they have even the right to speak of neutrality towards the common Administration of them and all the States, is something almost inexplicable to the sentiment of the Free States. We venture to say that in New-York City, at least two-thirds of the population would have to reflect a moment if they were suddenly asked to what State they belonged, so thoroughly cosmopolitan and intermingled is our population. In New-England, and in the West, though in some communities the pride of province is more marked, yet in general, local feeling is mostly swallowed up in the national. State sovereignty in the Free States has come to be principally interesting as a subject for debate to college sophomores, or as an ancient historical question which deeply moved our fathers. Who thinks of the "sacred soil" of Connecticut, or the "historical glories" of Pennsylvania, or the "sovereignty" of Wisconsin? The Yankee of one year becomes the Hoosier of the next, and the proud citizen of the Empire of New-York may end his days in a remote corner of Kansas. If we were called upon to "die for our State," we should be obliged to ask for which one out of the six we had inhabited!
headline: {'main': 'State Sovereignty.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'State Sovereignty.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The news of the evacuation of Harper's Ferry, and of the destruction of the bridge and Government property there, by the rebels, is fully confirmed, in the more voluminous dispatches relating to the occurrence which we publish this morning.
lead_paragraph: The news of the evacuation of Harper's Ferry, and of the destruction of the bridge and Government property there, by the rebels, is fully confirmed, in the more voluminous dispatches relating to the occurrence which we publish this morning. There seems to be no doubt that the entire rebel force has withdrawn from the vicinity -- though one account states that so late as Saturday noon there still remained a body of two thousand rebels at Bolivar -- and has proceeded to Manassas Junction, by way of Winchester, Strasburgh and Front Royal. The immediate cause of this precipitate retreat will be found in the contiguity of Gen. PATTERSON's advance guard, which is announced to have already reached Hagerstown, while the whole column of Federal troops is in rapid march southward. In view of this concentration of the rebels at Mannassas Junction, a question is now being agitatied in Washington as to the next probable movement. Many entertain the opinion that an advance will be made on the capital; but this, in the face of the large body of well-disciplined troops now there, strongly entrenched, with heavy cannon capable of sweeping all the approaches, is by others considered extremely improbable. It is considered certain, rather, that another retrograde movement must soon take place, from Manassas Junction to Richmond.

abstract: Workmen have been employed for some time, excavating a portion of Smith's Island, for the purpose of providing accommodations for loading coal vessels at the island. Yesterday, while at work, they exhumed three coffins, supposed to contain the bodies of some pirates who were hung on the island about sixty years ago. The coffins were in an excellent state of preservation, and the skeletons within them were perfect, with the exception of two of them being without the skulls. The other skull was of remarkable size and formation. The supposition that these were the remains of pirates, arises from the fact that an execution took place, in 1800, upon the island, (then known as Windmill Island,) of three individuals, for piracy on board the schooner Eliza, Capt. WHEELAND. Their names were JOSEPH BROUS, alias La Roche; PETER PETERSON, alias La Croix; and JOSEPH BAKER, alias Boulenger. We have also heard a tradition that five pirates were hung there in 1803, but we can find no record of the fact. The fact that only three skeletons have been found, imply that the remains are those of the three persons named. The skulls of two of them were probably taken away to ornament some curiosity shop or medical museum. We did hear that a physician of this city, depending upon his memory for the fact, thought those two skulls were a part of the curiosities in the museum of the Academy of Natural Science. It would be a singular fact, if the heads and bodies should be again connected, after so long a separation. -- Philadelphia Ledger.

abstract: The movement recently commenced in this State to enrol and to arm and equip by volunteer supscriptions a regiment for the war, to be composed of one member from each town and ward in the State, is successfully progressing.
lead_paragraph: The movement recently commenced in this State to enrol and to arm and equip by volunteer supscriptions a regiment for the war, to be composed of one member from each town and ward in the State, is successfully progressing. The fund required for the purpose is $150,000, and for this the Ellsworth Association, under whose auspices the effort has been inaugurated, call for dollar subscriptions from all parts of the State. Mayor THACHER, of Albany, is the President, and Hon. ERASTUS CORNING, of the same city, is the Treasurer of the Association. Each town is to select its representative in the regiment, who is required to be not less than five feet eight inches in height, unmarried, active, able-bodied, and not to exceed thirty years of age. Already the call of the Association has been liberally responded to, and many towns have forwarded their subscriptions and designated the person who shall represent them in the corps.

abstract: Our western. MORE SPEED THAN BOTTOM. Our western correspondent, in his letter of a day or two ago, relates an anecdote of a "chattel" that had run itself away from a Southern plantation, and having swam across one river, and rowed itself across another, arrived at Cairo, where it tabernacled for a season in a condition of great bodily comfort and mental exaltation.
lead_paragraph: Our western correspondent, in his letter of a day or two ago, relates an anecdote of a "chattel" that had run itself away from a Southern plantation, and having swam across one river, and rowed itself across another, arrived at Cairo, where it tabernacled for a season in a condition of great bodily comfort and mental exaltation. On being asked (chattels talk as well as run away, down South) whether it felt like lighting, replied, "Laws, Masea, no! "Dis nigger is not a fightin' nigger, he's a runnin' nigger!"

abstract: The rebels, we are told, have left Harper's Ferry, They signalized their departure by destroying the railroad bridge, burning the workshops, and taking various other measures for making the place inaccessible to the National forces, and untenable, should they occupy it. The destination of the retreating army is represented to be the Manassas Junction. Beyond, however, the destruction of property, the story should be received with hesitation. Harper's Ferry is not a position to hold against a powerful enemy; but it is an admirable trap into which one may be decoyed to be annihilated. It is quite possible, therefore, that the rebels may be willing to withdraw long enough to see the approaching army of the West fairly caged, and then, reoccupying the surrounding heights, have every advantage in the work of slaughter.

abstract: It is needless to deny the existence throughout the North of a strong feeling of dissatisfaction at the clemency the Washington authorities are disposed to exhibit towards the rebellious and disaffected.
lead_paragraph: It is needless to deny the existence throughout the North of a strong feeling of dissatisfaction at the clemency the Washington authorities are disposed to exhibit towards the rebellious and disaffected. The people who have lavished their millions and are offering their lives to punish traitors and defeat their treason, are amazed to find that the just and patriotic indignation which has prompted such sacrifices is not shared by those in charge of the Government, who apparently entertain as cordial and amicable relations with the rebels, as with those who sustain the Government. Well-known traitors are permitted to remain in Washington; they are even retained in confidential positions under Government, and even when insurgents are captured with arms in their hands, they are allowed to return to their treason, with no other warrant for their behavior, than the farcical repetition of an oath, which the very first condition of the secession movement pronounces to be of no obligation. It is indeed difficult to discover a distinct indication that the Administration of Mr. LINCOLN regards treason with any stronger sentiment of reprobation than did that of Mr. BUCHANAN. So powerful is this feeling of popular discontent and anger at the apparent sympathy of the Government with those in revolt, that we understand the leading merchants and citizens of New-York, whose labors and money have given the Administration what strength it has to make war upon the insurrection, are contemplating an organized demonstration, which shall either compel the Government to reflect more truthfully the will of the people, or shall constitute the basis of a vigorous opposition, looking to a reconstruction of the Cabinet. An example, proving that we really regard treason to the Union and the Constitution as a capital crime, has been needed and demanded in vain. The offense has been treated rather as a claim to extraordinary displays of courtesy and respect.

abstract: CLAIBORNE F. JACKSON, Governor of Missouri, whose devious course for many weeks back in reference to the present rebellion and war, and whose hostility to the Government, at last avowed, have given his name prominence before the country, is, we believe, a native of Missouri. He was long a resident of Howard County, a stronghold of the Pro-Slavery Democracy.
lead_paragraph: CLAIBORNE F. JACKSON, Governor of Missouri, whose devious course for many weeks back in reference to the present rebellion and war, and whose hostility to the Government, at last avowed, have given his name prominence before the country, is, we believe, a native of Missouri. He was long a resident of Howard County, a stronghold of the Pro-Slavery Democracy. A few years since he removed his residence to Saline County, which is his home at the present time. He is about fifty years of age, courteous and pleasing in manners. Though possessing only mediocre talents, he has, by the low cunning of a scheming politician and a fortunate accident, arisen in political life. Some twelve years since, Judge NAPTON, a leading Soft (Anti-Benton) Democrat, prepared a series of resolutions, to be introduced in the Legislature, the import of which was, that the State of Missouri would abide by whatever decision the Southern States should come to in defence of their institutions. To this was added another resolution, instructing their Senators and Representatives in Congress to assume this position for Missouri in their public acts and votes. JACKSON, who was then a member of the Legislature, was used by NAPTON as a catspaw, to introduce the resolutions before that body. After some resistance, they were passed but Col. BENTON repudiated them, as an effort on the part of the Legislature to pledge the State for nullification. Hence arose the hue and cry of the nullifying Democrats against Col. BENTON, which resulted in the formation of a strong Anti-Benton party, and his defeat when a candidate for reelection, for the United States Senate. Pending this canvas, Col. BENTON, in his public speeches, took frequent occasion to denounce JACKSON, and by doing so gave him an importance which he little deserved. Hearing that JACKSON had threatened to shoot him if he attempted to speak in Howard County, BENTON proceeded thither at his earliest opportunity, and made a public speech filled with scathing sarcasm directed at JACKSON and his fellow-nullifiers, and mentioning them by name. Though JACKSON was present and made some interruptions, no violence was offered.

abstract: ARREST OF COUNTERFEITERS. -- On Friday night a large quantity of counterfeit bank-notes were put in circulation, the efforts of the counterfeiters having been simultaneously carried on in all parts of the City. The note counterfeited was the $5 issue of the Catskill Bank, and it is either a very accurately engraved fac-simile of the genuine or a photograph. There were, however, too many "green hands" employed in the matter to make it successful, as the following arrests prove: HENRY SWIFT, who passed one at the store of M. MCCORMICK, No. 140 Ninth-street -- he had $50 of the paper in his wallet; GEORGE FERGUSON and GEO. WALLACE, who passed one at the store of M.K. PENDLETON, No. 3 Ninth-street; HENRY DIXON palmed one upon JOHN GRANNON, Third-avenue, corner of Fourteenth street; OAKLEY BROWN swindled a woman named LOUISA MONTEGTIRO with one; LOUISA HOWLETT passed one upon H.W. WIEHOLDT, storekeeper, at No. 11 Catharine-slip; JAMES CLARK got rid of one at BENJ. HARRIS' store, No. 264 Grand-street, and CHAS. MORRIS, a tailor, defrauded S. ROSENBERG, of No. 68 Chatham-street, with one. The prisoners were taken to the various Police Courts, and the improbable stories told by them leave no doubt of their guilt. All were held for trial.

abstract: Dixie's Land" has SONGS FOR THE SOUTH. "Dixie's Land" has been the inspiring melody which the Southern people, by general consent, have adopted as their "national air" a sort of cotton "Yankee Doodle." Like most articles of Southern consumption, the melody was imported from ...
lead_paragraph: "Dixie's Land" has been the inspiring melody which the Southern people, by general consent, have adopted as their "national air" -- a sort of cotton "Yankee Doodle." Like most articles of Southern consumption, the melody was imported from the North, -- Northern men being guilty of perpetrating both words and music. Still, as a "national air," the Mobile Mercury objects to it. Considering that the Southern "nation" is a negro slave aristocracy, it seems paradoxical that the editor of that journal should insist that it is "absurd to imagine that Dixie, a dancing, capering, rowdyish, bacchanalian negro air, will ever be the music of such words as a nation of free men can sing with any respect for themselves." Hence, believing that national songs are never ground out to order, the Mercury is hoping that some, as yet undiscoverd, Carey, Rouget del'Isle, or Key will turn up who can reduce rebellion, repudiation, and robbery to hexameters. As the Muses have never sufficiently appreciated the attractions of Southern scenery, to recline their forms for any length of time under the shade of "persimmon trees," or to stretch their classic lengths, except for brief periods, upon the "sandy bottoms," the time is very uncertain when, to quote the choice language of the Mercury, "a national anthem will be born into original poetic and musical life," with "words simple and thrilling, and the music bold, swelling, speaking, majestic." Still, as the want exists, we would humbly suggest how it can be temporarily met. Let Mr. GILMORE SIMMS and Mr. PAUL HAYNE, whose genius the clouds of war have temporarily obscured, emerge from their seclusion, put their shoulder to the poetic wheel and compose some appropriate verses in which patriotism and piracy, chivalry and shin-plasters, and "neutrality" and niggers, may be appropriately blended in verse to be set to the "Rogue's March." We would also suggest that the words be dedicated to His Excellency, Hon. JEFF. DAVIS, President C.S.A., and the members of his Cabinet. Such a poetical effort will answer the requirement temporarily; and, as the "Southern Nation"seems likely to suffer a total eclipse at no very distant day, it matters not if the inspired genius, whose advent the Mercury so fondly awaits, should not attempt to perpetuate, as well as inaugurate, the worship of the Muses on Southern soil.

abstract: A very-exciting contest took place Saturday on the Union Course, between gentlemen's road horses, for $4,000. Mile heats, best three in five. The horses were Tartar, driven by HORACE F. JONES, and Rattlesnake, driven by D. PIFFER, both well known as fast ones. A large number of the friends of the owners of both horses were on the Course, and much money changed hands, Rattlesnake being the favorite. Tartar, who had lost the two first heats by breaking into a gallop, won the third through the like mishap to Rattlesnake; but was again defeated in the fourth heat by some bad breaks, which gave the race to Rattlesnake.

abstract: SHIPMAN. -- At Halifax, the other day, a number of midshipment of the English man of-war steamer St. George were enjoying themselves in rather a disorderly style, when they discovered upon the Victoria Building the sign of the American Consul "It is not to be supposed," says one of the Halifax papers, "that these youngsters wished to show their contempt for the American Eagle, but true it is that their love of what they considered fun predominated over their high respect for the arms of the United States, and they removed it to one of the wharves. Six watchmen succeeded in capturing three of the depredators, not, however, until one of the former was pretty severely handled. They were taken to the station, and brought before his Worship the Mayor, when they were fined $10 each, and ordered to make good the damage done."

abstract: The last will and testament of STEPHEN A. DOUGLAS was filed in the office of the Judge of Probate, in Chicago, Wednesday morning. The document is in his own handwriting, and its terseness of composition is the reflection of his own mind.
lead_paragraph: The last will and testament of STEPHEN A. DOUGLAS was filed in the office of the Judge of Probate, in Chicago, Wednesday morning. The document is in his own handwriting, and its terseness of composition is the reflection of his own mind. It will be seen that, after the payment of his debts, all his properly is left to his wife and children. Mrs. DOUGLAS and Mr. DANIEL P. RHODES, of Cleveland, are named as executors of the will.

abstract: Mr. LOUIS DELA, a prominent literateur, died in Philadelphia on June 14. He was born in Portland, Me., in 1823, and, when only eight years old, delivered an oration on Temperance before the Common Council of Portland, of which NEAL DOW was a member. He began to write verses, too, at that time, and many of them were published in the Portland American and the Temperance Journal. His father was a grocer, and he employed him in his shop till he was nearly of age. When he was about twenty-one, he received nearly $2,000 for some prize conundrums, offered by a Boston party. He engaged for a time in the jewelry business, then in the drug, and afterwards studied, law with Attorney-General CLIFFORD. In 1851, he was admitted to the Bar, but as the profession old not suit his state of health, and as he had considerable property left him by his father, he engaged in some speculations, which did not turn out well. In 1855, he went to Philadelphia, and engaged for a time in the manufacture of agricultural implements. In 1857, he suffered heavy losses by the financial troubles, a good deal of his money having been invested in Pennsylvania Bank stock. The closing years of his life have been spent in an insane asylum.

abstract: The evidence accumulates that the Southern rebels are alarmingly destitute of arms and munitions of war. The traitor JOHN B. FLOYD has just issued a circular address to the people of Southwestern Virginia, in which ...
lead_paragraph: The evidence accumulates that the Southern rebels are alarmingly destitute of arms and munitions of war. The traitor JOHN B. FLOYD has just issued a circular address to the people of Southwestern Virginia, in which he says that there is great danger to that portion of the State from the Federal troops advancing from Ohio, and threatening to seize the Virginia and Tennessee Railroad. This movement would effectually cut off all aid to the rebel army in Virginia, from the State of Tennessee and those States south and west of it Mr. FLOYD says: "We have plenty of men to defend the country, if they were armed." He adds: "I call upon all patriotic citizens to come promptly forward, and supply our men with such arms as they may have. Agents will be appointed, to receive the arms, and give a receipt for the same, stating therein the character of the gun, and the value thereof. These guns will be faithfully returned to their owners, or, if not, will be paid for."

abstract: A FEMALE ROBBER. About 12 o'clock noon, on Saturday, the residence of Mrs. MARY SERANT, in Bergen-street, near Pearsall, was entered by some person during the temporary absence of the family, and clothing, valued at $75, was carried off.
lead_paragraph: A FEMALE ROBBER. -- About 12 o'clock noon, on Saturday, the residence of Mrs. MARY SERANT, in Bergen-street, near Pearsall, was entered by some person during the temporary absence of the family, and clothing, valued at $75, was carried off. Some of the neighbors saw a woman come out of the house carrying a large bundle. Information was given at the Ninth Precinct Station-house, and shortly afterwards. Officers CLOONEY and JOHNSON of that Precinct, succeeded in finding the goods at the house of a man named THOMAS DARLY, who was arrested as a receiver. A woman answering the description given by the neighbors, was arrested last night as she was attempting to cross the South Ferry, and being identified was locked up for examination. She gave her name as MARY ROONEY.

abstract: The Fourteenth Regiment, New York State Volunteers, Col. McQUADE, will arrive in this City at 10 o'clock tomorrow morning. A very beautiful regimental standard for this regiment was furnished by TIFFANY Co., on Saturday, to the order of gentlemen of our City.
lead_paragraph: The Fourteenth Regiment, New York State Volunteers, Col. MCQUADE, will arrive in this City at 10 o'clock tomorrow morning. A very beautiful regimental standard for this regiment was furnished by TIFFANY & CO., on Saturday, to the order of gentlemen of our City. It is of the dimensions prescribed by State military regulations -- six feet by six and a half, and its material a rich, dark blue silk, heavily fringed in yellow. The staff is of lance wood, mounted in fire-gilt, tipped with a silver spear-head, and so constructed as to fold together when not in use. The device of the flag, elegantly embroidered, represents the military arms borne by our New-York contingent, the shield containing in one half the State arms, and in the other the bars of the Federal coat. Over the shield is the State-crest, the eagle perched upon the globe, and beneath it a graceful garter inscribed Excelsior. Under this motto is the Regimental designation, Fourteenth Regiment, New-York Volunteers.

abstract: A letter to the Missouri Republican, dated at Abiquia, N.M., May 10, says: "About two weeks ago, the first wave of returning emigration reached here from the mines. On the 15th ult, KIT CARSON, the old guide in FREMONT'S expeditions, started from Taos, with two or ...
lead_paragraph: A letter to the Missouri Republican, dated at Abiquia, N.M., May 10, says: "About two weeks ago, the first wave of returning emigration reached here from the mines. On the 15th ult, KIT CARSON, the old guide in FREMONT's expeditions, started from Taos, with two or three Ute Indians, who were to show him some place to the north of Baker's, where there was plenty of gold. As KIT is the United States Agent for the Ute Nation, every one thought that they could and would do as they promised, and many stopped to hear the result. On the 2d inst. information was brought in by the Animos Express rider that KIT's horse had fallen, and rolled down hill with him, injuring him so seriously that he had to return to Taos. This was a damper. Many had placed their last hope, on him, and now gave up. KIT's party, now under the command of Capt. PFRIFFER, (the Ute Sub-Agent,) and guided by the Indians, has not yet returned from the mountains, and may still bring good news.

abstract: In our last number we proved, first, that the national unity and supremacy of our Government existed in fact before the Articles of Confederation were submitted by The Congress to the ...
lead_paragraph: In our last number we proved, first, that the national unity and supremacy of our Government existed in fact before the Articles of Confederation were submitted by The Congress to the people; and, second, that the proposition contained in the submission of these Articles for ratification was not an appeal to the States to accede to or become members of the Union. We claimed, and shall now proceed further to show, that the simple and only material question involved was Shall the Union already existing be made perpetual? The Congress propose to make it so, not by dissolving it, but by establishing it under an organism which, while it guarantees to the several colonies, within their ascertained limits, the capacities and privileges of States released from allegiance to the Crown of Great Britain, shall also make their position as such conformable to the unity and supremacy of the general governing power, and to the relations of dependence and allegiance which they had hitherto sustained to that. In other words, the time has come when they are called upon to give to the people and to each other, to foreign Powers and to the whole civilized world, a covenant of further assurance as to the duration of their national character and Government. This they aim to do by the proposed Articles of Confederation.

abstract: Joseph Beyer and Charles M. Foster, Policemen of the Seventeenth Ward, were arrested yesterday, charged with stealing a gold watch, chain and locket, valued at $108 and $50 in bank bills, from Francis Baaden, a druggist doing business at No. 16 Bayardstreet. It appears that late on Friday night the com- ...
lead_paragraph: Joseph Beyer and Charles M. Foster, Policemen of the Seventeenth Ward, were arrested yesterday, charged with stealing a gold watch, chain and locket, valued at $108 and $50 in bank bills, from Francis Baaden, a druggist doing business at No. 16 Bayardstreet. It appears that late on Friday night the complainant was in a disreputable lager-beer cellar, kept by Emily Marsh, at No. 265 William-street, and after imbibing sundry drinks and partaking of other refreshments, was presented with a bill of $4, by his hostess. This amount he considered exorbitant, and refused to pay, when the woman called up the two police officers, who were present at the time, and introduced them as such to Baaden. They then showed their shields, and deliberately took from him his watch, money, &c., he making no forcible resistance. The following morning the matter was made known at the head-quarters of the Police Department, and the arrest of the officers was ordered. On searching the house of Foster, No. 648 Fourth-street, the complainant's watch was found, but the chain, locket and money have not been recovered. The officer says he found the watch upon the sidewalk, and took it home for safe keeping, and subsequently told one of the Sergeants that he had it, and wished to find its owner. Both officers gave bail for their appearance to answer the charge. Of late they have been on duty at the sub-station in Beekman-street.

abstract: We have received a detailed account of the riots in St. Johns, N.F., of the 13th ult., from a gentleman on the spot, but the crowded state of out columns prevents its insertion. Do new facts being adduced, and the major part of...
lead_paragraph: We have received a detailed account of the riots in St. Johns, N.F., of the 13th ult., from a gentleman on the spot, but the crowded state of out columns prevents its insertion. Do new facts being adduced, and the major part of the communication being an exposition of the state of political parties in the island, and rather severe (though it may be just) reflections upon the conduct of a high dignitary of the Roman Catholic Church, whom the writer makes to bear the brunt of all the troubles. The investigation which is said to be making into the origin of the difficulties, will doubtless show who is and who is not guilty in the premises.

abstract: The Southern newspapers are in a state of acute perplexity. They want "a pet name for the Southern Confederacy." Having "turned 'Uncle Sam' over to the Yankees as an inveterate old curmudgeon," the editor of the Mobile Tribune, who seems to have a fine conception of the eminent fitness of things, and he having patriotically cudgeled his poetic brains, says: "Let us make Cousin Sally our watchword and our rallying cry;" and he adds, with much feeling, "The thought would be in harmony with the chivalrous gallantry that should mark the character of the sons of the South." The concluding interrogatory -- "Who would not fight for Cousin Sally?" -- removes all doubt as to the complexion of the allegorical female. The South fights only for its "niggers," and Cousin Sally may prove to be contraband of war, which Uncle Sam must seize and confiscate.

abstract: The Government ought to furnish the regiments which are employed on scouting or skirmishing duty with rifled muskets without delay. Some of those which have been thus employed in the vicinity of Fort Monroe, the Fifth Zouaves among them, have nothing but the common musket. It is impossible for them to render effective service with these weapons. Their range is very limited, and their aim by no means accurate. Unless skirmishers can pick off the gunners in intrenchments, and render similar service dependent on sharpshooting at considerable distances, they are comparatively useless. This defect should be remedied without delay. Some of our home regiments have rifled muskets, which they do not need for any service they are likely to be called on to perform, and there would seem to be no good reason why an exchange should not be made.

abstract: Our volunteer troops at the various military camps and forts throughout the country have thus far enjoyed a remarkable degree of general health, and an almost entire immunity from the various epidemics which so frequently follow in the wake of advancing armies.
lead_paragraph: Our volunteer troops at the various military camps and forts throughout the country have thus far enjoyed a remarkable degree of general health, and an almost entire immunity from the various epidemics which so frequently follow in the wake of advancing armies. The chief local or special diseases which have appeared among them thus far have been intermittent fever and diarrhoea at Cairo, measles among the New-Englanders at Fort Monroe, scurvy among the marines at Fort Pickens, and diarrhoea to some extent among the Pennsylvania troops; -- of small pox only a few isolated cases have occurred here and there, but its spread has been everywhere instantly checked by prompt attention to isolation and vaccination. As for the story to which the Southern Press some time ago gave currency, that yellow fever was raging among our men on Santa Rosa Island, that was only a melancholy instance of the wish being father to the thought; for, though we believe that that terrible epidemic has really appeared within the last fortnight at New-Orleans, it had certainly not, at latest advices, shown itself at any of our Gulf posts. It is not likely, either, that any great bodies of our troops will be exposed, during the fervid months, along those sections of the Gulf or Atlantic coasts where the yellow or other contagious malignant fevers prevail; and it were to be hoped, in a medical as well as in a military point of view, that the bulk of those now at Fort Pickens might be able to Summer on the high grounds near Montgomery, and that those in tide-water Virginia also might be removed up to healthier localities in the vicinity of Richmond or Lynchburgh.
headline: {'main': 'Military Hygiene.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Military Hygiene.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The recent vote of the people of Tennessee, on the question of separation or non-separation of that State from the Federal Union, is boasted of by the Press of Tennessee as a fair and ...
lead_paragraph: The recent vote of the people of Tennessee, on the question of separation or non-separation of that State from the Federal Union, is boasted of by the Press of Tennessee as a fair and uncontrolled expression of the will of the citizens. A Memphis paper, published on the morning of the election, says of those who may choose to vote against separation: "Let them so vote without let or hindrance. They will incur a fearful responsibility, because such vote will be apt to be regarded as calculated to give aid and encouragement to LINCOLN in his unholy work of subjugation. Some may, indeed, construe them as equivalent to an invitation to the Federal troops to invade the State, relying upon their cooperation in our humiliation."

abstract: The Philadelphia North American, of June 12, says: "A telegraphic dispatch from Reading, Pa., announces the death, in that city, at his residence, of Hon. GEORGE M. KEIM, better known as Gen. KEIM, and who was well known to many Philadelphians. The General was a native of Pennsylvania, and belonged to the old Berks County stock, the family connections being quite extensive and influential. He represented the Berks County District in Congress from 1838 to 1843. Subsequently he served for a number of years as United States Marshal for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania, resident in Philadelphia. He was a gentleman of excellent character, always ranked high socially, and was universally respected.

abstract: It looks very much as if, by abandoning Harper's Ferry, the rebels had abandoned the only point where they could make any effectual resistance to the march of our troops through Virginia.
lead_paragraph: It looks very much as if, by abandoning Harper's Ferry, the rebels had abandoned the only point where they could make any effectual resistance to the march of our troops through Virginia. While in possession of at point they held in check all the forces from the West and Pennsylvania, and left their confederates at Manassas Gap and further South to exert their full strength, whatever that may be, against the American Army. Eventually, to be sure, they would have been driven from it; but time is an element of value to them in this struggle, and every day they could have held the Ferry would have been of essential service to their main army further South.

abstract: A very exciting contest took place Saturday on the Union Course, between gentlemen's road horses, for $4,000. Mile heats, best three in five. The horses were Tartar, driven by HORACE F. JONES, and Rattlesnake, driven by D. PIFFER, both well known as fast ones. A large number of the friends of the owners of both horses were on the Course, and much money changed hands, Rattlesnake being the favorite. Tartar, who had lost the two first heats by breaking into a gallop, won the third through the like mishap to Rattlesnake; but was again defeated in the fourth heat by come bad breaks, which gave the race to Rattlesnake.

abstract: There is clearly a misunderstanding in regard to the part Gen. BUTLER is to play in the Summer's campaign. The impression has been current that his forces were destined to cooperate in a general movement from the North, the West and the East upon Richmond;
lead_paragraph: There is clearly a misunderstanding in regard to the part Gen. BUTLER is to play in the Summer's campaign. The impression has been current that his forces were destined to cooperate in a general movement from the North, the West and the East upon Richmond; that as soon as sufficient, strength had been placed at his disposal, the advance would be made; and that in the presence of his complete preparations, the enemy would be swept from York peninsula. This is evidently an error. We now hear of Gen. BUTLER "planning expeditions"; arranging for alarums and excursions of the melo-dramatic type; projecting, in plain terms, a species of guerrilla warfare, in place of a well-conceived and matured demonstration upon the Virginia capital. It is with reluctance we abandon the idea that Gen. BUTLER's duties had been prescribed by a sounder military experience than his own, constituting in fact a well-understood portion of the campaign as declared by Gen. SCOTT, and accept the conviction that his occupancy of Fortress Monroe is designed rather to harass than to rout the enemy.

abstract: A WOMAN KILLED BY HER HUSBAND. EDWARD BULGER, a lumber-carman, residing at No. 271 West Thirteenth street, was arrested early yesterday morning, charged with the homicide of his wife, an intemperate woman, about forty years of age.
lead_paragraph: A WOMAN KILLED BY HER HUSBAND. -- EDWARD BULGER, a lumber-carman, residing at No. 271 West Thirteenth street, was arrested early yesterday morning, charged with the homicide of his wife, an intemperate woman, about forty years of age. It appears, from what can be ascertained, that BULGER went home at 9 o'clock on Saturday evening, and found his wife drunk and very abusive. She continued to use very violent and abusive language to him until about 12 o'clock, when she attacked him with her fists. He then lost all patience, and knocked her down, she falling with the back of her head upon the stove, and fracturing her skull. Some others in the house, on hearing the noise and ascertaining what had occurred, called for the Police, and Officer BOYD, of the Ninth Ward, appeared and arrested BULGER. A physician was called in, but the woman died before daylight. BULGER was taken to Court, and locked up to await the Coroner's inquest, which will be held to-day. He is represented as being a very peaceable and industrious man.

abstract: We have intelligence this morning that Virginia has been entered by two additional columns of Federal troops at Leesburgh by Col. STONE, with the New-York Ninth as his advance guard, and at a point opposite Williamsport, Md., by the advance ...
lead_paragraph: We have intelligence this morning that Virginia has been entered by two additional columns of Federal troops -- at Leesburgh by Col. STONE, with the New-York Ninth as his advance guard, and at a point opposite Williamsport, Md., by the advance guard of Gen. PATTERSON's army, under Gen. CADWALADER. With regard to the movement on Leesburgh, we have not yet received the particulars; but at Williamsport, we learn, our troops waded the Potomac, waist-deep, covered by a sufficient force of artillery. Toere have been no movements of importance in the vicinity of Washington.

abstract: ARRIVAL AND DEPARTURE OF THE FIRST MASSACHUSETTS REGIMENT. The announcement that the First Massachusetts Regiment was to arrive, yesterday morning, at Jersey-City, attracted to that place a large concourse of the citizens of New-York and ...
lead_paragraph: ARRIVAL AND DEPARTURE OF THE FIRST MASSACHUSETTS REGIMENT. -- The announcement that the First Massachusetts Regiment was to arrive, yesterday morning, at Jersey-City, attracted to that place a large concourse of the citizens of New-York and Brooklyn, many of whom were there as early as 9 o'clock in the morning. At about 10 o'clock, a large delegation of Massachusetts men assembled at the Astor House and proceeded in a body to Jersey City, for the purpose of formally receiving the regiment. Contrary to general expectation, the steamer Commonwealth, which had been chartered to convey the troops, did not arrive until the middle of the afternoon; but the people waited with most exemplary patience, and when, at a few minutes past 3 o'clock, the vessel hove in sight, gayly decorated with flags, and her decks crowded with over a thousand brave men, the people waved their hats and sent up a shout of welcome that must have sunk deep into every heart.

abstract: The "saucy little schooner" Savannah, the first privateer, and the first prize among the licensed pirates of JEFF. DAVIS, coutinued to attract much attention as she lay at anchor, yesterday, off the Battery, with the secession flag flying at her maintopmasthead, under the Stars and Stripes.
lead_paragraph: The "saucy little schooner" Savannah, the first privateer, and the first prize among the licensed pirates of JEFF. DAVIS, coutinued to attract much attention as she lay at anchor, yesterday, off the Battery, with the secession flag flying at her maintopmasthead, under the Stars and Stripes. Crowds thronged the Battery, to get a view of the vessel, while others, wishing to have a more particular inspection, hired boats and went alongside. These visitors becoming too numerous for the comfort of the officers in charge, they were at last obliged, politely, to refuse them admission on board. She was inspected, however, with the greatest curiosity, and all manner of questions were asked touching the history of the craft and of her capture. The mark of one of the Perry's shots, which grazed the squaresail-stay, within six inches of the foremast; attracted particular attention.

abstract: The genesis of the South Carolinians, as stated by themselves to the peripatetic correspondent of the London Times, has the merit of conciseness "The State of South Carolina was founded by Gentlemen." Further deponent saith not.
lead_paragraph: The genesis of the South Carolinians, as stated by themselves to the peripatetic correspondent of the London Times, has the merit of conciseness -- "The State of South Carolina was founded by Gentlemen." Further deponent saith not. We are enlightened with no definition of what constitutes a gentleman, theme of many a protracted Lyceum debate); but as the "gentlemen" who founded Carolina are mentioned in antithesis to the "witch-burning Puritans" who settled New England, and who are forcibly described in the alliterative trilogy, "brutal bigoted blackguards," we might infer, even if the "chivalry" had not sufficiently informed us, that the founders of that sovereignty were those dashing Cavaliers who flash through the reigns of the English Charles'. This gentle origin has long been a favorite theme of Carolinian eloquence; they have generally been listened to with the meekness befitting those who stand in presence of the scions of such lofty sires. And the only flaw in re, is that the whole theory is a stupendous fiction.
headline: {'main': 'The Original South Carolina Gentlemen.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Original South Carolina Gentlemen.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: We receive from almost every section of the Northwest the most encouraging accounts of the present prospect for the coming harvest. The lateness of the Spring and the continued wet weather was unfavorable for oats and ...
lead_paragraph: We receive from almost every section of the Northwest the most encouraging accounts of the present prospect for the coming harvest. The lateness of the Spring and the continued wet weather was unfavorable for oats and corn, but contributed to the benefit of grass and wheat. Of both these crops there can now be no doubt of at least an average yield. Lately the weather has been warmer and dryer; these conditions are congenial to the corn and oats, and in no respect, thus far, detrimental to other grains.

abstract: The Fourteenth Regiment, New-York State Volunteers, Col. McQUADE, will arrive in this City at 10 o'clock to morrow morning. A very beautiful regimental standard for this regiment was furnished by TIFFANY Co., on Saturday, to the order of gentlemen ...
lead_paragraph: The Fourteenth Regiment, New-York State Volunteers, Col. MCQUADE, will arrive in this City at 10 o'clock to morrow morning. A very beautiful regimental standard for this regiment was furnished by TIFFANY & Co., on Saturday, to the order of gentlemen of our City. It is of the dimensions prescribed by State military regulations -- six feet by six and a half, and its material a rich, dark blue silk, heavily fringed my yellow. The staff is of lancewood, mounted in fire-gilt, tipped with a silver spear-head, and so constructed as to fold together when not in use. The device of the flag, elegantly embroidered, represents the military arms borne by our New-York contingent, the shield containing in one half the State arms, and in the other the bars of the Federal coat. Over the shield is the State crest, the eagle perched upon the globe, and beneath it a graceful garter inscribed Excelsior. Under this motto is the Regimental designation, Fourteenth Regiment, New-York Volunteers.

abstract: On Sunday afternoon, ABRAHAM WOLF, a member of the Twenty-ninth Regiment, was dangerously injured in consequence of falling beneath the wheels of a Third-avenue car, from the front platform of which he had jumped. He was removed to Bellevue Hospital by the Police.... A lad, 6 years of age, named CLEMENT A. JENNINGS, was shot in the neck on Sunday afternoon by CARL HOWEDE, another member of the Twenty ninth Regiment, who was firing at a mark in Ninety-sixth-street, near Broadway. The wound, fortunately, was not severe. HOWEDE was taken into custody and held by Justice BROWDELL, pending an investigation.... One of the soldiers of DeKalb Regiment, JAMES CASEY by name, while intoxicated on Sunday night, fell down stairs at No. 446 Eighth-avenue. He was badly injured and the Police took him to Bellevue Hospital.

abstract: A letter before me, from a gentleman in England, says: "One of our largest dealers in hardware, metals, , states that the manufacturers at Manchester and Sheffield, as well as elsewhere in Europe, are alarmed lest there should be a revolution here among the laboring classes, should the American war continue long."

abstract: Yesterday was a busy day at the encampment at East New-York, in consequence of orders having been received for the regiment to march forward to Washington to-day. The cheerful countenances of the men, and their active movements, evinced the gratification produced at the prospect of soon meeting with the enemies of the country, and at the same time exhibiting their loyalty and patriotism. Since being quartered at East New-York they have been sadly neglected by the Union Defence Committee, many of them being for a long time unprovided with shoes, and a far greater number destitute of absolutely essential articles of clothing. The officers of the regiment have expended from their own private purses no less a sum than $5,000, and justly claim this amount at the hands of the Committee. It was only a few days ago that they commenced receiving their tents, the last of which did not arrive on the ground till Saturday of the preceding week. They are now in possession of one hundred small tents and fifteen large ones. All the equipments arrived yesterday, and if the arms are received this morning, as it was expected they would be, nothing will prevent them from leaving to-day. Six P.M. is the hour appointed for departure, and each man is to be supplied with ten days' rations, which will enable them to proceed beyond Washington without any unnecessary delay at that point. The whole force consists of about 800 men, all of whom are well and hearty, with the exception of Lieut. ROBERTS, of Company B, who is suffering from ill health, occasioned by exposure during the Mexican campaigns, and who, on this account will probably be furloughed for a few weeks. The Paymaster will, to-day, disburse the amounts due the soldiers, he having visited the authorities at Albany, yesterday, for the purpose of securing the requisite funds. The regiment may well boast of being excellently officered, for it must be remembered that several of the officers held high positions and achieved signal honors in the Mexican war. The following is a complete list of the officers:

abstract: Brig Hallie Jackson, of Savannah, a prize to the Blockading Squadron stationed off Savannah, has just arrived at this port. She is in charge of Lieut. BREANT, with a prize crew from the Minnesota, Mr. GREEN, master, from the same ship, and Mr. BOWES, Midshipman from the Union, also came in the brig The H.J. sailed from Matanzas with a cargo of molasses for Savannah, where she is owned, and was captured by the United States steamer Union off the Coast of Georgia, after a chase of five hours, in whish the speed of the steamer was severely tried. On board too brig was found a flag of the Southern Confederacy, which it is sail was displayed at Matanzas. It was found secreted on board, although the Captain strenuously denied having such an article. She sailed from the anchorage of Savannah June 11, at which time the Minnesota and Union were on that station the former to sail in a day or two for Hampton Roads. The Wabash and Flag were off Charleston. Part of the crew and Capt. JOHN BYERS are on board the Minnesota.

abstract: In the House of Commons, on the 4th inst., Mr. W.E. FORSTER asked the Secretary for Foreign Affairs whether Her Majesty's Government would exercise the discretion which by the law of nations the possess to prevent privateers sailing under the as yet unrecognized flag of the so-called Southern Confederacy from bringing their prizes into any port of Her Majesty's dominions? He added that he did not ask this question with regard to privateers sailing under the flag of the United States, simply because he had no expectation that any letters of marque would be issued by the United States' Government.
lead_paragraph: In the House of Commons, on the 4th inst., Mr. W.E. FORSTER asked the Secretary for Foreign Affairs whether Her Majesty's Government would exercise the discretion which by the law of nations the possess to prevent privateers sailing under the as yet unrecognized flag of the so-called Southern Confederacy from bringing their prizes into any port of Her Majesty's dominions? He added that he did not ask this question with regard to privateers sailing under the flag of the United States, simply because he had no expectation that any letters of marque would be issued by the United States' Government.

abstract: At the regular meeting of this Board last evening, the resolution previously passed of both boards, and sanctioned by the Mayor, continuing the salaries of the employes of the City Government during their absence in the army, was rescinded. The petition of the Gulick Volunteers for the use of Jefferson Market drill room two evenings in the week was granted. In answer to a resolution of the Board, the Comptroller sent in a communication, giving the amounts paid the various City newspapers for publishing the Common Council proceedings, and for advertising during the year 1860. The total amount, paid to all the papers is given at $90,671 23; of which the Daily News got $19,834 12; the Express, $13,023 06; the Transcript, $9,212 22; the Commercial Advertiser, $8,541 35; the Day Book, $5,818 71; and the other papers smaller sums from $4,000 down to $167 30. The Board concured in the resolutions of respect to the memory of Senator DOUGLAS, passed at the last meeting of the Councilmen. The Committee on National Affairs reported in favor of paying $800 23, expenses incurred in the funeral of Col. VOSBURGH. The Board concurred in the resolution of the Councilmen dispensing with the Daily News as a Corporation paper, by a vote of 8 to 4. An ordinance was adopted making the West Washington Market one of the public markets of the City, the same having been purchased from the State. The Law Committe prevented a report relative to the Harkley Street-cleaning Contract censoring the City Inspector and Comptroller for certifying to and paying the bills of Hackley, without being satisfied that he had faithfully fulfilled his contract, and requesting the Corporation Counsel, in case said contract is not fulfilled, to initiate proceedings to set it aside. A resolution was adopted directing the Street Commissioner to open Mount Morris square. The Board then adjourned to Friday evening.

abstract: The State of Missouri is at present in a condition of chaos unprecedented in the history of this country. The Chief Executive of that State has committed treason against the Federal Government, and has fled from the Capital, closely pursued by Federal forces who will soon have him in custody and safely transferred to a prison beyond the bounds of the State that he has dishonored and betrayed. The office of Governor of Missouri is clearly vacant, and all the functions of a State administration are suspended. The Lieutenant-Governor, upon whom the duties of Chief Executive would devolve under the Constitution, in the present contingency, is also absent from Missouri, having departed some time since, from extreme caution or on a (reasonable mission, to the State of Arkansas. Finding the State Government broken up, and its leading members prosecuted for treason, it is not likely that the Lieutenant-Governor (THOS. C. REYNOLDS, a South Carolinian by birth, and as great a traitor as any of them) will find it prudent to return. The President of the State Senate, the next in order of succession, has too dark a record to justify him in standing, when JACKSON and REYNOLDS have fled.
lead_paragraph: The State of Missouri is at present in a condition of chaos unprecedented in the history of this country. abstract: Commissary TAYLOR, just from Newport News, reports a skirmish there this morning. Three companies, sent out by by Col. PHELPS to gather in some cattle belonging to the Secessionists, were fired upon by a company of light-horse, and three men wounded. The rebels escaped, and the detachment succeeded in its purpose.

A resolution was adopted directing the Street Commissioner to open Mount Morris Square. The Board then adjourned to Friday evening.

abstract: On Thursday, May 9, the Mexican National Congress was duly installed. President JUAREZ on the occasion delivered a message to that body, in which he reviewed at great length the prominent events of the long struggle which commenced with the suppression of the Congress on the 17th of December, 1857, and terminated with the triumphant entry of the Constitutional Army into this capital on the 25th of December, 1860. Passing from the review of the principal features of the period, previous to the final victory, he says:

abstract: We publish this morning Lord JOHN RUSSELL's notification that privateers will not be allowed to bring their prizes into any English port. Under the circumstances of the case, this is a serious and heavy blow to the Southern Confederacy, inasmuch as they alone have proposed a resort to this method of warfare. The English Government, however, has taken special pains to avoid any appearance of hostility to the States in rebellion. It bases its policy, not upon any ground of objection to privateering, -- not upon any doubt as to the right of these communities to issue letters-of-marque, -- but solely upon its wish to avoid the complications of the war, and hold a position of complete neutrality. Its prohibition is carefully applied to both belligerents. Neither party can bring its prizes into English ports.

abstract: The Vanderbill has gone to sea, leaving some sixty of the regiment behind, including Capt. WHITING, who has been detailed to look after the "reserve corps," Lieut. LATHAM, of Company A, First Lieut. Company B, and some twelve pieces of music.
lead_paragraph: The Vanderbilt has gone to sea, leaving some sixty of the regiment behind, including Capt. WHITING, who has been detailed to look after the "reserve corps," Lieut. LATHAM, of Company A, First Lieut. Company B, and some twelve pieces of music. The Adjutant was sent ashore to look up the music, and was also left behind. All those who are still here are ordered to report themselves at the Frankfort House, corner of Frankfort and William streets. They will probably be sent forward on Wednesday or Thursday. About thirty or forty of the men are now on Governor's Island, waiting to be sent on to join their regiment. The subjoined orders have been promulgated:

abstract: The steamships Atlantic and Beltic lying at the foot of Canal-street, and now coaled and will, in a day or two, proceed to the Navy-yard, where they will be changed into gua boats. The steamships Florida and Augusta are also coaled, fires banked, and are ready at any moment to transport troops. The steamer Peerless, which arrived yesterday from Toronto, was formerly a British vessel, and is now under American colors, is 500 tons burden, six years old, has a trunk engine, cylinder 57 inches, and six feet stroke, and was built on the Clyde.

abstract: Andres Cassard vs. The Manhattan Gas Light Company. -- In January, 1858, the plaintiff purchased the interest in the cigar-store No. 592 Broadway, which at the time was lighted by the defendants. In February following, the plaintiff, as he avers, paid the gas bill presented, and asked the collector if it was necessary to give any other name than that of the party of whom he purchased, and whose name the company had. He also avers that the collector said "No; as long as the bills are paid it is all right." Subsequent bills were made out against the premises in the name of the former proprietor, and as alleged by plaintiff, paid by him. On the 1st of May following, plaintiff was however requested to make the usual application to be supplied with gas, and to make a deposit to secure the payment therefor. The plaintiff protested, but the Company threatened that he must either do so or have the supply of gas cut off. Plaintiff made application to have his name substituted in place of the former proprietor, but the Company refused, and sent a messenger to take away the meter. Plaintiff then made application for an injunction to restrain the Company from taking away the meter and cutting off the gas. Such an injunction was temporarily granted; but upon the trial of the cause, the Court dismissed the complaint, giving judgment for the defendants. From that judgment the plaintiff new appeals, claiming that the company had no right to stop his supply of gas for the reasons above given. The respondents' urge that the plaintiff was not entitled to a supply of gas by virtue of any contract between the Company and the former proprietors. Decision reserved. Coudert Brothers for plaintiff. A. Roe and B.W. Bonney for defendants.
lead_paragraph: Andres Cassard vs. The Manhattan Gas Light Company. -- In January, 1858, the plaintiff purchased the interest in the cigar-store No. 592 Broadway, which at the time was lighted by the defendants. abstract: Yesterday was a busy day at the encampment at East New-York, in consequence of orders having been received for the regiment to march forward to Washington to-day. The cheerful countenances of the men, and their active movements, evinced the gratification produced at the prospect of soon meeting with the enemies of the country, and at the same time exhibiting their loyalty and patriotism. Since being quartered at East New York they have been sadly neglected by the Union Defence Committee, many of them being for a long time unprovided with shoes, and a far greater number destitute of absolutely essential articles of clothing. The officers of the regiment' have expanded from their own private purses no less a sum than $5,000, and justly claim this amount at the hands of the Committee. It was only a few days ago that they commenced receiving their tents, the last of which did not arrive on the ground till Saturday of the procedings week. They are now to possession of one hundred small tents and fifteen large ones. All the equipments arrived yesterday, and if the arms are received this morning, as it was expected they would be, nothing will prevent them from leaving to-day. Six P.M. is the hour appointed for departure, and each man is to be supplied with ten days' rations, which will enable them to proceed beyond Washington without any unnecessary delay at that point. The whole force consists of about 800 men, all of whom are well and hearty, with the exception of Lieut. ROBERTS, of Company B, who is suffering from ill health, occasioned by exposure during the Mexican campaigns, and who, on this account will probably be furloughed for a few weeks. The Paymaster will, to-day, disburse the amounts due the soldiers, he having visited the authorities at Albany, yesterday, for the purpose of securing the requisite folds. The regiment may well boast of being excellently officered, for it must be remembered that several of the officers held high positions and achieved signal honors in the Mexican war. The following is a complete list of the officers:

The regiment may well boast of being excellently officered, for it must be remembered that several of the officers held high positions and achieved signal honors in the Mexican war. The following is a complete list of the officers:

abstract: The death of the Minister who in the space of nine years has carried the prostrate monarchy of Piedmont to the rank of a first class European Power, is one of those events which, even in the pressure of our own critical circumstances, commands us to pause and pay our tribute of respect. Count CAVOUR died at Turin on the 6th inst., of congestion of the brain, arising from intense occupation, want of bodily exercise, and either too strong an appetite or else excessive indulgence in the pleasures of his well appointed table.
lead_paragraph: The death of the Minister who in the space of nine years has carried the prostrate monarchy of Piedmont to the rank of a first class European Power, is one of those events which, even in the pressure of our own critical circumstances, commands us to pause and pay our tribute of respect. abstract: Ex-Governor and Secretary FLOYD has issued a proclamation as "Brigadier-General of the Confederate Army," calling upon the people of his military district to arm and organize for the defence of the Virginia and Tennessee Railroad, against an invasion which he understands is threatened by the Valley of the Kanawha. It may serve to allay the apprehensions of the Brigadier-General, to assure him that the threatened invasion of which he has heard a rumor, is not a part of the strategical plans of head-quarters at Washington, but merely a suggestion of the TIMES -- thrown out in our columns as, in our inexperienced judgment, a proper move to enable the loyal troops now forming in Western Virginia, to cut off the communications of the rebel army with the Southwest, and especially to secure the persons of the traitors who, when established in office at Washington, organized this wicked rebellion.
