abstract: At a meeting of the Board of Aldermen held last evening, Alderman VAN BEUNT, of the Eighth Ward, offered a resolution to pay all the bills necessarily incurred by the officers of the Thirteenth, Fourteenth and Twenty-eighth Regiments, previous to their departure for the seat of war. The resolution was referred to a Special Committee of five, to investigate and report.

abstract: The Eighty sixth Anniversary of the Battle of Bunker Hill is observed, to-day, with more than usual manifestations of patriotism. At the monument there was a civic and military gathering. The Stars and Stripes were raised on the flag-staff about forty feet above the shaft, making the height two hundred and sixty feet from the ground. Gov. ANDREW and others made eloquent speeches appropriate to the occasion. Salutes were fired, bells rung

abstract: One regiment of United States Volunteers, probably the Rhode Island, is expected here at daybreak to-morrow. They left Hagerstown last night, and at 5 o'clock this afternoon were at Middletown, eight miles distant from here, where they will encamp for to-night, and resuming their march at dawn, arrive here shortly after daybreak. Their destination is unknown.

abstract: Accounts differ with regard to the whereabouts of Col. STONE's command, which left Washington nearly a week ago, and passed up the Posomac. One authority insists that it is now in quiet possession of Leesburgh, while another is just as positive that it has not yet crossed the Potomac, but still remains at Edwards' Ferry, with a rebel picket in sight across the river. We shall probably learn the exact truth in good time. The report of a skirmish between a party of Federal troops under Major EVERETT and a body of rebels at Seneca is confirmed. Capt. SHEEVE, the Commander of the Virginians, and two of his men were killed. Major EVERETT, it seems, drew all the water out of the canal level in front of his position, and used the tow-path as a breastwork.
lead_paragraph: Accounts differ with regard to the whereabouts of Col. STONE's command, which left Washington nearly a week ago, and passed up the Posomac. abstract: THE WIFE-MURDER IN THIRTEENTH--STREET. -An inquest was yesterday held by Coroner JACKMAN at No. 27 West Thirteenth-street, upon the body of JULIA BULGER, who was murdered by her husband, EDWARD BULGER, on Saturday night. None of the witnesses were present when the violence was done, but all heard the outcry of the deceased for help. She was found upon the floor when the police entered the apartment, with her head, face and eyes badly cut and buried, and a deep gash across her forehead. Officer BOYD was the first to reach the house, and both he and another person whom he had summoned to assist him were assaulted by BULGER when they attempted to enter the room. CHRISTOPHER SILK and GEORGE MARSHALL testified to having heard deceased call "Watch." and say to her husband "ED.. don't strike me." Dr. WOOBTER BEACH Jr., Deputy Coroner, was of opinion that the deceased of Mrs. BELGER had resulted suite soon after the injuries, which were of an extraordinarily violent character, had been inflicted. A verdict was rendered that deceased came to her death by rupture of the liver and other injuries received at the hands of her husband, EDWARD BULGER" The prisoner stated that he was an Irishman, forty years of age, and a carman by occupation With reference to the charge, he said that deceased had struck him first, and for the past two year she had been a worthless character he was committed.

abstract: Harper's Ferry has acquired additional historic interest since my last exciting visit several weeks ago, and my curiosity to behold again its now classic scenes underwent a proportionate augmentation. abstract: We understand that the reporter of the Associated Press at Washington, at considerable expense and risk, procured a full report of the disaster of Monday, at Vienna, and placed it in the telegraph office at Washington in season for publication in the TIMES of yesterday morning. The Government censor at Washington refused to allow it to be transmitted! We are not in the least surprised that the Government should wish to withhold such knowledge from the public as long as possible, -- but we are utterly unable to see what possible harm could arise from their knowing the facts of the disaster the day after it happened.

abstract: We admit a certain necessity of red tape. The more a Government undertakes to manage men in masses, the more it must use of routine. Continual exceptions cannot be made in regulations, intended for great numbers of individuals.
lead_paragraph: We admit a certain necessity of red tape. The more a Government undertakes to manage men in masses, the more it must use of routine. Continual exceptions cannot be made in regulations, intended for great numbers of individuals. No machinery for the rapid movement and working of large bodies of men can be contrived which shall adapt itself for each isolated case. There ought to be in every part of our Army and Commissariat Department the strictest order and system, even if occasionally particular persons suffer. What we object to is, not the special instances of stupid management and dull routine, but that the general regulations are not changed, so as to secure the comfort and good condition of the men. There, for instance, is a regulation or practice in most European armies which gives the soldiers their pay in short periods. In the German armies, the men receive promptly, after ten days, the wages due them. Even in bankrupt Austria, the soldier never fails to get his kreutzers, on the eleventh day.

abstract: The most tragical  conclave on the broad earth, at this moment, is the rump Sovereignty Convention which has again convened itself in solemn session at Richmond, Virginia. The ablest and best of the original members of the Convention, ...
lead_paragraph: The most tragical conclave on the broad earth, at this moment, is the rump Sovereignty Convention which has again convened itself in solemn session at Richmond, Virginia. The ablest and best of the original members of the Convention, CARLISLE and others from the West, have ranged themselves on the side of loyalty, and now sit elsewhere in a nobler Virginia Convention; while the mountebanks like HENRY A. WISE, play their fantastic trick upon another stage. The toothless old beldames actually attending devote themselves principally to "making motions" about each other and about "slave property." Resolutions are passed inquiring how many members are present, why others are absent, and how said absentees feel toward the State in this her hour of trial; and before ascertaining either the one or the other, they resolve upon the "summary chastisement of the cowards and traitors who have entered our State for purposes of subjugation;" they roar terribly about BUTLER's "contraband" policy; and in revenge pass a resolution" authorizing military commands throughout the State to compel free negroes to labor on all works of defense;" they jabber about their "altars and their homes," and would feign avert from them the destruction which their own incendiary action has invited. Spectre-ridden Virginia! proud mother of States and statesmen once -- to such a plight has she been brought by following the lead of WISE, PRYOR, and the "venerable RUFFIN," rather than the counsels of her greater and older son, WASHINGTON.

abstract: The United States frigate St. Lawrence will be reported ready for sea on Monday. She is now at the Philadelphia Navy-yard, where she has been lying since her return from the Brazil squadron, of which she was flag-ship, under Commodore FRENCH FORREST, now commanding "the naval forces of Virginia." She is 1,726 tons burden, and was built at Norfolk.
lead_paragraph: The United States frigate St. Lawrence will be reported ready for sea on Monday. She is now at the Philadelphia Navy-yard, where she has been lying since her return from the Brazil squadron, of which she was flag-ship, under Commodore FRENCH FORREST, now commanding "the naval forces of Virginia." She is 1,726 tons burden, and was built at Norfolk. The St. Lawrence is to join the blockade fleet, several officers having reported for her with that understanding.

abstract: For several days the Northern papers have published--without comment, and apparently without suspicion of its characteristic thievishness--a patriotic appeal of the light-fingered Governor to the sons of Old Mother Virginia, "to come promptly forward, and supply our then with suck arms as they may have," for which a proper receipt will be given in each ...
lead_paragraph: For several days the Northern papers have published -- without comment, and apparently without suspicion of its characteristic thievishness -- a patriotic appeal of the light-fingered Governor to the sons of Old Mother Virginia, "to come promptly forward, and supply our then with suck arms as they may have," for which a proper receipt will be given in each instance by the agent of the State. A prompt compliance is urged, "without a day to be lost," on account of the rapid approach of Federal troops from Ohio upon the "sacred soil" of Virginia. Now this appears from a Confederate stand-point, and would read in their history, as an appeal worthy the head and heart of a patriotic Virginian. But its patriotism is only apparent. It is, in fact, like this veteran pilferer's official orders to our Northern arsenals, one of the Governor's cunningly devised meal-tubs, with the tail of the cat sticking out. Gov. FLOYD, while Secretary of War, transferred from Northern to Southern arsenals more United States arms than would equip four times the number of troops the rebels have or can maintain in the field. Why then, this call for the surrender of every old fowling-piece, King's-arm, sabre, or what-not, that may have been rusting for generations in the cabins and garrets of the mountains and valleys of Virginia, or why transfer these weapons from the hands of the present possessors to others no better able to use them. It requires but a glance at the relative position of the parties, to detect the false pretensions of the appeal, and but a word to show its two faces. It is a trap to disarm the simple-hearted and faithful mountaineers of Virginia, in anticipation of the Western army of occupation, and deprive this loyal Union population of the means of cooperating with the Federal army in putting down the rebellion. Though couched in the language of appeal, it will be enforced with all the severity of a military order, and any attempt at evasion or non-compliance in the surrender will be set to the account of abolition sentiments or submissionism, and draw down upon the defenceless citizen the cruelties and barbarisms which we know too well are the measures of "coercion" employed by these mad Secessionists even upon our own loyal people. The collections thus forced from these Union Districts are to be published abroad as the voluntary response of the people to FLOYD's appeal, and an evidence of the universal prevalence among them of secession sentiments. The very desperation of the secession cause is the secret of their acknowledged executive ability in employing the right men in the right places for the accomplishment of their designs. And in no case have they followed their instinct more correctly than in the use they are making of FLOYD. He is accomplished in his specialty, and can practice it without scruple as well at home as abroad. He is the Artful Dodger of the Southern Confederacy, and when he fails, it will be when the honest laws of meum and teum are again righteously enforced in the Old Dominion. ONE WHO KNOWS THE SOUTH.

abstract: A second blunder of our unpracticed military leaders has exposed our army to a seconds casualty. Advancing without sufficient precaution upon the enemy's lines, near Fairfax Court-house, they found themselves in the presence of what is described as a "masked" battery, of the existence of which ...
lead_paragraph: A second blunder of our unpracticed military leaders has exposed our army to a seconds casualty. Advancing without sufficient precaution upon the enemy's lines, near Fairfax Court-house, they found themselves in the presence of what is described as a "masked" battery, of the existence of which their earliest information came on the wings of a well-directed volley, before which a score of brave fellows bit the dust. A retreat saved the remainder of the little army from destruction. This is a lamentable tale to tell, and to hear. To know that the sturdy masses of men, who are daily thronging through our City streets on their way to the theatre of war, are to be exposed to something much beyond the necessary hazards of war; that they are to be the corpora vilia upon which the experiments of incompetent commanders are to found a future capacity for military leadership is a reflection which does not greatly strengthen confidence in eventual success. It is true we gain daily the prestige furnished by a retreating enemy; and we have the best evidence that the foe shrinks from a fair encounter upon equal conditions, sheltering himself in triply-armed intrenchments, and otherwise manifesting his aversion to hand-in-hand encounters. But these circumstances will not compensate for a destruction of life which the exertion of any ordinary prudence might readily prevent. For the best of things it is prodigal to pay a double price.

abstract: -- The South, it seems, is carrying its peculiar system of financiering into its benevolent movements. JACKSON, the murderer of ELLSWORTH, who met with such quick retribution at the hands of private BROWNELL, has been canonized a Southern saint, and efforts have been made to raise means to provide for the maintenance of his family. Four hundred dollars were recently collected at Charleston, S.C., for this purpose, which money, the Charleston Courier naively states, "has been wisely invested in Confederate State bonds, for the benefit of the family." If the Southern people are honest in their statements of the poverty of the family, it must require a new system of ethics, developed only at the South, to justify an imposition upon the benefactors, and the robbery of the beneficiaries by taking the hard cash contributed by the one away from the other, and giving in return the worthless promies to pay of treasonable and bankrupt rebellion. The Southern people may think that this system of replenishing the treasury of a government may be honorable; but elsewhere, highway robbery compared with it, is exalted to the dignity of a virtue.

abstract: In the account published in the TIMES of Sunday, of the arrival of the slave-ship Nightingale, seized by the sloop-of-war Saratoga, off the coast of Africa, the name of Lieut. TYLER was mentioned as one of the officers of the Saratoga who came home in the Nightingale, the reason of his returning home ...
lead_paragraph: In the account published in the TIMES of Sunday, of the arrival of the slave-ship Nightingale, seized by the sloop-of-war Saratoga, off the coast of Africa, the name of Lieut. TYLER was mentioned as one of the officers of the Saratoga who came home in the Nightingale, the reason of his returning home being given that "his health had been bad during the entire cruise of the Saratoga." The cause of Lieut. TYLER's ill-health was not stated, and to one who should look upon his rotund form and ruddy complexion it would be difficult of conjecture. Since his arrival, however, he has managed to throw a little light upon the true diagnosis of his case, and, for the safety of the patient, he has been handed over to the Government authorities, by whom his disease will no doubt receive the treatment it deserves.

abstract: The next best thing to having a gentleman for your friend is, to have a gentleman for your enemy. Particularly in war. A gentleman enraged is never sanguinary, except when enraged by one of equal cloth with himself. And then, when an equal does enrage him, he, the offending party, ceases to be ...
lead_paragraph: The next best thing to having a gentleman for your friend is, to have a gentleman for your enemy. Particularly in war. A gentleman enraged is never sanguinary, except when enraged by one of equal cloth with himself. And then, when an equal does enrage him, he, the offending party, ceases to be a gentleman in the estimation of the fastidious offended, and rage is superseded by disgust. Thus is the fighting point ever removed from the habits of gentlemen.

lead_paragraph: A SPECULATOR IN COFFINS. -- A few month ago an undertaker in the Bowery, near Houstonstreet, sold a number of first-quality rosewood and mahogany coffins on credit to a middle-aged German of gentlemenly appearance and address who had won his confidence. JACKSON represented that he was about to ship the coffins to California, on speculation, and that he wanted $3,000 worth, to be delivered in installments, as ordered, once a month, just previous to the departure of the steamer. After obtaining possession of the first lot, JACKSON made himself scarce, and the undertaker gradually was led to suspect that he had been duped. He gave a description of JACKSON to the Police, who recently learned that the individual of whom they were in quest had been operating his peculiar manner among the merchants of Philadelphia. Having turned his coffins into cash, he put up at the Continental Hotel, where he lived in magnificent and dashing style, finding it quite easy to make acquaintances of a profitable character. It is said that many business firms in Philadelphia suffered by his rascality, one establishment alone -- that of Messrs. LENNON & GILLENDER losing $8,000 by believing his misrepresentations. Before measures were taken to arrest him he came to this City, and on Monday evening he was encountered in the Bowery by Detectives SLOWEY and DUSENBERRY. They knew him immediately from the description that had been left at the office, and DUSENBERRY, stopping up, said "How d'ye do, Mr. JACKSON." The latter replied, "Quite well, but really he had not the pleasure, &c.," when SLOWEY interposed with a question as to what time he intended to call for those other coffins. Light at once flashed upon JACKSON's mind. He know he was caught and he made the best of it, making a full acknowledgment of his guilt when interrogated with reference to his many swindling transactions. He was confined at Head-quarters, and yesterday afternoon departed for Philadelphia, consenting to waive the formality of a requisition from the Governor of Pennsylvania.

abstract: Our readers will not have forgotten our attempt to demonstrate, some weeks since, that the insurgent army was distributed over so large an area that its communications could not be maintained, and that, consequently, some of its isolated divisions must either ...
lead_paragraph: Our readers will not have forgotten our attempt to demonstrate, some weeks since, that the insurgent army was distributed over so large an area that its communications could not be maintained, and that, consequently, some of its isolated divisions must either retreat or be cut off. Gen. JOHNSON's command at Harper's Ferry, we ventured to suggest, was posted in a position utterly untenable -- a very trap, whence it would he compelled either to retreat or surrender. A few days since, we began to receive news of the destruction of the bridges across the Potomac; then, of breaking up the boats on the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal; next, that the insurgents were tearing down the locks; and, finally, that they were destroying the dams on that costly work -- together with accounts of much other of that preliminary devastation which usually marks the beginning, and too often the progress, of a retiring army.

abstract: -- A new "Yankee Notion" has been brought to the notice of the Virginia rebels. Major EVERETT, it is stated, made the tow-path of the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal at Seneca, Md., available for the purposes of a breastwork, on the occasion of his recent skirmish with the enemy, by drawing the water from the Canal. He illustrates how the minds of men who live in those districts where labor is respected, and inventive genius encouraged, in times of peace, are, in war, quickened into a perception of new means by which they can insure their own safety, while they are permitted to deal defeat or destruction to the enemy. The Southern soldier would as soon have thought of diving for pearls in the Canal as of finding in such a work the essentials of a fortification ready made.

abstract: Another unfortunate encounter with the rebel forces, in which a small body of our troops were literally run into the very jaws of destruction is recorded this morning. The first Ohio Regiment, Commanded by Col. McCOOK, were on Monday afternoon sent out from Alexandria by rail to Vienna, with orders to drop companies at various ...
lead_paragraph: Another unfortunate encounter with the rebel forces, in which a small body of our troops were literally run into the very jaws of destruction is recorded this morning. The first Ohio Regiment, Commanded by Col. MCCOOK, were on Monday afternoon sent out from Alexandria by rail to Vienna, with orders to drop companies at various points along the route, to hold the road safe from damage by the rebel forces. All but four companies had thus been dropped, when, on approaching Vienna, a masked battery stationed at a curve in the road, which at that point passed through a deep cut, opened upon the train, with round shot, shell and grape, causing the death of a number of our troops, and wounding many others, before the train could be stopped. Some of the running gear of the train was damaged by the fire, so that the engine, which was in the rear, could not draw it back out of range, and the men were consequently forced to leave the cars and retire on foot, which they did in good order, taking their killed and wounded. Finding that the rebel battery was supported by a regiment of infantry and a body of cavalry, Gen. SCHENCK, who commanded the expedition, thought it prudent to retire, which he did, without further molestation from the enemy, who are understood to have been South Carolinians. The engineer in charge of the train detached his engine and returned to Alexandria, leaving the troops to their fate.

abstract: A gentleman of high literary ability, well-known by his contributions to literature, as well as by his efforts in other departments, and who has been honorably connected with the public service, has been reduced, through a protracted, and, it is feared, a permanent blindness, to a condition of extreme pecuniary embarrassment. The Editor of the TIMES knows the circumstances of the case, and makes this renewed appeal to those who may be disposed to aid the gentleman referred to and his suffering family. Any moneys that may be sent to this office for their relief, will be gratefully acknowledged and properly applied.

abstract: The CincinnatiCommercial of the 13th has the following account of a Railroad collision in Ohio: The collision on the Central Ohio Railroad, on Monday night, 10th inst., some four or five miles west of Bellaire, was frightful. It occurred at a sharp curve, and the night was intensely dark. The accommodation passenger train, with a few passengers, was dashing westward at the usual rate of speed. The wood train was crashing round the curve at high speed. Three men were killed outright -- horribly mangled; two were severely wounded; all except one, poor men, employes of the Railroad Company, connected with the wood and construction department of the road. The dead were JOHN MITCHELL, of Barnesville, and MCCULLOCH, helpers on the train and a citizen of Barnesville. The wounded were Mr. SAULSBURY, conductor, Mr. PORTER, engineer of the wood train, and GEORGE ELLIS, "wood-passer." The engineer's right shoulder blade was broken and he was otherwise severely hurt. Mr. SAULSBURY's back was badly hurt, and he was miscellaneously bruised; and ELLIS had one leg broken, besides receiving several painful concusions. Our informant was not able to furnish the names of the other two who were injured. Mr. THOMPSON, conductor of the accommodation train, leaped from it the instant of the collision, and landed safely, excepting that one of his ankles were sprained. Mr. SNIVELY, agent for Adams' Express, and Mr. BROWN, baggage-master, were in the baggage car, when the tender of the engine was crushed in upon them. The former was somewhat bruised. The escape of either was almost miraculous, since the wreck of the tender was literally dovetailed into the baggage-car. Four or five wood cars were wrecked, and both locomotives were apparently destroyed. The wrecks were removed within a few hours, and the trains resumed their trips.

abstract: Brig.-Gen. SCHENCK, who was in command of the Ohio forces in this unfortunate encounter, was born in Franklin, Warren County, Ohio, on October 4, 1809. In 1827 he graduated with honor at the Miami University, and for two years afterwards acted as tutor in that institution, leaving the post to commence the study of law. In 1831 he was admitted to the bar and settled down in Dayton, where he has since resided. He held a seat in the Ohio Legislature in 1840 and 1842; served as Representative in Congress four terms, from 1843 to 1851, during which time he held many prominent positions on Committees. President FILLMORE appointed him Minister to Brazil, and during his two years' residence there he negotiated several treaties. Since 1853, he has been identified with railroad interests in the West, and recently was President of a line running from Fort Wayne to the Mississippi River. He has the reputation of being a determined and brave man; but apart from these characteristics, his Brigadier-Generalship seems to be the only qualification which entitles him to lead troops to battle.

abstract: The Convention now is session at Wheeling, in which are represented about forty countries of Western Virginia, have, by a formal and unanimous vote, resolved to cut loose from the Old Dominion and form for them  selves a new and independent State. What name they will give to their new Commonwealth is not yet discussed.
lead_paragraph: The Convention now is session at Wheeling, in which are represented about forty countries of Western Virginia, have, by a formal and unanimous vote, resolved to cut loose from the Old Dominion and form for them selves a new and independent State. What name they will give to their new Commonwealth is not yet discussed. It may be ALLEGHANY. But whatever the name, the fact will be the same. The great State of Virginia is to be dismembered by the voluntary act of over a half million of her late citizens; and a new State formed from the Western part of her territory will claim a place in the Union.

abstract: Brigadier FLOYD has secured a certain reputation for prescience. It was his foresight that armed the Pro-Slavery insurgents, and very nearly disarmed the Government; it was FLOYD who, in anticipation of Confederate scrip, battened of the profits of Indian Trust Bonds; and what is germain to the present moment, it is FLOYD who begs the population, of Southwestern Virginia to bring in the only weapons they possess, the lash excepted, by which to keep the negroes in order, and deposit them for the use of himself and his sanguinary brigade. For this gallant officer foresees the strong probability of a descent upon his own neighborhood, by those Western armies, before whom the rebels have thus far scattered as so many sheep.
lead_paragraph: Brigadier FLOYD has secured a certain reputation for prescience. abstract: The trial of Nathaniel Gordon, the master of the Erie, for being engaged in the Slave-trade, was continued to-day. The Government gave some further evidence as to the parentage of Gordon, and proved that they had taken all means in their power to procure the attendance of Lieut. Dunnington, who was the officer from the Mohican who boarded the Erie, but who, being in Tennessee, could not now be brought here, and would not come himself.

abstract: Gen. LYON, who is in command of the Federal troops in Missouri, is evidently the right man in the right place. To a thorough military education and experience, he adds a promptness of decision and a vigor of execution, eminently appropriate to the stirring times in which he is called to act. Besides these admirable adaptations to service, he is inspired by that vigilant and enthusiastic loyalty which anticipates "situations," and ...
lead_paragraph: Gen. LYON, who is in command of the Federal troops in Missouri, is evidently the right man in the right place. To a thorough military education and experience, he adds a promptness of decision and a vigor of execution, eminently appropriate to the stirring times in which he is called to act. Besides these admirable adaptations to service, he is inspired by that vigilant and enthusiastic loyalty which anticipates "situations," and by being prepared for them before hand, he has nothing to do but execute and advance when his orders come. Not a bit of red tape has entangled the steps of the Government where Gen. LYON has commanded. We can always go to sleep quietly on a perplexing attitude of affairs in Missouri, for we know that a competent and sleepless leader is there.

abstract: The details of General Order No. 15, of the War Department, promulgated on the 4th of May last, have been published. In the list of officers appointed to positions of the new regiments, there are about five sixths outside appointments.
lead_paragraph: The details of General Order No. 15, of the War Department, promulgated on the 4th of May last, have been published. In the list of officers appointed to positions of the new regiments, there are about five sixths outside appointments. The following men have been promoted from the ranks to commissions: J.W. Spangler, Peter McGratin, Hugh McQuade, Cameron McClellan, (Second Cavalry,) William H. Brown, Frank Minnier, Edward Ball, Edward Depew, Frank Clark, Fred. McCourcey, Patrick Colins, Joseph H. Vanderstice, Wm. Ooceleston, Wilbur F. Melbourne, Wm. H. Ingerton, Thomas J. Dromin, Dick Burnes, Henry T. Inman, James Simmons, James Powell, Colin Ferguson, (of the Fort Sumter Garrison,) W.H. Leamy. Frank Brownell, the avenger of Col. Ellsworth, has also got a Second Lieutenant's commission. So, out of 1,500 officers made, only 21 are raised from the regular ranks.

abstract: Brig. Gen. NATHANIEL LYON, whose brilliant exploit at Booneville is now the theme of every tongue, is a native of Connecticut, having been born near the birthplace of Hon. GIDEON WELLES, Secretary of the Navy.
lead_paragraph: Brig.-Gen. NATHANIEL LYON, whose brilliant exploit at Booneville is now the theme of every tongue, is a native of Connecticut, having been born near the birthplace of Hon. GIDEON WELLES, Secretary of the Navy. He graduated with honors at the West Point Academy, and entered the regular army as a Second-Lieutenant in the Second Infantry, his first commission beating date on the 1st July, 1841. He was promoted to a Brevet First-Lieutenancy shortly afterward, subsequently to a Captaincy. He has occupied the latter rank practically since the 11th of June, 1851, and was booked for advancement to a higher position at the first opportunity, he being entitled to that title by brevet, before his recent appointments to a Lieutenant-Colonelcy and a Brigadier Generalship.

abstract: The Washington Star, of June 15, says: Yesterday, at 12 M., as a herd of beeves were being driven across the Long Bridge from the Virginia shore, two sections of the Virginia end gave way, and some fifty of the cattle were dropped into the water. After great difficulty, all, save eight or ten, were saved. A considerable force was immediately set to work repairing the damage, and by dark travel was again resumed over the bridge. It is suspected that there has been tampering with that portion of the bridge, and a strict guard will be established over it in future.
lead_paragraph: The Washington Star, of June 15, says: Yesterday, at 12 M., as a herd of beeves were being driven across the Long Bridge from the Virginia shore, two sections of the Virginia end gave way, and some fifty of the cattle were dropped into the water. abstract: Col. VON STEINWRER'S Regiment the Twenty-ninth did not succeed in getting off yesterday. The men have received their arms and equipments, and by this time have probably drawn a month's pay. But, although the bare necessities have thus been supplied, there are many small things to be procured, such as colors, music, , before the regiment will feel itself comfortably in harness.
lead_paragraph: Col. VON STEINWRER's Regiment -- the Twenty-ninth -- did not succeed in getting off yesterday. The men have received their arms and equipments, and by this time have probably drawn a month's pay. But, although the bare necessities have thus been supplied, there are many small things to be procured, such as colors, music, &c., before the regiment will feel itself comfortably in harness. There is no reserved fund for providing these things; not a penny has been received from the Union Defence Committee, and the men from their scanty purses cannot afford -- even if they felt disposed -- to complete their equipment for the war. The friends of the regiment are therefore raising contributions to further this object.

abstract: Senator ANDREW JOHNSON arrived here yesterday, en route to Washington. He made a three hours' speech last night to a very large audience, and declared in favor of a positive and unconditional Union and the maintenance of the General Government. East Tennessee, he said, would never leave the Union, if armed to prevent subjugation. His remarks were well received and warmly applauded.
lead_paragraph: Senator ANDREW JOHNSON arrived here yesterday, en route to Washington. abstract: The Eighteenth Regiment New-York Volunteers, Col. JACKSON, arrived at Jersey City, yesterday, at 1 1/3 P.M., having embarked the night previous from Albany at 6 o'clock P.M., on the barges President and Charles T. Colt, and the small steamer McDonald.
lead_paragraph: The Eighteenth Regiment New-York Volunteers, Col. JACKSON, arrived at Jersey City, yesterday, at 1 1/3 P.M., having embarked the night previous from Albany at 6 o'clock P.M., on the barges President and Charles T. Colt, and the small steamer McDonald. The men report themselves well and hearty, and certainly their appearance would not lead one to think otherwise. They enjoyed themselves much during the trip down the river, and were well pleased with the accommodations on the boat. On approaching the pier the men were delighted at seeing several cases of Enfield rifle muskets, which had been conveyed thither for distribution among them, and shortly after the boats were made fast, each man was armed. They received equipments at Albany, and when leaving that city a dense population lined the thoroughfares to witness their departure. The steamer New-World was ladened with people, who cheered the troops lustily as they moved away. The regiment is in posession of a beautiful banner, which was presented to it May 20, by lady friends of Albany. The material is double silk, fringed with gold, and bears the motto, "Rally around it." The staff is of oak, highly polished and tipped with silver, and ornamented with a silver band, upon which is inscribed, "Presented to the Eighteenth Regiment New-York State Volunteers, Col. JACKSON, from lady friends of Albany." The regiment numbers 800 men, who are provided with three days' rations, and their intention waste leave for Washington, via Harrisburgh, yesterday evening. The following list comprises the officers of this gallant and every-way efficient body of men: Colonel, W.A. Jackson; Lieutenant-Colonel, W.H. Young; Major, George R. Meyers; Adjutant, J.H. Russell; Surgeon, J. Vanigan; Assistant Surgeon, A.A. Edmundson; Quartermaster, W.V. Horsfall; Chaplain, A.A. Farr. Company A, Captain, Wm. S. Gridley; First Lieutenant, Daniel H. Daily; Second Lieutenant, Edmund Groot. Company B,Captain, John Hastings; First Lieutenant, H. Wans; Second Lieutenant, ----- Norton. Company C, Captain, H. Witsie; First Lieutenant J. Mitchell; Second Lieutenant, ----- Leath. Company D, Captain, John C. McGinnis; First Lieutenant, George Barry; Second Lieutenant, R.M. Seyrs. Company E, Captain, S. Truex; First Lieutenant, William Horsfall; Second Lieutenant, John Vedder. Company F, Captain, Michael Donavan; First Lieutenant, Edward Fisher; Second Lieutenant, John Mooney. Company G, Captain, Henry Frarot; First Lieutenant, James Morgan; Second Lieutenant, William Ellis. Company H, Captain, P. Hogan; First Lieutenant, Theodore Rogers; Second Lieutenant, W.E. Carmichael. Company I, Captain, T.J. Rudcliff; First Lieutenant, George Chapman; Second Lieutenant, O.J. Heald. Company K, Captain, Daniel L. Bartlett; First Lieutenant, Albert Seeley; Second Lieutenant, R. Goodnee.

abstract: Our Washington correspondence a day or two since gave late and important intelligence from Mexico. It appears that our Minister, Mr. CORWIN, presented his credentials, and was duly received by the Mexican Government on the 21st ult. From all we can learn, it does not appear that Mr. CORWIN has any immediate prospect of success in the negotiation of a treaty.

abstract: It is a hopeful sign of the speedy downfall of rebellion that, in the first spasm of sectional ardor and oligarchic rage, the traitors are already reduced to the last resorts of exhaustive war.
lead_paragraph: It is a hopeful sign of the speedy downfall of rebellion that, in the first spasm of sectional ardor and oligarchic rage, the traitors are already reduced to the last resorts of exhaustive war. It was not until France, under the First NAPOLEON had carried on an unequal contest with England and her continental allies for nearly twenty years, that the supply of men fit for military service began to fail, and that the conscription began to operate upon mere boys, or men of under size. But in the beginning of the conflict, the rebels are calling upon the youths under the prescribed military minimum age of eighteen, and men over the maximum of forty-five, to volunteer. They are also forcing men into their service on pain of forfeiture of goods and imprisonment or death, while the very slaves and despised free negroes are called upon to serve in the ranks or in the intrenchments. Their financial expedients show equal desperation, and betoken as speedy exhaustion of resources. The war is initiated by forced loans, and the first campaign is eked out upon the faith of "bonds" which no one expects to see redeemed, or upon the more solid basis of ladies' pin-money and jewelry.
headline: {'main': 'A Comparison of Resources.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A Comparison of Resources.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: To-day a special election is held in Kentucky for the choice of Congressmen to represent that State at the called session to meet on the 4th of July. Union candidates are in the field, with every prospect of success, in all the districts but two.
lead_paragraph: To-day a special election is held in Kentucky for the choice of Congressmen to represent that State at the called session to meet on the 4th of July. Union candidates are in the field, with every prospect of success, in all the districts but two. But still, the public mind there is in such a state of ferment, and the causes exciting to sudden popular revulsion so numerous, that nothing can be predicated with certainty as to the result.

abstract: The chance to send a letter to the TIMES has offered, and I cheerfully embrace it. My long silence was occasioned by two facts: First, we left Pickens. abstract: The ship Monarch of the Sea, Capt. GARDNER, arrived at this port yesterday from Liverpool, having a general cargo and 954 Mormon passengers. This is the largest number of Mormons that ever arrived at this port in one vessel.
lead_paragraph: The ship Monarch of the Sea, Capt. GARDNER, arrived at this port yesterday from Liverpool, having a general cargo and 954 Mormon passengers. This is the largest number of Mormons that ever arrived at this port in one vessel. They are all in fine health, and will leave to-morrow for Utah or Salt Lake City, where they intend to settle. Capt. GARDNER informs us that the most perfect order and discipline is maintained, among this class of passengers.

abstract: The question of food is daily becoming a more perplexing and dangerous one in the Confederate States. The lack of meat and bread may yet accomplish what reason and patriotism have failed to do.
lead_paragraph: The question of food is daily becoming a more perplexing and dangerous one in the Confederate States. The lack of meat and bread may yet accomplish what reason and patriotism have failed to do. In order to have men fight well it is absolutely necessary that they be fed well. There is a closer dependence of pluck upon porridge than the poetic devotees of military glory are willing to admit. And therefore it is that a wise captain who is about to lead an army forth, hoping that his men shall win imperishable honors and live in history as heroes in the expected contest with foes, carefully provides that they shall have enough of present substantial food while they work and fight for future fame.

abstract: This regiment, Thirty-eighth, which was ordered to leave for Washington on Tuesday, broke camp yesterday and started for Washington. The reason it did not leave on Tuesday is that the men neither received their arms or their pay. Yesterday, however, saw both those matters arranged, and the men heard with cheerful faces and beating hearts, the order for them to march.
lead_paragraph: This regiment, Thirty-eighth, which was ordered to leave for Washington on Tuesday, broke camp yesterday and started for Washington. The reason it did not leave on Tuesday is that the men neither received their arms or their pay. Yesterday, however, saw both those matters arranged, and the men heard with cheerful faces and beating hearts, the order for them to march. In Tuesday's paper we gave a full description of this regiment, with the list of officers, so at present it is only necessary to chronicle is departure. On leaving East New-York, it marched down to the Grandstreet ferry; crossed over, marched down Grand street to Broadway, from thence to Jersey City, where it got on board the cars for Washington, Supper hadbeen provided for them at the Park Barracks, but Col. WARD would not allow his men to stop and partake of it, as they had a sufficiency of rations in their haversacks, and he was anxious to get to the depot as soon as possible. This regiment is composed of fine athletic young fellows, and their appearance and drill made a marked impression as they marched down Broadway.

abstract: One of the first questions with which Congress will have to deal will be that of revenue. Some additional legislation will be imperatively necessary, to carry the country through the financial embarrassments of the war.
lead_paragraph: One of the first questions with which Congress will have to deal will be that of revenue. Some additional legislation will be imperatively necessary, to carry the country through the financial embarrassments of the war. Our tariff was adopted with no other object than to raise revenue enough for the ordinary expenses of the Government: -- and even this it will not do under the falling off in the taxable imports of the country. A resort to loans is safe, so long as it is backed up by proper legislative provision for the punctual payment of interest, and the ultimate discharge of the principal. But we take it for granted that Congress will take good care that Government six per cent. Stock is not again sold at 85.

abstract: The details of General Order No. 15, of the War Department, promulgated on the 4th of May last, have been published. In the list of officers appointed to positions of the new regiments, there are about five sixths outside appointments.
lead_paragraph: The details of General Order No. 15, of the War Department, promulgated on the 4th of May last, have been published. In the list of officers appointed to positions of the new regiments, there are about five sixths outside appointments. The following men have been promoted from the ranks to commissions: J.W. Spangler, Peter McGrath, Hugh McQuade, Cameron McClellan, (Second Cavalry,) William H. Brown, Frank Minnier, Edward Ball, Edward Depew, Frank Clark, Fred. McCourcey, Patrick Collins, Joseph H. Vanderstice, Wm. Ooceleston, Wilbur F. Melbourne, Wm. H. Ingerton, Thomas J. Dromin, Dick Burnes, Henry T. Inman, James Simmons, James Powell, Colin Ferguson, (of the Fort Sumter Garrison,) W.H. Leamy, Frank Brownell, the avenger of Col. Ellsworth, has also got a Second Lieutenant's commission. So, out of 1,500 officers made, only 21 are raised from the regular ranks.

abstract: The intelligence which reached us at a late hour on Tuesday night, that a battle had been fought at Booneville, Mo., between the Federal forces, under Gen. LYON, and the rebels concentrated there by Gov. JACKSON, proves to have been correct in all essential particulars.
lead_paragraph: The intelligence which reached us at a late hour on Tuesday night, that a battle had been fought at Booneville, Mo., between the Federal forces, under Gen. LYON, and the rebels concentrated there by Gov. JACKSON, proves to have been correct in all essential particulars. Gen. LYON landed four miles below Booneville, and marching up, opened a heavy cannonade upon the rebel forces, who dispersed into adjacent woods, where, under cover, they opened a brisk fire on the Federal troops. Gen. LYON, in order to draw the rebels from cover, feigned a retreat to the boats. This stratagem was perfectly successful, as the rebels falling into the trap, rallied and followed into an open field, where Gen. LYON halted, faced his troops about, and bringing the whole force of his artillery to bear, opened a murderous fire, which caused three hundred of the rebels to bite the dust. The rest, who were able, led in all directions, leaving their arms upon the field, and Gen. LYON was soon in quiet possession of Booneville. Gov. JACKSON, it is stated, viewed the battle from a safe position on a distant hill, and at its conclusion fled to parts unknown. Gen PRISE, it appears, was not killed in the action, as reported. He was taken seriously ill at the commencement, and left for home on a steamer.

abstract: EXHIBITION OF THE PREPARATORY DEPARTMENT OF THE NEW-YORK UNIVERSITY. The annual exhibition of the pupils attending the Grammar School attached to the New-York University, was presented yesterday in the large chapel of the institution.
lead_paragraph: EXHIBITION OF THE PREPARATORY DEPARTMENT OF THE NEW-YORK UNIVERSITY. -- The annual exhibition of the pupils attending the Grammar School attached to the New-York University, was presented yesterday in the large chapel of the institution. The most novel feature of the occasion was the profusion of flags of the Union which gaily decorated the room, almost concealing in their numerous folds its heavy, sembre-looking furniture. There are about 90 pupils in the Preparatory Department, and of course, a large audience, -- composed mainly of interested mothers and sisters -- lent their encouraging presence to the trembling novitiates in the art of declamation. Chancellor FERRIS, presided, and the Faculty were seated on the platform with him. The programme was long, but well selected, and with few exceptions the boys demonstrated that they had profited by the teaching of Prof. BROWN, their instructor in elocution Music by Dodworth's Band agreeably relieved the speaking. The exercises were concluded by a distribution of prizes for exemplary conduct and proficiency. In the evening an oration was delivered before the Alumni Association, by Mr BOPPER, of Long island, a graduate of the Class of 1839. The annual commencement of the of the University will take place at Niblo's Theatre to-day.

abstract: Col. EMORY in the national service is a step which the Administration will have serious reasons to regret. It is true he has professed profound regret for having caused his resignation to be tendered, upon the mistaken assumption that Maryland, his native State, would leave the Union; and that, in bringing off his force from Northwestern Texas, he exhibited loyal dispositions, and an efficiency which should qualify our strong condemnation. And it may be possible his zeal and energy may be redoubled, in order to efface the stain which his proposed treason has left upon his name. On the other hand, his retention must grossly offend those faithful officers who have never faltered in their fidelity, and who have much to suffer in witnessing the promotion of incompetent political hacks to positions for which they are so much more notably fitted. It is time also, that the Government should afford some intimation that it regards treason as in some degree reprehensible, and as an insufficient claim to reward and promotion. Col. EMORY demonstrated at a critical moment his belief that his allegiance to a State was of higher obligation than his allegiance to a Government, which had educated, sustained, and favored him from the beginning of his career. It is upon those who hold this heresy the North is proposing to make war; the Government is actually encouraging and employing them.

abstract: The Twenty-second annual Commencement of this institution was held yesterday at the Madison-avenue Baptist Church, the President, Dr. HENRY M. PRICE, presiding. A large audience was in attendance, and the exercises were very interesting. Premiums for scholarships were awarded to 28 pupils of the preparatory course, and honorable testimonials to 115 young ladies in the various departments. The graduating class numbered 18, as follows: Mattie C. Ackerman, Carrie A. Capron, Harriet L. Dolsen, Almira E. Gurnsey, Emma L. Holkins, Kate S. Lewis, Mary K. Pierce, S. Lizzie Post, Elizabeth Scott, Hattie N. Atwood, Elvina Close, Maggie E. Garretson, Cecelia R. Harkness, Maria L. Hoyle, Hattie E. Myers, Mary P. Pitkin, Sarah C. Sammis, Jennie B. Stevenson. After the award of the diplomas the graduating class was addressed by Rev. ASA D. SMITH, D.D., following which the exercises closed with singing and the Benediction.

abstract: We are requested to call attention to the grand operatic concert to be given at the Academy of Music, on Saturday evening next the 22d inst., in aid of the Regimental Fund of the United States Guards Regiment. This regiment is officered almost exclusively ...
lead_paragraph: We are requested to call attention to the grand operatic concert to be given at the Academy of Music, on Saturday evening next the 22d inst., in aid of the Regimental Fund of the United States Guards Regiment. This regiment is officered almost exclusively by soldiers who have seen actual service -- several of whom are graduates of military schools -- and it is the purpose of Col. MONTGOMERY to admit no officer into his regiment who has not seen actual service, or who is not at least thoroughly and efficiently drilled. The corps is assured of acceptance by the Government immediately upon its complete organization, and appeals to the public to come forward to its assistance. The most eminent musical celebrities have kindly volunteered their services for the occasion, including Miss HINCKLEY, Madam STRAKOSCH, Signors SUSINI and BARILI, Mr. MILLS, the eminent pianist, and others, together with the full orchestra of the Academy of Music, under the leadership of Mr. THEODORE THOMAS. We have no doubt that the affair will be entirely successful, and one long to be remembered by the community. Tickets are placed at the low price of 50 cents each, and are for sale at the principal music stores to-day, and at the Academy of Music on Saturday. See advertisement in another column.

abstract: newspapers of Texas have got wind of the existence of a secret association of Union men in that State; and the paper which conveys to us the news confesses also that the Unionists there have not yet been extirpated. It is certainly unfortunate that our loyal fellow-countrymen in the South should be compelled to adopt such a mode of maintaining their organization. Under a free Government secret political associations should have no existence, and the fact that the present disunion revolt owes its success, in great measure, to the machinations of secret treasonable leagues working under the title of "K.G.C.," "Sons of the South," Vigilance Committees, &c., ought to be sufficient to banish them forever from the category of political forces. (YANCEY, in his infamous Slaughter letter, revealed the villainous purposes for which such organizations were used.) But in a despotism, such as now domineers all over the South -- where freedom of speech, of action, and of association are prohibited -- where it is instant assassination to be known as a Union man, there is really no other way of forming a nucleus for combined and effective action. If the tens of thousands of Union men in Texas take wise advantage of the absence of the leading Texan brigands, now in Virginia and elsewhere, and consolidate themselves throughout the State, they can soon, with the Federal aid which will be forthcoming, roll back the tide of anarchy and destruction which is now sweeping over their noble State.

abstract: At the meeting of the Syrian Conference, yesterday, a definitive scheme was agreed to, according to which there will be one Christian Governor for the whole of the Lebanon, to be provisionally appointed by the Porte for three years. The Maronites and Druses are each to have a sub-Governor. Turkish troops will provisionally occupy the main roads of the country. TURIN, Saturday, June 8.

abstract: Israel Steinhart vs. John G. Boker. -- This case was stated in the TIMES about a year since, at the time it was tried. There is nothing in it of particular importance, excepting the question of the sufficiency of notice to the defendant that L700 of money in English banknotes were not the property of one Boker, who gave them to the defendant in payment for wires purchased of him. Upon the determination of this point rests the question of title to the money.

abstract: The news from England is direful to the Government of Mr. JEFFERSON DAVIS. A defeat by far the most damaging the rebel cause has yet, suffered abroad, has just been experienced in the English House of Commons.
lead_paragraph: The news from England is direful to the Government of Mr. JEFFERSON DAVIS. A defeat by far the most damaging the rebel cause has yet, suffered abroad, has just been experienced in the English House of Commons. Mr. GREGORY, the champion of the Cotton Confederacy, whose notice of an intended motion in favor of acknowledging its independence has delighted so many Southern hearts, has abandoned his purpose; and the hails of Parliament will not be made to resound with the beauties of free government based exclusively on the idea of chattel Slavery.

abstract: burgh Whig is in extacies over a free negro named JORDAN CHAVIS, who has written a letter to the agent of the Confederate Loan, in which he states that he has long been a resident of the County, and had received a land-warrant for services in the War of 1812; but being too old for active service, he now desires to present a horse to a cavalry company, and he also authorizes the agent to draw upon him for $500, to be paid out of his next crop, for the use of the Confederacy. The respectful manner in which the Whig speaks of CHAVIS is a little remarkable, especially in view of the Dred Scott decision. The paragraph is headed "Patriotic Liberality of a Colored Man." There is no intimation that he is a "negro," or a "nigger," or even a "boy;" but he is spoken of as "a real bona fide colored man, long well known in this community, who, by his correct and honest deportment, has gained the esteem of all who knew him." We doubt whether any "free nigger" who could not bring five hundred such substantial reasons for the respect of the Southern Confederacy as CHAVIS did, could get so high a eulogium from a Southern journal.

abstract: The undersigned, merchants and property owners of the City of New-York, respectfully represent, that inasmuch as the present, emergencies of the Government, may, and probably will require all the available forces of the regular service to be engaged in ac-
lead_paragraph: The undersigned, merchants and property owners of the City of New-York, respectfully represent, that inasmuch as the present, emergencies of the Government, may, and probably will require all the available forces of the regular service to be engaged in active operations, and that our harbor and forts may consequently be left with a force insufficient for its protection, it is deemed imperative that a Local Artillery Battalion, competently drilled by experienced officers, should be organized and equipped at once; and as the undersigned are informed that competent officers are available for such service, and that one company of experienced men is already formed and capable of performing this service, which would form a nucleus for the organization, we respectfully request that such a battalion may be organized at once.

abstract: Senator JOHNSON, of Tennessee, is reported on his way to Washington, being safely out of reach of the malignants that now control the political fortunes of that State. A few days ago, the Memphis Avalanche announced that indictments were at once to be found against Senator JOHNSON, Wm. G. BROWNLOW, EMERSON ETHERIDGE and other Unionists, for treason against the State, and warrants issued for their arrest. But none of these ...
lead_paragraph: Senator JOHNSON, of Tennessee, is reported on his way to Washington, being safely out of reach of the malignants that now control the political fortunes of that State. A few days ago, the Memphis Avalanche announced that indictments were at once to be found against Senator JOHNSON, Wm. G. BROWNLOW, EMERSON ETHERIDGE and other Unionists, for treason against the State, and warrants issued for their arrest. But none of these patriots are yet seized; nor does it appear that the gallant spirits of East Tennessee, who have sustained the Union, are at all prepared to go under the yoke of Confederate tyranny, and yield up their liberties, as well as their leaders, to the tender mercies of the Confederate Government.

abstract: It is natural enough that Americans should feel somewhat sore at the way the English Press talks about American affairs, and yet it is certain that they have treated us with much more fairness and candor than they ever have shown towards the Continental Powers or among themselves.

abstract: Accounts from the Virginia side of the Potomac indicate that the rebels are gradually extending and strengthening their lines, which are now supposed to reach from the vicinity of Occoquan to Centreville, and that they are intrenching themselves with heavy ordnance in the neighborhood of Fairfax Station, having fallen back from Fairfax Court-house. The station is between three ...
lead_paragraph: Accounts from the Virginia side of the Potomac indicate that the rebels are gradually extending and strengthening their lines, which are now supposed to reach from the vicinity of Occoquan to Centreville, and that they are intrenching themselves with heavy ordnance in the neighborhood of Fairfax Station, having fallen back from Fairfax Court-house. The station is between three and four miles from the Court-house, and about fourteen from Alexandria. It is believed also, that BEAUREGARD is pushing forward considerable bodies of troops daily from Manassas Junction, to strengthen his advanced lines, which now threaten those of the Federal Army in their entire extent. Gen. SCOTT, however, is fully advised of the rebel movements, and will be ready to meet them at every point.

abstract: more papers and correspondence, which exult in the fact that Gen. BANKS is resolved to continue the "conciliatory" policy of Gen. CADWALLADER, also furnish us with clear and unmistakable evidence of the mischievous effects of that policy. The secession sentiment in Baltimore is represented to be greatly in the ascendant. It includes three-fourths of the wealthy and middle classes; and so daring have its demonstrations become, that the exhibition of Union emblems, and the declaration of Union sentiments, are no longer safe. The press is noisy in its seditious assaults upon the Federal Government, and its expressions of sympathy with the rebels. Marshal KANE flaunts about the streets his hostility to the Government, and his defiance of the troops. Such is the fruit of conciliation. If it be persisted in, we shall have arepetition of the horrors of April 17; and for the blood that shall be shed, those who have held the reins of authority with so much laxity will be held responsible.

She is a woman about fifty years of age, giving the name of MARY LEEMAN. Her lady-like ap- ...
lead_paragraph: FEMININE AGILITY. -- The confidence operator, whose plan of awindling respectable residents of the up-town districts, by representing herself as the daughter of Gen. HALL, seeking donations in aid of the "Old Ladies' Home," has been already published, was arrested, in the Twentieth Ward, on Wednesday night. She is a woman about fifty years of age, giving the name of MARY LEEMAN. Her lady-like appearance impelled her kind-hearted custodians to place her in confinement in a rear apartment of the Station-house, instead of the cells where common prisoners are confined, and she imposed upon their good nature by escaping. To accomplish her object, it was necessary to leap from a window and scale three high fences, which she succeeded in doing, thereby showing extraordinary agility for a person of her sex and years. She has not as yet been rear-rested. Among those who have been defrauded by the fugitive are Messrs. Samuel Thompson, No. 24 Lamartine place; H.F. Sewell, No. 206 West Twenty-eighth-street; Theodore Martin, corner of Twenty-eighth-street and Ninth avenue; Mrs. W.E. Robinson, No. 22 Lamartine-place; Mrs. Waterbury, (District-Attorney's wife,) No. 25 Lamartine place; Mrs. Hoey, No. 23 Lamartine-place; Mrs. Post; Mrs. Daniel Carpenter, (wife of the Police Inspector,) No. 249 West Thirty-fourth-street; Mrs. Phillips, No. 310 West Thirty-fifth-street, and Mrs. W.D. Kennedy.

abstract: Whether it be the chastity and wisdom of Minerva; the mellifluous strains of music; the pleasing enthusiasm of young men about to enter upon the "world's wide field of battle;" the presence of grave seniors, who on such occasions always look preternaturally clean and sacred; or the floral temptations of early Summer, it is certain that the ceremonies pertaining to Commencement week are always hailed with delight and rapture by the fairer portion of our community. Yesterday, when the concluding University exercises were entered upon, the lobby of Niblo's Garden -- an Academic Grove, where hooped skirts prevailed in place of the simpler costume of ruder Goddesses -- presented a scene of rare animation. The last, best and most expensive gift floated through its once more opened portals in a way and with a splendor which has had no parallel since the last and palmiest Philharmonic rehearsal. Those, who were profound in toilettes, and knew the exact balance of the word ton were in extacles; others of a more serious turn regretted that they were not privileged to sit with the Chancellor, the Faculty and other big bugs, on the stage, who, it must be confessed, had a splendid opportunity of calmly gazing on this gorgeous spectacle, and of not being suspected. A few merely philosophical, such as the flower women outside, who had sold all their bouquets and pined for more, reflected that if Alma Mater had produced many noble sons, she could, where occasion required, exhibit as fair a sample of daughters, with correct ideas on the subject of flowers, and youth, and music, as any other mother in the wide world. It was wrathful to the middle-aged to see the youngsters of the University dressed in their gowns and trying to look like parsons, being frustrated and utterly routed out of every sober thought and solemn intention by their fair friends. It was almost shameful when some of these men, who had only just taken upon themselves the awful degree of Bachelor, were seen actually surrounded by the prettiest girls in the house, evidently listening to their blandishments with pleasure. But these things, we grieve to learn, are not unusual at Commencement time. Perhaps they blow over, but if they do not, oh! who can say what will be the consequences?

abstract: As Gen. LYON, with the steamers Yatan, McDonald and City of Louisiana, was approaching Boonville, on Monday morning, he espied a battery on the river bank, five miles below the town, at Adams' Mills. abstract: A special dispatch to the Republican, give forther particulars of the battle at Booneville. The Federal troops landed five miles below the encampment of the State forces. The latter had a battery near Booneville pointed toward the river, but it was circumvented by the Federal troops and proved useless. Gen. LYON immediately advanced on the State troops, and was met in a lane where the firing commenced.

abstract: choly spectacle for a conscientious rebel to behold, who has embarked all in his treason, must be a united and harmonious South when it isn't united and harmonious. But certain it is, from intelligence received, that while the seceded States have been expecting to see a divided North, and have been boasting of their own unanimity, the North is shown to be a unit in support of the Government, whereas (and that is the best of the joke) the South is divided. The Richmond Examiner comes to us in lamentation, that while the recent converts to treason -- mere fledglings in rebellion, so to speak -- "get all the good prizes," at the hands "of the State authorities," which decency, necessity and the actual safety of the State would be required elsewhere," the real, original rebels and dyed-in-the-wool traitors, who conceived and carried out the rebellion, are left out in the cold; in fact, "are proscribed, tabooed and disfranchised." On account of this, "the complaint is deep." We don't wonder at it, and especially when the editor announces that he "has yet to hear of a single original champion of the South who has been treated with common consideration and ordinary politeness." Republics are proverbially ungrateful, and we suppose that rebel Republics are no exception to the rule.

abstract: The weather was quite not the greater portion, of the week, throughout the whole West, and very favorable for maturing the wheat crop. A sudden change took place in the temperature on Sunday, the thermometer falling 25 degrees in a few hours; but yesterday it was warmer. There has been no rain, and the atmosphere is clear and dry, which will stop, the ravages of the worm and fly, of which there has been great complaint -- Cincinnati Price Current, June 9.

abstract: likely to be spoiled by the high-seasoned food it is receiving. A battle a day is the bill of fare now, with now and then an ambush or skirmish for breakfast or tea. The battle of Booneville was served up on Wednesday, and devoured with supreme satisfaction by the loyal public. The fight at Piedmont smoked on the table yesterday. Both came hot, and savory, for the nation has gone to war and expects battles and victories.

abstract: A recapitulation of the marine losses during May, shows that there were 5 steamers, 26 ships, 16 barks, 17 brigs and 32 schooners lost, the aggregate values of which were as follows: Vessels and freight, $1,174,300; cargoes, $1,628,800 -- total, $2,803,100. The total losses in April were 111; March, 158; February, 80; January, 110 -- total, including May, 555. The total value of vessels, freight and cargoes, $12,403,450.

abstract: Schureman Halstead et al. vs. James Gordon and Hugh McCrosson. On the 15th day of March, 1859, the defendant Gordon, residing in the City of Brooklyn, assigned his store of goods there to the defendant, McCrosson, in trust for the payment of his debts. The plaintiffs in this action had recovered judgments against the defendant, Gordon, between the 16th and 21st days of March, 1859.
lead_paragraph: Schureman Halstead et al. vs. James Gordon and Hugh McCrosson. -- On the 15th day of March, 1859, the defendant Gordon, residing in the City of Brooklyn, assigned his store of goods there to the defendant, McCrosson, in trust for the payment of his debts. The plaintiffs in this action had recovered judgments against the defendant, Gordon, between the 16th and 21st days of March, 1859.

abstract: Orders were received here a few days ago from the War Department to allow the present garrison of Fort Hamilton to petition for their discharges, their oaths is Texas having made many of them feel badly.
lead_paragraph: Orders were received here a few days ago from the War Department to allow the present garrison of Fort Hamilton to petition for their discharges, their oaths is Texas having made many of them feel badly. Accordingly, a document was drawn up, asking for discharges, which all but 25 of the 500 men signed. It was forwarded to the War Department the other day, and the soldiers await an answer, which will probably come this week. It is now quite likely that the whole of them will be let go. They are in a wretched condition; have no blankets to lie on in camp, and in many cases have not been paid off for fourteen months. As the regiments so which they belong must be filled up, we append a statement of their strength, as mustered yesterday on parade. It is as follows:

abstract: FRANK II, PIERPONT, Esq, who has been recently elected Governor of Virginia, in place of JOHN LETCHER, who vacated his office by ...
lead_paragraph: FRANK II, PIERPONT, Esq, who has been recently elected Governor of Virginia, in place of JOHN LETCHER, who vacated his office by the treason to the United States Government, is a resident of Marion County, one of the strong Union Countries of Northwest Virginia. Mr PIERPONT we believe, has been a member of the General Assembly of the State, and has had considerable legislative experience. He is a Counselor-at-Law by profession, and occupies a good position at the Bar. He is yet in the prime of life, being about [???] years of age. He has a fine personal appearance --a fall form and florid complexion,and is earnest public speaker. He was a warm supporter of BALL and EVEREST at the last Presidential canvas, and is now an unconditional Union man. He was a member of the first Wheeling Convention and was a zealous opponent of Mr. CARRILE, in his efforts to effect, at that time, the organization of a Provisional Government.

abstract: The skies seem big with disaster to the Confederate cause. It has been discovered that the supply of paper is very small within the limits of Secessia, and even this is each day becoming beautifully less. We do not wonder at the alarm evinced by the Southern editors. Paper is indispensable to the Confederate Government if the rebellion is to continue. It is essential for the manufacture of Confederate State Bonds; it is necessary to expand the system of shinplasters in the different States, so that it may meet the requirements of a currency; and it is wanted especially for the printing of the proclamations of the rebel leaders, to say nothing of the smaller quantities required for correspondence and the printing of rebellious newspapers. For the moment, Paper, not Cotton, is King.

abstract: The Twenty-ninth Regiment of New-York Vol"unteers, commanded by Col. VON STEINWEHR, took its departure yesterday for Washington. The men have been quartered for some time at Elm park a spacious place...
lead_paragraph: The Twenty-ninth Regiment of New-York Volunteers, commanded by Col. VON STEINWEHR, took its departure yesterday for Washington. The men have been quartered for some time at Elm park -- a spacious place, where they have had good accommodations and ample verge and scope for drill exercises. Its seclusion and remoteness from the ordinary routes of travel have contributed largely to the fine, healthy appearance and soldierly bearing of the men, who have been able to devote themselves exclusively to the preparatory business of war. Although this regiment has attracted but little attention from the public, and note at all from the Union Defence Committee, it is one of the finest that has yet left our City. It numbers upwards of 800 men, fully two-thirds of whom have seen service on other fields. In one company alone there were no fewer than fifty who had served is the German and Crimean wars. The officers, without exception, are experienced and well educated soldiers. Col. VON STEINSWEHR has himself occupied a high rank in the Prussian army, and is thoroughly familiar with fields operations, having been in several battles in Europe and South America. He is a most affable and courteous gentleman, and is greatly beloved by his men. From private sources and the State, this regiment has been handsomely equipped and aimed. The uniform is that of the United States regulations; the weapon, percussion muskets of the earliest pattern.

abstract: CHARGED WITH BIGAMY. -- A man named JOHN WILLIAMS, residing in Essex-street, Jersey City, was taken before Recorder MARTINDALE:, yesterday, charged with having two wives; the first one having been left by him in Ireland, some years since, together with four children. After residing in this country some three years, WILLIAMS was married to a widow woman named CASHIA, with whom he has been living for the past six years. A daughter by the first marriage, arrived in New-York a few days since, and upon finding that her father was again married, caused his arrest. He was committed to jail in default of 1,665 bail.

abstract: Thus far artillery has done the business of this war; and all modern history renders it probable that artillery will finish it, when the bayonet cannot be used. A first-class battle would be but half-an-hour's job, if the rifled cannon could be substituted for the rifled.
lead_paragraph: Thus far artillery has done the business of this war; and all modern history renders it probable that artillery will finish it, when the bayonet cannot be used. A first-class battle would be but half-an-hour's job, if the rifled cannon could be substituted for the rifled musket. While the latter, in default of the long practice and extraordinary coolness on the part of the soldier that alone insures good aim, throws away at least nine hundred and ninety-nine bullets, while the lucky one in a thousand bores but one small hole, the former, having a fixed support, and hence an accurate aim, drives its percussion shell fall of bullets, two or three miles away, and then whirls its hundred missiles of death in every direction. Of course, the weight of the cannon, and, to some degree, its expense, prevent its exclusive or very extensive use in the field; but, within certain limits, the more these can be reduced, the greater will be the number that can be practically used. To this end the energies of governments and inventors have been devoted for years. How to make cannon within reasonable limits of cost, out of the strongest material, and hence, the highest material, for a given strength, so that they can be easily transported, is one of the great problems of the day. Thus far the practice shows that there is one condition of cannon-metal, so extremely important, that many other features of great value can well be dispensed with to secure it, and that condition is harm-geneousness. Tenacity is very important, and se is hardness, but these are both sacrificed in the cast iron and the bronze gun, to secure that homogeneousness in the metal which it has been impossible to give to large masses of wrought iron and steel -- materials otherwise superior because stronger and harder. The greater the tenacity of the material the less thickness is required to sustain the force of the explosion; and the greater its hardness the loss the wear of the grooves by the projectile. But strength in one part and weakness in another is a defect, the risk of which, even, cannot be tolerated; and this is just the defect of wrought metals -- that although stronger than cast metals when sound, the welding of several parts into one is likely to leave seams which the explosive force of powder will soon open. Wrought iron and puddled steel are made from east iron in a puddling furnace; the cast iron is softened and decarbonized by a great heat, and worked by the operative into balls, which are hammered into blooms, and these blooms are made into slabs, or bars, and these are laid in piles, and welded together into cannon. Hence, there must be a number of welds in any large mass this made, for it is impossible, in the present state of the art, to work up a puddle-bail large enough to make a cannon without a weld, or to get the cinder out of such a puddle-bail, if it could be made. The trouble with welding is, that the oxidation of the surfaces, and the cinder squeezed by the process out of the iron or steel, prevent the absolute union of the parts. But it is probable that improved machinery, especially heavier hammers, wild seen remedy this defect. Blacksmiths find very little difficulty in wedding small pieces of from and puddled steel soundly, simply because they use hammers that are very heavy in proportion to the work, and so condense the parts to the very core at each blow. And there is no doubt that proportionately heavy hammers would make cannon nearly as sound. While in welding small parts, we strike there with a blow equal to that of a hammer of fifty times their weight, we have been attempting to weld masses weighing live or six tons with hammers of three or four tons weight. It is well known among iron-workers, that light hammering on a large mass of iron, instead of condensing the metal, will absolutely separate it in the centre. Steamboat shafts, made under light hammers, have been found absolutely hollow in the centre, from end to end, by reason of the stretching of the outer stratum of metal. But if a pile of bars or slabs, from which a cannon is to be forged, were struck at a welding heat three or four blows from a twenty-ton hammer -blows that would jam every particle in the mass, from circumference to centre, into intimate union, and squeeze the cinder out under this enormous pressure -- we believe there would be very little trouble with bad welds. But we might as reasonably hope to weld log-chains, with carpet-hammers, as to make sound work of large cannon with the light machinery generally in use. We are glad to learn that some of our iron-makers are aware of the serious defects in the processes now adopted. A reform will be of great advantage to the army and the public.
