abstract: Yesterday appears to have been a remarkably quiet day in the vicinity of Washington, on both sides of the Potomac. Not even an alarm occured. Evidences multiply, however, that the Government expects soon to in- ...
lead_paragraph: Yesterday appears to have been a remarkably quiet day in the vicinity of Washington, on both sides of the Potomac. Not even an alarm occured. Evidences multiply, however, that the Government expects soon to initiate active operations against BEAUREGARD's line -- among which are the continued arrival of troops at the Capital, to take the place of those which are daily pushed late Virginia. It is staird, also, that the Government has determined, at the solicitation of prominent gentlemen, to accept the services of twenty-two additional regiments immediately. From points further west we have little intelligence of moment.

abstract: THEFT AND RECOVERY OF $2,100 POLICEMEN SUSPECTED OF COLLUSION WITH THE THIEF. A noted rogue named MEYER JACOBSON, alias TRUEHEART, Was arraigned before Justice STEERS yesterday charged ...
lead_paragraph: THEFT AND RECOVERY OF $2,100 -- POLICEMEN SUSPECTED OF COLLUSION WITH THE THIEF. -- A noted rogue named MEYER JACOBSON, alias TRUEHEART, Was arraigned before Justice STEERS yesterday charged with having stolen $2,100 in gold coin from Mrs. MARY MASSER, of No. 120 Third-street. From the affidavits of Mrs. MASSER and others it appeared that the accused called at her house on Thursday evening, accompanied by three other men, and had not been there long before he broke open one of her trunks, took therefrom the money, placed it in his coat pocket and fled. Mrs. MASSER had her eye upon the entire proceeding, and following TRUEHEART to the street, she gave an alarm, which led to the thief's arrest in the Bowery, near First-street, by Officer MERRITT, of the Seventeenth Ward. During his flight, TRUEHEART threw his coat into an area-way, where it was found with the whole amount of coin in the pocket where Mrs. MASSER had seen him place it. When in Court, the prisoner informed Justice STEERS that the three men who accompanied him to Mrs. MASSER's house were Police Officers, who went there ostensibly to search for a quantity of watches which the woman is said to have smuggled from Germany. Their real object, however, was to give him an opportunity to steal the money. TRUEHEART refused to say what officers were engaged in the rascality; but if his story be true, it doubtless will be substantiated. Justice STEERS committed him for trial in default of $3,000 bail.

abstract: The Comptroller has recently furnished to the Board of Aldermen a statement of the amounts paid by the City authorities to different newspapers for publishing the proceedings of the Common Council, and advertising ...
lead_paragraph: The Comptroller has recently furnished to the Board of Aldermen a statement of the amounts paid by the City authorities to different newspapers for publishing the proceedings of the Common Council, and advertising for the different Departments of the City Government for the year 1860. The statement discloses the extent to which the authorities have exhibited a practical sympathy with the Southern conspiracy, by giving support to certain daily journals of this City which have been the advocates and apologists of the Southern rebellion, and whose tardy conversion to patriotic principles bears all the evidence of insincerity.

abstract: The Administration will have many friends in the approaching Congress. If party lines are to be thought of at all at such a time, the Republicans will be overwhelmingly in the majority; but when the existence of the Government and the integrity of the national territory are at stake, there can be but one line of division between parties, viz.; that which separates the friends from the enemies of the country. There may be a few men in each House whose hearts are not thoroughly in sympathy with the efforts of the people to suppress rebellion, and it will be the duty of the people and of the Press to watch their motions. Whoever is not in favor of prosecuting the war until the visitors are overthrows -- whoever begins to talk about offering terms of compromise, or of suspending hostilities until the rebels ground their arms -- may be set down as a sympathiser with the enemy.

abstract: Robert Beggs vs. Benjamin F. Camp. -- In this care, which was reported in the TIMES of Thursday, the plaintiff sued to recover damages for injuries alleged to have been sustained in consequence of the defendant's negligence. The defendant was contractor for the erection of certain buildings on lots Nos. 591 and 592 Broadway, and plaintiff averred that he left a platform in an unsafe condition, by reason of which he plaintiff was injured. The defendant denied plaintiff's allegations, and set up as his defence that the plaintiff was injured in consequence of his own negligence. Verdict was now given the plaintiff for $500.

abstract: The remains of Major WINTHROP, which have been lying under guard at the Seventh Regiment Armery, were yesterday removed to New-Haven for final interment. Shortly before 9 o'clock the doors of the Armory were thrown open, and the large room of the Armery was soon filled by citizens and ...
lead_paragraph: The remains of Major WINTHROP, which have been lying under guard at the Seventh Regiment Armery, were yesterday removed to New-Haven for final interment. Shortly before 9 o'clock the doors of the Armory were thrown open, and the large room of the Armery was soon filled by citizens and soldiers to the number of two thousand. Among those present were noticed Brig-Gen. HALL and a portion of his staff, Lieut. YELVERTON, of Col. DURVER's Regiment, Capt. MYERS, of Gen. BUTLER's staff, who acted as one of the pall-bearers, and other distinguished military men. The ceremonies were brief but impressive. Four companies of the Seventh Regiment, viz., the First, Sixth, Seventh and Ninth paraded as a guard of honor, while a detachment of Company I were specially detailed in charge of the body. The Regiment being drawn up, the remains were brought in enclosed in a metallic case, on which was a plate with a simple inscription, giving the name and age of deceased. Rev. Mr. WESTON, the Chaplain of the regiment, preceded the body, reading the opening Scriptures, followed by the pall-bearers. The full Burial Service of the Protestant Episcopal Church was then performed, after which the coffin was placed upon a howitzer-carriage, which was covered with a black velvet pall, trimmed with evergreens, and over which was thrown the American flag. The following gentlemen acted as pall-bearers:

abstract: The Seventeenth Regiment New-York Volunteers, Col. LANSING, broke camp yesterday at Staten Island, where they have been quartered ten days, and proceeded on board a special boat which conveyed them to this City, landing them at the foot of Fourteenth-street. The regimental line was then formed, and the troops marched through Fourteenth-street to Broadway, down Broadway to the City Park, where each man was served with two day's rations, thence to the New-Jersey Railroad depot, where cars were waiting to convey them to Washington vid Harrisburgh. The regiment displayed a beautiful silk flag with gold bullion fringe and tassels, bearing on one side the coat of arms of the State of New-York, and on the converse the inscription, "Seventeenth Regiment New-York Volunteers." The flag was presented to the regiment last Monday, by patriotic ladies of Westchester County, who proceeded to Staten Island for that purpose.

abstract: Our Parisian files continue to exhibit the same sympathy with the Federal Government as they have shown from the beginning of our struggle, and their aspirations for the triumph...
lead_paragraph: Our Parisian files continue to exhibit the same sympathy with the Federal Government as they have shown from the beginning of our struggle, and their aspirations for the triumph of our cause rather augment in intensity. They do not, it is true, fully realize our idea of the functions and attributes of government, and the constitutional necessity of preserving our national integrity does not impress them as we might desire. This is due to two causes; first, to the tone assumed by the English Press, the influence of which cannot but react on public opinion in France and, second, to the defective sources from which they derive their information. In several instances we have detected in French papers erroneous statements concerning American affairs, which evidently do not originate with the American Press, but must rather be attributed to the inventive genius of some foreign journals in the secession interest printed in our City. Thus M. GAILLARDET, the American editor of the Presse, writes nearly two columns on the acceptance of the Canadian regiment by Mr. LINCOLN, and on his order raising the blockade of Charleston -- two canards of the hugest magnitude. He speaks of the inactivity of the Federal army, as if our Army, which was not in existence two months ago, had not done wonders in so short a time, and seems surprised that Mr. LINCOLN does not prosecute the war in the interests of emancipation. These follies, delivered in sounding sentences, are crowned by the opinion that the threats made by Mr. SEWARD to Spain about her occupation of San Domingo, indicate a design on the part of the Administration to close the civil war by offering to the South the Island of Caba as a bonne bouche.

abstract: In view of the late extraordinary events that have transpired in our State, it becomes a serious question what must be done to put the machinery of our State Government into running order again. As the case stands at present, the sovereignty of the State rests in the late State Convention, which will probably assemble within a week, to resolve on some definite policy. The course which duty suggests is ...
lead_paragraph: In view of the late extraordinary events that have transpired in our State, it becomes a serious question what must be done to put the machinery of our State Government into running order again. As the case stands at present, the sovereignty of the State rests in the late State Convention, which will probably assemble within a week, to resolve on some definite policy. The course which duty suggests is plain enough. The whole present State Government must be declared out of power, and an election for a new Legislature and new State officials ordered, pending the result of which, the State Convention should form itself into a Provisional Government. Whether such a course of action will be adopted, is, however, very questionable. Although the Union sentiment was vastly preponderate in the Convention at its late session, yet a great portion of this loyalty was of that very suspicious kind, which is willing to compromise with traitors, and knows no higher standard of constitutional obligations than the deceptive phrase, "armed neutrality." Others have grown lukewarm and reckless in view of the neglect they have been treated with by the Federal Government. It is not therefore improbable that the State Conventi on will hesitate at energetic measures, although circumstances demand them imperiously, and that it will seek to patch up some new sort of a compromise between the outraged people of Missouri and its runway officials. Party considerations will plead strongly against a new election, and party considerations are by no means so weightless as one could wish, where a nation is engaged in a struggle for its very existence. But what is to be done if the State Convention refuse to do its manifest duty? If the General Government is at all equal to the emergency, Gen. LYON will be ordered to disband the State Condition at the first attempt to compromise with treason, -- for, it is to be hoped, that the General Government will by this time have awakened to the fact that Gov. JACKSON, with his whole clique of military and legislative adherents, are traitors, and immediately order a new election for delegates to a new Convention, fresh from the people. Of course party hacks and quibbling politicians would call this a high-handed proceeding, and rave and write stupid and voluminous treatises on the legality of the thing; but it ought to be about time to stop listening to these disquisitions on civil law. Violent diseases require violent remedies. Mobs and rebellions must be treated with doses of grape-shot and Minie-rifle balls. Gov. JACKSON has not only declared war against the Government of the United States, but he is also in open rebellion against the State of Missouri. He has stolen her archives and State papers, plundered her treasury, hired incendiaries to burn the bridges of her railroads, and is now -- a fugitive from justice -- attempting to accomplish her complete ruin by forcing her into a Confederacy she hates and despises. He and the whole gang of his accomplices are outlaws; to acknowledge them at still representing the State of Missouri is treason against the State as well as against the Union. Missouri is, until the State Convention assembles, without a Government; she it, in point of fact, under military law, established for her benefit by the Government of the United States. The loyal men, the large majority of her citizens, are thankful to the General Government for this long-expected interference, and only pray that it will not again result in a compromise with her bitterest foe, the now Ex-Gov. JACKSON, by which the conflict would only be once more postponed.

abstract: The cotton planters cannot get the hang of COBB's Cotton financiering. The whole thing is to them an inextricable nail of "bondss." "convertible," "non-convertible," "twenty years," and "eight per cents," and "Treasury notes," any or all of which the banks will or will not receive on deposit, as the case may be. To the Northern capitalist the scheme seems a high-pressure affair, go tup on the principle of "heads, I win -- tails, you lose:" but somehow or other the planters can't make head or tail to it. Hence, the Southern journals have been fruitful of explanations to clear up the difficulties. A recent issue of the Savannah Republican contains its explanation. It states that "all subscriptions stand in the light of a loan to the Government, on bonds, to run for twenty years and bear interest at eight per cent. These bonds are not convertible into treasury notes, as some seem, to suppose. Holders of Treasury notes may convert them into bonds at will, and these bonds into Treasury notes, if desired. These Convertible Bonds are issued to crop subscribers, and are the only bonds, which, together with treasury notes, the banks have resolved to receive on deposit." Could anything be more clear? Yet it is doubtful whether the daylight of that explanation will penetrate the obtuse crania of the planters. The bonds are "to run for twenty years" -- and with this advantage in their favor it is doubtful whether the subscribers will ever be able to catch up with them. But it is a very simple matter. The plaster gives his cotton and receives bonds. As the bonds will not buy bagging or corn or pork at the North or elsewhere, he naturally asks what he shall do with them? -- and it is precisely on this material point the Republican has nothing to offer.

abstract: The Committee on the National Hymn announce that the time for the reception of manuscripts by them has expired, and that no more will be admitted to competition. The number already in their hands is over eleven hundred and fifty. The public will see at once that the examination and comparison of such a mass of manuscript matter must be a work of some time. The Committee, therefore, ask the indulgence of those who are interested in this subject; and they take this opportunity of saying to contributors that the first announcement of their decision will be made publicly, and that personal inquiry upon that subject will be entirely in vain.
lead_paragraph: The Committee on the National Hymn announce that the time for the reception of manuscripts by them has expired, and that no more will be admitted to competition. abstract: The People ex rel. John Green vs. Fernando Wood. -- This case was stated in the TIMES of the 18th December last, and again March 16. The relator applies for a peremptory mandamus to compel the Mayor to countersign a warrant directed to the Chamberlain for the payment of $1,000 to the relator, for services in removing offal from the streets of the City. The relator sets forth that he has performed the work under a contract with the City Inspector, in persuance of authority from the Mayor and Health Commissioners. The City Inspector has also certified the bill.
lead_paragraph: The People ex rel. John Green vs. Fernando Wood. -- This case was stated in the TIMES of the 18th December last, and again March 16. abstract: We have repeatedly alluded to the great importance of organizing and supporting the Union Party of East Tennessee; for the reason that by this means the Government would...
lead_paragraph: We have repeatedly alluded to the great importance of organizing and supporting the Union Party of East Tennessee; for the reason that by this means the Government would become possessed of the Virginia and Tennessee Railroad, stretching from Knoxville to Richmond, Va., and thus effectually cut off the grand army of the rebels from all reinforcement of men or supplies in the only direction from which they can be obtained. This isolation would insure its speedy surrender or destruction; for being by this movement outflanked and segregated, no possibility of escape would remain.

abstract: The past week does not furnish the chronicler with a single item of interest. Our two up-town Broadway theatres continue to regale their patrons with the standard dishes, labeled the "Seven Sisters" and "Our American Cousin at Home," and to their complete satisfaction it would seem. The attendance at Laura Keene's and the Winter Garden, although subject to strange fluctuations, continues good enough to warrant the managers of those places in keeping to the beaten path, rather than hazarding an experiment with a new piece. We hear of a couple of changes in the dramatis personoe of the plays. Miss KEENS has surrendered her role into the hands of Mrs. LEIGHTON, a pleasing actress from the South, who does full justice to it. Mr. BLAKE, too, has thrown up his part of Binny, perceiving, as every one else did, that he was not likely to gain any reputation by it. A gentleman from Philadelphia, Mr. HEMPLE, comes in for the great artist's kicks and halfpence. He seems to be a valuable actor, and in this role at least is more than equal to his predecessor. Mr. BLAKE'S benefit on Tuesday evening was a very successful affair, and being the best house of the week, proved that the actor's name could "draw" more than the play in which it was his misfortune to appear. We trust that it will be the same on Monday evening when Mr. NAZER, the Treasurer, appeals for the first and last time to his many friends. Mr. NAZER is about to proceed to the war, where, we may depend on it, he will serve the public as efficiently as he has in his humble station at the Wluter Garden. The continued popularity of Mr. GAYLER'S piece has not rendered it necessary to change the bill, but a new series of extremely fine war pictures (tableaus vivant,) have been prepared, and will be exhibited tomorrow night for the first time. In view of this fact, and of the pleasure which all people feel in honoring over gallant volunteers, we hope we are not wrong in predicting for Mr. NAZER an overflowing house. He certainly merits, by long service and continued courtesy, all the favor that can be shown to him.

abstract: It would probably be as well to cease at once ail attempts to enlighten our ex-friends of the fast-anchored Isle in regard to American affairs. If they cannot be induced to furnish themselves with a copy of that "three-cent" Constitution of ours, or to learn the outlines of our geography, or to find out what color we are, or what are our social conditions, it can be of but little use to discuss with them the Constitutional right of secession, or the doctrine of concurrent majorities, or the question of extending Slavery into the Territories of Nebraska or Nevada. The leading paper of Scotland, the Edinburgh Witness, has lately had a series of articles on the American troubles, in which a great deal of good feeling toward us is mingled with the most fantastical misconceptions of our character and affairs. It seems to regard the present rebellion as a war raging between what it oddly calls the "American peasants" of the West and North and the tyrants of somewhere else; and seems to be in considerable of a quandary, as well it might be, as to which of the parties will ultimately get whipped. In a late issue, however, the editor gives out that the thing might all be peacefully settled somehow or other; and as the General Assembly or supreme court of the Scottish Kirk is in session, he bethinks him that an anti-war remonstrance from a body of so much weight and piety would doubtless be heeded by the belligerent peasants and their foes. "We have read with deep satisfaction," says the Witness, "the remarks on this subject made by the Moderator of the General Assembly in his opening address. It may, we suppose, be now taken for granted that the propriety of a Christian remonstrance (with the Americans for going to war) from the highest court of our Church will at least be discussed; and if such a thing should be adopted, we may certainly anticipate" -- well, perhaps, a cessation of hostilities. The whole thing is simple enough and can very easily be settled. The peasants, you see, are fighting for the freedom of the blackamoors, while the Southerners, according to Mr. RUSSELL, are anxious to have a king. Now, let the peasants choose two of their number, say CASSIUS M. CLAY and BEN. BUTLER, and let the other side select two of their representatives, say TOOMBS and BEAUREGARD. Let them conjointly hold a parliament somewhere in the State of Cairo, or in the flourishing burgh of South Carolina. Let the Southerners compromise by setting all their blackamoors free, and then let the peasants compromise by allowing a Southern king, say King JEFF, for instance, to rule over them. Then America, from Hudson's Bay to Jamaica, will enjoy quiet, and in due time may become a respectable appendage of the ancient Kingdom of Scotland.

abstract: Reliable information was received here last evening that the Confederate forces, 15,000 strong, were encamped at Stephenson's Depot, about ten miles from Martinsburgh. The force is composed of 11,000 volunteers and 4,000 men who have been impressed. It is supposed that the intention is to make a stand against the advance of Gen. McCLELLAN, if found practicable.

abstract: In the whirl of great events, our people, and even those in authority, seem to have forgotten that two loyal men, Lieut. WORDEN, of the navy, who carried the instructions to the fleet for the reinforcement of Fort Pickens, and JOHN MERRYMAN, collector of the port of Georgetown, S.C., who refused to recognize the treasonable action of his State, both are now in prison. Of the scores of influential traitors who are arrested, why could not some of them, at least, be held as hostages for the safety of these two loyal and patriotic men, with the view of their speedy release?

abstract: Mr. MALLORY, in his speech here to night, before a great Union crowd, spoke to this effect: There was no ground, no reason, no cause for the secession movement. Secession or revolution is nothing but war a lawless struggle of arms. The seceders commenced the war, are prosecuting the war, are directly responsible for the war.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Wednesday Night, June 19, 1861.

abstract: We have read much of late of the "impregnable" defences of the City of Washington; and while we would not have it supposed that we are under any serious apprehension for the safety of the Capital, against all the efforts the rebel army can bring to its capture, we admit that we would be glad to believe that, in the event of an unfortunate reverse to our arms in the field, the City of Washington would indeed be rendered, by the defensive works that have recently been raised for its better security, absolutely impregnable. But we are compelled to admit frankly that we do not rest as well assured on this point as we could wish to be; and that, to our inexperienced view, there are visible defects in the defensive works south of the Potomac, which ought to be forthwith cured.
lead_paragraph: We have read much of late of the "impregnable" defences of the City of Washington; and while we would not have it supposed that we are under any serious apprehension for the safety of the Capital, against all the efforts the rebel army can bring to its capture, we admit that we would be glad to believe that, in the event of an unfortunate reverse to our arms in the field, the City of Washington would indeed be rendered, by the defensive works that have recently been raised for its better security, absolutely impregnable. But we are compelled to admit frankly that we do not rest as well assured on this point as we could wish to be; and that, to our inexperienced view, there are visible defects in the defensive works south of the Potomac, which ought to be forthwith cured.

abstract: THE LINCOLN GREENS. -- Col. BYRON and an efficient staff are organizing a regiment of cavalry on the plan of the famous corps known in the military annals of India as Capt. HODSON's Light Sikh Horse, which distinguished itself so much in the mutiny of the Sepoys, and more recently in China. About five hundred members are already enrolled, and will be furnished with horses in a few days. Their Head-quarters at present are at a large building at the foot of South Sixth-street; they will probably drill at East New-York. In addition to the usual cavalry arms and equipments, the regiment will have a battery of light steel guns, six-pounders, throwing Hotchkiss' shell and shot.
lead_paragraph: THE LINCOLN GREENS. -- Col. BYRON and an efficient staff are organizing a regiment of cavalry on the plan of the famous corps known in the military annals of India as Capt. HODSON's Light Sikh Horse, which distinguished itself so much in the mutiny of the Sepoys, and more recently in China. About five hundred members are already enrolled, and will be furnished with horses in a few days. Their Head-quarters at present are at a large building at the foot of South Sixth-street; they will probably drill at East New-York. In addition to the usual cavalry arms and equipments, the regiment will have a battery of light steel guns, six-pounders, throwing Hotchkiss' shell and shot.

abstract: An able article upon the "State of the Country" has appeared in the Southern Presbyterian Review, and been republished in the NewYork Observer. It is said to be the work of Rev. Dr. THORNWELL, and is the ablest exposition of the more candid Southern view of secession which has yet been published. As such, it is worthy of careful attention.
lead_paragraph: An able article upon the "State of the Country" has appeared in the Southern Presbyterian Review, and been republished in the NewYork Observer. It is said to be the work of Rev. Dr. THORNWELL, and is the ablest exposition of the more candid Southern view of secession which has yet been published. As such, it is worthy of careful attention. Its ability, however, is of that inferior kind which belongs to the Abstractionist -- energetic, often impressive, but unreliable in its conclusions, which are drawn more from empty abstractions than from real facts and substantial truth. In this respect it is very different from the article by Prof. HODGE upon the same subject.

abstract: After a brief period of decadence, the old Union has begun to grow again. We rejoice to welcome, to-day, the return of the Old Dominion to the family of States. Let the star of the old flag that represents Virginia, be burnished anew and made to shine with a fresh lustre. Let the fatted calf be killed, and let us eat and be merry; for the dead is alive again, and the lost is found.

abstract: Idle rumors of a compromise proposed to the President of the United States, by certain Southern parties, have been in circulation for several days, and have at last become concrete in a morning journal. We are told that JAFFERSON DAVIS and his fellow conspirators, having become alarmed at the desperate condition of their enterprise, have recurred to the idea now only entertained by enemies of the Constitution and the Government, of an amicable adjustment; and have sent secret agents to Washington to sound the Administration as to its dispositions in the business. These men, we are assured, offered the Government a double alternative of war. One was a pacific separation, with a friendly settlement of all its preliminaries and results; the South to assume its share of the cost of the war. This having been declined, the other was presented in the shape of the line of 36Â° 30' as the limit of Slavery extension, with new and solemn guarantees in the Constitution on the subject of Slavery. This, the story goes, was also rejected, and the agents, discouraged, returned to their principals.
lead_paragraph: Idle rumors of a compromise proposed to the President of the United States, by certain Southern parties, have been in circulation for several days, and have at last become concrete in a morning journal. We are told that JAFFERSON DAVIS and his fellow conspirators, having become alarmed at the desperate condition of their enterprise, have recurred to the idea now only entertained by enemies of the Constitution and the Government, of an amicable adjustment; and have sent secret agents to Washington to sound the Administration as to its dispositions in the business. These men, we are assured, offered the Government a double alternative of war. One was a pacific separation, with a friendly settlement of all its preliminaries and results; the South to assume its share of the cost of the war. This having been declined, the other was presented in the shape of the line of 36° 30' as the limit of Slavery extension, with new and solemn guarantees in the Constitution on the subject of Slavery. This, the story goes, was also rejected, and the agents, discouraged, returned to their principals.

abstract: There was a busy day yesterday at the Arsenal, a place which now presents a very different appearance to what it did three months ago. Then there was nothing to create a stir among the officials or ...
lead_paragraph: There was a busy day yesterday at the Arsenal, a place which now presents a very different appearance to what it did three months ago. Then there was nothing to create a stir among the officials or assistants; now the building is crowded with equipments of war, arms and ammunition. Three regiments were supplied with equipments yesterday, and the packing of so many thousand separate articles kept the employes busy from early in the morning until late in the afternoon, when the goods were dispatched. Their destination was Albany, and will supply the wants of the Sixteenth, Twenty-second and Thirtieth Regiments of Volunteers. When the articles are stowed comfortably on the persons of the soldiers, we can form no idea of their bulk, but seeing them carried away in huge loads, conveys a very exact and different impression.

abstract: Some time in the month of April, Mr. JEFFERSON DAVIS issued a polite invitation to all those who might desire, by service in private armed vessels on the high seas; to aid him in resisting the Government of the United States, to apply for commissions, or letters-of-marque and reprisal, under the seal of the so-called "Confederate States."
lead_paragraph: Some time in the month of April, Mr. JEFFERSON DAVIS issued a polite invitation to all those who might desire, by service in private armed vessels on the high seas; to aid him in resisting the Government of the United States, to apply for commissions, or letters-of-marque and reprisal, under the seal of the so-called "Confederate States." Two days afterwards, President LINCOLN gave notice to the world that if any person, under the pretended authority of any such commission, or under any other pretence, should molest a vessel of the United States, or the persons or cargo on board of her, such persons would be held, amenable to the laws of the United States, for the prevention and punishment of piracy. Matters were in this position when Judge BETES instructed the Grand Jury of this District that piracy consists in a forcible capture or robbery on the high seas of any vessel or her lading, by a vessel not authorized by a lawful commission from a Government organized and acting under the law of nations, and is punishable with death in the tribunals of all countries where the offence is triable. Judge SPRAGUE, in the Massachusetts District, propounded similar ideas for the consideration of all such enterprising individuals as might be disposed to aid JEFFERSON DAVIS in resisting the Government of the United States.

abstract: We publish in another part of this morning's paper an able reply to the article of Rev. Dr. THORNWELL, published some weeks since in the Southern Presbyterian Review, on the state of the  country. This reply is from the pen of a clergyman in Massachusetts, and although it was written before the outbreak of the rebellion, and while secession was only threatened, contains many arguments and suggestions which will be found well worthy of attention.

abstract: However absorbing the arts of war may be at the present moment, it would be unjust to ourselves and to posterity, to neglect, or even modify our wonted enthusiasm in the great arts of peace; for by these arts, fostered under ...
lead_paragraph: However absorbing the arts of war may be at the present moment, it would be unjust to ourselves and to posterity, to neglect, or even modify our wonted enthusiasm in the great arts of peace; for by these arts, fostered under a free Government, have we attained that name and excellence among nations which we now fight to maintain. Recent history teaches that no means or influences so greatly stimulate improvement and success in what may be generally termed The Useful Arts -- in manufactures, Inventions, and processes, engineering, mechanical, chemical, agricultural -- in the utilization of natural materials and forces -- as that general distribution of special knowledge, and that healthy and noble emulation which are the fruit of public exhibitions of these results, by all the means new so commonly adopted, from the County fair at the County town, to the World's fair at the World's metropolis. No man can compute the solid gain which has accrued to the civilized, and, indeed, the uncivilized nations, from the development and results of that grand idea of SCOTT RUSSELL -- the Great Exhibition of 1851. No man can say, after a little reflection, that the Fairs of the American Institute and the Franklin Institute, and others among as commenced at a much earlier period, have not been worth millions to the people of this country. It must be so from the nature of things. Were men or communities isolated, no progress would be made; very little was made till means of communication became general, and as these means have increased, invention and discovery have kept pace with them. There is no doubt the steam engine would have been in use before the Christian era, if men of all nations or even the ingenious men and experimenters of one nation could have been brought into contact. We know that the power of steam was applied -- a steam engine invented -- centuries ago; but no one man could perfect it; and there is every reason to believe that the engines of SAVERY and NEWCOMEN would have been forgotten as the earlier, crude and impracticable devices were, had there been no rapid means of interchanging ideas, and the consequent handing down of the rough diamond from one generation of experimenters to another, till it is now, by the friction of many minds, the most glorious brilliant in the diadem of engineering achievement. Were a million of men to follow for a lifetime the same pursuit, each one being ignorant of the doings of the rest, there would be very little progress. So great art has been perfected till each one of generations of thinkers and workers have left their mark on it. And since it is impracticable for each representative man in a particular department to visit and compare notes with all the rest, great progress can only be made by centralizing -- condensing into limits which all men may compass, the best results and discoveries and aspirations of the whole world. The means of accomplishing such results, are scientific books and industrial exhibitions -- the former to cull the good things from the great mass of current practice, and to weigh, classify and preserve them and their principles -- the latter to stimulate a greater and better production.

abstract: BOARD OF EDUCATION THE NORMAL SCHOOL. A special meeting of the Board of Education was held, on Thursday, for the purpose of considering the propriety of abolishing the Normal School. The sum of $2,500 has always been appropriated annually for the support of this school; but a great many of the members of the Board are now in favor of abolishing it altogether. The matter was referred to a Committee of five for report.
lead_paragraph: BOARD OF EDUCATION -- THE NORMAL SCHOOL. -- A special meeting of the Board of Education was held, on Thursday, for the purpose of considering the propriety of abolishing the Normal School. The sum of $2,500 has always been appropriated annually for the support of this school; but a great many of the members of the Board are now in favor of abolishing it altogether. The matter was referred to a Committee of five for report.

abstract: It is stated by the Memphis Bulletin that the low estimate put upon Tennessee bonds in the Stock market, "is a mere ruse of Northern capitalists to cripple Tennessee during the war," that "they will command as much at home as the bonds of any other State, North or South, and are really worth as much," and that "the $5,000,000 voted by the Legislature will be taken at home at par." The Bulletin is unversed in matters of finance. Though a combination of brokers, for speculative purposes, may, for a day or two, control in a slight degree the price of a given security, yet the inevitable law of supply and demand will soon place it where it belongs in the financial scale. Tennessee bonds cannot sell for par at home and rate at 35 in New-York; and it is presuming a little too much upon the patriotism or the verdancy of Tennessee capitalists to suppose that they would buy a new issue of the bonds of that State at 100, when bonds already issued for which the faith of the State is pledged, can be bought in New-York for 35. With her securities at this figure, nobody believes that Tennessee is going to pay her coupons at maturity; and if the fifty thousand troops authorized by her Legislature are put in the field -- to maintain which would cost the State at least twenty-five million dollars a year -- Tennessee will be compelled to repudiate both principal and interest.

abstract: THE LIBRARY OF THE LATE REV. THEODORE PARKER. -- The work of removing to the Boston Public Library the books bequeathed by this distinguished theologian to the City of Boston, has been commenced. They number upwards of eleven thousand volumes, comprising the greatest portion of his library. As a whole, the collection is very curious and remarkable, and will be an exceedingly valuable addition to the Public Library. It is very full of German classic literature, a pursuit in which Mr. PARKER greater excelled, and is rich in Greek and Latin works of all kinds and dates. It is also exceedingly well endowed in metaphysical works and in those on metaphysical theology.

abstract: Latest advices from Missouri state that Gov. JACKSON, with about six hundred men, was pushing rapidly southward, probably with a view to crossing the Arkansas border. Large bodies of rebel Missourians are also reported to be leaving the State to join the forces of PILLOW, at Memphis. The whole State is in a ferment, and there will probably soon be more fighting. Gen. LYON is rapidly strengthening himself, and intends marching on Lexington, where the State troops are again concentrating.

abstract: FERRIS INSTITUTE. The Third Annual Commencement of this educational establishment for young ladies was held, Friday afternoon, in the Presbyterian Church corner of Twenty-ninth street and Madison-avenue.
lead_paragraph: FERRIS INSTITUTE. -- The Third Annual Commencement of this educational establishment for young ladies was held, Friday afternoon, in the Presbyterian Church corner of Twenty-ninth street and Madison-avenue. The exercises were of an interesting character, and the young ladies -- one hundred and twenty-nine in number -- presented a beautiful picture ranged as they were in front of the audience, and all apparelled in white. The names of the graduating class are: Almira Austen, Eleanor Bird, Balsora Davis, Josephine Patterson, Jessie Dinwiddle, Amelia Ostrander, Jennie D. Raynor, and Carrie V. Biggs. After the various reports of the examiners had been presented, the following-named pupils received testimonials: Jessie Dinwiddle, gold medal for excellence in Mathematics; Amelia Ostrander, premium for do; Eleanor Bird, gold medal for excellence in Penmanship; Emma Miles, premium for do; Balsora Davis, gold medal for price composition in the senior department; Annie Hustace, premium for do, do,; Jessie Dinwiddie, gold medal for excellence in French. Premiums were also given to the following members of the Middle Department, for excellence in Penmanship, French, and Needlework: Misses Sophie Hustace, Cornell, Miles, Clearman, and Liley Raynor. Agreeable singing by the pupils, under the direction of Prof. S. Lasar, varied the proceedings. The church was filled with the friends of the pupils, and supporting the Principal -- C.H. Gardner -- was Rev. Dr. Ferris, Chancellor of the New-York University, who is Counselor of the Institute. In the evening, the Graduating Class gave a reception at the house of Mrs. Gardner, No. 16 East Twenty-eighth-street.

abstract: LAYING OF A CORNER-STONE IMPOSING CEREMONIES REMARKABLE SPEECH OF BISHOP BAYLEY, The ceremony of blessing and laying the corner-stone of the new Roman Catholic Church, on the corner of...
lead_paragraph: LAYING OF A CORNER-STONE -- IMPOSING CEREMONIES -- REMARKABLE SPEECH OF BISHOP BAYLEY. -- The ceremony of blessing and laying the corner-stone of the new Roman Catholic Church, on the corner of Erie and South Seventh streets, Jersey City, took place yesterday. Delegations from the "Hibernia United Benevolent Society," of Jersey City, "St. Patrick's Temperance Benevolent Society," and the "Confraternity of the Sacred Heart of Jesus," were gathered at their usual meeting places, and marched in procession to take part in the ceremonies. The church -- the walls of which are built up to the second story -- is to be of brick, in the Gothic style of architecture. It is 142 feet by 70 feet It already has the appearance of a massive and magnificent structure.

abstract: The grand parade of this remarkably fine regiment which was announced for Sunday, the 10th, took place yesterday, and attracted a splendid attendance of the good folk from the City.
lead_paragraph: The grand parade of this remarkably fine regiment which was announced for Sunday, the 10th, took place yesterday, and attracted a splendid attendance of the good folk from the City. A visit to Fort Schuyler, under the circumstances which surround that fortification with interest at the present moment, is one of the greatest treats that can be afforded to our denizens. The trip on the boat Gen. Arthur is in itself one of the greatest pleasures that can be enjoyed on our beautiful Sound, or at least within easy reach of our City. The Fort is an institution so peculiar that to the stranger eye it is a feast; and then when there is a parade, as there was yesterday, there is the necessary military zest to the solid enjoyments of the peculiar surroundings. Every preparation was made for the reception of the many visitors, and when the host landed its living load the officers flocked to the wharf to tender their hospitable welcome.

MAHEW against FRANCISCO DE ATAZE, John Doe and Richard Boe, composing the firm of Ataze & Co. -- Summons for a money demand on contract --(Com. not here) -- To he defendants: You are hereby summoned and required to answer the complaint in this action, which will be filed in the office of the Clerk of the City and County of New-York at the City Hall, New-York and to serve a copy of your answer to the and complaint on the subscribers, at their office No. 74 Wall-street, in the City of New-York, within twenty case after the service of this summons on you, exclusive of the day of such service; and if you fail to answer the said complaint within the time aforesaid, the plaintiffs in this action will take judgment against you for the sum of fifteen thousand dollars with interest from the 17th day of June 18th besides the costs of this action. -- Dated New-York, June 17, 1861.

abstract: The arrangement which has been made between Gen. McCLELLAN and the State authorities of Kentucky, for preserving the peaceful attitude of Kentucky, doubtless has the approbation of Gen. SCOTT and the Administration, and must rest on excellent considerations of political and social policy. The arrangement itself is complete in its protection of the rights and honor of the Government.
lead_paragraph: The arrangement which has been made between Gen. MCCLELLAN and the State authorities of Kentucky, for preserving the peaceful attitude of Kentucky, doubtless has the approbation of Gen. SCOTT and the Administration, and must rest on excellent considerations of political and social policy. The arrangement itself is complete in its protection of the rights and honor of the Government. One of the stipulations of Gen. BUCKNER (who acts for Gov. MAGOFFIN) is this: "The Kentucky authorities will protect the United States properly in the State; will enforce the laws of the United States according to the interpretation of the United States Court, and will enforce all obligations of neutrality as against the Southern States." Among the Federal laws to be enforced in Kentucky will be that against treason, and the law of blockade. This will prevent all further treasonable movements in Kentucky, and perfect the embargo on supplies to the rebels, heretofore sent by public enemies over the roads of Kentucky. We know that the rebels will resent this action of Kentucky. Only a few days ago the Memphis Bulletin, probably having word of the arrangement, broke out as follows:

abstract: Capt. CURTIS, of the ship Windsor Forest, arrived at this port yesterday from Liverpool, and reports that on the 13th of June, when southeast from Carysfort Reef, they fell in with a suspicious-looking schooner of about 150 tons burden, which gave chase to them, and followed in the wake of the ship for nearly two days Capt. CURTIS observed that there were more than the usual number of men on board for a schooner of her size, and that a man was placed on the lookout at each masthead.

CURTIS observed that there were more than the usual number of men on board for a schooner of her size, and that a man was placed on the lookout at each masthead.

abstract: Mr. GREGORY, the Irish advocate employed by the secession agents in London to put their case through Parliament, has to be consented with putting it through the columns of the Times. There is nothing in this effort which was heralded as an exhaustive demonstration of the propriety of recognizing the Southern Confederation which deserves the name of argument. It is a recital of the usual...
lead_paragraph: Mr. GREGORY, the Irish advocate employed by the secession agents in London to put their case through Parliament, has to be consented with putting it through the columns of the Times. There is nothing in this effort -- which was heralded as an exhaustive demonstration of the propriety of recognizing the Southern Confederation -- which deserves the name of argument. It is a recital of the usual platitudes and sophisms of his clients, with some adroit appeals to that most accessible of an Englishman's sympathies, self-interest. But there is one point in which Mr. GREGORY is original, and deserves notice. He declares he is overwhelmed with letters from the Northern States, urging him in passionate terms, to press his advocacy to success, as the only means of defeating the National Government, and bringing the war to a close. And he argues that but for the terrorism which prevails in the North, these wishes would find open utterance, and from a mass of the population so numerous as to give them great political weight. We are quite prepared to believe that Mr. GREGORY is in receipt of the correspondence he describes. We have traitors of various kinds among us, and it is fair to assume the existence of a class willing to see England victorious over their country. But a vulgar mistake of the barrister throws much doubt upon the numerical strength he ascribes to this specific class. There is no terrorism in the Northern States. Men everywhere speak their opinions with entire freedom. Secession sentiments are uttered as loudly as any other; and there is hardly, perhaps, a community in the North without its swaggerer, to bluster on the side of treason and rebellion. In this City we have three daily journals of small importance, violently and abusively hostile to the Government and open in their sympathy with the South. There are one or two others, of large circulation, known to have the same decided proclivities; but who are compelled to a certain demonstrative loyalty, by the fear, not of violence, but of the entire demolition of their subscription lists. Terrorism, therefore, excercises no despotism over thought in the Free States. A safe measure of the justice of this assertion may be had by ascertaining whether one instance of compulsory return to the South can be found to balance the enforced flight for opinion's sake, of the ten thousand who have been driven hither by the rebels. Mr. GREGORY's statement about his American letters may go for what it is worth, but his inference is palpably worthless.

abstract: An aggregate of over thirteen thousand additional troops have reached Washington within the past week, and these troops have generally taken the place of those which have been pushed forward across the Potomac, to swell the grand ariny of invasion. Military movements were quite active yesterday, but the caution with which everything is now done by the War Department precludes the possibility of explaining their meaning.
lead_paragraph: An aggregate of over thirteen thousand additional troops have reached Washington within the past week, and these troops have generally taken the place of those which have been pushed forward across the Potomac, to swell the grand ariny of invasion. Military movements were quite active yesterday, but the caution with which everything is now done by the War Department precludes the possibility of explaining their meaning. It is rumored in Washington again, however, that the rebel forces intend to make an attack this week. They have, it is asserted by those who are supposed to be in the secrets of the enemy, one hundred and eighty thousand men in the field, and that they will soon make an attempt to surround Washington, under the direction of BEAUREGARD, is considered not improbable At any rate, the War Department seems to be preparing for such a possibility. Gen. MCDOWELL yesterday made himself fully acquainted with the positions occupied by the enemy, through the medium of a balloon, in which were a telegraph operator and two topographical engineers. This operation, it is to be hoped, will prevent the recurrence of any, more such affairs as that of Vienna, as the exact localities of all the enemy's batteries, masked and otherwise, are now known.

abstract: The foreign mails bring us the declaration of neutrality in American affairs, issued by the Emperor of the French. This document, it will be observed, achieves its purpose quite as thoroughly as that of the British Government, while it is free from one or two characteristics by which the latter justly aroused the ire of the Northern people. It was not issued in undue and undignified haste, without waiting for conference with the...
lead_paragraph: The foreign mails bring us the declaration of neutrality in American affairs, issued by the Emperor of the French. This document, it will be observed, achieves its purpose quite as thoroughly as that of the British Government, while it is free from one or two characteristics by which the latter justly aroused the ire of the Northern people. It was not issued in undue and undignified haste, without waiting for conference with the representative of the new Administration at Washington, known to be on his way to Europe. Its language is carefully studied to recognize the Government of the United States as existing in unaltered vigor, and as maintaining peaceful relations with France; while the South is referred to, not as a Government at all, but as "States claiming to form a particular confederation." Thus anything like a recognition of an equality of the parties in the struggle is distinctly avoided. As we are not prepared to demand that France shall take up our quarrel by land or sea; or that its cruisers shall pursue and seize Southern privateers as pirates, in anticipation of the amendment to the Parisian doctrine, which the acceptance of our Government will perfect; we must approve this action of the French Government as a necessary measure in the circumstances, and one executed with all possible delicacy.

abstract: If any one objects to the notice of an old book under the above head, we have but to reply that as no more books seem likely to be published during the next five years, we conceive ourselves justified in taking up and passing in review all that have been published within the last ten.
lead_paragraph: If any one objects to the notice of an old book under the above head, we have but to reply that as no more books seem likely to be published during the next five years, we conceive ourselves justified in taking up and passing in review all that have been published within the last ten. To the thinking of many a better reason for noticing the book before us might be found in the fact that it is eminently worthy of a second mention, but we prefer to be capricious. Our readers will readily recognize in Mr. FLETCHER, one of the joint authors and the main mover of the book, we fancy, the gentleman whose pleasant lectures have made us almost as familiar with the Brazilian forests as with our own woodlands, and placed us on the footing of old acquaintanceship with that most amiable sovereign, Dom PEDRO SEGUNDO. It is very pleasant this quiet June weather to boat with these entertaining gentlemen on the Amazon, thread its luxuriant valley, and make ourselves acquainted with the latent resourcesand boundless, though undeveloped wealth, of a country to which not a tithe of the attention has been paid that it is entitled to.

abstract: Notwithstanding the unjust and incorrect statement of the English Press concerning the position assumed by the United States on the right of privateering, it would be erroneous to believe that its views have been shared, or its opinions indorsed, by the Continental papers. We notice, on the contrary, that while some of them have remained silent on the subject, others have, with a laudable readiness, acknowledged the true character of our...
lead_paragraph: Notwithstanding the unjust and incorrect statement of the English Press concerning the position assumed by the United States on the right of privateering, it would be erroneous to believe that its views have been shared, or its opinions indorsed, by the Continental papers. We notice, on the contrary, that while some of them have remained silent on the subject, others have, with a laudable readiness, acknowledged the true character of our interference in the debates which took place in the Congress of Paris in 1856, and have spoken of us with that respect for justice and truth, for which England is often inclined to substitute cotton crops and manufacturing interests. Among the papers which have shown themselves the open advocates of our position at that period, we will mention the Nord, published in the French language at Brussels. That paper, which passes for the accredited organ of the Russian Government, but is really controlled by that of France, has lately expressed on our affairs views calculated to give a high opinion of its knowledge of international jurisprudence, and of its acquaintance with our Constitution, and with the diplomatic acts of our Government.

abstract: It was announced in the dailies of Saturday that HENRY WARD BSECHEE would preach to the soldiers on the island of the "Two Brothers," on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: It was announced in the dailies of Saturday that HENRY WARD BRECHER would preach to the soldiers on the island of the "Two Brothers," on Sunday. Consequently the dailies of Sunday teemed with advertisements from steamboat proprietors giving information as to the way of getting to the Camp. In the morning Mr. BEECHER confirmed the news, and stated that he should leave in the boat that started at 2 P.M. As a consequence upon that announcement hundreds of people, delighted at the prospect of combining recreation and instruction rushed to the various landings, swarmed upon the boats leaving at 2 P.M., and turned their happy faces towards Camp Plymouth. On the little Cornelia was the ministerial party, comprised of Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER, with his family and Mrs. H.B. STOWE; Prof. ROBERT R. RAYMOND, of the Polytechnic Institute, with his Bible class; Rev. Mr. Church, of the Baptist Chronicle, with his family; and Mr. CONANT, of the Assay Office, who had charge of sundry young ladies who proposed to aid in the choral exercises at the camp.

abstract: Some details of Mr. COBB'S scheme of cotton financiering have reached us. It is proposed, it seems, to relieve each planter at once of half his crop. and transport it to New-Orleans. When it has reached that point, England will be notified of its readiness for her shops; and will of course break up the blockade and take it. The remainder of the crop. will be moved subsequently, and with a similar result.

abstract: The Memphis Appeal, of June 14, contains election returns from a number of counties in East Tennessee. They are all strongly Union, as follows: Belmont, Union 1,776, separation 418; Bradley, Union 1,382, separation 507; Carrer, Union 1,400, separation 83; Grainger, Union 1,756, separation 495; Knox, Union, 3,206, separation 1,216; Savior, Union 1,527, separation 60; Sullivan, Union 1,586, sepation 627; Hankins, 440. Union majority; Hancock, 400 do.; Reane, over 1,000 do.; Washington, 389 do.; Anderson, over 1,000 do.; Monroe 247 do.; Jefferson, 1,500 do.; Green, 1,600 do.; Hamilton, 406 do.; Marion, 150 do. The majority against representation in the Southern Congress is much larger than the above. In Middle Tennessee, Wayne gives 500 Union majority; Macon, 225 do. In some of the other counties the vote is nearly divided. In West Tennessee, Decatur County gives 200 Union majority. The vote of the Tennessee troops at Pensacola was for disunion, 737; Union, none (of course.)

abstract: The bridge-burning traitor who lately governed Missouri is still in full flight no one knows where. The last seen of him was on Wednesday, at the little town of Syracuse, on the line of the Pacific Railroad, but he was then on horse, sweeping southwestwardly at a hot and furious pace, apparently making for the Indian Territory west of Arkansas.
lead_paragraph: The bridge-burning traitor who lately governed Missouri is still in full flight -- no one knows where. The last seen of him was on Wednesday, at the little town of Syracuse, on the line of the Pacific Railroad, but he was then on horse, sweeping southwestwardly at a hot and furious pace, apparently making for the Indian Territory west of Arkansas. Whether he will ever reach that happy land, and whether he will stay there if he should attain it, we shall know by and by. In the meantime, we would urge him not to stay his steed till be reaches the Mexican line, where he will find congenial confederates in a score of rebel Mexican Governors, and where, moreover, he can enjoy, for the rest of his natural life, a style of Government precisely like that which he is ambitious to rear on the ruins of this glorious Union.

abstract: Our military correspondent, who writes from the most advanced portion of our troops at Arlington Heights, sets forth some strong grounds for apprehending a serious disaster in that quarter. It seems to be pretty well established that the rebels are able to throw at least 50,000 men upon our troops, upon the other side of the Potomac, within...
lead_paragraph: Our military correspondent, who writes from the most advanced portion of our troops at Arlington Heights, sets forth some strong grounds for apprehending a serious disaster in that quarter. It seems to be pretty well established that the rebels are able to throw at least 50,000 men upon our troops, upon the other side of the Potomac, within twenty-four hours, while our whole force beyond the Potomac consists of thirteen regiments of only 800 men each, -- but little over 10,000 in all. This disparity of force is certainly alarming. It is true, there are something like 30,000 American troops on this side the Potomac, in the neighborhood of Washington; -- but it would not be easy to throw all these across the river in time to prevent a defeat, even if the safety of Washington would permit their withdrawal. A considerable time would necessarily be consumed in crossing so wide a river by the means at command of our troops.

abstract: Gov. LETCHER, of Virginia, has just issued two proclamations. One announces to the world the important fact, which has hitherto been clothed in some obscurity, that the people of Virginia by a very large majority of votes, lawfully cast, have resolved to withdraw from the Federal Union and unite themselves with the Confederate States. The other proclamation is in the nature or an appeal to the people of Northwestern Virginia, over whose loyalty to the powers at Richmond a cloud is supposed to rest, to return to their duty and follow the fortunes of the Confederates. Both addresses are in the TIMES of to-day, and will, of course, be read with interest.

lead_paragraph: "Large bodies move slowly," and Col. PRATT's Regiment (the Thirty-first) being a large body, has been proportionately delayed in moving towards the seat of war. True, the veracious Herald and the impatient Tribune started the regiment comfortably off for Washington several days since, but the readers of the TIMES were correctly informed that Col. PRATT and his command still sojourned at the Park Barracks, from whence they finally departed yesterday afternoon.

abstract: CORRECTION. -- In our yesterday's issue, we stated that a sailor was being tried at the Navy-Yard; on a charge of having pulled Capt. MULLANY's case. We are assured that this is an entire mistake. The accused struck Capt. MULLANY a blow, and he, in conformity with the regulations, reported the matter to the Secretary of the Navy, for his action. The man is now filed on the charge of striking a blow. A letter written by the accused to Capt. MULLANY, asking his pardon, for the offence, has been laid before the Court.
lead_paragraph: CORRECTION. -- In our yesterday's issue, we stated that a sailor was being tried at the Navy-Yard; on a charge of having pulled Capt. MULLANY's case. abstract: Whether or no we are going to have any great battles during the Summer in Virginia or elsewhere, with their immense rolls of killed, wounded and missing, is still in the hands of fate and Gen. SCOTT; but certain it is that the grand volunteer army we have in camp and in the field is now subject to the most imminent peril from the ravages of an enemy far more to be feared than the fiercest of mortal fees. Nearly a hundred thousand men, from "black and chilly" New-England, from New-York, and, from the high latitudes of the Northwest, have been suddenly precipitated into the low, unwholesome regions of Southeastern Virginia, and along the line of the Potomac; and there subjected to moral and physical conditions radically differing from any within their experience; suffering also from the most defective sanitary regulations, and a badly managed commissariat. This, too, at a season of the year when, of all times, danger is most to be apprehended among troops unacclimated and unaccustomed to the hard routine of camp life. It seems almost providential that thus far no epidemic or other serious malady has made any headway among them, and that the records of the various camp hospitals and surgeons have exhibited a general condition of health almost without parallel.
lead_paragraph: Whether or no we are going to have any great battles during the Summer in Virginia or elsewhere, with their immense rolls of killed, wounded and missing, is still in the hands of fate and Gen. SCOTT; but certain it is that the grand volunteer army we have in camp and in the field is now subject to the most imminent peril from the ravages of an enemy far more to be feared than the fiercest of mortal fees. Nearly a hundred thousand men, from "black and chilly" New-England, from New-York, and, from the high latitudes of the Northwest, have been suddenly precipitated into the low, unwholesome regions of Southeastern Virginia, and along the line of the Potomac; and there subjected to moral and physical conditions radically differing from any within their experience; suffering also from the most defective sanitary regulations, and a badly managed commissariat. This, too, at a season of the year when, of all times, danger is most to be apprehended among troops unacclimated and unaccustomed to the hard routine of camp life. It seems almost providential that thus far no epidemic or other serious malady has made any headway among them, and that the records of the various camp hospitals and surgeons have exhibited a general condition of health almost without parallel.

abstract: EXTENSIVE FIRE IN THE TWENTIETH WARD-- A ROW OF STABLES AND TENEMENT HOUSES BURNED.--A fire occurred yesterday afternoon in a row of frame  stables located in the rear of No. 248 West Thirtyeighth-street, belonging to PATRICK CAVASNAGH. In a very little while the flames had communicated to...
lead_paragraph: EXTENSIVE FIRE IN THE TWENTIETH WARD -- A ROW OF STABLES AND TENEMENT HOUSES BURNED. -- A fire occurred yesterday afternoon in a row of frame stables located in the rear of No. 248 West Thirtyeighth-street, belonging to PATRICK CAVANNAGH. In a very little while the flames had communicated to other stables on the adjoining lots, Nos. 346, 350 and 352, owned and occupied by JOHN MCGRANE, and also to the five-story tenement house No. 347 West Thirty-seventh-street, causing damage to the extent of $300; covered by insurance. The property of the tenants was injured slightly by water. None were insured. A five story factory, owned by JAMES S. GAGE, in the rear of lots Nos. 251 and 253 West Thirty-seventh-street also caught fire, and was damaged about $200, the only reason why it was saved from destruction being the iron shutters with which it was provided. Another tenement house, No. 244 West Thirty-eighth-street, owned by JOHN MCGRANE, was likewise injured by the flames, although the loss is not extensive. The building was insured in the Bowery Insurance Company. The four-story frame tenement house No. 246 West Thirty-eighth-street was damaged to the extent of $1,200. Mr. MCGRANE owned it also, and had it insured in the North River Insurance Company. A shed in the rear of this building, containing 400 bales of hay, was destroyed, with its contents. Mr. MCGRANE estimates his entire loss at $3,000, upon which there was no insurance. A two-story frame building on the front of lot No. 248 West Thirty-eighth-street, owned by PATRICK CAVANNAGH, was damaged about $200; insured. Another frame building, No. 252, owned and occupied by THOS. BALLOU, was injured about $400 and the furniture $150; insured for $600 in the People's Insurance Company. A blacksmith's shop on lot No. 250, was also burned down. Between thirty and forty families have been rendered houseless by the fire, most of whom have loss a part of their furniture. None of them were insured. The fire was occasioned by children to the yard of No. 247 West Thirty-seventh-street, who set fire to some straw, and the flames spread to the staple.

abstract: The obsequies of Lieut. CHARLES W. WALKER, Company B, Second New-Hampshire Regiment, who came to his death by accidentally falling from the cars at Westfield, N.J., were celebrated yesterday, upon the removal of his remains to his late home in Concord, New-Hampshire.
lead_paragraph: The obsequies of Lieut. CHARLES W. WALKER, Company B, Second New-Hampshire Regiment, who came to his death by accidentally falling from the cars at Westfield, N.J., were celebrated yesterday, upon the removal of his remains to his late home in Concord, New-Hampshire. The funeral took place at St. Ann's church, where the burial service of the Episcopal Church was lead by the rector. A detachment of several Commanderies of the Knights Templars were present, and the officers of the Eleventh Regiment served as a guard of honor. The Committee of the Sons of New-Hampshire attended as an escort. The ceremonies were very impressive. The coffin was draped in the American flag. At the conclusion of the funeral ceremonies the procession passed through Fifth-avenue, Varick and Hudson streets, to the foot of Deabrosses street, where the remains were placed on board of the steamboat for Norwich. Deceased was about 39 years of age, and belonged to Fryburg, Me. He was foremost in organizing the Goodwin Rifles at Concord, which practiced the Zouave drill, and he was elected First Lieutenant of the Company. He was highly esteemed among his masonic and military brethren, and was an excellent citizen, and no man in his regiment probably possessed better prospects for usefulness and promotion.

abstract: The Merchants' Insurance Company vs. Richard H. Hinman et al. -- The particulars of this case were stated in the TIMES of the 19th inst. The action was brought to recover an alleged deficiency in the settlement of an estate, and the main question to be determined was concerning the parties qualified to take the personal property of one Lewis, who died intestate, as next of kin. It will be remembered that one of the parties claimed that the widow of Lewis, who is now the wife of defendant, was, for the purposes of distribution, next of kin.

abstract: The People ex rel. John Green vs. Fernando Wood. -- This case was stated in the TIMES of the 22d inst. It will be remembered that this was an application for a peremptory mandamus to compel the Mayor to countersign a warrant sub-certified by the City Inspector, for the payment to the relator of $1,000 upon a contract for the removal of offal, &c, from the streets. The Mayor refused to perform the act, alleging that the relator had failed to do the work in accordance with the terms of the contract. Such was also the substance of the return made by his Honor to the alternative writ of mandamus. The relator demurred to this return, and moved that it be quashed, and that a peremptory writ issue. The Court gives judgment for the relator upon the demurrer, with leave to the defendant to amend within twenty days on payment of costs. If not so amended, the return will be quashed, and a peremptory writ will issue.

abstract: A horrible disaster occured at Wyandotte, Kansas, yesterday, by the falling in of the walls of two buildings and part of a third, burying all the inmates, some forty persons. The buildings were four stories high and situated on the levee. They had previously been used as the head-quarters of the First Regiment of Kansas Volunteers.

abstract: The weather continued unfavorable for sugarmaking. The quantity of sugar shipped to the 10th, amounted to over 18 185 hogsheads, but there was in store 3,000, and a similar quantity on the stauncheons. There was a great want of fuel, which would cause an additional expense. The young crop was looking well. Potatoes and corn had been planted. There had been a good deal of sickness, and some rather sudden deaths. The Comptroller of the Customs and his family had returned to the Island.

abstract: No movement of importance among the Federal troops, aside from the ordinary arrivals and departures, appears to have taken place in the vicinity of Washington yesterday. Our lines are being strengthened daily whenever such a proceeding seems necessary, and will doubtless soon be, if they are not already, in a condition to withstand the onset of the fifty thousand rebel troops which are reported to be ready to attempt the capture of the Capital.

abstract: MURDER OF THE FIRST MATE OF AN AMERICAN VESSEL AT HAVANA. -- The steamship Columbia, which arrived from Havana yesterday, brought as prisoner CHAS. RAMEZ, a Chilien, charged with the murder of R.M. EMORY, first mate of the American bark Ocean Traveler, of Belfast, Maine, at the port of Havana, on the 17th of May. It seems that on that date a scuffle occurred on board the vessel between the mate and RAMEZ, arising out of the insolence of the latter, during which RAMEZ indicted a stab upon the mate, from the effects of which he died on the 20th of June. The prisoner was taken to the United States District Attorney's office, where an order for his commitment was made out. Another hand on board the Ocean Traveler, named JOHN MYERS, is implicated in the murder, but he now lies sick in the hospital at Havana.
lead_paragraph: MURDER OF THE FIRST MATE OF AN AMERICAN VESSEL AT HAVANA. -- The steamship Columbia, which arrived from Havana yesterday, brought as prisoner CHAS. abstract: We publish this morning a very admirable report of affairs in the National and the Rebel camps at Fort Pickens, from the pen of the special correspondent of the London Times. On the same day he was shown through both camps by their commanding officers, and permitted to explore and examine every preparation made on either side. Such a thing, as he himself remarks, was probably never before known in the history of war. Mr. RUSSELL's description is minute, graphic and picturesque -- and, read in connection with the capital Chart of the vicinity which we have received from our own correspondent, it gives the public a very clear insight into the condition of affairs in that quarter.

abstract: The new Senator of the United States, from California, Gen. JAMES A. McDOUGALL, arrived yesterday in the Ariel, en route for Washington. He is an independent Union Democrat, and as such was elected by a combination of Douglas men and Republicans in the California Legislature last May. It is understood that he will support earnestly the policy of the Administration in asserting the power of the Federal Government over all the States of the Union.

abstract: A statement having been made to the effect, that the whole panel of the jurors lately discharged were unsatisfactory to the Court and District Attorney, it is proper to state that such is not the fact. We learn from the District-Attorney that the panel has served with great acceptance, and has deserved every commendation. While just to the accused, they have convicted unsparingly in all cases, except that of the slaver Capt. Gordon. With those who failed to agree with the majority in that case just fault is found. With the exception of those two or three men, the panel was composed of men of unusual intelligence and proved integrity. As to them, they may have erred conscientiously, and, perhaps, may not have erred at all. But it is certainly to be regretted and wondered at, that a jury could fail to agree in a case involving such evidence of turpitude.

abstract: Major-Gen. DIX arrived in Washington yesterday, and is expected to assume command of the Federal forces across the Potomac, in a few days. It is not anticipated, however, that even then any forward movement will be made. It is now pretty wellsettled, that unless an attack is made on our lines by the rebels, matters will remain about as they are, with respect to the position of the troops -- continued additions, meantime, being made to their numbers. The fear of an immediate attack by BEAUREGARD's forces appears to have again died out, as the latest reports from their camp at Manassas Junction represent them to be in no condition for aggressive movements. At Fairfax Court house they have now but one thousand men, understood to be commanded by Col. HARDEE, while at Vienna they have none, as ascertained satisfactorily yesterday morning. There appears, however, to be no doubt of the fact that the rebel pickets now extend from Occequan to Centreville.

abstract: Same of our cotemporaries are either very much alarmed themselves, or are very anxious to alarm the public, about the danger of compromising the questions now at issue between the Government and the States in rebeilion against it. The World led off ...
lead_paragraph: Some of our cotemporaries are either very much alarmed themselves, or are very anxious to alarm the public, about the danger of compromising the questions now at issue between the Government and the States in rebeilion against it. The World led off last Saturday in a sensation dispatch, purporting to have come from Washington, but which was really written for effect in this City, asserting that JEFF DAVIS had made certain proposals for peace, which our Government had under consideration. The Tribune of yesterday followed suit, repeating substantially the original story, and adding that Senators HUNTER and BAYARD were in this City, in disguise, on a mission to FERNANDO WOOD (!) for the restoration of peace.

abstract: The People ex rel. Nicholas J. Marselus vs. The Ministers, Elders, , of the Reformed Protestant Dutch Church. lead_paragraph: The People ex rel. Nicholas J. Marselus vs. The Ministers, Elders, &c., of the Reformed Protestant Dutch Church. -- This case has been several times stated in the TIMES, and in the last instance on the occasion of the argument at General Term, of the appeal taken therein. The relator is a minister of this Church, and he brings the action for himself, and on behalf of all other ministers of the same denomination officiating as such in the City. It is alleged that the Reformed Protestant Dutch Church of this City has two funds created years since for the benefit of all the ministers in the City of that denomination, and that the relator and others have been excluded therefrom. At Special Term the complaint in the case was dismissed. This appeal was then taken, and the following is the opinion of the Court, rendered therein, which will fully explain the case:
