abstract: Thomas Rigney and others vs. William Barllet. This was an action brought to recover the sum of $700 for moneys alleged to have been received by the defendant upon a joint adventure and charter party entered into by the parties to the suit. The ...
lead_paragraph: Thomas Rigney and others vs. William Bartlet. -- This was an action brought to recover the sum of $700 for moneys alleged to have been received by the defendant upon a joint adventure and charter party entered into by the parties to the suit. The plaintiffs' evidence showed that the parties had entered into this transaction as copartners, the defendant having the management of the affair; and also that the defendant had admitted that the profits, as shown by the freight bill, exceeded the amount of charter party some $1,500.

abstract: FATAL CASUALTIES. -- Yesterday afternoon, about 4 o'clock, a laborer named ELIAS GREFFIN, employed at the shipyard of the Dry and Wet DOCK Company, was instantly killed, in consequence of the hooks used for hoisting slipping off from a piece of timber, and striking him upon the neck, which was afterwards found to be broken. Deceased resided in Hoboken, and leaves a family. A man named MICHAEL EARNEST, a canal-boat hand, while employed, yesterday afternoon, at the Morris Cana[???]pier, in showing off the boat at, lost his balance, and, falling overboard, was drowned His body was soon after recovered. Coroner GAPNEY held an inquest in both cases, and verdicts of accidental death were rendered.

abstract: from the blockading fleet in the Gulf, that emigrant ships are almost daily arriving at the delta of the Mississippi, consigned to New-Orleans. Though the ships are not permitted to proceed further on their voyage, the emigrants are allowed to go to the city. Landed there, they must soon experience much suffering, as thousands of the resident laboring population already are known to be in a state of destination. The Fish, as a general rule, arrive with little or no means; and though the Germans usually come with sufficient money to convey them to their ultimate destination which is generally above the mouth of the Ohio, communication by steamer is now suspended above Memphis. Their means are soon exhausted, and the alternative is at once presented to the emigrant, either to starve or to enlist in the rebel army. But it seems that in all cases the rebel troops do not wait until this class are compelled to make their election. By way of Louisville we were informed, a few days since, that nearly three hundred German emigrants, on their way to Memphis, were forcibly taken from the steamer at a point in Arkansas, and made to work on the rebel fortification. We are certain that such an exhibition of heartless infamy could only be made by a slaveholding despotism of the lowest grade. But independent of any considerations of sympathy for the sufferings of these people, a sound policy would dictate that this source of recording their ranks be cut off from the rebels, by causing the officers of the blockading fleet to be at once instructed to direct masters of vessels arriving in the Gulf to convey their passengers to some port North not under blockade.

We are certain that such an exhibition of heartless infamy could only be made by a slaveholding despotism of the lowest grade. But independent of any considerations of sympathy for the sufferings of these people, a sound policy would dictate that this source of recording their ranks be cut off from the rebels, by causing the officers of the blockading fleet to be at once instructed to direct masters of vessels arriving in the Gulf to convey their passengers to some port North not under blockade.

abstract: We are advised of a very serious riot that occurred, day before yesterday, in the city of Milwaukee. A number of banking-houses were broken into, their furniture destroyed, and the inmates, officers and owners roughly handled by an enraged populace. One or two ...
lead_paragraph: We are advised of a very serious riot that occurred, day before yesterday, in the city of Milwaukee. A number of banking-houses were broken into, their furniture destroyed, and the inmates, officers and owners roughly handled by an enraged populace. One or two very serious injuries occurred, and the riot was only suppressed at last by a military company, that fired on the mob. At the latest dates the military were guarding the banks and the jail in which some of the rioters were confined, and no further outbreak was apprehended.

abstract: WINTER GARDEN -- Mr. JACKSON has added to the interest of "Our American Cousin at Home," by introducing a series of very elaborate tableaux at the end of the last act. They are typical of the times, and while showing the horrors of war, poetize the beauties of returning peace. The groups are arranged with much good taste, and are very beautiful. They were exhibited for the first time on Monday evening, and gave decided satisfaction to the audience.

abstract: The first case under the President's pro- clamation, which declared privateering to be piracy, is to be tried in this City. The Harriet Lone has landed here the officers and crew of the Savannah, transferred from the Minne- sota; and by this time the fellows are in the custody of the United States officers, and will only have to await the nation of the Grand Jury of the District Court to have their trial.

abstract: The Twenty-eighth Regiment New York State Volunteers, Co. DONELLY commanding, arrived in this City yesterday noon from Albany, and at 5 o'clock P.M. took a steamboat for Elizabeth, from whence they proceeded, without change of cars, to Harrisburgh, and thence to Baltimore and Washington. They have a full supply of camp equipage, and ...
lead_paragraph: The Twenty-eighth Regiment New York State Volunteers, Col. DONELLY commanding, arrived in this City yesterday noon from Albany, and at 5 o'clock P.M. took a steamboat for Elizabeth, from whence they proceeded, without change of cars, to Harrisburgh, and thence to Baltimore and Washington. They have a full supply of camp equipage, and are furnished with Remington's rifle and sword bayonet, made at Ilion, Herkimer County. They have six horses belonging to the staff, and carry 50,000 round of ball cartridge. The regiment is composed mostly of farmer's sons and the substantial men of the interior counties of the State, as well as mechanics, professional men, school-teachers, &c. They compare favorably with the Rhode Island and other New-England regiments. The following are the names of the officers and places where the companies were recruited:

abstract: WINTER GARDEN. -- Mr. JACKSON has added to the interest of "Our American Cousin at Home," by introducing a series of very elaborate tableaux at the end of the last act. They are typical of the times, and while showing the horrors of war, poetize the beauties of returning peace. The groups are arranged with much good taste, and are very beautiful. They were exhibited for the first time on Monday evening, and gave decided satisfaction to the audience.

abstract: This regiment, occupying Yorkville and Hamilton Park, expect to move Southward the latter part of this week. abstract: CLOSE OF A YOUNG LADIES SEMINARY. -- June and the warm weather are beginning to close our fashionable boarding-schools for the season. Last Friday witnessed the end of the Summer term at Mile ROSTAN'S institution on Twenty-fifth-street, but the closing ceremonies did not occur until Monday evening, when the elegant salons of that establishment were thrown open to the parents and friends of the pupils, and the latter exhibited their proficiency in various accomplishments chielly in mania, compositions and language. The young ladies disolved remarkable proficiency in french -- the everyday language of the establishment. Many of the compositions read were more than ordinarily merit ri[???]u, while the execution of several of the young ladies at the piano reflected decided credit even upon such in structors as MILLS and MASON. The parting address was delivered by a young lady of the graduating class, who paid the highest possible complement to the management to the institution, when she reminded nor school mates that their pleasant intercourse had been marred by no cliques nor petty jealousies -- that they had nothing to look back upon but Kindness and love. The school of which such a remark is true, must be under excellent and julicious discipline.

abstract: the plunge of the Gulf States into secession, we invited the attention of the Board of Brokers to the propriety of excluding the bonds of that Commonwealth from their list. The reasons for this measure were obvious. There was not only a chance that the disloyal State, guilty of the highest crime known to the law, might descend to a lower degree by issuing factitious securities, and bartering them in this market for Northern gold, but there was also a certainty that some eleven millions of the bonds held in Virginia would be sent here for sale, while the market is [???] kept open for their [???]. The Board of Brokers admitted the subject to discussion, but finally decided to retain the bonds of all the Border States on their schedule, even after the States had repudiated their Federal obligations.

abstract: The United States steamer Harriet Lane, Capt. JOHN FAUNCE, commanding, arrived at this port yesterday, in twenty-eight hours from Fortress Monroe. The II. L. had on board six invalids from the flag-ship Minnesota, the master and three of the crew of the prize brig Hallie Jackson, and four officers and nine of the crew of the rebel privateer savannah. The Harriet Lane was ordered to the Brooklyn Navy-yard for repairs, having been constantly under steam since February last, and actively employed since the commencement of hostilities.
lead_paragraph: The United States steamer Harriet Lane, Capt. JOHN FAUNCE, commanding, arrived at this port yesterday, in twenty-eight hours from Fortress Monroe. The II. abstract: CLOSE OF A YOUNG LADIES' SEMINARY. June and teh warm weather are beginning to close our fashionable boarding-schools for the season. Last Friday witnessed the end of the Summer term at Mile.
lead_paragraph: CLOSE OF A YOUNG LADIES' SEMINARY. -- June and the warm weather are beginning to close our fashionable boarding-schools for the season. Last Friday witnessed the end of the Summer term at Mile. ROSTAN's institution on Twenty-fifth-street, but the closing ceremonies did not occur until Monday evening, when the elegant salons of that establishment were thrown open to the parents and friends of the pupils; and the latter exhibited their proficiency in various accomplishments, chiefly in music, compositions and language. The young ladies displayed remarkable proficiency in French -- the every-day language of the establishment. Many of the compositions read were more than ordinarily meritorious, while the execution of several of the young ladies at the piano reflected decided credit even upon such instructors as MILLS and MASON. The parting address was delivered by a young lady of the graduating class, who paid the highest possible compliment to the management of the institution, when she reminded her schoolmates that their pleasant intercourse had been marred by no cliques nor petty jealousies -- that they had nothing to look back upon but kindness and love. The school of which such a remark is true, must be under excellent and judicious discipline.

abstract: -- The causeless destruction of property by the rebel forces at Martinsburgh shows the Vandal assure of the war they are waging. There was no military necessity requiring it. It did not belong to and could not be used by the enemy. It was, moreover, the property in the main of those who sympathised with secession. It was private property, and policy, as well as the rules of civilized warfare, required that it should have been respected. When they destroyed the railroad bridges they rendered the half-million worth of locomotives as useless as if they had been at the bottom of the river. The destruction of them was, therefore, the mere wantonness as well as the wickedness of mischief. It has served them no good purpose, but rather injured their cause by alienating the sympathies of thousands who were disposed to aid them in their treason. There may be something retributive in the measure so far as the [???] were concerned, but it was far from being demanded at the hands of Gen. JOHNSTON. It was act for him to punish his friends for their disloyalty to the Government against which he was himself in arms.

abstract: The Special Committee of the Common Council, appointed to examine into the funds of the city, which had been appropriated in fitting out the volunteers, held a meeting on Tuesday evening, and first proceeded to examine the unpaid bills. Different bills, amounting to about $5,000 were presented, and the parties who furnished the different articles were closely questioned and the bills were audited are lopping off some excessive charges. At the next meeting of the Committee witnesses will be called to testify as to the bills already paid.

abstract: One of the most destructive fires which has visited Flushing for several years, occurred in that village yesterday afternoon. About 12 1/4 o'clock, fire broke out in the second story of Mr. EDWARD EAGLE's hardware-store, on Main-street, and obtained such rapid headway as to defy all efforts to extinguish it. The town was soon alarmed by the ringing of the bells, and in a few moments Engine Companies Nos. 1 and 2 were on the spot with their machines. The citizens also rallied, and assisted in removing the goods which were upon the first floor, and a considerable portion of these was saved. Powerful streams of water were poured upon the building, but the entire edifice was soon enveloped in flames, which spread to the adjoining store of Messrs. PECK & FAIRWEATHER, communicating to the roof. A fresh wind was blowing from the westward, and fears were now entertained of an extensive conflagration. The citizens formed lines with vacants; and even the schoolboys, with air. GATES, their Principal, at their head, worked heroically in passing water into the burning buildings, while others worked with equal energy is passing the property out. The principal part of the goods on the first and second floors were thus saved, but that portion of the stock which was in the basement and other portions of the store were destroyed. An express was seat to Newtown, and the engine company from that place promptly responded to the call for assistance, and burried to the scene of conflagration. They were in season to render effective aid, but both stores were wholly consumed. Mr. EAGLEE's was a brick building three stories in height, and contained a large assorted stock of hardware, stoves, &c. Messrs. PECK & FAIRWEATHER's was a three story frame building, and was one of the largest and best arranged variety stores in Flushing, having a stock valued at some $30,000. Two or three persons were injured by fragments of the falling structures, but no one was dangerously hurt. The fire is said to have originated from one of the small furnaces used by the workmen. The property was insured, but the owners of the stock will suffer considerable loss.

abstract: In war, all things else being equal, the length of purse of the respective parties is the measure of their endurance. The credit of belligerents is put to the severest tests. Under the pressure now existing, a forced sale of Louisiana bonds recently in New-Orleans only realized for them ten per cent. of the amounts called for by their face. Tennessee and Virginia bonds fluctuate between 35 and 40, North Carolina only reaches 50, and neither Mississippi, Florida nor Arkansas could buy a yard of jeans, a side of bacon or a bushel of corn on the strength of their public credit. And the Southern Confederacy, so called, is compelled in its financial desperation to borrow cotton in the hope of a market to keep their treasonable concern in motion. In contrast with this, the State of New-York, advertising for a loan of $700,000 to meet a deficiency in the General Fund Debt Sinking Fund, has nearly $3,000,000 offered at rates varying from par to 4.50 premium, the lowest bid accepted being at a premium of 1.38.

abstract: The Sixteenth Regiment New-York Volunteers, Col. THOS. A. DAVIES, arrived here yesterday afternoon from Albany, which place they let at 5 o'clock on Tuesday evening. It was their original intention ...
lead_paragraph: The Sixteenth Regiment New-York Volunteers, Col. THOS. A. DAVIES, arrived here yesterday afternoon from Albany, which place they let at 5 o'clock on Tuesday evening. It was their original intention not to land in the City, but to go direct from the barges on which they came from Albany to Elizabethport, where they would take the cars for Philadelphia; but on learning that it was the desire of some of the friends of the regiment to present them with a banner, Col. DAVIES changed the programme and landed the regiment at the foot of Fourteenth-street, at 2 1/2 P.M., whence they marched to Washington-square, where they were presented with a beautiful regimental flag, the gift of the wife of Adjutant G. HOWLAND. The presentation speech was made by Mr. R.S. HOGE, and was appropriately responded to by Col. DAVIES. The regiment then took up their line of march for Pier No 2 North River, passing through Union-square, around the Statue of WASHINGTON, and down Broadway, receiving the enthusiastic greetings of crowds of people that lined the streets on the route. The regiment was preceded by an excellent band, and presented a very fine appearance. The dress of the soldiers is of the United States Army pattern, and all the officers wear the regulation uniform, with felt hats and plumes. The commander of the regiment, Col. DAVIES, is a graduate of West Point, and served in the war with Mexico. The men composing the regiment are volunteers from the region of country about Albany, and northward as far as Plattsburgh, which place sent out one company for the regiment, whose beautiful yellow silk banner, inscribed "Plattsburgh Volunteers," attracted a good seal of attention as they marched down Broadway. The regiment embarked on board the Kill von Kull for Elizabethtown about 5 o'clock P.M., and will proceed direct to Washington. The following is a list of the officers of the regiment:

abstract: The news from the Virginia State Convention, now sitting at Richmond, is somewhat interesting, as it tends to develop the total madness that controls the Southern heart ...
lead_paragraph: -- The news from the Virginia State Convention, now sitting at Richmond, is somewhat interesting, as it tends to develop the total madness that controls the Southern heart, and is preparing the unhappy people of the Confederate States for a horrible doom. It is announced that the Convention have under consideration an ordinance for organizing a guerilla system of warfare against the enemies of the State, which means its own Union citizens and the Federal troops wherever found. The practical effect of this ordinance will be to condemn to death every Unionists "without clergy and without jury," to relieve their murderers from any penalty incurred by technicality of law, or perhaps from the evil consequence of any unwitting mistake, in the taking off of these public enemies. There is to be a general carnival of butchery -- pure and simple -- such as civilized nations have never tolerated, and only devils and Secessionists could have devised.

abstract: We are glad to see indications of an effort on the part of the Post-office Department to put an end to the gross abuses which are becoming chronic in the franking privilege.
lead_paragraph: We are glad to see indications of an effort on the part of the Post-office Department to put an end to the gross abuses which are becoming chronic in the franking privilege. Several members of congress have ostentatiously devoted themselves for some weeks to franking letters from volunteers at Washington to their friends at home, and the newspapers have dealt in unmeasured eulogy of their self-denying devotion to the wants of the army. If they would contribute out of their own pockets money enough to pay the postage, they would be entitled to this commendation; but the simple sacrifice of such portion of their time as may be required to defraud the Government out of the amount, scarcely establishes a claim to this extravagant laudation.

abstract: The Trustees of Columbia College, at their Annual Commencement, held yesterday at the Academy of Music, most happily struck the chord of public feeling, by conferring on ...
lead_paragraph: The Trustees of Columbia College, at their Annual Commencement, held yesterday at the Academy of Music, most happily struck the chord of public feeling, by conferring on ABRAHAM LINCOLN the honorary degree of Doctor of Laws. The announcement of the act, by the President of the College, from the stage, to the immense and brilliant audience, male and female, which its Annual Commencement always gathers, though taking them by surprise, was caught up at once and received with shouts of enthusiasm, the band instantly interrupting the accustomed gravity of the ceremonial by bursting into the National air.

abstract: THE ARGUMENT IN THE BLOCKADE CASKS. -- The argument upon the case of the English bank Hiawatha, seized for alleged violation of the blockade at Hampton Roads, will commence to day, before Judge BETTS, in the United States District Court. This case is looked to with much interest, as it involves the entire question of the blockade established by the United States Government STEWART L. WODDRUFF, Esq., Assistant District-Attorney will open the argument on behalf of the Government, which will be closed by District Attorney E.D. SMITH, CHAS. EDWARDS Esq., counsel for H.B.M.'s Consul at this port, appears for the vessel.
lead_paragraph: THE ARGUMENT IN THE BLOCKADE CASKS. -- The argument upon the case of the English bank Hiawatha, seized for alleged violation of the blockade at Hampton Roads, will commence to day, before Judge BETTS, in the United States District Court. abstract: Our European advices instruct us that large bodies of English troops are in motion for Canada; that the Great Eastern has been secured for their transportation; and that in addition to the number of frigates already detailed to reinforce the squadron in our waters, a fleet of gunboats is to be forthwith dispatched. This formidable preparation for contingencies never in the slightest degree likely to occur, may well excite our surprise; but it certainly excites none of that alarm which the English Press and people seem to anticipate. The London papers are filled with sedatives for apprehensions, which they assume will thrill the American mind with terror at the news of these demonstrations. But while we are quite sure the display of military and naval power is uncalled for by any conceivable exigency, and that the pretended fear of hostile incursions into Canada, from the American side, is the shallowest of pretences, we can safely assert that these movements are witnessed here with thorough indifference; as much so, indeed, as if the shipment was away from rather than into the adjoining colonies. It is probable no Englishman will ever learn to comprehend the genius and character of our people. If the manifestation of indignant feeling at the cool unfriendliness of John Bull in our day of emergency be received as an evidence of fear on the part of this people, the fact proves how impossible it is to penetrate the stolid self-conceit and prejudice of our venerable ancestor by any direct appeal. That manifestation was indeed the highest evidence of the rash and almost reckless spirit of our population. There was even an unreasoanable eagerness to accept the attitude of the British Government as a just cause of war; and foolish men, prompted by designing ones, labored earnestly to work up the masses to a fighting pitch of Anglophobia. It has only been the amended and chastened temper of the English themselves that has rendered this effort vain; and we are quite sure the coming of armies to Canada as numerous as that of XERXES, and of fleets as formidable as the Armada, will excite no other emotion here than of momentary surprise, followed by permanent indifference.

abstract: The Commencement exercises of Columbia College the one hundred and seventh anniversary of the Academic session-took place, yesterday, at the Academy of Music, under the pleasant auspices of ...
lead_paragraph: The Commencement exercises of Columbia College -- the one hundred and seventh anniversary of the Academic session -- took place, yesterday, at the Academy of Music, under the pleasant auspices of President KING, who with the Faculty and Board of Trustees, and a number of well known citizens, occupied the stage. The building was crowded with as delightful a throng as was ever attracted to this favorite Temple of the Mutes, and if a new prima donna had been about to make her appearance, the fair enthusiasts could not have come better prepared with floral offerings, to shower upon their favored one.

abstract: LAYING OF A CORNER-STONE -- The corner stone of a building, to be used as a "Home for Destitute Children," was laid at the corner of Flatbush-avenue and Butler street, last evening, with appropriate exercises. The opening prayer was offered by the Rev. Dr. CUTLER, after which the Hon. C.P. SMITH made an address, in which he described the building and stated the purpose for which the "Home" was to be used. The Rev. Dr. STORRS and others delivered addresses, [???] sum was collected towards paying for the new building. The building is to be constructed of brick, with stone trimmings in the [???] style of architecture. It will be five stories high, and replace with every convenience. The cost will be about $15,000, $5,000 of which has been appropriated by the State.

abstract: By our dispatches from Washington, we are informed definitely of Gen. SCOTT'S plan of the campain. His purpose is to avoid a general engagement, but by the concentration of immense bodies ...
lead_paragraph: By our dispatches from Washington, we are informed definitely of Gen. SCOTT's plan of the campain. His purpose is to avoid a general engagement, but by the concentration of immense bodies of Federal troops, to force the rebel army to retreat from the Border States. In doing this, he relies upon the cooperation of the loyal citizens of the Border States. By a demonstration against the ports of the Gulf States from the sea, he expects that the troops composing the rebel army will be recalled to their respective States, and that, finding themselves powerless to take the offensive against the superior forces of Government troops, the rebels will be compelled to accept terms from Washington, and return to their allegiance. The steamer Guy, having returned from her trip down the Potomac, reports that on Tuesday she went to Matthias Point, in company with the Pawnee, and discovered that the Confederates, to the number of about 800, had arrived, and were encamped about a mile from the Point, near a marsh. The Pawnee opened fire upon them, and they fled in all directions.

abstract: The bark Virginia Ann, Capt. BRYANT, from Bordeaux, via Pass a L'Outre, (New-Orleans Bar,) arrived at this port yesterday, and reports that on the 23d inst. was chased all day and night by a very suspicious looking vessel, schooner rigged, and having the appearance of having previously been a pilot-boat, and fitted up for a privateer. The Virginia Ann, in order to get clear of her, was compelled to carry a heavy press of canvas, in doing which she had her maintopmast backstay carried away. On the following day both vessels were becalmed, when the schooner used sweeps and made for the bark, but fortunately at this time a fresh breeze sprung up and the schooner was soon out of sight. The Virginia Ann, during the passage, encountered a succession of S.W. gales and squalls, during which she lost some suits, split foretopmast and broke the main tressel-tree. From May 3d to June 2d, experienced calms, with occasional heavy squalls from N.W. The Virginia Ann was bound to New-Orleans, and arrived at the Balize June 5, where she was boarded by the United States steam sloop of war Brooklyn, and ordered off, receiving the information of the blockading of all Southern ports. The Commander of the Brooklyn was then informed of the crippled condition of the vessel's spars and the scarcity of provisions on board, but left with his vessel without taking any notice of it and Capt. BRYANT was compelled to make the best of his way to some Northern port. June 10, lat. 27' 04째, lon. 84' 28째, Capt. B. boarded the English ship Bramleamore, from Mobile, with a cargo of cotton, bound to Liverpool, and received from her some provisions and a negro man, who belonged North, and was allowed to leave in the Bramleamore, she being the last vessel permitted to leave that port by the blockading squadron. The Bramleamore reported being boarded by the U.S. steamer Massachusetts, and that the Massachusetts had the day previous taken twenty-five prizes, one of which was the English ship [???], from Mobile. June 18, lat. 29' 52째, lon. 79' 05째, at 8:30 P.M., experienced a heavy squall, accompanied with vivid lightning, lasting 3 hours and twenty minutes without intermission, every clap of thunder shaking the vessel from truck to keel, during which time the vessel lay under bare poles. After the squall she found the maintopgallant cap sprung. On the 21st she spoke the U.S. gun-boat Union, off Charleston. She reported having captured off that port the ship Amelia, from Liverpool, loaded with arms and ammunition for the rebel army. The commander of the Union kindly offered any assistance the Virginia Ann stood in need of.

abstract: The cadets attached to the above institution, to the number of fifty, paid a visit to this City yesterday, arriving here at 2 P.M., via Hudson River Railroad. The Academy is located at Sing Sing, and is ...
lead_paragraph: The cadets attached to the above institution, to the number of fifty, paid a visit to this City yesterday, arriving here at 2 1/2 P.M., via Hudson River Railroad. The Academy is located at Sing Sing, and is under the management of Mr. PHELPS and Major W.W. BENJAMIN. Having reached the Chambers-street depot, the corps formed in line and marched down Broadway, headed by a band of thirteen pieces, to the Astor House, where a lunch had been provided for them. After disposing of the lunch the cadets again formed in line and proceeded down Broadway and Wall-street, and up Nassau-street to the City Hall Park, where they were reviewed by the Mayor, the Recorder, and members of the Common Council. The corps was divided into four companies, under the leadership of Maj. BENZAMIN, and was escorted by the Madison square Zouaves, the same company that met the Seventh Regiment on their return from Washington. They went through the various military movements in a manner that elicited frequent applause from the vast number of spectators that surrounded them, and several experienced officers were heard to say that their performance of the Zouave tactics was equal to that of any regiment that has left the City. Mayor WOOD addressed them in a few remarks in which he said he believed he expressed the opinion of the gentlemen present, when he said they had acquitted themselves with great credit to the institution of which they were members. He was gratified at the exhibition they had given, and would say, without casting any reflection upon others, but rather as a compliment, that they had acquitted themselves as well as any of the City regiments he had reviewed during these impending troubles. He said they appeared to be active, well disciplined, and to understand their duties thoroughly. It was gratifying to learn that their ranks contained representatives from almost all the States -- from the South as well as from the North -- and he hoped that their union and cooperation with each other would be followed by a reunion of the States. It was the duty of the cadets, the duty of us all, while we shall maintain the authority and the integrity of the Government, to be prepared, at the same time, to defend that authority. The Mayor hoped, if they ever were called upon to take the field, it would be to fight against a foreign enemy, and not against their fellow-countrymen. At the conclusion of the remarks, the corps visited the Governor's Room in the City Hall, after which they marched up Broadway and back again to the depot, where they took the cars at 6 o'clock for home. Tonight they have a ball, to be followed by a six week's vacation commencing on the following day.

abstract: A correspondent of the Boston Transcript, writing to that paper under date of June 22, gives some interesting particulars of the state of things at the Military Academy, and of the recommendations of the recent Board of Visitors. The Board, which has just closed its session, recommended an increase in the number of cadets. The maximum number that can now be admitted is 273, while the barracks to the buildings are capable of accommodating 400. Although, in the last forty-nine years, the population of the country has been multiplied fourfold, the legal number of cadets admissible into the Academy has been enlarged by the addition of but twenty-three. The complement in 1812 was 250. The Visitors, therefore, recommend that the corps be raised to 400 cadets, that each United States Senator, and each United States Representative, be allowed, respectively, to nominate one, and that the remainder be appointed by the President at his discretion.

abstract: The new Governor of Virginia appointed by the late convention, has called an extra session of the Legislature, to meet at Wheeling on Monday next.
lead_paragraph: The new Governor of Virginia appointed by the late convention, has called an extra session of the Legislature, to meet at Wheeling on Monday next. The meeting of this body will be a new thing in the history of this country. It will be the first session of a Legislature in a seceded State, under a decree of the people, repudiating and deposing their former government on account of its treason, and reorganizing under the Constitution. The presence of the loyal forces in Virginia have enabled the people of that State who preserved their allegiance, to maintain their position, and hold the Old Deminion to her place in the Union. When Gov. LETCHER and his associates went over to secession, it did not enter into their calculations that they would be superseded by a new dynasty, that would prevent them from striking from the national flag the star that Washington and his great compeers placed there. They did not take into the account that their own people, whom they were betraying, would, by an assertion of the original powers vested in them, repudiate their action, revoke their commissions, and strip them of official trust and authority. In their haste to destroy the Union, they overlooked the loyalty west of the mountains, that had no sympathy with secession, and that execrated the treason that hurried Virginia into rebellion.

abstract: At a meeting of the natives of Maine resident in this City, yesterday afternoon, at the office of HAWKINS & COTHREN, Esqs., Capt. AMBROSE SNOW, in the Chair, and HENRY DUNLAP, Esq., Secretary, the following Committee of Arrangements were chosen: DEXTER A. HAWKINS, Esq., Chairman; W.H. Fogg, Geo. F. Dunning, Wm. L. Cogswell, H.H. Bevely, H.T. Capen, H.W. Allen, Isaac H. Bailey, Aaron Healey, Jonathan Chase. The natives of Maine in this City and vicinity are requested to meet at the Astor House this morning at 9 1/2 o'clock where they will form in procession and proceed to Pier No. 3 North River, to receive the regiment on its arrival from Fall River. The regiment will be escorted up Battery-place and Broadway to the City Hall, where a flag will be presented by I.T. WILLIAMS, in behalf of the Sons of Maine in this City. After the presentation the officers will dine at the Astor House and the regiment at the Park Barracks. After dinner the regiment will proceed by the night train to Washington.

abstract: The army destined for operation in Western Virginia is organized and fairly in the field; ana Gen. McCLELLAN is in command in person. We hear of him, by telegraph, at Grafton ...
lead_paragraph: The army destined for operation in Western Virginia is organized and fairly in the field; ana Gen. MCCLELLAN is in command in person. We hear of him, by telegraph, at Grafton, where he has just issued an admirable proclamation to his troops, reminding them of the sacred duties of their campaign, or which the following is the key-note: "Bear in mind that you are in the country of friends, not of enemies; that you are here to protect not to destroy."

abstract: The Sixteenth Regiment New-York Volunteers, Col. THOS. A. DAVIES, arrived here yesterday afternoon from Albany, which place they left at 5 o'clock on Tuesday evening. It was their original intention not to land in the City, but to go direct from the barges on which they came from Albany to Elizabethport, where they would take the cars for Philadelphia; but on learning that it was the desire of some of the friends of the regiment to present them with a banner, Col. DAVIES changed the programme and landed the regiment at the foot of Fourteenth-street, at 2 1/3 P.M., whence they marched to Washington-square, where they were presented with a beautiful regimental flag, the gift of the wife of Adjutant G. HOWLAND. The presentation speech was made by Mr. R.S. HONE, and was appropriately responded to by Col. DAVIES. The regiment then took up their line of march for Pier No. 2 North River, passing through Union-square, around the Statue of WASHINGTON, and down Broadway, receiving the enthusiastic greetings of crowds of people that lined the streets on the route. The regiment was preceded by an excellent band, and presented a very fine appearance. The dress of the soldiers is of the United States Army pattern, and all the officers wear the regulation uniform, with felt hats and plumes. The commander of the regiment, Col. DAVIES, is a graduate of West Point, and served in the war with Mexico. The men composing the regiment are volunteers from the region of country about Albany, and northward as far as Plattsburgh, which place sent out one company for the regiment, whose beautiful yellow silk banner, inscribed "Plattsburgh Volunteers," attracted a good deal of attention as they marched down Broadway. The regiment embarked on board the Kill von Kull for Elizabethtown about 5 o'clock P.M., and will proceed direct to Washington.

abstract: The necessity of obtaining new and reliable sources of cotton supply, presses more urgently upon England as the prospect of an early settlement of our national difficulties disappears.
lead_paragraph: The necessity of obtaining new and reliable sources of cotton supply, presses more urgently upon England as the prospect of an early settlement of our national difficulties disappears. The British manufacturers are now thoroughly alarmed in regard to the stability of their business, and are making strenuous efforts to provide against the certain diminution of their supply of American cotton. They are stimulating cotton production in every available region throughout the world. India has supplied them with nearly one-sixth of their cotton for several years past, and they hope to increase the amount very largely this year. But Indian cotton is generally so inferior to the American staple, that it cannot drive the Southern cotton out of the British market. African cotton, however, is of a much better quality, and is equal to the Southern for most manufacturing purposes. The attention of Great Britain is, therefore, turned to Africa as the region from whence the anticipated deficiency must be supplied. It is now definitely ascertained that the Continent of Africa is throughout a cotton-growing region, and all that is necessary to procure immense quantities of that staple is to promote civilization there, and bring the natives under sound influences, which, in elevating them, will supply them with the incentives to a vigorous development of the resources of their fertile territory.

AMBROSE SNOW, in the Chair, and HENRY DUNLAP, Esq., Secretary, the following Committee of Arrangements were chosen: DEXTER A. HAWKINS, Esq., Chairman; W.H. Fogg, Geo. F. Dunning, Wm. L. Cogswell, H.H. Bevely, H.T. Capen, H.W. Allen, Isaac H. Bailey, Aaron Healey, Jonathan Chase. The natives of Maine in this City and vicinity are requested to meet at the Astor House this morning at 9 1/2 o'clock, where they will form in procession and proceed to Pier No. 3 North River, to receive the regiment on its arrival from Fall River. The regiment will be escorted up Battery-place and Broadway to the City Hall, where a flag will be presented by I.T. WILLIAMS, in behalf of the Sons of Maine in this City. After the presentation the officers will dine at the Astor House and the regiment at the Park Barracks. After dinner the regiment will proceed by the night train to Washington.

abstract: The bark Virginia Ann, Capt. BRYANT, from Bordeaux, via Pass a L'Outre, (New-Orleans Bar,) arrived at this part yesterday, and reports that on the 23d inst. was chased all day and night by a very suspicious looking vessel, schooner rigged, and having the appearance of having previously been a pilot-boat, and filled up for a privateer. The Virginia Ann, in order to get clear of her, was compelled to carry a heavy press of canvas, in doing which she had her maintopmast backstay carried away. On the following day both vessels were becalmed, when the schooner used sweeps and made for the bark, but fortunately at this time a fresh breeze sprung up and the schooner was soon out of sight. The Virginia Ann, during the passage, encountered a succession of S.W. gales and squalls, during which she lost some sails, split foretopmast and broke the main tressel-tree. From May 3d to June 2d, experienced calms, with occasional heavy squalls from N.W. The Virginia Ann was bound to New-Orleans, and arrived at the Balize June 5, where she was boarded by the United States steam sloop of war Brooklyn, and ordered off, receiving the information of the blockading of all Southern ports. The Commander of the Brooklyn was then informed of the crippled condition of the vessel's spars and the scarcity of provisions on board, but left with his vessel without taking any notice of it, and Capt. BRYANT was compelled to make the best of his way to some Northern port. June 10, lat. 27' 04째, lon. 84 28째, Capt B. boarded the English ship Bramleamore, from Mobile, with a cargo of cotton, bound to Liverpool, and received from her some provisions and a negro man, who besieged North, and was allowed to leave in the Bramleamore she being the last vessel permitted to leave that port by the blockading squadron. The Bramleamore reported being boarded by the U.S. steamer Massachusetts, and that the Massachusetts had the day previous taken twenty-five prizes, one of which was the English ship Perphishire, from Mobile. June 18, lat. 29' 52째, lon. 79' 65째, at 8:30 P.M., experienced a heavy squall, accompanied with vivid lightning, lasting 3 hours and twenty minutes without intermission, every clap of thunder shaking the vessel from truck to keel, during which time the vessel lay under bare poles. After the squall she found the maintopgallant cap sprung. On the 21st she spoke the U.S. gun-boat Union, off Charleston. She reported having captured off that port the ship Amelia, from Liverpool, loaded with arms and ammunition for the rebel army. The commander of the Union kindly offered any assistance the Virginia Ann stood in need of.

abstract: The Petersburgh Express, of Thursday, says: About 500 more troops arrived here, yesterday morning, from Georgia. Besides several detachments for companies already here, there arrived the Irvin Guards, 97 men; Layfayette Volunteers, 84 men; Calhoun Rifles, 116 men; and a detachment of 140 men belonging to the Ninth Georgia Regiment, under command of Capt. GEORGE HILLYER, All of them were in excellent trim, and many were splendid-looking soldiers.

abstract: The Maryland Legislature, whatever their action may be in respect to taking care of the Union, have a way of taking care of themselves. They meet, talk a great deal of secession, enact a little treason, and then take a recess. Anon they meet again, talk more, and enact a little more treason, and take another recess. There is a secret about this process which the simple minded people of that State have only just discovered. The members invariably vote themselves and receive pay during the recess, at the rate of four dollars per day, which, with the addition of a liberal mileage, is a very comfortable thing in these times of war and scarcity of personal revenues. Were they to adjourn sine die, their pay would, of course, stop. Hence the exigencies of State require their frequent meeting, especially as the Governor is a Union man, and would not be likely to call them together. They have just taken and her recess until the 30th of July -- at four dollars per day.

abstract: Having passed several sleepless nights, disturbed by the agonies and cries of a suffering child, and becoming convinced that Mrs. WINSLOW'S SOOTHING SYRUP was just the article needed, procured a supply for the child. On reaching home, and acquainting his wife with what he had done, she refused to have it administered to the child, as she was strongly in favor of Homeopathy. That night the child passed in suffering, and the parents without sleep. Returning home the day following, the father found the baby still worse, and, while contemplating another sleepless night the mother stepped from the room to attend to some domestic duties, and left the father with the child. During her absence he administered a portion of the SOOTHING SYRUP to the baby, and said nothing. That night all hands slept well and the little fellow awoke in the morning bright and happy. The mother was delighted with the sudden and wonderful change, and although at first offended at the deception practiced upon her has continued to use the Syrup, and suffering, crying babies and restless nights have disappeared. A single trial of the Syrup never yet failed to relieve the baby, and overcome the prejudices of the mother.

abstract: -- A curious scene occurred in the Superior Court this week. The proprietors of the Stadt Theatre, HAMANN & HOYM, were sued for the penalty incurred by the violation of the Sunday Theatre act of 1860. HOYM subsequently enlisted and has gone to the seat of war, and his counsel made the most of the fact; but refused his assent to the proposition of the counsel for the House of Refuge to proceed with the case, accepting as true every allegation of his answer to the complaint. At last, the suit was discontinued as to HOYM, and HAMANN alone was tried. No witness was examined. Admitting every point made by the defence, the cause was argued and submitted to the jury -- and notwithstanding its peculiar composition -- embracing Jews and Germans -- a verdict was instantly rendered, mulcting the defendant in $1,000 fine on the two suits pending. This is the second Jury trial under this act, that of LINDENMULLER having been the first. The constitutional question having been settled by the Supreme Court, the pending suits and indictments will doubtless be adjudicated, and the palpable facility of enforcing the law, with its heavy penalties, will deter all parties from attempts to violate or evade a well-established statute.
lead_paragraph: -- A curious scene occurred in the Superior Court this week. The proprietors of the Stadt Theatre, HAMANN & HOYM, were sued for the penalty incurred by the violation of the Sunday Theatre act of 1860. HOYM subsequently enlisted and has gone to the seat of war, and his counsel made the most of the fact; but refused his assent to the proposition of the counsel for the House of Refuge to proceed with the case, accepting as true every allegation of his answer to the complaint. At last, the suit was discontinued as to HOYM, and HAMANN alone was tried. No witness was examined. Admitting every point made by the defence, the cause was argued and submitted to the jury -- and notwithstanding its peculiar composition -- embracing Jews and Germans -- a verdict was instantly rendered, mulcting the defendant in $1,000 fine on the two suits pending. This is the second Jury trial under this act, that of LINDENMULLER having been the first. The constitutional question having been settled by the Supreme Court, the pending suits and indictments will doubtless be adjudicated, and the palpable facility of enforcing the law, with its heavy penalties, will deter all parties from attempts to violate or evade a well-established statute.

abstract: The Ellsworth Association, of which Mayor THACHER of Albany, is President, have issued a second circular. They announce that the organization of the Edsworth Regiment, to be composed of one member, from each town the State, is rapidly progressing. They are in correspondence with one half of the counties in the State, and others will have the opportunity of cooperating until July 15, when any vacancies will be filled by such towns as have requested the privilege of selecting more than one man. The Committee have secured the services of the members of the original Chicago Zouaves, who were the drill officers of the Fire Zouaves. The arms, equipments and uniforms will be purchased by the Executive Committee. A competent officer, who has seen actual service, will be selected as the Commandant.

lead_paragraph: The Star of the South arrived at this port yesterday afternoon, having left Fort Pickens on June 17, and Key West on the 22d. abstract: "In my shirt sleeves and forags cap!" was the reply of a British trooper to an inquiry as to what kind of uniform he should prefer going into action with. Regulation orders
lead_paragraph: "In my shirt sleeves and forags cap!" was the reply of a British trooper to an inquiry as to what kind of uniform he should prefer going into action with. Regulation orders required that trooper to face the enemy accoutered in brass helmet, closely fisting, padded, red cloth coat, heavy leathern bells, stiff gauntlets and (if he belonged to a "Guard" regiment) steel cuirass and long, unwieldy jark-boots. The inference to be naturally drawn from the contrast between the costume he would have chosen and the costume he was compelled to wear, is, that almost everything which went to make him spruce and soldier-like upon parade, turned to a positive incumbrance in actual combat.

abstract: Gen. BANKS dealt a vigorous blow at the rebels in Baltimore, yesterday, by arresting Marshal KANE, Chief of the Police force in that city. At the time of the riots which disgraced Baltimore
lead_paragraph: Gen. BANKS dealt a vigorous blow at the rebels in Baltimore, yesterday, by arresting Marshal KANE, Chief of the Police force in that city. At the time of the riots which disgraced Baltimore some weeks ago, proof was not wanting that Marshal KANE had availed himself of his position to incite the mob to acts of violence; and the only subject for wonder is that he has not before been consigned to Fort McHenry for safe keeping. That the people might not fear their rights were to be trespassed upon, Gen. BANKS issued a proclamation, giving his reasons for the arrest of the Marshal. He charges him explicitly with aiding and abetting the traitors who are in arms against the Government, both by direction and indirection. Under these circumstances he says that he cannot be regarded otherwise than as the head of an armed force hostile to its authority. For these reasons he has declared him under arrest, and in accordance with his instructions, Gen. BANKS has appointed Col. KENLY, of the First Maryland Regiment of Volunteers, Provost Marshal for Baltimore, to see that the police laws are effectually executed. This he is to do with the aid of the subordinate police officers, and without that of the Police Commissioners, who are probably regarded as infected with the same madness which has seized Marshal KANE. Very naturally, this action created much excitement in the city. The Union men were as gratified as the Secessionists were indignant. The Police Commissioners gave notice that they should enter a formal protest against Gen. BANKS' action, and then issued orders disbanding the entire force under their control, thus giving sufficient proof that the suspicions of their loyalty were well founded.

abstract: As the question is frequently asked, who is MRS. WINSLOW? we will simply say that she is a lady who, for upwards of 33 years, has untiring devoted her time and talents as a female physician and nurse, principally among children. She has especially studied the constitution and wants of this numerous class, so generally overlooked or carelessly treated by the faculty in too many instances; and, as a result of this effort, and practical knowledge obtained in a lifetime spent as nurse and physician, she has compounded a Soothing Syrup for children teething. It operates like magic -- giving rest and health, and is, moreover, sure to regulate the bowels. In consequence of this article, Mrs. Winslow is becoming, world-renowned as a benefactor of her race; children do certainly RISE UP and bless her; especially is this the case in this City. Vast quantities of the Soothing Syrup are DAILY sold and used here. We think Mrs. Winslow has immortalized her name be this invaluable article and we sincerely believe thousands of children have been saved from an early grave by its firmly use and that millions yet unborn will share its benefits and unite in calling her blessed. No MOTHER has discharged her duty to her suffering little one, in our opinion, until she has given it the benefit of MRS. WINLOW'S SOOTHING SYRUP. Try it, mothers -- TRY IT NOW. -- Ladies' Visitor, New-York City.

abstract: THE COUNTRY COURT-HOUSE -- At a meeting of the Kings County Board of Supervisors, held yesterday afternoon, Supervisor BOOTH. Chairman of the Committee on Court-house, reported that the Committee had received twenty nine plans in answer to their advertisement, four of which they had adopted as suitable to receive the prizes offered, viz.: GAMALIEL KING & Co., Brooklyn; cost of structure, $185,000; size, 140 by 282 feet. P.R. WIGHT, No. 98 Broadway, New-York; cost, $334,000; size, 140 by 316 feet. BURRESS & PIERSON, No. 72 East Twenty sixth-street, New-York; cost, $145,000; size, 132 by 224 feet. E. BOYDEN & SON, Wallstreet, New-York; price, $139,280; size, 140 by 272 feet. The report of the Committee was accepted and adopted. The Board can reject or adopt either of these plans, as they may finally determine.

abstract: We have abundant reason for the belief that the Rebels have a very large army on foot in Virginia. We know that in his message to the Confederate Congress, on the 29th of April,
lead_paragraph: We have abundant reason for the belief that the Rebels have a very large army on foot in Virginia. We know that in his message to the Confederate Congress, on the 29th of April, DAVIS stated that the army then enlisted in the cause of secession amounted to 35,000 men -- of whom 19,000 were stationed at the various military posts in the seceded States, and 16,000 were en route to Virginia. He further declared in his message that it was proposed "to organize and hold in readiness for instant action an army of one hundred thousand men." It is also well known that the Confederate Congress gave unhesitating sanction to all the measures proposed by DAVIS; and we may rest assured that the mad military spirit of the South has outrun even the precipitancy of the leaders, and that more men have been offered than the Confederate authorities could provide for. All testimony concurs in the statement, that ever since the secession of Virginia, under the tempting promise of an early sacking of Washington, a universal movement of armed men from all the States of the South has been in progress towards Virginia. In squads, in companies and in regiments, they have filled all the avenues of travel, darkening the land the land as, in certain seasons, the migrating wild-fowl darken the air.

abstract: The Common Council having yielded to a general demand that the Daily News be stricken from the list of Corporation papers, Mayor Wood has interposed his veto. With curious,
lead_paragraph: The Common Council having yielded to a general demand that the Daily News be stricken from the list of Corporation papers, Mayor Wood has interposed his veto. With curious, possibly studied, neglect, his Honor has omitted to name among his reasons for this measure, the face that his brother, Mr. BENJAMIN WOOD is "sole editor and proprietor" of the journal in question; nor does he tell us how it happened that the same arguments filled to occur to him when the Day Book was similarly treated; but he has taken pains to express his dissent, official and personal, from a majority of its doctrines, so that if any of the evil-minded be disposed to charge him with treasonable sympathies, he may put in this ambiguous traverse as his defence. It is exclusively on the popular ground of free discussion that the Mayor founds his case. He justly assumes that the News is aimed at because of its political opinions. As the champion of the liberty of the Press he attempts to parry the blow.

abstract: It will be seen that Gen. BANKS has arrested the famous Marshal KANE. We regret the fact sincerely; not because there is not abundant reason for his action, but because it is simply a repetition of the senseless farce that has been so often repeared in Maryland and the other Border States. Like MERRIMAN and WINANS, he will of course be discharged to resume his authority and renew his treasonable courses. There will be no indictment, no trial, no punishment, and if Gen. BANKS escapes being superseded or censured for making the arrest, he will fare better than other officers of distinguished patriotism and energy. We are weary of this dalliance with treason, these exhibitions of timidity or tenderness that draws no distinction between the traitor and the true man; and any act that furnishes us with a repetition of the spectacle we profoundly deprecate.

abstract: The commodities brick building erected in 1857 as a depot for the Third-avenue Railroad, situated between Sixty-fifth and Sixty-sixths streets, was to tally destroyed last evening by fire. The flames were
lead_paragraph: The commodious brick building erected in 1857 as a depot for the Third-avenue Railroad, situated between Sixty-fifth and Sixty-sixths streets, was to tally destroyed last evening by fire. The flames were first seen about 5 o'clock by JACOB FAITH and JOHN BOGERT, among some bales of hay in the feedroom, on the second floor of the building, where they were employed. At this time the fire could have been extinguished with little difficulty but it was impossible for the workmen to obtain water without going to the street, and although they quickly gave an alarm and returned with hose, it was too late and the room could not be entered. There were about 700 horses in the stable at the time, and the laborers at once let them loose and drove them into the street. Here the neighbors, police and others had a lively time in catching the animals, which having been done, they were hitched to the fence posts find provided with temporary accommodations in the neighborhood.

abstract: The Fifth Maine Regiment, which left Portland on Wednesday morning arrived in this City yesterday at 11 A.M., via the Fall River Line. They were expected at 9 A.M., but owing to delays in embark-
lead_paragraph: The Fifth Maine Regiment, which left Portland on Wednesday morning arrived in this City yesterday at 11 A.M., via the Fall River Line. They were expected at 9 1/2 A.M., but owing to delays in embarkation, and the necessity of waiting for an order to debark at New-York, did not reach the City proper until about noon. During the passage from Boston to Fall River an Irishman belonging to one of the Portland companies jumped from the train and was instantly killed.

abstract: Military matters in this city are about so-so. There are about twenty recruiting offices in different portions of the city, and from five to twenty-five men are enrolled at each of these places per day, for
lead_paragraph: Military matters in this city are about so-so. There are about twenty recruiting offices in different portions of the city, and from five to twenty-five men are enrolled at each of these places per day, for half a dozen different regiments. Occasionally a squad of twenty-five or fifty men arrive from the country and enrol their names all at one place, and when this occurs the recruiting officers are in excellent spirits. Yesterday a squad of this kind arrived from Suffolk County, having failed to get an opportunity to join the Union army in that locality. Letters still come pouring in, bearing serious complaints against Col. ABEL SMITH, of the Thirteenth Brooklyn Regiment. The most serious charge is that he sells the nations belonging to the men.

abstract: The hariequin of the Herald astonished the public yesterday, by a proposition for the compromise of all difficulties between the Federal Government and the Confederate
lead_paragraph: The hariequin of the Herald astonished the public yesterday, by a proposition for the compromise of all difficulties between the Federal Government and the Confederate States, so entirely novel and so extremely absurd, so destitute of all sense and justice, as to authorize a suspicion that the plan really and truly emanates from the Confederate leaders. May we not presume, therefore, considering the secession antecedents of the Herald, and its long and faithful support of the political opinions of such United States Senators as BAYARD and HUNTER used to be, that these two worthies, who, according to the Herald and other papers, visited New-York the other day as Messrs. "Brown and Robinson," made their approaches to the Herald instead of to FERNANDO WOOD; and that yesterday's issue of that paper presents the "basis of adjustment" now deemed practicable at Richmond? We shall entertain this opinion, and hold, beside, that it is far more reasonable, and therefore more credible than any story hitherto connected with this subject.

abstract: The e are more agreeable things in the world than for a man to stand for two hours in a broiling sun in front of the City Hall, with a heavy knapsack on his back, and a Minie musket at his shoulder. We could give excellent reasons for this opinion, one of which would be drawn from the fact, that in front of that whitened wall the thermometer ranges higher than in any other place in the city. Gentlemen who review regiments and make speeches to them in that locality, should remember this, and if reviews and speeches are absolutely necessary, the one should be prompt, and the other brief. The nearer both these operations are brought to the standard of a quarter of an hour in the matter of time, the better the weary soldiers will like it. They will be better pleased with, one speech of two minutes, than with a dozen occupying half an hour each in the delivery, a specially after a march of a mile or more along the glowing streets.

abstract: At the meeting of the Board last, evening, a resolution was offered and adopted directing the City Inspector to inform the Board whether any payments had been made under his order to HENRY J. HACKLEY
lead_paragraph: At the meeting of the Board last, evening, a resolution was offered and adopted directing the City Inspector to inform the Board whether any payments had been made under his order to HENRY J. HACKLEY, since April 30, and the amounts, if any, thus paid. Also what sum is still due Mr. HACKLEY for work done under the street cleaning contract, and whether the terms of the contract were now complied with, and what measures are employed by the City Inspector to enforce the terms of the contract, and also what measures have been taken to provide for the health of the City during the present Summer.

abstract: In a letter from Harper's Ferry to the Louisville Courier, dated, June 8, "Se DE KAY" says: In the dearth of other news, let me give you another instance of the lovely devotion of women to our noblest and most glorious of all causes. Very recently, Mrs. BRADLEY JOHNSON, of Frederick, Maryland, wife of a leading lawyer and daughter of ROMULOUS M. SAUNDERS, formerly Minister to Spain, hearing that the Baltimore regiment, stationed at this point, were not adequately armed and equipped; determined to remedy the defect. Alone she journeyed to North Carolina, her native State, and there, before a meeting of prominent citizens, explained the object of her mission. But a few words of her eloquent and pleading tongue were necessary. Five hundred of the most approved rifles were instantly supplied, beside clothing and accoutrements of all descriptions. She returned here, and was received with the honors due a worthy woman, who bad nobly accomplished her patriotic mission. But this is not the only feat of Mrs. JOHNSONS worth recording. On her route homeward, while passing over the Orange and Alexandria Railroad, her suspicions (womanly, and of course more acute) were aroused by the appearance of a man on the train. She inveigled the fellow into conversation, and finally elicited from him such expressions of sympathy for the North, as to justify an officer being called, and an arrest made. He proved to be a Mr. MCKENZIE, of Alexandria, and a paid spy in the service of LINCOLN's Government.

abstract: The troops that were taken prisoners in Texas were paid off on Tuesday, a member of the Pay Department having arrived from Washington for the purpose. The discharges of the men are being made
lead_paragraph: The troops that were taken prisoners in Texas were paid off on Tuesday, a member of the Pay Department having arrived from Washington for the purpose. The discharges of the men are being made out at the War Department, and will be forwarded with the balance of their wages. A recruiting office for the new Twelfth Regiment, of which the head-quarters are to be at the fort, has been opened in Yorkville for some days, but no candidates apply.

abstract: -- This remarkable inquiry, which has for so many months engrossed the attention of the Surrogate, has been decided in favor of the proponent. The cause has provoked a more than ordinarily rigorous scrutiny; and the large number of witnesses has been examined with a thoroughness and shrewdness by the counsel on both sides, that do infinite credit to the professional skill engaged. The fact gives assurance that the decision answers the ends of justice. Mr. BLANKMAN may therefore he congratulated not only on his pecuniary triumph, but on the acquittal from the gross charges upon which the opposition to the will was founded.
lead_paragraph: -- This remarkable inquiry, which has for so many months engrossed the attention of the Surrogate, has been decided in favor of the proponent. abstract: Wm. W. Winans et al vs. The Williamsburgh Ferry Company et al. The plaintiffs sue as assignees of Oliver Charlick, for an accounting by the Williamsburgh Ferry Company and other defendants, for the income and profits of the Grandstreet and Peck-slip Ferries to Williams-
lead_paragraph: Wm.W. Winans et al vs. The Williamsburgh Ferry Company et al. -- The plaintiffs sue as assignees of Oliver Charlick, for an accounting by the Williamsburgh Ferry Company and other defendants, for the income and profits of the Grandstreet and Peck-slip Ferries to Williamsburgh. The Williamsburgh Ferry Company -- Wm. Wall and R.M. Demill -- are the only defendants who litigated, and they allege that Charlick's interest in the lease, which is the foundation of the action, was only nominal. They deny that Charlick or those claiming now as plaintiffs -- his assignees -- ever paid any portion of the rent or contributed any capital. It is alleged that a stock company used the franchise, and that the profits had been divided among the various stockholders without notice of any claim by the plaintiffs. The lease was dated Sept. 12, 1848, and was soon after authorized, but, as alleged, before it was delivered. Charlick became hostile to his associates, and directed the Corporation not to deliver it to them. He had received $2,000 from his associates as a consideration for his aid, and in October, 1848, he received from Withers and others $5,000 for his opposition. From the time of the assignment by Charlick to Withers and others, these assignees and Charlick did all in their power to destroy the lease. There was no evidence of the value of the one-fifth or of the whole of the lease. The facts found by the Referee are unimportant. The conclusions of law are that the plaintiffs cannot recover. The ground was, that the paper between the Corporation and Charlick was, though in the form of a lease, yet a contract, in which there were provisions founded on personal reliance on the grantees or lessees.

abstract: The Mozart Regiment, which has been recruited to a great extent under the auspices of Mayor WOOD, has been encamped about a week at Yorkers, NewYork. The camp is situated on a delightful eminence,...
lead_paragraph: The Mozart Regiment, which has been recruited to a great extent under the auspices of Mayor WOOD, has been encamped about a week at Yorkers, NewYork. The camp is situated on a delightful eminence, just beyond the long line of villas that grace the town, and serve to consume the spare dimes and leisure hours of the New-York merchant princes. From a vehicular point of view, the camp is about a mile from the railroad station, but woe be to the pedestrian who, relying upon the placid assurance that "its only a nice walk," should attempt (as the TIMES' reporter did) to foot it. Parnassus is a hillock in comparison -- especially when the day is warm, and everybody else (including the excellent Committee that invites you) has a carriage.

abstract: nent capitalists and others was held yesterday, at the Chamber of Commerce, to organize an association to act in connection with and as auxiliary to the Sanitary Commission recently appointed by the Secretary of War. Mr. JOHN A. STEVENS, of the Bank of Commerce, presided. Much feeling was expressed as to the importance of speedy and efficient action by the Commission, and the necessity of prompt and liberal cooperation by the citizens of New-York and of the country at large, to save the volunteer forces now in the field from must serious loss by disease. Statements were made, showing the gross incompetency of the surgical and medical force in many regiments, and moreover, that many of the camps are now in such a condition, that epidemics will inevitably break out among their occupants, unless the proper sanitary precautions be taken before the more unhealthy season arrives.

abstract: The revelations connected with the recent events in Baltimore have a deep significance, and are well calculated to attract the popular attention. They show the folly of attempting to win the Secessionists back to their...
lead_paragraph: The revelations connected with the recent events in Baltimore have a deep significance, and are well calculated to attract the popular attention. They show the folly of attempting to win the Secessionists back to their allegiance by forbearance, and that the leniency of the Government, so far from being appreciated, is taken advantage of by them to perfect their conspiracies and mature their plans of revolt. The arrest of the head of the Police Department, with a commission as Brigadier-General of the rebel army in his pocket, is suggestive of a wide range of inquiry. Who are his subordinate officers, and where the men who are to fill his brigade? The resignation of nearly four hundred of the police force under his control throws some light on the subject, but they would make but a small portion of the four or five thousand necessary to compose his command. The proceedings of the Commissioners, censuring and protesting against the course of Gen. BANKS, and the tone of the resolutions passed by them, prove that they are not imbued with that spirit of loyalty which it would be pleasant to find prevalent in such a body. It is said that information is in possession of the loyal authorities, that many thousand stand of arms are concealed in the city and vicinity. From those facts, the conclusion is irresistible that a formidable conspiracy against the Government has been organized in Baltimore, and that its ramifications reach to an alarming and dangerous extent.

abstract: Nothing of any great importance occurred at the Capital yesterday. A number of our regiments have been sent off, which has been the cause of some little excitement at Washington, but Gen. MANSFIELD has ordered a strict investigation of the matter with a view of punishing the offenders. Our army is moving quietly but steadily into Virginia. Secretary CAMERON sees no one but those high in authority. He is busy preparing official reports having connection with the War Department. The Secretary of the Treasury is preparing a plan to enable the country to raise the necessary funds to carry on the war. It is talked of to establish a National Bank, with a capital of one hundred millions for a basis; no notes less than ten dollars to be issued. The Navy Department is busily engaged in increasing our naval forces, so as to enable us to establish a thorough blockade. Thirteen men, belonging to Col. WALLACE's Indiana Regiment, when on a reconnoitering; excursion, fell in with a party of the enemy, near Cumberland; after some skirmishing. They killed twenty-three of the rebels, only one of our side was hurt. A man named P. MCQUILLAN, of Charleston, S.C., who is suspected of having purchased arms for the traitors, has been arrested by the authorities. A number of practical measures of legislation are being prepared for the opening of Congress. Martial law has not, as yet, been thoroughly established in Baltimore.

abstract: from Virginia show that there is little harmony among the leaders of the rebel forces in that State. Virginia abounds in hist families, whose men were born, like Gov. PICKENS, "insensible to fear," who are all entirely willing to lead, but have no stomach for following. Hence, Gov. LETCHER has no relish for being overshadowed in his greatness by JEFF. DAVIS. It was one thing to be the supreme head of a State Vice Virginia, the Commander-in-chief of the armies and Admiral of the Navy. There was dignity and honor in the position in the Governor's estimation. But it was quite another thing to be the tail of a Confederation in which even the little State of South Carolina is more honored than the Mother of Presidents. So too Gen. LEE has no taste for being superseded by BEAUREGARD, or overslaughed by JOHNSTON. He regards himself as having been born to command, and not to obey, and his pride demands a fulfillment of his destiny. What is thus true of these two representative men, is true all the way down through the gradations of social and military life. There is no earnest cordiality between Virginians and their more Southern allies. In one respect we think that partisans of JEFF. DAVIS [???] Gov. LETCHER great wrong, and that is in doubting the genuiness of his treason against the Constitution. There is probably no more thorough traitor south of Mason and Dixen's line that Gov. LETCHER of Virginia, or one who would do more to dishonor the great and good men who have made that State the traditional Mecca of patriotism throughout the Union.

lead_paragraph: The Promptness with which citizens of foreign which have responded to the call of the Government for men to swell the ranks of its armies, in the midst of the dangers which threaten its existance, from traitors born upon upon his soil, and reared under the protectionin its institutions, is one of the most gratifying spectacles which has attended the progress of the war. If an hones suspicion has ever existed of the loyalty of adopted citizens, those who entertained it must be disarmed ofit for the future, in this exhibition of deep, earnest and native sympathy for our Government, the children of no foreign race are an exception. If our institutions possess the adventures over others which we claim, there should be none. The judgment of those who were born and reared abroad, but whose homes are now here, is scan in the hosts into which they have marshaled themselves for awar to defend the Government of their choice.

abstract: There still seems to be much, misapprehension as to the affair at Great Bethel. All talk of masked batteries is fancy. The batteries were supposed to exist, and it was intended to surprise them in advance to prevent any such, where the batteries were before we attacked. The rencontre between our own forces stopped that, and Gen. PIERCE deeming it best to continue the original purpose essayed, and did not deem it best to press the attack.

abstract: Permit me, though reluctant to do so, to find fault, through your columns, with what is said with great probability to be Gen. SCOTT'S plan for crushing out the great rebellion. I must confess that it strikes me as trifling with the serious business of restoring...
lead_paragraph: Permit me, though reluctant to do so, to find fault, through your columns, with what is said with great probability to be Gen. SCOTT's plan for crushing out the great rebellion. I must confess that it strikes me as trifling with the serious business of restoring peace to the country. Instead of settling our difficulties by the sword, Gen. SCOTT proposes to do it by entirely sacrificing the commercial interests of the country North and South. In other words, the soldiers in the field are merely to prevent hostilities, but in the meantime, they are to consume the material wealth of the people, the victory to be finally accorded to the side which is capable of holding out the longest in this strange and unnatural campaign. If such is really to be the struggle, then why not avoid this useless waste of treasure, by at once coming to an ignoble compromise; for a victory obtained on Gen. SCOTT's plan would be a mere temporary cessation of hostilities between the North and the South, to be resumed again when the combatants recovered from mutual exhaustion. The fact that the rebels do not attack us is evidence that they feel it would be unsafe to do to; then why not vigorously drive the rebels from Virginia, and by destroying their prestige, if not at once end the war, at least let the people see that its end is not far distant. It is lamentable, indeed, that the delusion of the "sacred soil of Virginia" paralyzes the North and West. When are we to get clear, in our national councils, of the demoralizing effects of "Southern influence" and Southern rottenness to the Constitution and Union of our country? X.Y.Z.
