abstract: FIRE IN A CABINET SHOP. At 1 o'clock yester- day morning a fire broke out in the bedstead-makers shop of Mr. JOHN HORAN, situated on the third floor of No. 380 Hudson-street. The shop was in the rear, the front rooms being occupied by HORAN and his...
lead_paragraph: FIRE IN A CABINET SHOP. -- At 1 o'clock yesterday morning a fire broke out in the bedstead-makers shop of Mr. JOHN HORAN, situated on the third floor of No. 380 Hudson-street. The shop was in the rear, the front rooms being occupied by HORAN and his family, consisting of his wife and four children, who at the time were asleep. HORAN states that when he awoke he was almost suffocated by the smoke, and at once caught two of the children and attempted to escape by the stairs; but the smoke and flames had made such progress that he was compelled to return.

abstract: It was well known in New-York, after the Seventh returned from Washington, that many of its members wished to return to the seat of war as officers, and the general belief was that some united effort would be made for that purpose, so that old associations might be continued; but as two or three weeks passed without any such action, a person in no way connected...
lead_paragraph: It was well known in New-York, after the Seventh returned from Washington, that many of its members wished to return to the seat of war as officers, and the general belief was that some united effort would be made for that purpose, so that old associations might be continued; but as two or three weeks passed without any such action, a person in no way connected with the regiment suggested that the object might be accomplished in a most agreeable and serviceable manner, by forming a regiment to serve for three years or for the war, of which the Colonel and Lieutenant-Colonel shall be experienced graduates of West Point, agreed upon at a future day by the line officers -- the Major, the Staff, the line, exclusively, and the non-commissioned officers, so far as they can be obtained, or it may be expedient, old competent members of the New-York Seventh; thus securing to them good positions, and for our country's service a harmonious, most efficient and useful command. As a further means of making the officers' duty as pleasant as possible, they may be united in companies as most agreeable to themselves, always regarding, however, their utility to discharge the duties they are to perform. Such an organization will secure the confidence of recruits, the approbation of our citizens, and approval of the highest Government authority, as regiments are now formed for the battle field without much time to drill, and every national, military and humane consideration demands that they should be well officered from the beginning. The whole plan has been so warmly approved by gentleman of the best military judgment, that the proposer is encouraged to assume the trouble of its organization, and will endeavor to carry it out, being at the same time disqualified by want of military experience for any position in an regiment after it is formed, but should his expectations be realized be will be amply rewarded by its high character and efficiancy. The following gentlemen have thus far united to carry out the above plan: Francis McIlvaine, S.M. Kullinger, George W. Bard and Alfred D. Chapman, as Captains; Edwards L. Halsiano, Henry H. Mott, E.R. Osborne, W.C. Jacobsen, L.D. Goodrings, Albert A. Curtis, as First Lieutenants; WM. Irving Ellis, John Truner, Jr., and George King, Second Lieutenants; Orderly, A.U. Valleplaity all of the Seventh. It will begin and end in a day or two, where they will recruit and drill, where is to be done principally in the coming, no it is not proposed to without any one connected with this regiment from their daily business until it is absolutely necessary; and, for thepretent, no recruits will be received unless they can uniform and sustain themselves until a short time before departure on service. Gentlemen, with the requisite qualifications, who with positions as officers in the "National Guard Zouaves," are invited to consider at the office of E.G. BURLING, No. 45 Williamstreet, as day, between 12 and 3 o'clock.

abstract: "Flour has fallen a dollar and a half a barrel, and freth beef is lower than it has been for ten years; thanks to LINCOLN'S blockade. Keep it up for some time, most noble Gorilla. It is just what we resi- dents and cant-get-aways have been wanting for some...
lead_paragraph: "Flour has fallen a dollar and a half a barrel, and freth beef is lower than it has been for ten years; thanks to LINCOLN's blockade. Keep it up for some time, most noble Gorilla. It is just what we resi- dents and cant-get-aways have been wanting for some years. The effects of this blockade have been beneficial in many respects. We rejoice, especially, in its operation upon those heartless speculators who sought to forestall our market by buying up all the provisions in the city, and holding them for a big rise. The villainy was laid before the Governor, end steps were about to be taken to correct it by summary action on the part of the authorities or the people. when most seasonably and kindly POORE came with the Brooklyn and saved us all this trouble, by blockading the mouth of the river. Thus all export being stopped, both up and down the river, we have an abundance of everything that is produced between the Ohio and Missouri Rivers and the Gulf of Mexico. The effect on Texas cattle is particularly interesting. Large droves of these cattle have hitherto been driven northward into Missouri and even into Illinois; and even those which were sent hither had to compete with the better conditioned cattle of the West. Hence the supply was comparatively small. But now, having no other market, and being without competition, the Texans are all driving their cattle to New Orleans, not only supplying this market at very reasonable rates -- cheaper to fart, than the rates in the Northern cities -- but furnishing enough to send to the river towns, as far as Memphis. No less than two hundred head of these cattle were sent in that direction a few days ago. It is established now, beyond all doubt or uncertainty, that the vield of corn will far exceed the demands of the South, and new flour will be in the market to a few days in the greatest abundance. We may have less hog meat than we have hitherto had, but whether that will prove a loss or inconvenience remains to be proved."

abstract: The very large and steadily increasing circulation of the TIMES gives constant occasion for remonstrance as to the tardiness with which, it is delivered to subscribers in New-York and Brocklyn. The attention of the proprietors has for some time been directed to obviating this defect. They are now enabled to announce that in the course of a few days such arrangements will be perfected as will cause a much earlier delivery of the entire morning edition, and thus remove all ground of complaint.

abstract: Louis Planer, &c. vs. John A. Bouibard. The defendant, who resides in Brooklyn, was arrested in February last by the Sheriff of this county, and gave bail. Judgment was taken by default, and execution issued against his property, and returned, unsatisfied. Execution was then issued against the defendant's person, whereupon, being notified by his bail, he was placed in Eldridge-street Jail, and is shall in confinement. Motion was now made to vacate the order of arrest, on the ground that the defendant was brought within the jurisdiction of this Court, and within the bailiwick of the Sheriff of the City and County of New-York, as alleged, by trick and device. This device, as it is, defined, was based upon the allegation that one Louis Lange went to defendant in Brooklyn, and invited him to New-York to purchase some cheap clothing in Spring-street, giving the defendant a card which contained the address of one Nicholas Kuerr, with whom Lange boarden. Defendant accordingly visited the home of Kuerr, and Lange, as alleged, procured the attendance of the plaintiff, who was soon after followed by a Deputy Sheriff, by whom defendant was arrested.

abstract: We have taken occasion to show the strong probability that the rebels muster in Virginia a force exceeding 75,000 men; all well armed and well proportioned in the particulars of infanity, cavalry and artillery. These troops are commanded, not by impromtu brigadiers.
lead_paragraph: We have taken occasion to show the strong probability that the rebels muster in Virginia a force exceeding 75,000 men; all well armed and well proportioned in the particulars of infanity, cavalry and artillery. These troops are commanded, not by impromtu brigadiers, but by men who have seen active military service, and have acquired not only experience, but such distinction as secures them the thorough confidence of their men; and must compensate in a great measure for that lack of mature discipline subordination which we may reasonably suppose to exist in a Southern army. DAVIS, BEAUREGARD, LEE and MAGRUDER are something more than holiday soldiers, the heroes of militia musters, and the victors in sham conflicts. They have been educated, to arms at the national expense, have served, creditably, and are conversant with all the resorts and advantages of modern warfare. They have the benefit also of intimate acquaintance with the composition and organization of the national army, the character and competency of its leaders, and the resources immediately avoidable to make it efficient in action. Nor is there any reason to believe the enemy to be deficient in the matter of subsistence. So long as the Virginia Central, and the Virginia and Tennessee Railroads remain in their hands, there will be no difficulty in procuring live stock from the great grazing region on the western slope of the Alleghanies; while Tennessee will supply and the Richmond mills will grind all the breadstuffs their army can consume. In the equipment and clothing departments they are perhaps less fortunate; but the season is genial, and the observe of otherwise indispensable articles of military wardrobe will not be severely felt until the approach of Winter. Indeed, if the campaign be pressed with the successful vigor we have a right to demand, the rebels will move southward so rapidly that Winter will new or overtake them.

abstract: Eliphalet Lyon vs. Richard Dudgeon. This was an action to dissolve a partnership formerly existing between the parties to the action, made, as al ledged, 1st January, 1859. The plaintiff claims that for $5,000 he purchased of the defendant a one-half interest in the business of the manufacture and sale
lead_paragraph: Eliphalet Lyon vs. Richard Dudgeon. -- This was an action to dissolve a partnership formerly existing between the parties to the action, made, as alledged, 1st January, 1859. The plaintiff claims that for $5,000 he purchased of the defendant a one-half interest in the business of the manufacture and sale of "Dudgeon's hydraulic jacks and punches." It was also alledged that the plaintiff took possession of the business, and conducted it for a time. The defendant answers that at the time of making and signing such contract, as the plaintiff well knew, he was insane and unable to transact any business. The defendant avers that he was so deranged in his mind and careless in his business that he consented to make such a contract, when he could have sold the half interest for $20,000.

abstract: We never like to suspect our contemporaries of a wicked design to trifle with the feelings and interests of the public, by the publication of exciting bulletins on the subject of the war that now absorbs all their thoughts.
lead_paragraph: We never like to suspect our contemporaries of a wicked design to trifle with the feelings and interests of the public, by the publication of exciting bulletins on the subject of the war that now absorbs all their thoughts. But some of them almost daily put us in the painful dilemma of regarding them as willful propagators of stories that they know to be false, or as dupes of impostures so shallow and so absurd that it is simply impossible for sound minds to be deceived by them for a moment.

abstract: Having passed several sleepless nights, disturbed in the agonies and cries of a suffering child, and becoming continued that Mrs. WINSLOW'S SOOTHING SYRUP was just the article needed, procured a supply for the child. On reaching home, and acquainting his wife with what he had done, she refused to have it administered to the child, as she was strongly in favor of Enteropathy. That night the child passed in suffering, and the parents without sleep. Returning home the day following, the father [???] the baby still [???] and, while contemplating another sleepless night the mother stepped from the room to attend to some domestic duties had left the father with the child. During her absence he administered a portion of the SOOTHING SYRUP to the baby, and said nothing. That night all heads slept well and the little fellow awake in the morning bright and happy. The mother was delighted with the sudden and wonderful change, and although at [???] offender, at the [???] practiced upon her, had [???] to [???] the Syrup, [???] crying babies and restless nights have disappeared. A single trial of the syrup never [???] to relieve the baby, and overcome the prejudices of the mother.

abstract: Hon. FRANK P. BLAIR, Member of Congress from Missouri, arrived in this City yesterday, on his return from Connecticut, where his family spending the Summer, on his way to attend the approaching session of Congress. His presence at the Metropolitan, where he was a temporary guest, becoming known, the citizens, without distinction of party, determined to pay him some suitable testimonial of respect for the prompt and energetic part he has acted in the contest in Missouri particularly, in conjunction with Col. LYON, who so recently and so effectually dispersed the rebels at Booneville. A serenade was accordingly resolved upon, and the Messrs. LELAND, proprietor of the Metropolitan, cordially united in the ovation. The band, Dodworth's, arrived at 11 1/2 o'clock P.M., in front of the hotel, and soon several thousand people assembled. Calls for Col. BLAIR brought him out upon the balcony, and he spoke as follows:

abstract: seceded, are hugely disgusted with the conduct of Gen. LYON in Missouri, and they threaten him with all manner of vengeance. They would gladly make that State the battle-ground on the West, as they have made Virginia on the East, of the mountains. It would keep the horrors of war far from their own homes, and throw upon Missourians all the burthens of the campaign, while they enjoyed whatever there might be of its benefits. But the resolution, which this selfish policy has brought upon Virginia, furnishes a lesson too striking to be overlooked by Kentucky or Missouri. The neutrality of the one and the increasing loyalty of the other are the results of its impressive teachings, and the chances now are that they will leave the Cotton States to take care of themselves in the conflict their madness and folly have invoked. They appreciate at its proper value this Southern scheme of making their soil the debatable land, to be trampled by armies and drenched in blood, and they have come to the wise conclusion that neither their honor nor their interests require that they should join their fortunes with secession.

abstract: Capt. PRINCE, of the First Infantry United States Regulars, has made a report to the War Department of his expedition to Liberty, Mo., which was so successful. It does not differ materially from the ac- counts published in the newspapers.
lead_paragraph: Capt. PRINCE, of the First Infantry United States Regulars, has made a report to the War Department of his expedition to Liberty, Mo., which was so successful. It does not differ materially from the accounts published in the newspapers. The following regular troops participated in the engagement; Company C, First Cavalry, 68 men; Company C, same regiment, 70 men; Company C, Second Dragoons, 72 men, and some recruits of the Mounted Riflemen. A large number of horses and arms were captured.

abstract: Shortly before 8 o'clock on Wednesday evening this regiment left Albany, and arrived in this City at 5 o'clock yesterday morning. The men partook of breakfast at the Park Barracks, white the Field, Staff, and Commissioned officers breakfasted at the Astor...
lead_paragraph: Shortly before 8 o'clock on Wednesday evening this regiment left Albany, and arrived in this City at 5 o'clock yesterday morning. The men partook of breakfast at the Park Barracks, white the Field, Staff, and Commissioned officers breakfasted at the Astor House by invitation of Mr. STETSON. The men are all armed with United States muskets, which will be exchanged for Enfield rifles on the arrived of the regiment at Washington. The men are fine, hardy looking fellows, are have the appearance of those who will give a good account of themselves when needs be. A band, composed of sixteen men, and a drum corps of twenty is attached to this regiment, which numbers over eight hundred men. Annexed is a list of the officers:

abstract: Winans et al vs. The Williamsburgh Ferry Company. -- This case, which was reported in the TIMES of yesterday, is now decided by the Court as follows: We think the plaintiffs have no right, as against the Ferry Company, to call them to an account, and to claim from them a division of the profits of the ferry. The remedy, if any, is by the grantees of the franchise against them as trespassers. The right of any lessee to transfer to others his interest without the consent of the Common Council is denied. Whether such an action could be maintained by such assignees, without such consent, is not clear. Such consent is necessary to vest any legal right in the assignee. The judgment is affirmed with costs.
lead_paragraph: Winans et al vs. The Williamsburgh Ferry Company. -- This case, which was reported in the TIMES of yesterday, is now decided by the Court as follows: We think the plaintiffs have no right, as against the Ferry Company, to call them to an account, and to claim from them a division of the profits of the ferry. The remedy, if any, is by the grantees of the franchise against them as trespassers. The right of any lessee to transfer to others his interest without the consent of the Common Council is denied. Whether such an action could be maintained by such assignees, without such consent, is not clear. Such consent is necessary to vest any legal right in the assignee. The judgment is affirmed with costs.

abstract: KENTUCKY NEUTRALITY. -- It is announced by telegraph that shippers at Louisville are about testing the legality of the blockade of the Nashville Railroad. As the blockade was instituted to prevent shipments of munitions of war, provisions and supplies to the rebels of Tennessee and others of the seceded States, It is hardly probable that the United States Government will permit its effectiveness to be interfered with by a judicial decision rendered in time of war. If Kentucky neutrality means permission to aid the rebellion and a passive interest in the General Government, the sooner United States troops take possession of the Railroad to Nashville the better.
lead_paragraph: KENTUCKY NEUTRALITY. -- It is announced by telegraph that shippers at Louisville are about testing the legality of the blockade of the Nashville Railroad. abstract: Col. E.B. BAKER'S First California Regiment, which has been quartered at Fort Sebuyler for the last five weeks, yesterday took its departure for Fortress Monroe, in accordance with general orders. This regiment, rank and file, is composed of some of the most sterling men which have yet enlisted for the...
lead_paragraph: Col. E.B. BAKER's First California Regiment, which has been quartered at Fort Sebuyler for the last five weeks, yesterday took its departure for Fortress Monroe, in accordance with general orders. This regiment, rank and file, is composed of some of the most sterling men which have yet enlisted for the war. Not a few, particularly among the commissioned officers, are well known citizens of New-York, and some of them have been in active service. Yesterday bring the fast day of their stay at Fort Schuyler, the friends of the regiment, in large numbers, availed themselves, of the opportunity to go down by the steamer Gov. Arthur, to take leave of their friends. The orders for marching were promulgated at an early hour, and as soon as breakfast was over arrangement's were commenced for breaking up their camp.

abstract: As the question is frequently asked, who is MRS. WINSLOW? we will simply say that she is a lady who, for upwards of as gears, has untiringly devised her time and talents as a female physician and nurse, principally among children. She has especially studied the constitution and wants of this numerous class, so generally overlooked or carelessly treated by the freelty in for many instances; and, as a result of this effort, and practical knowledge obtained in a lifetime spent as nurse and physician, she has compounded a Soothing Syrup for children teething. It operates like magic -giving rest and health, and is, moreover, sure to regulate the bowels. In consequence of this article, Mrs. Winslow is becoming world-renowned as a benefactor of her race; children do certainly RISE UP and METS her; especially is this the case in this City. Vast quantities of the Soothing Syrup are DAILY sold and used here. We think Mrs. Winslow has immortalized her-nurse by Him, invaluable article, and we sincerely believe thousands of children have been saved from an early grace by its timely use, and that millions yet unborn will there its benefits and unite in calling her blessed. No nurses has discharged her duty to her suffering little one, is one opinion, until she has given to the benefit of MRS. WINSLOW'S SOOTHING SYRUP. Try it, mother. -TRY IT NOW. -- Ladies' Visitor, New-York City.

abstract: The reverberation of Mr. RUSSELL's letter in regard to the craving desire of the South Carolinians to have a King to rule over them is heard, to-day, in an article from the Charleston Courier, the organ par excellence of the Palmetto aristocracy, which will be found in the columns of the TIMES. The Courier characterizes the statements of Mr. RUSSELL on this subject as baseless and absurd -- quite an offence to the intelligence of a people who are doing and suffering so much for their free, republican institutions as the South Carolinians. In a subsequent article to the one we publish to-day, the Courier begs the wags of South Carolina, if Mr. RUSSELL should return among them, "not to assure that gentleman that the good people of South Carolina were very anxious to adopt and introduce Mormonism" among them.

abstract: We have received the following communication from Mr. GUION in relation to the "compromise" petition circulated by him, a notice of the seizure of which by the Police authorities was published in yesterday's TIMES. A sufficient answer to the complaints of Mr. GUION will be found in a letter from Rev. Dr. VINTON, which follows his communication, showing the deception practiced in obtaining signatures to the petition. The object of the seizure, as we understand it, was not to interfere with the right of petition, either of Mr. GUION or any one else, but simply to enable citizens who had been imposed upon, to expose the fraud, and set themselves right before the community:

abstract: When the Secessionists so vauntingly parade the South's material independence of the North, it proves either their own ignorance or their disposition to misrepresent. The cry against the blockade, and especially the embargo against the export of provisions and breadstuffs into the seceding States, and the high prices which they command in the Gulf States, is the best evidence of the misrepresentation. Tennessee has always favored a policy which should develope its own material resources, and how far the State has succeeded may be judged by an analysis of advertisements in their journals. A page of advertisements from the Nashville Union and American included the following: Professional, 1; runaway slaves, 1; political, 2; military, 7; legal, 10; articles of Southern production, 6; articles of Northern production, 42. Among the articles of Southern manufacture is "Rags wanted." The list of Northern articles includes clothing, boots and shoes, harness, patent medicine, fire-arms, ammunition, hats and caps, cloths, cotton goods, breadstuffs, provisions, garden seeds, mills, hardware, &c., &c.

abstract: The first movement, in a new and very impor tant direction, has just been made in this City. A considerable number of our leading commercial and financial men have held several...
lead_paragraph: -The first movement, in a new and very important direction, has just been made in this City. A considerable number of our leading commercial and financial men have held several informal and preliminary meetings, to organize an association having for its principal object the increase and extension of the commerce of the country, under the conviction that hitherto, or at least for the last twenty years, it has been grossly neglected or altogether ignored by the Government of the United States. While other nations, through their organized administrative departments, have sedulously studied every means of developing and extending their trade, external and internal -- and none more so than Great Britain, during every vicissitude of war or peace -- the Government of our eminently commercial people, mainly occupied with partisan objects and struggles at Washington, has virtually left the commerce of the country to shift for itself.

abstract: A world-wide difference is notable between the proclamation recently issued by Gen. McCLELLAN to the soldiers of the army of the West, and that lately isssued by BEAUREGARD on taking command of the rebel forces in Virginia.
lead_paragraph: -- A world-wide difference is notable between the proclamation recently issued by Gen. MCCLELLAN to the soldiers of the army of the West, and that lately isssued by BEAUREGARD on taking command of the rebel forces in Virginia. The one is calm, dignified, eloquent -- abounding in sentiments of soldierly honor, indulging in no asperities, no vulgarities of epithet -- inciting to deeds of noble daring against armed enemies, and still nobler deeds of mercy towards the defenceless, the unarmed or the vanquished. It inculcates respect for individual rights, the safety of the persons of the citizens, and the inviolability of private property, guaranteeing liberty of speech and opinion to all; deprecating the stern necessities of war, and enjoining that forbearance and mercy which diminishes and softens its calamities. The other, commencing with the stale and exploded falsehood of "booty and beauty," inculcating intensified hatred and stimulating the brutal passions of the soldiery -- justifying in advance every atrocity, rendering war a system of mere robbery, of causeless and indiscriminate slaughter, as if its only objects were the acquisition of plunder and the shedding of blood.
headline: {'main': 'THE TWO PROCLAMATIONS.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE TWO PROCLAMATIONS.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The sensation of yesterday was the announcement of the arrest of Col. ALLEN, of the First Regiment of New-York Volunteers, by order of Gen. BUTLER, and the reported protest of certain officers under Gen. BUTLER of his continuance in command. We are, of course, not in possession of authenticated facts in either case sufficient to justify us in an opinion as to the merits or demerits of these officers.
lead_paragraph: The sensation of yesterday was the announcement of the arrest of Col. ALLEN, of the First Regiment of New-York Volunteers, by order of Gen. BUTLER, and the reported protest of certain officers under Gen. BUTLER of his continuance in command. We are, of course, not in possession of authenticated facts in either case sufficient to justify us in an opinion as to the merits or demerits of these officers. Nor is it likely that the public will know soon, if it ever does, precisely where blame should fall between them. There is indeed very great reason to question the entire story, which certainly has many traits characteristic of the canards to which some of our neighbors give daily circulation.

abstract: Friday night was a grand time in our sister City. It was the "Commencement" of the "Brooklyn Collegiate and Polytechnic Institute, of which Prof. JOHN H. RAYMOND, LL. D., is the honored President. Such occasions invariably attract large congregations, and this was far from an exception. There are several hundred boys in regular attendance upon the school, and each boy's father and mother and particular friends were there, to whose number being added that floating mass of active intelligences who always go to literary entertainments of whatever grade, and there is at once an audience of several thousand individuals.

abstract: -- At Montreal West, a few days since THOMAS O' ARCY MCGEE, (not unknown in this City,) was proposed as a fit and proper person to represent the Western Decision of the City of Montreal in the new Parliament. A gentleman named OGILVIE had the to merit, to nominate, THOS. RYAN, Esq., into position, whereupon MR. OGILVIE was politely, and without the shortest notice, on hed over the hustings, had his clothes pretty well torn, and get sundry small kicks and brokes until he took refuge in a cup, in which he drove off the ground. The show of hands was in favor Mr. MCGEE, and, as there was no one who dared to demand a call in behalf of Mr. RYAN, Mr. MCGEE was declared ejected.
lead_paragraph: -- At Montreal West, a few days since THOMAS O' ARCY MCGEE, (not unknown in this City,) was proposed as a fit and proper person to represent the Western Decision of the City of Montreal in the new Parliament. The show of hands was in favor Mr. MCGEE, and, as there was no one who dared to demand a call in behalf of Mr. RYAN, Mr. MCGEE was declared ejected.

Green-room reports are favorable of the piece.

abstract: Yesterday afternoon, at 3 o'clock, the Cadets of the Military Academy at White Plains, Gen. MONSON J. LOOKWOOD, Principal, arrived in the City via Harlem Railroad, alighting at White-street.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday afternoon, at 3 o'clock, the Cadets of the Military Academy at White Plains, Gen. MONSON J. LOOKWOOD, Principal, arrived in the City via Harlem Railroad, alighting at White-street. The corps was then formed in line, and marched down Centre-street in good order to the Park, preceded by DODWORTH's Band, consisting of thirteen pieces, and the Zouave Cadets (youths) of this City, who performed escort duty. They entered the Park from the east side, and presented a fine appearance as they came up, to take their position in front of the City Hall, for the purpose of being reviewed by the Mayor and members of the Common Council. In the absence of the Mayor, however, Col. BURNHAM, the City Marshal, stepped to the platform, where he remained during the whole exhibition, which continded nearly two hours. The Cadets were dressed in blue jackets, trimmed with gilt and red, red pants, and fatigue caps, and carried knapsacks and short bayonet muskets. The corps consists of forty-five boys and youth, whose ages rank from ten to twenty years, and they evinced by their superior drill in the Zouave tactics that their military education had been well attended to. The various evolutions peculiar to this system of manoeuvering were beautifully and faithfully executed, and the spectators present did not fail to testify their approbation by frequent and hearty applause. They were under the military command of Major HENEY LOCKWOOD, who is also connected with the Academy. After a severe exercise, in which they fully sustained their reputation as young soldiers, they were drawn up. In two columns facing the City Hall, and were presented with a beautiful banner by Gen. WRIGHT, of New-Jersey, on behalf of ladies who have taken an interest in the young and gallant soldiers. On presenting the banner, Gen. WRIGHT complimented them on the proficiency they had attained in military science. It was an inappropriate time for speech-making, and as they had been on the ground along time engaged in active and arduous drill, he would not occupy their attention but for a few minutes. He had been so pleased with their efforts that he had almost forgotten what he should say. He held in his hands the Stars and Stripes of the American Union -- (cheers) -- it was unstained, and he hoped it would remain so when committed to their care. They should adopt as a motto, "never fail, never give up." This had been the ruling sentiment in the American army, and we had passed successfully through three wars, and made a peace.

abstract: The English screw steam frigate Mersey. Capt. H. CALDWELL has reached Halifax. When approaching the Banks of Newfoundland, Capt. C. fell in with some icebergs and thought it would be interesting to experiment on them with rifled cannon. Accordingly, an Armstrong shell was fired at a small iceberg about 150 feet high, from a distance of four miles and a half. Such was the effect, that a block of ice judged to be of about 100 tons fell from the summit. This large weight, falling from the top of the berg, removed the centre of gravity, which caused the whole fabric to soil over and rock to and from. It was considered a most satisfactory test of the vast range and destructiveness of these missiles. Further trials were made, with other projectiles supplied to the navy namely, follow shot percussion and shrapnell and time fuze shell, molten iron shell &c -- all tending to exhibit one feature in molten warfare at sea, viz., the extreme probability of every vessel [???] flames so on after she is engaged -- Boston Traveller, June 28.
lead_paragraph: The English screw steam frigate Mersey. Capt. H. CALDWELL has reached Halifax. When approaching the Banks of Newfoundland, Capt. C. fell in with some icebergs and thought it would be interesting to experiment on them with rifled cannon. Accordingly, an Armstrong shell was fired at a small iceberg about 150 feet high, from a distance of four miles and a half. Such was the effect, that a block of ice judged to be of about 100 tons fell from the summit. This large weight, falling from the top of the berg, removed the centre of gravity, which caused the whole fabric to soil over and rock to and from. It was considered a most satisfactory test of the vast range and destructiveness of these missiles. Further trials were made, with other projectiles supplied to the navy namely, follow shot percussion and shrapnell and time fuze shell, molten iron shell &c -- all tending to exhibit one feature in molten warfare at sea, viz., the extreme probability of every vessel [???] flames so on after she is engaged -- Boston Traveller, June 28.

abstract: It has been the boast of the South, and especially of Virginia, that her civilization was of a high and chivalrous character; that her men were all gentlemen, and her women all ladies. That they were more refined, more classical in their tastes, and better educated than any other race in the world, and particularly were they at a sightless distance above the money-getting, dollar-loving people of the Free States.
lead_paragraph: It has been the boast of the South, and especially of Virginia, that her civilization was of a high and chivalrous character; that her men were all gentlemen, and her women all ladies. That they were more refined, more classical in their tastes, and better educated than any other race in the world, and particularly were they at a sightless distance above the money-getting, dollar-loving people of the Free States. They boasted of a more sublimated patriotism, a higher sense of honor, a loftier appreciation of soldierly duty, a more chivalrous courage, and a purer regard for the amenities of peace or war, with a profounder love for freedom in its broadest significance; in short that they were the only true specimens of American gentlemen extant, and that all outside of the Slave States were mere mongrels, indebted for whatever of gentle blood that flowed in their veins to crossing with the first families of Virginia, or some other of the States wherein the civilizing influences of Slavery were enjoyed. The world laughed at these silly pretensions, and they were subjects of special amusement to the Northern people; but inasmuch as they harmed nobody, and appeared to afford great satisfaction to those who entertained them, but little was thought or cared about the matter. The time, however, was approaching which was to subject these claims of superiority to a practical test. When it came, the boasted patriotism of Virginia turned out to be the rankest treason. Her vaunted honor, as embodied in her representative man, FLOYD, was found to consist in capabilities for plundering on a gigantic scale -- using the confidence of official trust as a cover for stealing from the Treasury and robbing the Government to an extent embracing in value millions upon millions of dollars. Her appreciation of soldierly duly, of military honor, was exemplified in the desertion by LEE, and LAY, and MAGRUDER, of the flag they had sworn to support, -- of the country that had educated and supported them, that had conferred honors upon and given them whatever of social or official respectability they ever enjoyed; and turning the education and experience they had acquired through the bounty of that Government, to the aid of rebellion for its overthrow. Her love of freedom was exemplified in the persecution, the banishment, or murder of citizens whose only crime was that they entertained sentiments of loyalty to the Constitution, and by the establishment of a lawless terrorism that utterly destroyed liberty of opinion, of speech and of the Press. Her courage has thus far been exemplified in running away whenever confronted with the loyal forces, and ensconcing behind conconcealed intrenchments and masked batteries, and firing upon opponents at times when they were unconscious of danger. Her appreciation of the amenities of civilized warfare is now to be exemplified in the formation or authorization of roving bands of Free Lances, whose only pay is the plunder they may secure, and whose cowardly warfare is waged only against weak or careless detachments, unarmed citizens and defenceless women. In no country, save Mexico, has this mode of warfare found favor or been tolerated, for the last three centuries. It is a relic of barbarism which civilization has everywhere rejected and condemned. These guerrilla hands have, in all Christian countries, been regarded as mere robbers and murderers, and, when taken, have been executed by summary process. But Virginia, cowering before the advance of the loyal armies, lays aside her boasted chivalry, and, by a solemn decree of her State Council, gives license to these organized marauders, and sends them out to plunder and to slay. It exemplifies the falsity of her pretensions, while it demonstrates the reality of her weakness. Unable to cope with the Government forces in the field, she sends abroad her guerrillas on midnight forays, in the mere wantonness of revenge. Short work should be made of them. The bullet and the halter, with a shallow grave by the roadside, should close their marauding career.

abstract: Capt. BARTHOLOMEW PRUYN, Company K, Thirtieth Regiment New-York State Volunteers, while stopping at his home in Valatle for a night, was presented with a sword, trappings and epaulettes by his friends, and with a Coh's revolver by his sisters. The presentation ceremonies were held in the largest church in town, which was filled to overflowing, and speeches were made by Dr. TALLMADGE and Rev. Mr. CHASE. Capt. PRUYN replied briefly and appropriately, and the ceremonies closed by singing the "Star Spangled Banner" and prayer.

abstract: The Fifteenth Regiment New-York Volunteers, Col. J. MCLEOD MURPHY, which has been encamped at Willett's Point, departed yesterday for the seat of war. Everything being in readiness the day before, there was little else to do but to pack the camp equipage and embark. The paymaster finished paying off the regiment Saturday morning. The men all had their leave of absence, and returned promptly to camp, so that there was no trouble about giving them a parole. The Camden and Amboy Company sent their steamer, the Atlas, to Willett's Point, and at 1 o'clock P.M. the entire regiment was on board and ready to start. The boat proceeded directly to Amboy, where the regiment took the cars for Washington. They are furnished with the United States musket of 1842, and have all the requisites of a well appointed force. A little drilling, the officers assert, will make them some of the finest soldiers who have gone to the war.
lead_paragraph: The Fifteenth Regiment New-York Volunteers, Col. J. MCLEOD MURPHY, which has been encamped at Willett's Point, departed yesterday for the seat of war. Everything being in readiness the day before, there was little else to do but to pack the camp equipage and embark. The paymaster finished paying off the regiment Saturday morning. The men all had their leave of absence, and returned promptly to camp, so that there was no trouble about giving them a parole. The Camden and Amboy Company sent their steamer, the Atlas, to Willett's Point, and at 1 o'clock P.M. the entire regiment was on board and ready to start. The boat proceeded directly to Amboy, where the regiment took the cars for Washington. They are furnished with the United States musket of 1842, and have all the requisites of a well appointed force. A little drilling, the officers assert, will make them some of the finest soldiers who have gone to the war.

abstract: THE ARMY HOSPITAL AT GEORGETOWN. -- We learn from private M.C. MCDONOUGH, of the Thirteenth Regiment, that the Hospital at Georgetown, under the superintendence of Miss POWELL, of this City, came near being destroyed by fire on Friday, having been fired in two places by some of the fiendish traitors who still infest the vicinity of Washington. The flames were finally extinguished, mainly through the efforts of the convalescent inmates. Mr. MCDONOUGH, who has been confined in the Hospital for some weeks, speaks in the highest terms of Miss POWELL and her assistants, to whose careful attention he says he owes the preservation of his life. There are at present 160 patients in the Hospital.

abstract: STABBING AFFAIR. -- A man named JAMES MCGOVERN was taken before Justice CUTTER, of Jersey City, on Friday night, and held to bail in the sum of $1,000, on a charge of stabbing JAMES LYNCH, a member of the Board of Chosen Freeholders. It is alleged that as Mr. L. was standing in front of his dwelling, in Washington-street, the accused, without apparent provocation, came up and stabbed him in the arm, inflicting a not very serious wound.

abstract: A lady, just arrived in Philadelphia, from Charleston, states that when she left the latter city, everything but cotton and rice was very dear. The stores are almost empty, and for dry goods the prices are shockingly dear. Three weeks ago the young lady went to buy a common delaine dress. The style of goods are sold here at 17 cents per yard. She was asked 31 cents, but did not buy it, the price being too high. The next week she went back for it and could only get it by paying 40 cents, to which the price had been raised. A week or so later the price was raised to 75 cents, at which figure all the remaining stock was ultimately sold out. The goods were the "Manchester delaines," such as the commission houses in this city sell at 16 cents per yard.

abstract: A letter to the Nashville Gazette, dated at Fort Smith, June 15 says: "In every part of this country we have the most intents excitement in regard to the war. Everybody is preparing for it. In every town, village or hamlet, however shall you here nothing but the talk of war, the [???] of arms, and the music of drum and fife. The people here are in constant fear of an attack from JIM LANE of Kansas notoriety, with an armed for [???] 5,000 or 10,000 thieving and murdering Abolitionists and we are preparing to give him a warm reception. We have seen several gentlemen from Kansas City, some of whom heard LANE making speeches, and they say he is raising men and making preparations for an attack upon this country; that it is his intention to seek Forts Smith, Washita, Cobb, Arbuckle and other important places.

abstract: Missouri may now be regarded as safe on the side of the Union. There may be occasional local outbreaks, and a few companies of volunteers furnished by stealth to the enemy; yet the loyal people are so far in the ascendant, and so well organized and armed, as to be able not only to protect themselves, but to hold the State firmly in position, under the national flag.
lead_paragraph: Missouri may now be regarded as safe on the side of the Union. There may be occasional local outbreaks, and a few companies of volunteers furnished by stealth to the enemy; yet the loyal people are so far in the ascendant, and so well organized and armed, as to be able not only to protect themselves, but to hold the State firmly in position, under the national flag. The Governor and other officials had prepared to plunge Missouri into secession, through the same system of fraud and terrorism that precipitated Virginia and Tennessee into the vortex of rebellion, but they lacked the promptitude and courage of the Virginia and Tennessee rebels. They delayed decisive action until the people discovered their conspiracies, and were prepared to resist them. Under pretence of neutrality they sought to recover the ground they had lost, but their treachery in violating the truce concluded with Gen. HARNEY, was as much too hasty as their former action had been too slow. The people had not forgotten their late treason, and remained on the watch. When, therefore, Governor JACKSON threw off the mask, and demanded fifty thousand volunteers, they came at the call with arms in their hands, but to his utter discomfiture they were arrayed in the defence of the Constitution, and beneath the National flag.

abstract: We are pleased to learn something even in a remote and roundabout way, of the Attorney-General of the so-called Southern Confederacy.
lead_paragraph: We are pleased to learn something even in a remote and roundabout way, of the Attorney-General of the so-called Southern Confederacy. When Mr. BENJAMIN made his great secession speech preparatory to the consummation of his treason, the most extravagant laudations among the Southern Secessionists at home reechoed the plaudits of the packed gallery of the United States Senate which greeted its delivery. Mr. BENJAMIN was a great man among the conspirators. His colleague, SLIDELL, was quite extinguished in the blaze of light which surrounded the eminent orator and lawyer, who had not long before come over from the Whig ranks, to read lessons on Democracy to STEPHEN A. DOUGLAS, and bow him out of the party in the politest possible manner. SLIDELL was overslaughed in the formation of the new Government. Not much could be spared to great men outside of Georgia, but some two or three had to be provided for, and Louisiana was entitled, at least, to one seat in the Cabinet. As SLIDELL and BENJAMIN could not both enjoy it, the necessity of having some legal information in the new Government, and the fame he had acquired by his extreme secession speech in the Senate, united to turn the scale in favor of BENJAMIN -- and his appointment was hailed with a jubilant outcry throughout all secession-dom.

abstract: The schooner Mary Clinton, of New-Orleans, MCNORTON RYAN, Captain, arrived yesterday morning in 28 days from the passes of the Mississippi, with rice. On May 29, when thirty miles from the Balize, was boarded by the United States steamship Powhatan, Lieut. PORTER commanding, and ordered to New-York. The Mary Clinton was from Charleston, bound to New-Orleans, with a cargo of rice. Lieut. PORTER ordered Mr. DUYCKER, gunner of the Powhatan, on board the Mary Clinton as sailing master, and on the night of June 26, in a heavy squall, Mr. DUYCKER was knocked overboard by the main-boom and lost, although every effort was made to save him. It is believed that Mr. DUYCKER is a native of Anterly, and that his family reside in Philadelphia.

abstract: The discoveries made on searching Marshal KANE'S office, not only demonstrate his treason, and that he must have a large number of confederates, but that he was preparing for an outbreak that involved...
lead_paragraph: -- The discoveries made on searching Marshal KANE's office, not only demonstrate his treason, and that he must have a large number of confederates, but that he was preparing for an outbreak that involved in its consequences an immense destruction of life. There were weapons enough found to arm a regiment, and with ammunition sufficient for a battle. There can be no doubt that there are other private depots in the city equally well supplied with arms, nor that where were men selected who were relied upon to use them when the time should be ripe for a rising. Why there should be any hesitancy under such circumstances in proclaiming and enforcing martial law, passes our comprehension. It seems to us that the quiet of the city, the safety of the loyal troops and of the loyal and order-loving citizens demand it. The arrest and removal of Marshal KANE may, and doubtless has deranged the plans of the conspirators for the present, but the snake will be found to have been "scotched, not killed." In timely precaution is not taken, and a rigid guard kept, the silence of midnight will be broken by the roar of an armed mob, which even in times of peace has been no stranger to that unhappy city.

abstract: "As the Kingston approached the wharf, the form of his Royal Highness, [???] in a fight suit of tweed was easily distinguished standing on the forward deck, beside the Governor General, and surrounded by the members of his suite, together with several ladies. Laud cheers went up from the mass of people, in acknowledgement of which his Royal Highness gracefully raised his hat. At this moment some enthusiastic individual, who, armed with a bugle, had concealed himself on an adjoining wharf, struck up 'God Save the Queen' in agonizing style. The Governor General, fearing probably that a band of music and a procession lay in ambush, looked exceedingly astonished; but the player's wind noon gave out, and the [???] were drowned in the deafening cheers of the assemblage. The vessel being laid alongside the wharf, the royal party descended to the main cabin and passed along the gangway to the wharf. Here they were met by Hon. J.C. MORRISON and Lieut.-Col. IRVINE, who alone had managed to make a way though the crowd in time for the arrival of the steamer. No, not alone; for we forgot a couple of militia officers, who could not let this opportunity escape of displaying their loyalty -- and their uniform -- and had, therefore, valiantly fought a passage to the gangway, and stood with military stiffness to salute royalty as it passed. The Prince stepped ashore, and followed by the remainder of the party, walked with a firm and manly step to the head of the wharf where the carriages were in waving. It was [???] 8 1/4 o'clock, and almost dusk, but the crowd -- numbering several thousands -- had an excellent opportunity of viewing him. He is not quite so tall, but stouter and more robust than the Prince of Wales; his features, however, bear a close resemblance, and he wore the same modest air which charmed all who approached the heir apparent."

abstract: By no Government in the wide world other than this of ours is treason treated so kindly or rebellion sprinkled with so much rosewater. Everywhere else they are regarded as crimes ` deserving of severe punishment and if clemency interposes its pardons, it is always after the forms, at least, of a trial, and a record of conviction.
lead_paragraph: By no Government in the wide world other than this of ours is treason treated so kindly or rebellion sprinkled with so much rosewater. Everywhere else they are regarded as crimes ` deserving of severe punishment and if clemency interposes its pardons, it is always after the forms, at least, of a trial, and a record of conviction. A traitor has never been regarded as a fit associate for loyal citizens and gentlemen of the government which he seeks to overthrow, much less do the officials of such government recognize him as a companion and friend. Infamy is everywhere else coupled with treason, and dishonor with rebellion. If the culprit guilty of these crimes escapes the halter, it is to sink into degradation and suffer under the contempt of all patriotic and true men. The exceptions to this rule are to be found only in the oppressions of the government sought to be overthrown, where the citizens suffering under a tyranny too grievous to be borne, rise in defence of their rights, and for the preservation of their liberties. In such cases the pressure of necessity is their vindication, and they are justified by a law higher than legislative enactments -- the law of instinct and self-preservation.

abstract: Washington is at present most agitated by the questions arising in anticipation of the coming extra session of Congress. Members are arriving daily, and the merits of the different candidates for the offices to be filled before proceeding to business, are being actively canvassed.
lead_paragraph: Washington is at present most agitated by the questions arising in anticipation of the coming extra session of Congress. Members are arriving daily, and the merits of the different candidates for the offices to be filled before proceeding to business, are being actively canvassed. The most prominent candidates for the Speakership are said to be Hon. GALUSHA A. GROW, of Pennsylvania, Hon. F.P. BLAIR, Jr., of Missouri, and Hon. SCHUYLER COLFAX, of Indiana, -- and their chances seem to be about equal. Troops continue to arrive in Washington, in immense numbers. Within the twenty-four hours ending last evening, eight regiments had arrived from the North, including three from New-Jersey and three from New York. Col. CASS' Massachusetts Regiment, originally destined for Fortress Monroe, was also among the number. No movements of importance among the National troops across the Potomac, are reported. The rebel forces, however, have again been heard from at CLOUD's Mills, at Springfield, and at Fairfax Court-house -- at the latter point to the number of four thousand. Gen. FREMONT, who has arrived in Washington, is expected to assume the duties of his position immediately.

abstract: One of the incidental blessings of the blockade is, that it effectually excludes from the ears of the world all those terrific rantings and sheet-iron thunderings which have so long been the staple manufacture of this ridiculous little empire.
lead_paragraph: -- One of the incidental blessings of the blockade is, that it effectually excludes from the ears of the world all those terrific rantings and sheet-iron thunderings which have so long been the staple manufacture of this ridiculous little empire. No longer are we paralyzed before the military attitudes of Gen. QUATTLEBUM, or struck dumb by the awful rhodomontade of Col. KEITT; Gov. PICKENS fulminates his edicts in the ears of his own petty niggerarchy only; the sweet though bloody notes of RHETT and SPRATT are heard no more; HAMMOND is as good as done for -- the mud-sills have effectuually fenced him in; and the little local newspapers, also, which erst chronicled Palmetto small beer to the wonderment of all mankind, now rave, and lie, and curse before a little audience, not a quarter of whom know their a, b, abs. Thus, South Carolina, of whose glory and prowess we have heard every day and dreamed every night for a quarter of a century, is now as effectually shut off from the great world as if she were sunk fathoms deep beneath the waves. She, before whose dread power all gods, men and negroes were supposed to tremble, now exhibits before them all her contemptible insignificance, her puny weakness. Her ambassadors to other empires are not permitted to sail from her own ports; her plenipotentiaries, now abroad, cannot return to her sacred soil without sneaking in through some back door; neither a newspaper nor a fibril of cotton can she export; neither an item of news nor a demijohn of whisky can she import, without begging permission of the Yankee dastard whom she has so often whipped ten to one. Probably she is whipping them yet -- in her newspapers. About the last we heard was that she had sent an immense army northward, who, after driving the Yankees from Virginia, were going to-march through Pennsylvania in triumph -- were proceeding to thrash Philadelphia, sack New-York, and put all Boston to the sword. They marched into Virginia on the double-quick, some two or three months ago, but suddenly came to a dead halt when they approached within rifle-crack of the advancing Yankees. If we could hear from KEITT, we have no doubt but we would learn that mountains of slaughtered Yankees were piled up all around them; while millions and millions of Abolitionists fled before them. But, thank Heaven! KEITT, RHETT, QUATTLEBUM, and all the other Palmetto Generals and Honorables are now locked in a prison-house, where the world neither hears their howlings nor fears their threats. If they could only be locked in for the rest of the century. America would enjoy peace and quiet, while the black and white Palmettos would probably by that time have pretty effectually used each other up.p

abstract: It is perfectly obvious that every nation has the right to name its own ports of entry, and to change them as occasion and necessity demand. A great deal of misconception might have been saved to Europeans, especially to Englishmen, if instead of using the term "blockade" as applied to ports in rebellion against our Government, we had simply stated that those ports were closed as ports of entry, Th euse of the term "blockade" being technically applied to the sealing of the ports of a foreign nation, naturally, suggested to the various Powers that the laws of blockade could be applied to such, of the Southern ports as were no longer open with our consent, If the European nations can be led to understand that the rebel cotton ports are simply under the operation of our revenue laws, and that to insure their faithful execution, we have shut up those ports, and stationed armed vessels to watch them, of course, they will perceive that they have nothing to do with the question, and that even the presence of their vessels near those ports is intrusive upon our jurisdiction. They will also clearly see that any attempt of a foreign vessel to enter those ports and land cargoes, subjects them to forfeiture by our laws. Thus the proper use of the terms whereby to denote the suspension of the privileges of those ports, so long as in a state of rebellion, will clear the vision of foreign officials, and guard against unnecessary misconception and disputes. The first thing Congress should do, is to declare that rebel ports are closed as ports of entry until they have resumed allegiance to the Government. This will aid the merchants of those ports to a clear perception of their duty and interests. We look to the shipping ports of the South to be among the first to return to their loyalty, and by driving out the traitors, and elevating the national standard, resume their maritime activity, and recover their prosperity.

abstract: The Virginia State Convention were troubled with certain grave doubts as to what portion of the loyal forces on their march across Virginia towards the Gulf were negroes. It was bad enough for Virginia gentlemen to be compelled to fight "cobblers and greasy mechanics," but to allow an army of "niggers" to come "between the wind and their nobility" was disgusting. Whereupon they called upon Gov. LETCHER for information as to the number of troops from Ohio and other States that had invaded Northwestern Virginia, and what proportion of them were "colored persons." The Governor instituted an inquiry, which resulted in a communication submitted by him to the Convention on the 20th of June inst., the closing remark of which is: "Gentlemen from the Northwest, who arrived in Richmond on Sunday and Monday, think no part of the troops are negroes, while others entertain a different opinion." The schoolmasters have been driven out of Virginia.

abstract: Col. JOHN H. PRENTISS died at Cooperstown on the 26th, aged 77. He was born in Worcester Mass.; was foreman in the office of the New-York Evening Post in 1808; at the close of that year he assumed the editorial supervision of the Cooperstown Freeman's Journal, and was for many years among the most prominent politicians of the State. He was a genial gentlemen, whom every one respected.

abstract: What shall we say of the mystic MICHELET, now? RUDD CARLTON, his faithful interpreters, give us The Sea, another dreamy book, abounding with facts and fancles--the latter predominating, of course.
lead_paragraph: What shall we say of the mystic MICHELET, now? RUDD & CARLTON, his faithful interpreters, give us The Sea, another dreamy book, abounding with facts and fancles -- the latter predominating, of course. Our singular author approaches the sea with reverence and awe, yet subsequently he disports himself in the waters in such a manner as to induce the belief that in their wondrous depths is his most familiar home. He believes in sirens, and has a profound faith in the existence of mermen. He fishes pearls from the coral caves, and wreathes them about the brow of beauty with the most sensuous suggestions. The Oriental ladies of "high degree," he tells us, more delicate and tasteful than our vulgar rich, shun the diamond, allowing their soft skin to be touched only by the pearl. "In truth," says MICHELET, "the brilliancy of the diamond is not in accordance with the light of love. A necklace and bracelets of fine pearls are the harmonious and true decorations for woman; instead of diverting the glance of the lover, they move him, make tenderness more tender -- say to him -- no noise; let us love!" Thus we infer that the pearls are sensible and prudent as well as amorous. He traces an analogy between the pearl and the silken tunic, which the Odalisque wears close to her person, and loves so much that she will not part with it until it is worn and torn beyond all possibility of repair; believing it as she does to be a talisman, an infallible love charm. To a near Northern lover, a garment worn that length of time, and without washing, would prove a source of repulsion rather than of attraction, we fancy; -- commend us rather to the bosomed pearl, equally treasurable for associations, but lets absorptive than silk or linen.

abstract: Some account has recently been given of the earthquake at Mendoza, an interior city of the Argentine Consideration. Twelve thousand persons are known to have perished in the city and neighborhood. Many thousand survivors are left entirely destitute, and a large number have been so maimed that they will be necessarily dependent upon charity for the rest of their lives. The complete destruction of the city so prostrates the ordinary commerce of the Province, that those able to work find no one able to employ them, and the most object poverty hangs over the people. Subscriptions have been made in the neigboring Provinces, and in Europe, to help these unfortunate people and it is hoped that in this country some charitably disposed persons may be able and willing to assist them, notwithstanding the demand now made by events here.
